channel.title: 20 Sides of Nerd
channel.itunes:subtitle: We're multifaceted!
channel.itunes:summary: Can a Mac and Console gamer get along with a PC gamer without driving each other crazy? In 20 Sides of Nerd, we aim to find out. We, Emdee and Draeno, join forces to tackle the tough issues in the nerdy world. Be it games, tech, comics, film, or just talking about the things that annoy us, we'll give you an hour worth listening to.
channel.itunes:keywords: nerd, games, tabletop, PC, Mac, Xbox, PS3, technology, news, opinions, comics, television
channel.itunes:author: Emdee & Draeno

item.content:encoded:
In a four-man cast this week, Emdee and Draeno once again by Charles of The Happiness Patrol and fellow cohort Malcolm. The topic list appears to have been thrown out as is known to happen when more than three people take part in the podcast. Topics for the bounce all over because of this from convention illness or diseases much worse, the President signing the cell phone unlocking bill, random government policies, issues with flying, Apple’s deal with Beats closes with a weird commercial, Bose suing Beats in Texas, virtual assistants, Nokia and Microsoft protests in China, Microsoft suing Samsung over Android licensing fees, Apple’s e-book case, Aereo’s woes and television issues, Doctor Who and Guardians of the Galaxy and other superhero issues.

Be aware this episode talks briefly about Guardians of the Galaxy at the 62-minute mark. There are spoilers, so listeners pay attention for the warning!

item.content:encoded:
Welcome listeners new and old! Thank you for tuning in for another episode of the 20 Sides of Nerd. This week Draeno and Emdee bring Charles of the Doctor Who podcast The Happiness Patrol along for the ride. This week we talk about Doctor Who, Cybermen, the return of Doctor Who to the big screen for Peter Capaldi’s first episode, Comic Con 2014 news including the Firefly game and Evil Dead, James Garner’s passing, Halo composer Marty O’Donnell’s scores and lawsuit settlement with Bungie president Harold Ryan, Destiny, Google’s rumored Twitch purchase, latest happenings with the FCC and broadband, cell phone unlocking, reminiscing our bad inventions, the demographics of shooter games, Star Trek Continues and fandom, and some current games we’re looking at.

For those Doctor Who fans in need of more content, make sure you check out this week’s The Happiness Patrol podcast.

item.title: 20 Sides of Nerd S03E13 – DC Universe Unchained
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: On this week’s episode of 20 Sides of Nerd, Emdee and Draeno welcome Justin Korthof (SixOkay) of Robot Entertainment for a return visit to the show. As Justin is the community manager for the company, the team spends some time... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
On this week’s episode of 20 Sides of Nerd, Emdee and Draeno welcome Justin Korthof (SixOkay) of Robot Entertainment for a return visit to the show. As Justin is the community manager for the company, the team spends some time talking about Robot’s next iteration of the Orcs Must Die! series, Orcs Must Die! Unchained. The team talks about some of the differences in the game from the previous ones, including some multiplayer mayhem. Afterward, the Aereo Supreme Court decision is debated before moving into the area of comics.

Getting into some passionate territory, the future of the DC Universe is talked about, including Batman vs. Superman, Fox’s Gotham, the New 52 comics, the future of films with Warner Brothers and how a fan could see them going. It wouldn’t be a comic’s discussion if they didn’t talk about the effect on digital comics the change in Comixology’s ownership will have. Make sure to check out SixOkay’s post on “Man of Steel isn’t about Superman” for some reference.

Those interested in some of SixOkay’s other projects check out his Griddle Me This Tumblr, the Nerds Who Wait podcast or find him on Twitter as @SixOkay.

item.title: 20 Sides of Nerd S03E12 – Interview: David Sirlin
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: David Sirlin, creator of Yomi, Puzzle Strike and Pandante, joins Emdee and Draeno for a return appearance on the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast. Forgoing the usual nerd and news talk of the week, everyone jumps on board to talk... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
David Sirlin, creator of Yomi, Puzzle Strike and Pandante, joins Emdee and Draeno for a return appearance on the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast. Forgoing the usual nerd and news talk of the week, everyone jumps on board to talk about the news in Sirlin’s world. Since Sirlin’s last appearance as a guest on the cast, he’s has shipped a new gambling game called Pandante. His biggest game, Yomi, has also made its way to iOS. Delving into the happenings of the last two years, the team talks game development and the problems it faces, the challenges of balancing, how Sirlin got his start in games, some talk on Hearthstone, Kickstarter and the mentality around it, and much more. Fans of Sirlin’s work will be happy to hear that there is some news and development insight on Codex in this episode.

Don’t forget to check out Sirlin’s latest Kickstarter, a new run and expansions for the physical version of Yomi! Those unfamiliar with his work can read up on his projects on his blog or play them online at Fantasy Strike. If you want a physical version to play, make sure to check out the Sirlin Games online store.

item.title: 20 Sides of Nerd S03E11 – Automotive DLC
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: In this week’s episode of 20 Sides of Nerd, Emdee and Draeno make some discoveries that could haunt the automotive industry for some time to come. For that, they wish to say they are very sorry for the pain they... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
In this week’s episode of 20 Sides of Nerd, Emdee and Draeno make some discoveries that could haunt the automotive industry for some time to come. For that, they wish to say they are very sorry for the pain they have inflicted on car buyers in the future. Outside of allowing DLC practices or Project $10 coming to your next compact car, the team covers component swaps in Kingston and PNY solid state drives, Emdee’s Orge purchase, the perks of getting large review shipments, E3, the idea of Nintendo moving away from consoles, Amazon’s Fire Phone, Steam’s Summer Sale, the Far Cry series, Apple’s new inexpensive iMac, T-Mobile’s announcements and issues, the end of Cosmos, and some other smaller topics.

And as they should, the team closes with another apology for the money you’ll end up paying to automotive corporate overlords to drive cars.

item.content:encoded:
This week on 20 Sides of Nerd the team is joined by The Quantum Cat as the tackle the issues in tech and geekdom. Topics include a child exposing Xbox Live vulnerabilities, the end of Gamespy servers, a short branch out into the past of online gaming services, Draeno talks about his time at Emerald City Comic Con 2014, another round of Apple/Samsung lawsuits, Kindle Fire TV, Metacritic on Amazon, Titanfall on 360, PC game demands and indie games.

The crew spends a good chunk of time on the Brendan Eich and the Mozilla CEO debacle. It is a touchy subject sure, but braving it is important for both Internet culture and geeks worldwide. Thus, 20 Sides of Nerd needed to talk about it.

Other topics include Star Wars: Clone Wars, the departure of Jack Trenton from Sony Entertainment, Titanfall, the proposed Halo 2 update, Mini Metro, the Delta Six Controller, a return to Dr. Who internet outrage, and Draeno gets lost in a metaphor.

item.title: Captain America 2 Finds Director(s)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Rumors started circulationg earlier last month when The Hollywood Reporter announced that the Russo Brothers were in the final stages of negotiations to take the reigns of the Captain America sequel. The sequel due in theatres April 2014 will pick... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
Rumors started circulationg earlier last month when The Hollywood Reporter announced that the Russo Brothers were in the final stages of negotiations to take the reigns of the Captain America sequel. The sequel due in theatres April 2014 will pick up its story with Chris Evans reprising his role of citizen turned super soldier Steve Rogers in a modern day setting. Marvel has had a tough time nailing down directors for their upcoming projects Iron Man 3 and Thor 2, but thought that the Russos were the right team for this job. Marvel did have another pair of directors in Mark Neveldine and Brian Taylor (the pair responsible for the Crank series, Gamer, and Jonah Hex) on the Columbia Pictures Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance, so you can see why there may be some hesitation by critics of accepting the Russos.

However, there shouldn’t be cause for concern. While there probably aren’t many people that are clued in to just what the Russo brothers are responsible, I assure you that they are some projects that make for a good pedigree. Their only film directing credit may be for You, Me, & Dupree, but their television background is what needs to be looked at for consideration. The most notable of which is directing for shows such as Community and Arrested Development. If those series don’t convince you that Captain America 2 is in good hands, I don’t think that anything will.

Source – Hollywood Reporter

item.title: Scream to Become TV Series for MTV
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: If you didn’t think the slasher genre of horror films was dead, you most certainly will now. Michael Ausiello of TV Line is reporting that MTV has gained the rights to turn Wes Craven and Kevin Williamson’s reinvigorating film series... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
If you didn’t think the slasher genre of horror films was dead, you most certainly will now. Michael Ausiello of TV Line is reporting that MTV has gained the rights to turn Wes Craven and Kevin Williamson’s reinvigorating film series Scream into a weekly scripted series for the network. While nothing has been said about what direction the show is going to take, as it has yet to find its writer, there are many questions about how the show will translate to a television audience given the content of the films.

I’m not exactly holding out hope for Scream to turn into a decent television show in the hands of MTV. The network may have success with the re-envisioning of Teen Wolf, but it definitely isn’t a show for everyone. Even though Williamson created a solid script and characters for the film to work with, I have to hold onto hope that MTV won’t involve him in anyway. Given that Williamson has been a producer and writers for teen hormone oozing shows like Dawson’s Creek and the Vampire Diaries, this isn’t a show that I’ll be waiting by my TV to see if they do give him a call.

Source – TV Line

item.title: Lost Girl Returns to Syfy for Season 3
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: At least it appears that Syfy is keeping some of its scripted television around, even if it is a show that they don’t actually produce themselves. Earlier this month the cable channel announced that it was renewing the broadcast rights... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
At least it appears that Syfy is keeping some of its scripted television around, even if it is a show that they don’t actually produce themselves. Earlier this month the cable channel announced that it was renewing the broadcast rights for the supernatural crime drama, Lost Girl, for its 13 episode third season. The announcement had been made months prior by the Canadian company Showcase, causing Syfy to hold out until it was clear the next season was in production.

For those not familiar with Lost Girl, it revolves around Bo, a succubus that discovers that she feeds off the life force of others, or more pointedly, their sexual energy. As one would guess, this is a struggle as the world of who she thought she was clashes with who she will become. Unaware of her powers at a young age, she now has to cope with being identified as a Fae. She becomes entangled in an underground world as she tries to figure out who she is and what her place is in life.

Syfy is moving the show from Mondays at 10:00PM to the same time slot on Friday when the show returns on July 20th. It is unclear why the move was made to the Friday night death slot, especially when it had a 1.64 million viewer average from the second season. Hopefully this wasn’t done with the intent of killing off yet another scripted show to replace it with more reality shows. Time will tell though.

Source – Syfy

item.title: Ubisoft Motion Pictures Announces Assassin’s Creed Star
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: It appears that Ubisoft isn’t messing around when it comes to bringing Assassin’s Creed to the big screen. After a lengthy shopping process for the franchise that would grant Ubisoft an unprecedented amount of control, Sony finally ended up in... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
It appears that Ubisoft isn’t messing around when it comes to bringing Assassin’s Creed to the big screen. After a lengthy shopping process for the franchise that would grant Ubisoft an unprecedented amount of control, Sony finally ended up in negotiations with the gaming studio to develop the title. However, it looks like it may end up handled solely by Ubisoft Motion Pictures. Better yet, the actor slated to play Desmond/Altair/Ezio will have a hand in producing the film as well through his company DMC Film Ltd. Who is it that is going to play our genetic memory assassin? None other than current Hollywood hot shot, Michael Fassbender.

Jean-Julien Baronnet, CEO of Ubisoft Motion Pictures, confirmed that “Michael Fassbender was our first choice” in an interview with Variety. “Michael (Fassbender) is an extremely smart, talented, versatile and committed actor.”

Truer words could not be spoken when you look at his range of films from X-Men: First Class, Band of Brothers, and Prometheus.

Any way you look at it, an adaptation of Assassin’s Creed marks a major development for the gaming studio turned large scale entertainment producer. Assassin’s Creed has a diehard following that could easily make or break the franchise with a feature film. Ubisoft has had a property turn sour after a flop on the silver screen. Even with the series creator, Jordan Mechner, penning the story for the film. Ubisoft looks to avoid this by securing outside financing to help the startup picture studio keep creative control on the film rather than having the film studio twist it to their desires. As this was the plan all along, it gives hope that finally we may have a good video game adaptation to film.

Source – Variety

item.title: PowerA Star Wars Themed iPhone Cases Now Available
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: If you were paying attention to some of the announcements coming out of E3, you might already know that PowerA was developing cases for the iPhone 4/4S that might have caught your geeky eye. The first wave in a limited... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
If you were paying attention to some of the announcements coming out of E3, you might already know that PowerA was developing cases for the iPhone 4/4S that might have caught your geeky eye. The first wave in a limited series of Star Wars inspired cases have been launched from the vendor online, and are set to be available through Best Buy on July 22nd. With four now available, two from the Star Wars Collector Case Series and two from the Star Wars Saga Cases collections, it is going to be interesting to see how this series pans out both in sales and durability. The hair on the Chewbacca Collector Case Series does certainly raise a bunch of questions on a phone case.

According to John Moore, vice presedent of product development and marketing for PowerA, “These are indeed the iPhone cases you are looking for.”

Not all of the cases have been officially announced in the series, but pictures surfacing from E3 would lead us to believe that the Collector Case Series will round out with C-3PO and Darth Vader versions. The Saga Cases collection is only limited to the droids and A New Hope poster art at this time, but it seems like more will be coming our way. To the development team for PowerA, I’ll make a quick suggestion. If you are planning to be Jar Jar Binks on any of the cases, you better make it a ruggedized version. Many a iPhone will be thrown in rage.

  • Case securely snaps into place. No Force powers required.
  • A limited edition case fit for the most avid Star Wars collector.
  • Look closely to see the engraved details in this premium case.
  • Chewbacca fur keeps this case cozy.
  • Officially licensed Star Wars™ product developed by PowerA.
  • iPhone sold separately.

  • Case securely snaps into place. No Force powers required.
  • Art, straight from the original Lucas Arts movie posters.
  • A limited edition case fit for the most avid Star Wars collector.
  • Officially licensed Star Wars™ product developed by PowerA.
  • iPhone sold separately.

Source – PR / PowerA

item.title: New The Amazing Spider-Man Trailer Featuring Bruce Campbell
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: What would a Spider-Man film be without a game being released as a merchandising tie right before its debut? As The Amazing Spider-Man is set to hit theaters on July 3rd, and the game coming out next week (June 26th),... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
What would a Spider-Man film be without a game being released as a merchandising tie right before its debut? As The Amazing Spider-Man is set to hit theaters on July 3rd, and the game coming out next week (June 26th), it comes as no surprise that some more details would come out to whet the pallet of potential fans. I think Beenox and Activision hit it big with the release of the newest behind the scenes trailer of the game. This new video features the voice behind the boastful tutor and challenge setter, The Extreme Reporter.

With the Extreme Reporter, Campbell returns to a role similar to the ones he provided for the game spin-offs from the Sam Raimi directed trilogy of Spider-Man films starring Toby Maguire. Campbell brings back his signature comedic styling that taunted the previous incarnation of Peter Parker. From the skies the reporter, a former MMA fighter that gained his glory though trash talking his opponents according to Campbell, uses his attitude and mouth to set Spider-Man on various challenges and objectives throughout the game.

“The Extreme Reporter is very similar to me in that it’s the intelligence and the wit that is the same. So really we have a lot in common. We’re really simple people that who don’t think that highly of ourselves other than the fact that we’re awesome,” says Campbell.

I wish that Campbell would have been able to play another cameo part in Mark Webb’s reboot of the series, but at least we see him return to a familiar role in the game. Don’t forget to check out the film when it hit theaters.

Sources – PR / Marvel

item.title: No Renewal for Sanctuary
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Here we go again. Syfy has cancelled yet another one of their scripted television series. After four seasons with the network, Sanctuary has been put to an end by the genre favorite network.
item.content:encoded:
Here we go again. Syfy has cancelled yet another one of their scripted television series. After four seasons with the network, Sanctuary has been put to an end by the genre favorite network. This is an announcement that I’m sure really didn’t come as a shock to anyone, especially if you’ve been following how the network has been treating the show since bringing the show to the network from its first home on the web. According to TV by the Numbers, the show has been averaging a 0.4 viewership average in adults 18-49 since it returned in the fall. Given how low that is for the cable network, even on a Friday, you can imagine that this was along time coming.

If you were hoping that the show was going to get a wrap up after the ending of season four, I’m sorry to disappoint you. Given the low ratings share, I doubt that even an aggressive fan campaign would bring a favorable outcome. I guess all we can hope for is for Sanctuary to return to the web to bring a conclusion to the series. Sad day for sure given the advances this show provided for CGI filming.

item.title: Getting Ahead of Evil Inc.
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Recently, one of my favorite comics has decided to take a different path in the type of content it releases. Since Brad Guigar's return from Emerald City Comic Con, he has announced an experiment in which all of April's strips for Evil Inc. can be purchased before the strips run their course. While Guigar is known to work far ahead in his work, partially due to newspaper time frames, this foray into a new aspect of the online comic model pushes him to work even further in the future. Mr. Guigar was kind enough to take some time out of his busy schedule to sit down with me to answer a few questions.
item.content:encoded:
Recently, one of my favorite comics has decided to take a different path in the type of content it releases. Since Brad Guigar’s return from Emerald City Comic Con, he has announced an experiment in which all of April’s strips for Evil Inc. can be purchased before the strips run their course. Packaging this all up into a neat PDF (or MOBI for you Kindle users), the document features an arc of Dr. Muskiday running from April 2 to April 28. While Guigar is known to work far ahead in his work, partially due to newspaper time frames, this foray into a new aspect of the online comic model pushes him to work even further in the future. Mr. Guigar was kind enough to take some time out of his busy schedule to sit down with me to answer a few questions.

Draeno: Thank you for taking a moment to sit down with me, Brad. I know that you’ve probably got your hands full right now. First I have to know, what stirred up the idea to sell a months worth of comics prior to posting them on the Evil Inc. website?

Brad: This is something I wanted to do for a long time. I wanted to offer a digital download, but offering stuff that was readily available on my site didn’t seem to make sense. Neither did competing with my print book sales. I maintain a significant buffer — partially out of the necessity of giving Ed Ryzowski time to color the strips, and partially out of wanting to make sure that the comic isn’t interrupted by unforeseen events. So it kinda dawned on me that this might be a fun thing to experiment with.

Draeno: How did Ed (colorist Ed Ryzowski) take the news when you told him the plan?

Brad: Ed is unshakeable. He has a completely can-do, confident attitude. He’s amazing.

Draeno: What kind of workload has pushing out the strips this far ahead added to your plate?

Brad: I’ve been slowly building up this buffer for months now. The extra workload hasn’t been huge. I just nibbled away at it for a long time.

Draeno: Was the $1.50 price an arbitrary number that you plucked out of the air or was there some logic to it? Does it go along with the idea of making it accessible, similar to selling buttons or stickers at a convention at a low price point?

Brad: I wanted to make it low enough for an impulse buy without making it seem cheap.

Draeno: Based on the response of your fans, is this something that you will keep doing?

Brad: The response has been very strong. My goal is to release the May edition during the last week of April.

Draeno: You mentioned that you may raise the price to $2 or $3. Do you think that price range will still be in that area? Even with it being a similar price to picking up a comic issue at your local shop?

Brad: I think $2-3 is the sweet spot for digital downloads.

Draeno: Do you think this will have a negative or a positive effect on your book sales?

Brad: I don’t think it will have any effect on my book sales. The books have a completely unique hook. They’re graphic novels based on the daily strip. I use the individual panels of the daily comics to lay out a graphic novel. And where I have always used narration boxes and panels that were not part of the original Web presentation to smooth out the storytelling, the next Evil Inc. book is going to raise that experience to a whole new level.

Draeno: Would you say there has been a difference in net traffic of ad revenue over the previous month by creating an avenue for fans to read the story instead of visiting the site daily?

Brad: This has had no discernible effect on traffic or ad revenue. Both have stayed at their regular levels.

Draeno: Have you thought of using this as a way to arrange gift copies to other people that may not be regularly able to read the strips? For instance, military personnel stationed in various areas, people in lands without stable internet, hermits in caves with iPads, etc.

Brad: No, but that’s a dandy idea!

Draeno: In creating a digital file for distribution, do you worry about potential piracy issues? I know that it isn’t a big issue since the comics are posted online to begin with. There is that small window where you may miss out on some revenue though.

Brad: That’s always a worry, but I didn’t want that to keep me from trying this idea out. To a large extent, I trust my readers. They’ve been incredibly supportive of me for many years.

Draeno: You mentioned in your announcement that you were excluding the Saturday strips. Since you do these strips “on the fly,” as you put it, for the newspapers do you have any future plans for them as a separate release?

Brad: You’re full of great ideas, aren’t you? I just might!

Draeno: Finally, are they any numbers thus far that you could share up to this point? I think people are curious about how successful this has been. I know I am.

Brad: I never share numbers. It’s not that I’m secretive. It’s just that there’s no real context for numbers in a case like this. No matter what number I give you, one person could say, “That’s astounding,” and the next person could say, “That’s not a third of what I thought it would be.” And there’s no way to prove either one of those people right or wrong. So I’d rather not talk numbers. The response was strong enough for me to commit to a May release by the end of the first day. And surprisingly, as of ten days into the month, people are still downloading the April issue. That’s a very positive response to this concept.

Draeno: I’d like to thank you Brad for taking the time out of your schedule to answer a few questions. I know that putting out a product like this for Evil Inc. will do more for keeping readers like me able to catch up on big chunks of story amidst our busy live. I really hope that everything goes as well, if not better, than planned with this next step on getting Evil Inc. out there. Just don’t kill Ed, OK?

Brad: Thanks again for the opportunity!

As you can see, the project did end up being enough of a success for Brad to put out May’s edition at the end of April. I’m excited and interested to see how this trend goes into the future. The price is so low, that it is perfect for the impulse buy as he had intended. Better yet, with the May edition he only bumped the price point up $0.50. Hopefully, Brad will be able to keep pushing these monthly volumes out as time goes on. Given how naturally far ahead he works, I don’t see how keeping up will be a problem. When you consider how this has become a full time job recently, it makes you want it to succeed that much more.

item.title: 20SON Review – FPS Freeks
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: The next wave of performance enhancements for serious console gamers is always sitting on the horizon. Some companies create useful products that can be used every day, while others craft questionable attachments that leave people scratching their heads. The market is a mixed bag of random ideas that are thrown out there to see what sticks. Most hit the market place dead on arrival, but a few gems pop up from time to time that have consumers questioning if they are worth their gaming buck. Kontrol Freek came out with a series of thumb stick extensions for various game types that had me pondering if they were worth taking a look at. Considering the fact that their products have a bit of science behind them makes it worth investigating.
item.content:encoded:
The next wave of performance enhancements for serious console gamers is always sitting on the horizon. Some companies create useful products that can be used every day, while others craft questionable attachments that leave people scratching their heads. The market is a mixed bag of random ideas that are thrown out there to see what sticks. Most hit the market place dead on arrival, but a few gems pop up from time to time that have consumers questioning if they are worth their gaming buck. Kontrol Freek came out with a series of thumb stick extensions for various game types that had me pondering if they were worth taking a look at. Considering the fact that their products have a bit of science behind them makes it worth investigating.

Simple aren't they?

The FPS Freeks claim to have a 40 degree increase in range movement. Kontrol Freek says that this improvement offers the “closest feel to a mouse possible on a console without an internal controller mod or cheat.” There is logic behind the statement. If you think about the extension of the analog sticks, the length allows for smaller movements in the controls versus the shorter throw of the standard controller’s sticks. In comparison to the standard stick, these micro movements can give the player a feeling of fine tuning their aiming. This can result in fewer missed opportunities from overshooting the targets by simply putting too much pressure into the move. This improvement is done in a way that keeps them still legal in tournament settings like the MLG.

There isn't much take away from the natural grip of the Xbox controller. From a distance you would just think they were a natural part of the construction.

The minimalist packaging houses the two extenders that use their joined snaps to anchor them to a plastic card. Pulling them from the package you find that they are fairly light weight. In theory this shouldn’t affect the balance of the Xbox controller, nor one that of the lighter battery pack free PS3 controller. Inspecting the extensions closer you can plainly see that the pieces are injected molded plastic, with a rubberized coating on the head. Small bumps appear at the top offering a reference for your skin to grab onto in the concave dome shape your thumb will rest in much the same way that the bumps on the F and J key provide a reference for finding the home position for typing. The head feels a bit more comfortable on the thumbs than the standard rubber on the Xbox controller. Moving down you see the feet or snaps that would be placed on the analog stick of your choice. These little feet grab onto the head of your analog stick on your controller and wrap around underneath to secure themselves.* They can require a bit of force to pop on if you try to mount them straight on. I found it was easier to sit part of the adapter on one side and tilt it to force on fewer points at a time.

The extenders don't add on as much height as one might think. As you can see in comparison, there isn't really much gain.

The real question is, “Are the FPS Freeks practical?” Indeed, they are. They offer a little more comfort to a player’s hand without putting your thumbs too far away from a standard configuration. More than that, they aren’t some gadget of the month type of doo hickey that adds unnecessary clutter to an already crammed playing space. They are easy to install and even easier to use. How much performance is gained is an altogether different question. The gains from either end of the spectrum (casual to hardcore) will be very different. A casual player might find that he or she is able to tolerate playing shooters for a little longer. The enhanced gaming endurance is not only due to the reduction of thumb fatigue thanks to the now shorter moving distances with less hunting for the sweet spot, but also because from a lesser feeling of frustration. Hopefully it will help eliminate the slow panning movements that often plague the unfamiliar or ‘sometimes’ player. For seasoned, “All I do is play X game every day, all day” type of players, they can easily benefit from the quicker snaps to aiming. Focusing on the tighter scoped shots become much more of a twitch reaction than a conscious movement. Even the trivial task of movement was made easier, leading to more fluid motions and quicker turn arounds. I found myself somewhere in the middle, as my hands aren’t conditioned from hours upon hours of player per day. However, my PC experience kicked in with higher sensitivity levels I was able to set to because of the increased leverage of the Freeks. Either way the learning curve isn’t huge.

Running the Freeks through vigorous testing in both Halo: Reach and Gears of War 3 was definitely a different experience than normal. Not so much as it was when I did my review of the Eagle Eye, but different enough that it took a little bit of time to get used to. It felt incredibly easier to actually aim for my target in each of these games. Reach saw a larger benefit as the game itself no longer felt like a slug traveling across my TV when I tried to gun someone down but it still wasn’t the natural mouse feeling that I’m used to. The nubs provided a better adjustment than the Eagle Eye did as well. Where with the converter box I had to max out all sensitivities, Reach still allowed me some leeway this time around. Gears of War only felt like a slight improvement. I found myself stopping and changing the sensitivity often as I couldn’t find a good balance between the run and gun and the hide mechanic. Though, I could tolerate the Retro Lancer a little better with than without the Freeks. I did notice that panning from side to side was improved as I could pick off incoming hordes a little quicker. Shifting up and down to focusing on those shooting above at distance was a slicker experience as well. I would like to think that there was improvement in my game, but there was no quantifiable statistics other than I won a few games in Reach (which rarely happens outside of team play) and I was actually able to enjoy GoW3 instead of bitching at the mechanics.

The arms pictured here give an example of the concern with the final product.

For all the good the adapters do in games, they have some problems outside of them. The biggest issue is the polish of the units themselves. Small sprue remnants can be seen along the diameter of the head and plastic base from the molding procedure. The seams from the mold halves coming together are also predominately visible when looking at them. While the seams don’t bother me much in the final product, the little remnant bits could have been cleaned off a bit better before leaving the assembly line. The rubber coating seems to have an inconsistent joint with the plastic base as well, causing some places of them to not evenly meet up. At the place where the rubber coating and plastic meet, there are uneven bits. The molded feed or snaps are also a point of concern in regards to overall longevity of the parts. Each one of the addons I received were different in one way or another. Extra bits hung on, pieces seemed to be cut off in error. One of them I even wondered about the structural integrity. It just looked as if it was going to snap when I put it on. Thankfully it has survived multiple on/off scenarios. I must voice my annoyance at using the Freeks while doing normal tasks on the Xbox as well. Using them for navigating applications like Netflix or Hulu feels a little awkward. Fixing that is done by popping them off or using Kinect Voice navigation though.

Oh yes, I broke out the micrometer. Thickness of the rounded head came in at 0.8 and 0.792. Height was measured at 0.437 and 0.444, excluding the legs.

Now, brace yourself for the cost. Models start at $9.99 before rolling up to $13.99 if you buy them straight from the company. Better yet, those are the best prices you can get on them. Free shipping enters the room at a certain price point, so it does make it worth it to look at their other products. Kontrol Freek does offer different styles and limited releases for their FPS line of extensions if you are into changing the look or feel. If you don’t like the concave feel of the standard models that feature the Xbox styling, don’t worry. There are some FPS models that have been made to mimic the dome shape that PS3 players would be familiar with. In addition to the changes to the base structures, shapes in tribute to Call of Duty, Halo and Gears of War have been used in the past as grip points for the nodules. They even make shorter attachments marketed as the CQC model. The company’s website even offers bundles of various kinds of the Freeks, causing the price to dip further if you were considering getting some for different titles or even mixing and matching sets.

They look damn sexy on those Reach controllers, don't they?

After spending some quality time with these little nubs of plastic, I have to say that Kontrol Freek makes a solid product. I can’t firmly confirm the science that they claim with the motion range, but at face value any average person can see that there is some level of truth to it. My only wish was that the company spent a little more time on the finish of their products. The uneven joints and inconsistencies of the molded feet turn me off a little. For a flagship product, I’d want to put some pride into each any every piece that goes out the door. This letdown doesn’t kill the product for me though. You simply can’t ignore the fact they work, and they work well. For the cost, even having to replace these every six months still factors in at a good value for the improvements they’ll make to your game.

*It’s worth noting that the FPS Freeks don’t attach to the Razer Onza because of the resistance dials on the Onza.

Units provided by manufacturer for review

item.title: 20SON Analysis – 3rd Generation iPad Announcement
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: To nobody's surprise, Apple announced the new iPad. Note that it's not the iPad 3, nor the iPad HD, or any InterCap variation of same. It's just the iPad. With a new technological iteration comes some improvements to the base device. My issue as it has always been is will the promises and marketing speak live up to the hype, and what's the reality behind the raw numbers.
item.content:encoded:
To nobody’s surprise, Apple announced the new iPad. Note that it’s not the iPad 3, nor the iPad HD, or any InterCap variation of same. It’s just the iPad. With a new technological iteration comes some improvements to the base device. My issue as it has always been is will the promises and marketing speak live up to the hype, and what’s the reality behind the raw numbers.


Retina Display
While I’m not sure I buy the grandiose claims of indistinguishable pixels made by Apple when touting their retina display, I do agree that they are very nice displays. At 2048 by 1536 pixels, Apple made a big deal pointing out that it was more pixels being pushed than on a 1080p television that many of us have sitting on our entertainment centers. While I’m pleased about this generally, and I feel that it will greatly enhance marathon eBook and PDF reading sessions, I’m not convinced it’s a good thing all around.

We’re now in a situation where developers have the choice of supporting four different resolutions, depending on what devices they wish to fully support. Original iPhones through the 3gs have displays running 480×328. The iPhone 4 and 4s are 960×640. The original iPad and iPad 2 are 1024×768 displays, and now the 3rd generation iPad sports the previously mentioned 2048 by 1536 pixel density. To accommodate the screen doubling feature so iPads can run iPhone specific apps, iPhone developers have to support 328×480 displays. So-called universal applications support at least 480×328 and the iPad’s native 1024×768. Retina display utilization on the iPhone 4 or 4s add a third resolution. What are we going to call support of a 3rd generation iPad’s much higher resolution? I feel that fragmentation of the app store is going to get worse, not better, with this. The 2012 iPad does in fact use the retina display graphics if available for resolution doubling of iPhone only applications. A side effect of the higher resolution on the new iPad is app size increasing. While vectorized text and PDFs won’t get any bigger to support the higher resolution, graphical assets that can’t be mathematically scaled will increase in size, and this in turn leads to larger app sizes. Given that the storage capacities on the iPad hasn’t changed, this may prove to be a problem going forward.

Camera improvements
The camera on the back of the iPad is now a 1080p capable camera versus the 720p capable device in the 2nd generation iPad. As before, I think this is extra and not truly necessary. If it came down to having it versus not, and the price remaining the same, obviously, keep the camera. I just don’t see where it’s necessary in this class of device.

Processor
The A5X processor’s existence was leaked a few weeks before the event. Speculation was that it was still a dual core processor, just faster. In fact, Apple stated that the A5X is a quad core processor. It reality it may not be- there is some discussion that it’s a dual core processor with a quad core graphical sub processor on die. With it brings a higher power demand, but Apple has managed to keep run time to 10 hours with the new iPad. Not every application will benefit from the 4 cores. In fact, most will see modest speed gains, if any. For sure, applications that need 3D acceleration for gaming will benefit the most.

Whither Siri?
While the iPad has a dictation feature, I don’t currently see any mention of Siri (the voice recognition and interpretation technology found on the iPhone 4S). The dictation feature may prove to be quite handy with journalists, but time will tell what applications will leverage this technology to it’s fullest extent.

On the Go
The new iPad sports 4G wireless technology and some impressive benchmarks and demos were shown at the presentation. Two models supporting AT+T and Verizon will be available. I’ve never had much of a use for even 3G on an iPad, as any kind of portable use I’ve needed has been more than adequate on an iPhone, but different users have different needs. As always, your mileage may vary.

Pending Questions
During the event, an Apple employee stated that the iPad had “more memory or screen resolution than either the xBox 360 or PS3.” I’d like to think that this means that the iPad has a full gigabyte of application RAM, versus the 512 megabytes that the iPad 2 has. Breakdowns of the iPad by third parties has revealed 1 gigabyte of application RAM. I did wonder where Siri was in all this earlier, and that question stands. As an interesting aside, the iPad 2 will still be available in the product line at $399, putting a lot of pressure on the the other companies trying to make a tablet to successfully compete with the iPad. It will be interesting to see what this does to the tablet market as a whole.

Stay or Go?
Just as with the iPhone 4S debacle, if you can call it that, this iPad revision is iterative, not revolutionary. More, faster, better. I’m not sure there’s a compelling reason to upgrade from an iPad 2 to a 3rd generation iPad, unless your eyes scream for mercy after reading e-books on the iPad 2 for a while. If you’re in the market, it’s a pretty impressive improvement over the original iPad. Should your budget trend a bit lower, the iPad 2 is still available new and I’m sure there will be some fairly compelling deals on Craigslist before not very long on people itching to upgrade to the new shiny Apple-spawned tablet.

item.title: Guest Review – Playstation Vita
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: The Playstation Vita is Sony's answer to a question nobody asked. "Can we make a handheld console that provides a home console experience for gamers on the go?" Sony needs to convince the gaming public this is something they want, something they need. This is no small challenge, particularly with the Nintendo 3DS already entrenched in the dedicated handheld market and given the increasing prominence of smartphone/tablet gaming.
item.content:encoded:
The Playstation Vita is Sony’s answer to a question nobody asked. “Can we make a handheld console that provides a home console experience for gamers on the go?” Sony needs to convince the gaming public this is something they want, something they need. This is no small challenge, particularly with the Nintendo 3DS already entrenched in the dedicated handheld market and given the increasing prominence of smartphone/tablet gaming.

Sony wants to appeal to the most hardcore of gamers, the casual market be damned. To this end, they’ve assembled an impressive bit of hardware. It has just about every feature a gamer could ask for, and several no one asked for. It aims to be the most flexible console on the market, handheld or otherwise–and it has done a fairly good job.

The most noticeable feature of the Vita is its size–at 3.3 inches tall and 7.2 inches across, it is the largest handheld on the market. It achieves this size without significant bulk. At 0.73 inches, it is no thicker than a PSP-3000, and weighs a little less than 10 ounces. It feels study and it’s comfortable to hold, even through extended gaming sessions.

Left to Right, iPhone 4/4S, Nintendo 3DS, PSP-3000, PS Vita

Most of this space is dedicated to its gorgeous 5 inch OLED capacitive multi-touch screen. With a qHD resolution of 960 x 544, it boasts 220 pixels per inch. While it doesn’t quite match the iPhone4′s retina display (326 ppi), it is still crisp and detailed. The colors are rich and compared to it, the PSP and 3DS’s displays look horribly pixellated.

The touch screen is responsive and accurate–as good as any smart phone. The large amount of screen space helps offset the relative lack of precision from using fingers instead of a stylus. Unfortunately, it doesn’t seem to be oleophobic. Light fingerprints are largely invisible while the system is in use. However, a slight rainbow effect occurs on the heavier smudges over the course of an extended session.

In addition to the touchscreen, the system boasts a wide array of control options. It has the same basic control options as its predecessor–a d-pad, 2 shoulder buttons, and 4 face buttons. It also has a rear touchpad, six-axis motion sensing (3 axis gyrometer, 3 axis accelerometer), a front camera, a rear camera, and most importantly–dual thumb sticks.

The thumb sticks are small and squat, with the familiar convex tops and slightly rubberized surfaces. They’re responsive and feel very natural, although I can’t shake the feeling they’re about to slip out from under my thumbs–although they have yet to do so.

The rear touchpad is somewhat bewildering. I’m not entirely sure what it’s for and I’m not sure game developers know either. I’ve yet to see an implementation in a game that wasn’t completely shoe-horned in. Of course, I said something similar about the Nintendo DS’s touch screen at first–perhaps some inventive developer will rise to the challenge.

The six-axis motion sensing is an interesting touch. While it’s largely ignored and shoehorned in when it isn’t, there are potentially useful applications for it. Its use in Uncharted: Golden Abyss bears special mention: you can move the system to shift the reticule. While this alone would be a horridly awkward way to go about aiming, it is superb in conjunction with the thumb sticks. Using the sticks to aim, then moving the system slightly to make fine adjustments quickly becomes second nature–to the point you wonder how you got along without it before.

Both cameras are 1.3 megapixels. The Vita won’t take the place of, well, anything when it comes to home photography. They’re not without purpose, though. The back camera allows for “Augmented Reality” games, which use the real-life background as a backdrop for the game. The front camera features face detection and head tracking capabilities, although I’ve yet to see a game that makes use of them. Last, but not least, the conventional controls are comfortable and about what anyone familiar with a PSP would expect. It’s worth noting the d-pad isn’t as stiff and the face buttons are noticeably smaller when compared to the PSP’s. The Vita also features Wi-Fi (802.11 b/g/n), Bluetooth, microphone, stereo sound, a headphone jack, and slots for game cards and its proprietary storage. For $50 more, you can opt to have 3G in addition to Wi-Fi. It is worth noting the game cartridge compartment has a door that’s infuriatingly difficult to jimmy open with short fingernails.

Note the really small slots for port opening.

Software
The Vita’s interface is quick and clean. It eschews the XMB for a phone-like home screen–it displays 10 icons per page, which are only navigatable via the touch interface. Swiping up and down navigates you through your installed apps, and swiping left and right cycles through your open applications. Whenever you insert a new game card, it “installs” the game, adding a new icon to the menu that persists even after the card is removed. I haven’t seen a list option, so the menu might get fairly bloated as one’s library grows.

PS Vita home screen

Pressing the PS button again from the home screen brings up a list of currently open apps, which you can also see as a small row of icons on the top margin.

The Vita has apps for most of the things you would expect on a portable handheld–Friends list, PS Store, Trophies, Remote Play, Settings, etc. It also has apps you would commonly see on smartphones–Facebook, Twitter, Netflix, Maps, and a web browser. There are a few apps that warrant special mention. Unlike the PSP or PS3, the Playstation Vita supports both party voice chat and group messaging through PSN, via the Party and Group Messaging apps, respectively. While neither are mandatory additions, party chat is a godsend if you want to talk to friends (and only your friends) while playing online. It also comes with a quirky app called Near, which shows you what people are playing nearby. I’ve seen it extend out to about a mile around me, with their positions relative to where I am. At the time of writing, it has found 38 Vita owners within half a mile of me. Never fear, if you desire privacy, you are not obliged to disclose your location or activities.

This is a gaming system, through and through. While it makes a nod toward expanded functionality, it is merely a token effort–there is no reason not to include those functions if the device can perform them. While activities like Netflix and Twitter are perfectly pleasant using the Vita, it is not designed to be a smart phone replacement and is merely usable when it comes to web browsing. The virtual keyboard is nice, but it lacks an autocorrect function (for good or for ill)–and personally, my hands are too small to conveniently reach the middle keys. Similarly, I wouldn’t use the system for its music player, video player, or camera functions.

Sony has set out to create a console that can play almost any kind of game and they have succeeded admirably. From “phone games” to first person shooters, it can do it all. The importance of dual thumb sticks on this system cannot be overstated. It was a revolutionary concept when it came to home consoles, and it similarly expands the range of games available to the PS Vita–essential when attempting to recreate the home console experience. The Vita is flexible and powerful, and successfully imparts the home console experience on the go. Unfortunately, the Vita price point is also similar to home consoles- $250 for Wifi only or $300 with Wifi and 3G connectivity. The proprietary memory is also prohibitively expensive, ranging from $20 for a 4GB card to a whopping $100 for a 32GB card. If you avoid downloading retail titles, you can probably get by with a 4GB or 8GB card. If you want a purely digital library, be prepared to pay dearly–each retail game takes up 2-4GB. 3G service isn’t free either–the cheapest plan is $15 per month, with a cap of 250MB. Overall, the Playstation Vita is a truly impressive piece of hardware with a lot of potential but with its price and added costs, will be a hard sell at these price points no matter how many shiny features it has to offer.

Guest review by ALbert Lee aka @quantumcatphd on Twitter. If you have any questions or things you’d like covered in more depth, shoot him a message!

item.title: 20SON Review – Klingon, Romulan, and Alien Armada
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: In 2011, Amarillo Design Bureau and Majestic 12 games adapted the Starmada system to the Star Fleet Universe. We've already declared Starmada to be an excellent fleet and squad level starship combat system, but do the peculiars of the Star Fleet Universe translate well to the Starmada system?
item.content:encoded:
Star Fleet Battles as a gaming system has a long and dramatic history. It’s replete with licensing issues, deviations from Star Trek canon, supplier problems, player discontent, and a plethora of revisions. It’s quite a tale, but through it all the complexity and detail of the system has remained. Complexity is simultaneously it’s greatest strength and biggest weakness. Star Fleet Battles is an excellent small scale engagement simulator, but even the most adept of players has a hard time fielding more than a small handful of ships. As such, large fleet actions are very difficult to orchestrate and play. Until recently, large fleet actions were only abstractable in Federation and Empire, an operational level game involving entire empires and the fate of the galaxy in the balance. In 2011, Amarillo Design Bureau and Majestic 12 games adapted the Starmada system to the Star Fleet Universe. We’ve already declared Starmada to be an excellent fleet and squad level starship combat system in this very website, but do the peculiars of the Star Fleet Universe translate well to the Starmada system?

We’ve already thoroughly reviewed the Starmada system. In summary:

In conclusion, Starmada is just a wonderful game.The rules are easy to learn, the cost is extremely reasonable, and the only limit to how you play is how much time you want to invest. Games can take a little as an hour if you wanted an extremely casual game or days if you built up massive, customized fleets. Majestic 12 was even kind enough to give you all the printable resources you could need, in terms of play board, ships, and even tokens to keep track of your ships.

As far as general mechanics go, very little has been added that wasn’t already present in the Starmada core book or rule annex. A couple of different Starmada products have been harvested for Klingon Armada to bring you what you need to get started in the Star Fleet Universe. That’s not to say that if you want to play in this particular universe that you shouldn’t get Klingon Armada if you already have both books. There is a great deal of universe specific text with the ruleset that you won’t have if you just have the core books. There are also about 40 Star Fleet Universe ships included per volume of the Armada series which you also wouldn’t get with just the core Starmada book. It is important to note that the Starmada system has a significant departure from normal starship combat games. Power allocation is an important factor in the original source material, but in Klingon Armada as in Starmada there is no power allocation phase. If it’s installed on your ship and not damaged, you can use it. Power allocation for perhaps dozens of ships on one side would prove to be problematic and extraordinarily time consuming, so this isn’t a flaw of the system. Rather it is a design choice and a nod towards simple and fast play rather than the epic level of detail found in other products.

This is essentially the Enterprise from Star Fleet Battles, in it's simplest form. It's normally a full 8.5 x 11 page.

There are four books in the Star Fleet Universe Armada series. The Klingon Armada book includes the Klingons, Federation, Tholians, Orions and Kzinti. Romulan Armada includes more Federation ships, and adds the Romulans and Gorn to the play field. Alien Armada includes more Tholians, more Orions, and adds the Neo-Tholians and Seltorians. Distant Armada adds the Hydrans, WYN Cluster, Lyran Empire, and Lyran Democratic Republic. All of these books are stand alone and don’t require any other products in the series to use. You could get just the Distant Armada book if you were so inclined and still have a complete product with everything you need to play. If you’re a Trek purist, many of these names are foreign to you. The variant of the Star Trek universe that Klingon Armada lives in diverged from the “main” Trek fictional universe at about the time of the original Star Trek movies. Licensing issues are a bitch sometimes.

The Star Fleet Battles universe has a few different scales of play as I alluded to before. Strategic Level is handled by Federation and Empire. Single and small number of unit skirmishes are best handled by Star Fleet Battles itself in ridiculous system level detail. One on one duels are best handled in Star Fleet Battles. Federation Commander has two scales which speeds play a bit at the expense of some detail. Small squads of ships are best handled in either scale of Federation Commander. The gap between Federation Commander and Federation and Empire is now filled with the Armada series which allows for truly epic levels of fleet engagements. Even though the Armada series of products isn’t quite Star Fleet Battles, the customizability of the base Starmada system has allowed for the game to still mostly feel like and play similarly to the basic Star Fleet Battles system.

This is the same ship as above, just in Starmada. Perhaps somewhat less flashy, but only half a page. The two pictures are essentially to scale.

While an overall success, the Armada series isn’t perfect. If you’re a veteran Star Fleet Battles player, you likely have a large notebook filled with official starship ship system displays from the designer. While Starmada has a robust starship construction system allowing you to make your own ships, there isn’t an easy set of instructions to convert your existing ships to the new system. There just isn’t a 1:1 conversion. Furthermore both Star Fleet Battles and the Starmada system have a point system to balance combats, but the numbers don’t quite add up. In Star Fleet Battles, the standard Constitution class Heavy Cruiser (the Enterprise) has a slight advantage over a Klingon D-7 cruiser. In Starmada, the point total is tipped slightly towards the D-7. This isn’t a major difference and we’re only talking a few percentage points in any event, but it is enough to make a veteran scratch their head a bit in confusion. Also, if you have an early revision of the Klingon Armada rulebook a critical rule is missing. Specifically, the range based rate of fire rule governing how phasers work isn’t present. This is easily obtainable on the Majestic 12 website. If you’ve got a PDF version from Steve Jackson Games’ webstore E23, the version currently available for download has the rule properly included. I’m a little concerned about Majestic 12′s announcement that there is a new Starmada system in the works and due very soon. I have reached out to the developers for more details about the new version of Starmada’s interoperability with the existing Armada series of products. At press time I haven’t received a response. However, in the Majestic 12 forums there is a post that states that there will be a method to “up convert” existing Starmada Admiralty Edition ships. If this is in fact the case, the Armada series ships will still be compatible with that ruleset but not vice versa.

Klingon Armada and it’s sister publications in the series share a solid background based on a flexible game engine. The PDFs are comparative in price to the paper version of the rules, running about $12 per complete ruleset. Your $12 purchase contains both the rules for that iteration and an additional book of starships that utilize those rules, but both are available separately if you just need one or the other for some reason. The dead tree version runs $14 or so assuming you can even find a friendly local game store near you. The battle for the idea of a One True Star Trek has waged in nerd circles for years with no end in sight. Pocket Star Trek universes exist in everybody’s mind and we all have a tendency to disregard what other people have to say about what’s in their Star Trek. The Star Fleet Battles universe is pretty far from Trek’s normal as it stands today. The flavor of this universe is firmly grounded on mostly retconned out of existence original Star Trek, the Star Trek animated series, and the Franz Joseph Technical Manual. A disregard of Paramount official canon in the Star Fleet Universe shouldn’t discourage you from playing the Armada series.

item.title: 20SON Recommends – Free Gaming Stuff!
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: We’ve done a bunch of podcast episodes. Sometimes in our unending search to find cool crap for you, we find or mention stuff that may or may not get linked and we get all smartassy and tell you to google... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
We’ve done a bunch of podcast episodes. Sometimes in our unending search to find cool crap for you, we find or mention stuff that may or may not get linked and we get all smartassy and tell you to google it. I thought I’d take a few minutes and link you to some of my favorite free-ish stuff that I’ve found. Some I’ve mentioned, some I haven’t. Keep in mind that my particular bent is old school style gameplay and turn based strategy. Most of these picks skew in that direction. Almost all of this stuff is Windows compatible. I’ll specifically mention if they run on OSX as well.

Representational but functional. Par for a turn based game!

Star Trek Starship Tactical Combat Simulator – Windows

Back in the day, FASA had the license for Star Trek. By back in the day, I mean just before Star Trek: The Next Generation launched. The tale differs somewhat on what caused the end of the FASA license, but the all-powerful wikipedia says that two Next Generation supplements weren’t fully vetted by the licensing gods at Paramount.

In any event, there is a small but devoted following of the Star Trek Starship Combat game online to this day. Most of the rules from the final edition of the ruleset are implemented Jason Robinson’s version of the game for windows. Given all the Paramount official material published since the original rules for this game was released, this is in no way canon, but rather a quick and fun way to get involved in the very old school war-game.

Edit – March 30, 2012. To get the game running in Windows 7 (and probably 8) you need to install the Visual Basic DLL located here prior to running the executable. Source.

Remember that "functional" thing I spoke of in the previous picture? Yeah, more of that.

Megamek – Java, cross platform

Yeah, okay, I was a FASA whore when I was a young man. FASA’s other major property in the eighties was Battletech, and I penned a bit of a love letter to it’s modern interpretation here. For the last 10 years, there’s been an unofficial Java version of it called Megamek. The bot for single play is decent, but this version really shines online versus other humans. Various mech construction programs like the one we linked to from Solaris Skunk Werks will export to Megamek, making the game about infinitely customizable.

Alien Assault – Windows

A few years ago, a small group of programmers got together, and pounded together an excellent verbatim implementation of Space Hulk for the computer. The program befell some legal difficulties with finger pointing between major corporations complicating the issue. Such are the complications of a third party development of a licensed property. Long story short, some graphical assets had to change, but the gameplay remained the same. With a persistent campaign and easily moddable assets, Alien Assault deserves a bit of your time if you’re a fan of turn based strategy.

This isn't Babylon 5, but it came from it.

Advent of Galactic Wars – PDF

Another licensed property that went beyond the rim is the Agents of Gaming product Babylon 5 Wars. Similar to the very complex Star Fleet Battles, AoG’s ruleset simulated ship to ship combat in the Babylon 5 universe to exacting detail. The game was pretty well balanced and presented fairly well, but AoG lost the license when Warner Brothers decided that they weren’t doing anything to enhance the license. Since then, Mongoose published their own ruleset, but that’s gone now too.

A group of fans banded together to protect the work, and released the Advent of Galactic Wars ruleset. It’s basically all the rules from the Babylon 5 Wars rulebooks and supplements with the Babylon 5 color text and graphical elements removed. This manipulation doesn’t make it any less of a good game, though, just be prepared for lots of rule references as you play! The linked source also includes ships from other universes, just in case you wanted to run a Robotech versus Star Trek versus Babylon 5 scenario.

The rather plain original cover for Time Lord

Timelord : Adventures Through Time and Space – PDF

Once more, back in the day, there were two Doctor Who roleplaying games. Time passed, and so did the Doctor Who franchise, so into the vortex they went seemingly never to return. One of the two games was Timelord. Originally published in a large paperback format rather than the industry conventional 8.5×11 size, I think the game suffered a bit because of it. In 1998, the game was released for free on the internet. There are no character creation rules to speak of, but it’s fairly well fleshed out, at least for classic Who. Since the new official Doctor Who RPG from Cubicle 7 doesn’t really acknowledge the earlier series other than some passing mentions, this is the only way to get your classic Who on.

21st century graphics for a 20th century game

Renegade Legion – PDF

When FASA dissolved, their properties went all over the place. The most egregious treatment after the breakup was Night Shift Games’ handling of the Renegade Legion franchise. Technically, the license is held by Topps who seemingly has no interest in the product. The old post FASA Night Shift Games work is available with a fan produced supplement for the game.

The rules, specifically fighter and tank damage are very flowchart oriented. For fear of sounding old and cantankerous, they don’t seem to make games like this anymore. With a unique armor widowing mechanic as well as the wiring diagram damage flowchart, it’s worth a play.

This is one of the most ornate space ships I've ever seen, from Battlefleet Gothic.

Battlefleet Gothic – PDF

This one confuses me a great deal. Games Workshop jealously protects it’s intellectual property, and even old versions of the Warhammer franchises aren’t readily available online. In a notable exception, their own starship combat rules are, and have been since 2008. It’s a good game, if a bit ponderous, but most starship combat games are!

Last Night on Earth in the Vassal Engine. Looks more complicated than it is!

VASSAL – Windows, OSX, and Linux

Once upon a time, if we wanted to play a war-game we’d have to get a bunch of players together, find a sufficiently clean large flat surface, and break out the million pieces of cardboard or multi-thousand dollar miniature armies. With the advent and ubiquitousness of fast internet connections, there has to be a better option!

There is a better option. Founded in 2003, VASSAL is a universal game engine limited only by the ability of the module programmers. There are over 800 games with modules available for VASSAL. Some are official, some not so much, and some are straight out forbidden by the game designers! You still have to have a functional knowledge of the rules for whatever game you’re playing, but VASSAL will provide everything else you need for a smooth internet play session. A modicum of technical knowledge is required for proper use- if you can’t open and redirect ports on your router, then you shouldn’t serve a game. Otherwise, if you’ve got the ability to understand war-game rules, then you can use VASSAL!

Added 2/28/2012:

The Ur-Quan Masters. One of the best games of it's time.

Star Control – The Ur-Quan Masters – Windows, OSX, and Linux

One of the earliest video games ever was Spacewar. Two players duking it out on a single screen for control of the galaxy. Almost 20 years later the Star Control series was very popular for a number of computers. In August 2002 Toys for Bob, the developer of the 3D0 released the source code for Star Control 2 to the community.

This version of the Ur-Quan Masters takes assets from all the games and combines them into one mega-game. Graphically, the game is dated, but the gameplay is excellent with an outstanding Rock Paper Scissors mechanic and fantastic balance between the factions. Good for either a campaign or a quick deathmatch!

Added 2/29/2012

Double barreled action, from Mechwarrior 4.

Mechwarrior 4 Mercenaries Free download – Windows

Mechwarrior 2 may have been ubiquitous, but Mechwarrior 4 was a much better game! Yes, the game is 10 years old, but there is still a vibrant community that stands behind and maintains the game to this day. Featuring a branching storyline and a robust online contingent of gamers this game is a must play even now, 10 years after release.

I hope this whets your appetite a bit. I intend on this being a living document- as I find more cool stuff in this vein, I’ll add to it!

Did you get this far? Do you remember our review of 20SON Review – AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA: For The Awesome?

Want it on Steam? 3FRQA-NY745-8TT9E Leave a comment here if you’ve snagged it.

item.title: 20SON Retro Review – Falling Skies Comic by Dark Horse
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: I knew about the comic while the show was airing, but didn't pay it much attention at the time. With the announcement of Terry O'Quinn appearing for two episodes this coming season, I looked back at some of the Falling Skies media, and thought I'd give the comic a chance.
item.content:encoded:
Genre television isn’t hard to find. Every year there’s something produced that tries to tap into our elusive nerd market. Some of it is good, some of it not so much. In the summer of 2011, Falling Skies starring Noah Wylie debuted on TNT. I thought it was mostly good, but I thought it had a ways to go. Too many tropes. Magic BBs causing major plot advancement. I thought it was about as good as Star Trek : The Next Generation’s first season. In a nutshell, promise unrealized, but there nonetheless. Nobody on the writing staff quite seemed to know who the characters were beyond the main man- Wylie’s portrayal of history professor Tom Mason. I knew about the comic while the show was airing, but didn’t pay it much attention at the time. With the announcement of Terry O’Quinn appearing for two episodes this coming season, I looked back at some of the Falling Skies media, and thought I’d give the comic a chance.

Technologically, the comic uses the Dark Horse portable reader JAVA and html applet. No flash is in use making the reader cross platform and usable on Windows, OSX, iOS, Linux, and most flavors of android. Bookmarks are stored server-side if you have an account, so you can easily pick up reading where you left off even if you used a different device previously. The default page size is somewhat enormous, requiring you to zoom in a bit to see the entire page on one screen but that’s just my preferred reading method. I tested the website’s usability on an iPhone 4, an original iPad, and a Macbook Pro running both OSX Lion and Windows 7. The user interface was clear and precise in every iteration of hardware and operating system. I will say though, that a phone isn’t an optimal platform for comic consumption, so I really don’t’ recommend it. I’m not sure that any screen smaller than the nearly 10″ diagonal iPad screen is optimal, but I didn’t have any 7″ devices to test my theory on.

Artistically, the comics have a certain grit to them, reflecting the post apocalyptic setting of the show. Most panels I had a pretty good grip who was who. It’s hard to get a likeness of somebody real exactly right and recognizable panel after panel, angle after angle, page after page. I only had a “huhwha?” moment every once in a while. The context of the dialog was consistent, so it was pretty clear who was who by dialog if not always the art. Scaling of sci-fi elements was done well- this is a pet peeve of mine. Skitter ships were consistently large. The aliens themselves were imposing and threatening. Perspectives were done well. Human weapons were easily recognizable as what they were, and for the most part, portrayed accurately with no more artistic license than Hollywood itself uses. As a quick note to comic writers and Hollywood- there are a lot of military members looking for work. It wouldn’t kill you to hire one or two as advisors if even part time for consultation on such matters like if you can reload anti-tank weaponry or even simple military tactics.

From a story perspective, the comic takes place before the series itself starts. The invasion is over, the aliens occupy Earth. Militia are forming the Second Massachusetts regiment and with any luck, an organized resistance can be formed to help keep humanity alive. The four issues of the comic (which are contained in the trade paperback, should you go the dead tree route) cover Tom Mason’s discovery and subsequent joining of the militia and the 2nd Massachusetts regiment. As a primer to the TV series, the bases are covered. Tom “discusses” what’s going on with the world and the invasion in the form of diary entries bookmarking chapters of the comic, giving historical perspective to the “current” time. The Skitter and mech threat to the survivors is made abundantly clear by the body count which mounts page after page, as it likely would in the end phases of an alien invasion. In the beginning of every militia formation, you need to find guns, food, and shelter. These realities of post-apocalyptic survival are just touched on in the comic, saving the deeper and heavier implications of humanity teetering on the edge of extinction for the television show. The webcomic, then print comic, is part of the Falling Skies extended universe. While a logical start to the story it may be rendered non-canon by future television episodes, as is often the case with comic adaptations or extensions of other media. The comic is free and fun to read, so no further spoilers here.

The comic is free on Dark Horse’s digital comics web portal, only requiring a no-cost account be made. Our normal value equation is a little difficult to include here. If you’re interested in seeing how Tom Mason and family got involved with the 2nd Mass, here’s where you start. If you’ve got no interest in Falling Skies, then this comic’s not for you. The fact that the Dark Horse comic reader is so nimble on multiple platforms and operating systems should be considered while you figure out what your path is for digital comic distribution.
