item.title: 20SON Retro Review – Civilization V
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Civilization V is the latest turn based strategy game in the legacy of Sid Meier. Chances are you’ve heard of, or played, one of the great games in this series. By some awkward chance you haven’t heard of this pentalogy of games (like me), let’s give it a brief run down.
item.content:encoded:
Throughout history, leaders have risen and fallen. As one goes down another must come to power. Have you ever wanted to have a rule remembered in time as your own? I can’t really help you with that. What I can provide is something to allow you to live vicariously through the great leaders of our past. I present to you Sid Meier’s Civilization V by Firaxis. Civilization V is the latest turn based strategy game in the legacy of Sid Meier. Chances are you’ve heard of, or played, one of the great games in this series. By some awkward chance you haven’t heard of this pentalogy of games (like me), let’s give it a brief run down. The Civilization series of games place you in a world with other prominent figures of our past. Through methods of expansion, science, money and diplomacy you navigate the world in search of your ultimate society of victory. This time around, the navigation of the game is built upon a hex grid for movement, with basic stats and strength checks to determine the outcomes of battles. Victory is made by whichever path you choose to take. Of those, there are many.

First and foremost, I must disclose a little here. Turn based games and I have never really got along. Time was always a factor in our arguments. It always seemed like the genre of games was too demanding of my time to get anything accomplished. For that reason, RTS games always were granted my favor. Truth be told, the last even sort-of turn based games that I granted any sort of time were the original Fallout games. After those, these seemingly slow time mongers never even were a blip on my gaming radar. After spending time with Civilization V, henceforth know as Civ 5, I think that perhaps I may have dismissed turn based a bit hastily.

Ease of Play
Civ 5 is a simple game to jump right into. The game menus are crisp and to the point. In this age of too many options, this is a blessing. Want to jump into a random game? Done. Want to tweak the settings, like your fabled leader, number of players, world type or starting technological age? You can do that too. Never having played a Civilization game in the past, I appreciated the fact that it spelled everything out for me. Not once did I feel lost about what I was jumping into. The objective of the game, well, that was something else.

Upon venturing forth in my first game, I was happy to find that everything was continuing to hold my hand. Every building, research project, combat unit and upgrades tell you exactly what their attributes are and what they can do. As your civilization grows, more and more things become available to you. There hasn’t been a thing in any game I’ve been through that left me scratching my head as to what the hell it did. If you ever run into one, let me know. There just wasn’t anything confusing that I could see. Per chance of you arriving at a point where you may be lost on how to progress your piece of earth, it even has you covered there. Advisors are there to provide you guidance on how to grow. Icons are even places next to suggestions on which path to take per that advisors’ specialty.

Ranged combat is a little different this time around.

Conditions of Victory
Some time has passed since there has been a game I played in which you could win in other fashions than slashing or shooting your way to the end. Total world military domination is an option if you choose and you are going to have a hell of a time doing it! You remember that I wasn’t too sure on the objective of the game? That came into play when I went head first into my first challenge- I had no idea how to win. Sure you could check your progress once you figured out where that was (I’ll save you some time. It’s a small circle with the drop down menu on the upper right). It doesn’t really come out and say what you are working towards though. Nor does it ever warn you about the 500 turn limit which would have been nice. There’s a manual I could have read but who does that now though? Given my past with real time strategy games, I figured that pummeling my enemies out of the gate would be the best course of action. Oh, how I was wrong. After ignoring all requests for aid, agreements and open borders from the city-states around me, I knew it was my time to strike. My army was a decent size and ready to take on opponents. I ended up being on the receiving end of an ass beating with only myself to blame. Game number one was done in less than 200 turns.

On the next go around, I thought perhaps it would be wise to pace myself a little bit, maybe flow with the events of the game. Going with the flow seemed a better choice than allowing the computer to murder my civilization. While there were no proclamations announcing me supreme ruler of the world, I was able to learn more. My previous attempt at world domination may have been a bit short sighted. Let me explain why- if advances are made on the scientific, economic and political fronts, you military might could crumble even if you have superior numbers. This was a fatal flaw that was embedded in my mind from all those days playing RTS games. Unfortunately, that idea was forcefully extracted from my cranium after my terrible, terrible loss.

Fret not, as there are other conditions under which I could achieve victory. By achieving victory, I really mean avenging my honor. And by avenging my honor, I mean taking my sweet revenge. My eyes were opened to the paths of science and culture. Instead of an arms race, it quickly boils down to a resource balancing act. Build and research as fast as you possibly can. Tailor your next move to maximize whatever value you are looking to win by. There is a catch though. Your army and expansion can’t suffer while you keep working. If either shows any sign of weakness, the other leaders will call you on it. And they mock you. They will let you know just how pathetic you are. In my opinion, I think that most people would fit into this play style though. It is a much easier path to balance to victory. Plus, you don’t have to act as reactionary, withering away your resources when your attack squads start falling. Diplomacy is another option. It is by far the hardest route in which to win. Your world has to be coupled with such a bustling economy to pull it off. Don’t let that detour you if you want to try it. It is possible to win.

When it comes to the end, if a decisive victory cannot be won through any of the fore mentioned options, the battle will come by points. This is perfect if you want to play a balancing game with your eyes on the long road. Whichever way you craft your vehicle to subjugation weighs heavily on how you will play the game. Please, try them all. You’ll be surprised just how fun each method can be.

This time, hexes!

The Audio and Visuals
Expectations for Civ 5 were actually low for me on the graphic side of things I must admit. It wasn’t to say that it couldn’t look good. It was more of a thought as to if it needed to be. That said, this game is quite the looker. While there isn’t anything brand spanking new or revolutionary, it is still very pretty. This is a good thing considering the amount of time you’ll spending looking at it.

One thing I was particularly impressed by were the animations of the individual units. Each unit has a specific animation that it carries out to fulfill its purpose. For example, when you get to the artillery cannons, they have to setup before firing. Upon each initiation of an attack, little people walk up to the heavy guns and set up the legs to brace the force of the shot. Afterwards, when the recoil is all said and done, the gun is reloaded and the legs are put back into place for movement. Each time you call an action, the unit must perform. All animations are fluid and seem to be purposely crafted to the action. Another example that I rather enjoyed were the workers shoveling or raking in unison when working land tiles. For some reason it is enthralling to watch.

Any time a world leader interaction occurs, you get a CGI representation speaking to you in their native tongue. It gives a personal touch as if you were having a one on one meeting. While I do like this, I would have appreciated a little more variation in it. Each leader has only a few phrases and small variety of expressions and gestures. Also, each has a different backdrop that never seems to change. No turning of the seasons or different camera angles to pull you deeper into your experience. To add another sour note to the leaders, I have to add something about the CGI itself. All of them just appear to be really cartoony and overly smooth looking. I’d prefer that they looked just a little more realistic.

A nitpicky graphical complaint is that I wish the images shown once you complete a world wonder looked more appealing. As they stand now, all the pictures look rough, not unlike a painting. While I like the idea of drawing attention to completing one and letting the whole world know, I’m just not a fan of the way these look. There is too much contrast between them and everything else.

Lastly on the graphics side, I must warn of some of the issues in this game. I don’t know in my case how much of it was on my end, but this game locks up a lot. For me, it mostly seemed to happen in my interactions with other known leaders. While I’ve read a fair amount about this, there are many people with issues far worse than that. Patches are coming though! And please, look up how to disable the intro video once you’ve watched it. Otherwise, it’ll annoy you as it randomly seems to select when it is done playing if you try and prompt it. I still advocate that it is great to look at though.

Music is something that really must be brought up about this game when it is talked about. Frankly, it is fantastic. Each culture has a different score that progressed as you advance. The greatest thing about it is that it’s all very ambient. Most of the music just lightly adds to the overall atmosphere. Sure, there are events that trigger heavier tones, for instance battle. However, even those sounds fit the mood. Subtle soundtracks are much appreciated as you tend to envelop yourself in this game. More times than not, a game will possess an overpowering soundtrack that just kills the end user experience. Civ 5 is not one of those at all.

Time
You didn’t need to go anywhere for a while, right? Matches can take a few hours or even days in Civ 5. From my trials a game lasting six hours was not uncommon. You can make this quicker in the settings, but the step down just doesn’t feel the same. If you are a brave soul, turn it to the slowest setting. Descriptios claim that one turn could last the length of a standard speed game to end. Think about that for a second. One turn would be one whole game. To put some perspective on that, during my six hour games each turn would take roughly 45 seconds. Now, amp that up a little to six hours a turn. I am not a brave soul. Frankly, turning the game to that speed intimidated me. I think that is for the best. If it was still a 500 turn game, with the time table I had above it would take 125 days to complete. If I ventured out to do that this review still wouldn’t be done and I might have some serious hygiene concerns I’d need to attend to.

All joking aside it is very easy to lose long amounts of time to Civ 5. You get so engrossed in it that you begin to stop tracking things. Take note though, as it is easy to pick up again from where you left off once you are able to pry yourself away. Everything is tracked for you. Because of that, it is very easy for your brain to disconnect. Trouble is you have to want to break away. Just make sure you keep an eye on a clock. (Editor’s Note- Draeno cursed me and Civ V out one day during the review process because it took too much time out of his schedule!)

In Closing
Overall, I was very impressed with Civilization 5. It changed my perceptions of turn based games. Really, it makes me sad that I didn’t approach any other game in the series in the past. From here out, there is a strong possibility that I would pick up another turn based title in the future. As for buying the game, I whole heartily recommend it. Especially I’d say if you were a fan of previous outings or just a fan of the genre. Perhaps if you were on the fence about the purchase, I’d even say snatch it up at a $39.99 price point. As I stated, my own experience may have been crippled by my dying machine. I maintain that Civ 5 killed my computer.

Civilization 5, thumbs up to you.

Editor’s Note – This review was written by Draeno about 14 months ago. Nothing has really changed about the review with patches. We thought it would be relevant considering that there’s a new expansion for Civ V due soon.

item.title: 20SON Review – Rise of the Martian Bear DLC for Iron Brigade
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Back in 2011 Double Fine released Iron Brigade, a playful giant stomping robot of destruction game crossed with tower defense that didn't take itself too seriously. Honestly, it's on a very short list of my favorite games of last year. When we last left our heroes the melodramatically sinister leader of the Signal Vlad lay defeated at the hands of the valiant trench pilots. The mobile trench carrier USS McKinley steamed off into the sunset with our heroes aboard. A great deal has happened since we left our victorious heroes. In our world, a legal challenge forced the game's name to change to Iron Brigade. With the name change came a survival/horde mode. In their world, Vlad has apparently survived and rocketed off to Mars in a 400 point downloadable content called Rise of the Martian Bear. Should you spend the 400 point premium to continue the valiant effort against the tube menace, or should Vlad be left to attack humanity from Mars?
item.content:encoded:
Back in 2011 Double Fine released Trenched Iron Brigade, a playful giant stomping robot of destruction game crossed with tower defense that didn’t take itself too seriously. We reviewed it here, and honestly, it’s on a very short list of my favorite games of last year. When we last left our heroes the melodramatically sinister leader of the Signal Vlad lay defeated at the hands of the valiant trench pilots. The mobile trench carrier USS McKinley steamed off into the sunset with our heroes aboard. A great deal has happened since we left our victorious heroes. In our world, a legal challenge forced the game’s name to change to Iron Brigade. With the name change came a survival/horde mode. In their world, Vlad has apparently survived and rocketed off to Mars in a 400 point downloadable content called Rise of the Martian Bear. Should you spend the 400 point premium to continue the valiant effort against the tube menace, or should Vlad be left to attack humanity from Mars?

Plot-wise, there isn’t a lot of elapsed time from the end of the core Iron Brigade game and the Rise of the Martian Bear. After discovering his emaciated body in the core of the blasted Earth broadcast center, Vlad transferred his consciousness to the Signal itself. Needing to manifest himself physically once more, he outfitted his pet bear with a grand mustache and set forth to enslave humanity again from the cold reaches of space. Over the course of five missions, you have to protect the McKinley from attack while it’s being outfitted to travel into space. After blasting off, you spend some time on the moon before reaching your ultimate destination- Mars.

Mayhem on the Red Planet. Blast them Tubes!

From a gameplay perspective, Rise of the Martian Bear is hard, even with a level 10 pilot fully ranked from the original title. I don’t think I can stress this enough. Rise of the Martian Bear is hard. It’s designed as such. My first attempts at the DLC review were solo, as just about everybody this week is playing the Mass Effect 3 demo. This left my regular squad unavailable. I must have thrown myself at the first mission 11 times before I beat it. When I finally did, it was by the skin of my teeth. The second mission took 18 times, the third, 19 times. I was way too frustrated to count how many times I played the fourth mission before beating it. For fear of blowing a gasket I still haven’t completed the DLC solo. There was no real trial and error process. There was just way too many very powerful enemies including some new ones raining down entirely too much fire on my position to have any success. Iron Brigade’s combat mechanics are very much a rock/paper/scissors(lizard/Spock) kind of situation. No matter what you have on your trench something else always seems like it will work out a bit better at some point in the onslaught of enemies facing you on any given level. You just can’t carry enough towers and have enough firepower to do the job in single player. The problem is all of the missions have wide-spread objectives you need to protect simultaneously. As I alluded to before, I think this is by design, not by accident. I finished the original game co-op with a full squad, so I never played the last few levels solo. As an experiment I went back to the Pacific Theater from the core game and tried some of those levels by myself. The last few levels before the final confrontation with Vlad were also very hard single player. It’s pretty clear that the game was designed with opposition tailored towards requiring all the firepower that multiple players can muster to defeat them.

Rise of the Martian Bear adds a great deal of replay value to the core game. Two new survival levels are added to the game bringing the total to three. There are three new bad guys added that appear in the DLC campaign levels and all of the survival missions. More importantly, 80 new pieces of gear have been added including some very welcome new emplacements. I found that the best testing ground for new equipment was in survival as you’ll see every enemy type at least once. Assuming you survive long enough you can collect some new loot in the process! I didn’t see any new trench chassis types, but they do seem to have received a helpful health upgrade at some point. If you’re into total overkill, bringing some of the epic weaponry you receive in Rise of the Martian Bear or survival back to the core game will drive up your kill counts for the glory of yourself or the enrichment of your squad. After the thrashing you receive over and over in the DLC, going back to the core game with mega-weaponry can be cathartic.

The landscape of Mars is foreign. Use it to your advantage!

From a technical standpoint Iron Brigade is as solid as it’s predecessor. I didn’t experience any real bugs or issues other than some currency of the game (scrap) being stuck behind a girder or in a hole or other such obstruction from time to time. Frame rates with one exception were solid. I had a minor hiccup when I received a beacon from someone on my friend’s list who signed on and wanted me to play Halo. even though he was playing something else. Beacons are a new feature of xBox Live where somebody on your buddy list sets a game that they want to play. You get notification of this desire from this person, even if the buddy isn’t playing that game at the time. The response to beacons isn’t the fault of Iron Brigade nor of Rise of the Martian Bear, but rather the new OS on the xBox.

Rise of the Martian Bear is more of the same gameplay and experience you’d expect from Iron Brigade. That’s both good and bad. There’s nothing here that will attract a player dissatisfied from aspects the first game as core gameplay is basically unchanged. If you feel you’ve extracted maximum enjoyment out of the core title more of the same isn’t a draw. However, if more survival levels and better gear appeal to you or you want to revisit gameplay style from the core Iron Brigade, then 400 Microsoft Points is a very low price to pay. You get arguably 10 or more hours of gameplay added to the title. Whether you do or don’t help me rid the world of the evil Tubes, I’m getting my ass back to Mars to finish this fight.

item.title: Season 3 of The Walking Dead Gets More Episodes
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: As we mentioned a few months ago, the show was able to pick up a third season. Since then we’ve learned that AMC has a little more in store for viewers. Even amidst rumors of cast departures, story changes, and ownership lawsuits, AMC increased the season order from 13 episodes to 16.
item.content:encoded:
On the heels of an episode marathon and a mid-season premiere, fans of The Walking Dead have even more to look forward to other than the rest of the season. As we mentioned a few months ago, the show was able to pick up a third season. Since then we’ve learned that AMC has a little more in store for viewers. Even amidst rumors of cast departures, story changes, and ownership lawsuits, AMC increased the season order from 13 episodes to 16. This is good news for an hour long drama that has nothing but increase its episode order every season (6, 13, 16 respectively). In a time where shows are approaching and sticking to the 13 episodes mark it is good to see in a genre show.

Are we going to see the tale of the soldier in the tank that Rick ran into during season 1? Are the writers going to try and line up the series to be more like the comic? Will we see the rumored web series have new life in the extended episodes? We can all wonder, but in the end it’ll come back to the road of survival. I’m certainly not going to argue against seeing more of this great show. If we get more episodes like last night, we could just see a 20 episode order for a season four. Check out the summary below.

Source – AMC

item.title: Blizzard to Release Boardgames with USAopoly
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: It seems that Blizzard just hasn’t done enough to change MMOs or video games as we know it. I guess they felt the need to topple the tabletop industry with a makeover for some of our most beloved games. Getting their first play through at the New York Toy Fair Blizzard is bringing to life Monopoly: World of Warcraft and Risk: Starcraft in a venture with USAopoly.
item.content:encoded:
It seems that Blizzard just hasn’t done enough to change MMOs or video games as we know it. I guess they felt the need to topple the tabletop industry with a makeover for some of our most beloved games. Getting their first play through at the New York Toy Fair Blizzard is bringing to life Monopoly: World of Warcraft and Risk: Starcraft in a venture with USAopoly. Supposedly these are a “fresh takes on two classic board games” according to Blizzard’s press release. Both titles bring the worlds to players’ hands from properties renamed in lieu of Warcraft zones or bringing Protoss, Terran, and Zerg players to the battle front. Blizzard is even getting potential players involved with the production of the games by having them vote for the Monopoly player pieces via Facebook. Make sure to at least cast your vote for Murky here.

Remember that these aren’t the first Starcraft or World of Warcraft tabletop games we’ve seen either. They are the first to take the form of some of the classics though. What do you think? Is it bad enough that Blizzard is taking your $15 a month for WoW? Is it really necessary to retcon some of the staples in table gaming? I guess we’ll find out when they hit the shelves later this year.

Look forward to Monopoly: World of Warcraft to be released in May 2012 at price point of $39.95, while Risk: Starcraft will be out later this summer at $49.45.

Source – Battle.net

item.title: 20SON Recommendation – Battletech
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: About two weeks ago, we interviewed Jordan Weisman for the show. I made a flippant remark about how he was responsible for most of my gaming purchases over the years, and we all had a nice laugh about college funds. I thought about it a bit more. While I'm sure my personal contribution to the college fund was pennies rather than dollars, I do have a favorite game of his that I keep poking at year after year. We did allude to it in the podcast- I love me some Battletech.
item.content:encoded:
About two weeks ago, we interviewed Jordan Weisman for the show. I made a flippant remark about how he was responsible for most of my gaming purchases over the years, and we all had a nice laugh about college funds. I thought about it a bit more. While I’m sure my personal contribution to the college fund was pennies rather than dollars, I do have a favorite game of his that I keep poking at year after year. We did allude to it in the podcast- I love me some Battletech. Yeah, I like Mechwarrior and Mech Commander on various operating systems and consoles, but nothing really compares to some tabletop mech stomping destruction.

This is what $14.99 got you in 1984. Yeah, it was a long time ago.

I broke out my 1984 vintage Battledroids box set that I purchased as a teenager from a game store that still exists to this day. How times have changed. The box still had the rubber bases for the cardboard chits, a brief rulebook, some graphical representations of some lifted from anime stomping robots, and to a 14 year old brain, a world of possibilities. As a first iteration of the rules, the equipment sets were rudimentary yet well balanced between weight for construction, heat, and damage. In this day and age, the level of rules as presented then approaches the beer and pretzels threshold. Good balance, simple mech construction, and easy gameplay. The initial sets didn’t even have rules for buildings, cities, air cover, or other armored vehicles- those were entirely different boxed sets that arrived much later.

After an assortment of company closures, license swaps, and intellectual property purchases, about seven years ago Fanpro published Total Warfare- the modern equivalent of my decades old boxed set for the battle tech enthusiast. It assumed a certain level of rule familiarity as well as other publications in the purchaser’s hands for play, such as technical readouts with mech specifications. The rules, just the rules, and nothing but the rules, all in one tome. This one book covered the rules of warfare all the way from infantry up to aerospace units. Construction of all these units lives in the Technical Manual now, a discrete tome for the customizer and totally optional. If you’re so inclined, a free cross platform design tool can be downloaded from the Solaris Skunk Werks page. Sure, there’s even more rules that have been introduced since Total Warfare was originally published, and there’s more construction options than presented in the Tech Manual, but that’s how the game industry works. The Battletech universe suffers less from game play upgrades than most other games, so the incremental changes over the years in other source books are both optional and not a problem to integrate.

Most importantly, my entire $14.99 purchase from 1984 is a free PDF now modernized for the 21st century. To entice you into the world Catalyst Game Systems, the current license holder, has a starter download to get you up to speed with the universe and basic game play. If you’re accustomed to the Mechwarrior computer games the universe is familiar, but game play is a bit different by nature of the media change. Plus the price is right. For the big price of free, you get the details on how to play the game, a handful of mech specs, a few tanks, and some infantry. More of a role-player? They’ve got a basic free PDF for that too.

The next year or so will see a resurgence of the battlemech on consoles and the PC. There’s a Mechwarrior title coming out for the iOS and a Mechwarrior free to play game due shortly. I alluded to a free Mechwarrior 4 release in a review the other day. That’s a fantastic game too, if a bit dated by modern standards. You owe it to yourself to see where all this started. Even if you don’t buy the rulebooks, download the PDFs, grab a couple of buddies and play.

item.title: 20SON Review – Dungeons of Dredmor and The Realm of the Diggle Gods
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Lately Dungeons of Dredmor by Gaslamp Games has grabbed my attention. Gameplay is decidedly old school. The graphics and game mechanics are in a similar vein. I know I can make the time to enjoy a Roguelike dungeon crawler, but should you?
item.content:encoded:
I seem to be attracted to titles that rekindle an old interest. First, there was Ascendancy. Next came a slew of other remakes and re-imaginings for various operating systems including the free release of Mechwarrior 4. Lately, though, Dungeons of Dredmor by Gaslamp Games has grabbed my attention. Gameplay is decidedly old school. The graphics and game mechanics are in a similar vein. I know I can make the time to enjoy a Roguelike dungeon crawler, but should you?

The term Roguelike has been coined to describe a genre of games that are typically turn based with a text-based graphical interface. They are a throwback to the single digit megahertz days where graphics took an exacting toll on game performance and the mechanics of the game were primary over presentation. It can be argued that the original Dungeons and Dragons gold box games drew inspiration from early Roguelikes. Dungeons of Dredmor is certainly a roguelike- it has most of the characteristics; randomized dungeons, an assortment of items (some random in nature) and turn based gameplay. It does eschew the ASCII based presentation for a whimsical graphical display, but that’s not a strike against it.

In roguelike death is death. Don't take it too seriously.

If you’re not familiar with a dungeon crawl, the basic formula is simple. Generate a character by whatever means the game allows, saddle up and smash some bad guys. Collect, craft, or buy better gear as you descend into the depths and sell the crap to further finance the expedition. Dredmor takes the skills as attributes method of character development. Basically, whatever seven skills you pick from the pool determine your starting attributes. A subset of calculated attributes based off the primary attributes are calculated from there. I’m going to brace you for the cold hard truth. Even if you’re a veteran of the roguelike battlefield you’re going to die a lot. In most roguelikes, death is permanent. If your character dies, that’s it. Dredmor’s default setting is perma-death, as having retrievable game saves is generally considered cheating in this genre. There is mercifully a check box to allow game saves to be used, which I consider a great addition in games like this for the more casual berserker types like yours truly.

Combat is, well, roguelike. You take your shot, then everybody who can take a shot at you takes theirs. Anyone familiar with traditional RPGs should know this concept. There are three general classes of weapons- melee, ranged, and thrown. Melee weapons have traditional breakdowns like mace, staff, sword, and axe. Ranged weapons are in the form of an equippable crossbow and bolts, some with area effects or other special attacks. Thrown weapons range from softballs, through bolas, up to grenades and other area affect weapons.  There are no specific class prohibitions per se on any class of weapons. What you wield is chosen by the skill set you select during character creation. Want a sword swinging Gandalf mage? Fine. Rather play a vampiric duel axe wielding Viking? That’s fine too. Your approach to combat will vary depending on what you want to play.

It gets a little crazy in Dredmor.

All was not well during my (admittedly continuing) playtime with Dredmor. My initial purchase of the game was with an Indie Bundle and all was going fairly well. A patch came out, and all of a sudden, save games didn’t seem to function by hard crashing the game on load. This was fixed and seems to be limited to players on OSX Lion. The smaller population of users inflicted by this is makes it not a large, all encompassing bug by any means. I’ve had a periodic random crash but since I’m not playing on perma-death mode, that doesn’t bother me a lot. Gaslamp Games has issued a fair amount of bug fixes and promise more content in the future.

Okay, here’s the bottom line. If you hate turn based games, and just can’t play them, then Dungeons of Dredmor isn’t for you. Everybody else can and should play this well crafted humorous take on the rogue like genre. Dredmor’s regular price is $4.99 on Steam. There is also an expansion that adds more monsters, items, and generally more content for another $2.99. I consider both the main title and the expansion to be what you want to purchase here and it’s the state I reviewed the game. The combination costs all of $7.98 combined when not on sale. We’ve all spent a lot more for a lot less, movie tickets, large creme drinks at Starbucks, or what have you. The dollar to hour of entertainment equation weighs heavily towards Dredmor rather than you keeping your paltry stack of cash, so go buy it now!

Both the title and expansion were purchased by the reviewer.

item.title: Terry O’Quinn Headed to TNT’s Falling Skies
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Reports are coming in that Terry O'Quinn has been cast In TNT's Falling Skies in the role of a history professor and mentor to Tom Mason, as portrayed by Noah Wylie.
item.content:encoded:
You may not know his name, but I bet you know his face. He’s played Admirals both Starfleet and U.S. Navy, Generals, Colonels, and Majors. He’s currently portraying a Lieutenant Commander ex-Navy Seal on Hawaii Five-0. Perhaps his most popular role in the genre is John Locke on Lost. Moving back to our genre, Entertainment Weekly reports Terry O’Quinn has been cast in the role of a history professor and mentor to Tom Mason, as portrayed by Noah Wylie.

Did you miss Falling Skies? In a unique spin on the genre, Falling Skies portrays an American resistance against an alien invasion which is all but complete. Humanity survives on it’s wits alone and scavenges to survive. The end of the first season series ended with a miracle RPG shot fired by Tom Mason, disabling part of a alien base from much farther away than I thought possible. On the way back to the base after the miracle BB, Mason ends up voluntarily leaving the resistance and flying off with the aliens at their “invitation”.

It’s not clear yet what specifically O’Quinn’s character’s role is on the second season of Falling Skies beyond “mentor”. Time will tell, as Falling Skies’ second season debuts sometime this summer.

Source – Entertainment Weekly

item.title: Kinect Star Wars Bundle and Game to be Released April 3rd
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Missed out on the R2D2 edition of the Motorola Droid 2 a few years back? Have you been drooling for another piece of boxy, technological modeled after the world’s favorite astromech droid (or his copper counterpart)? Maybe you just need another special edition console to go along with your Halo Reach, Gears of War 3, and Modern Warfare 3 Xboxes? Whatever the reason is be prepared to force sprint to your favorite retailer to shell out $449.99 for the new Kinect Star Wars Bundle.
item.content:encoded:
Missed out on the R2D2 edition of the Motorola Droid 2 a few years back? Have you been drooling for another piece of boxy, technological modeled after the world’s favorite astromech droid (or his copper counterpart)? Maybe you just need another special edition console to go along with your Halo Reach, Gears of War 3, and Modern Warfare 3 Xboxes? Whatever the reason is be prepared to force sprint to your favorite retailer to shell out $449.99 for the new Kinect Star Wars Bundle. When you might ask? It appears that Xbox Live’s Major Nelson let the proverbial bantha out of the bag today. The console and Kinect Star Wars will be dropping from hyperspace to arrive on shelves on April 3, 2012.

A few breadcrumbs of new information about Kinect Star Wars were also detailed in the release. Are they something to get really excited about? I’ll let you be the judge of the list below:

With five dynamic modes – Jedi Destiny: Dark Side Rising, Podracing, Rancor Rampage, Galactic Dance Off and Duels of Fate – Kinect Star Wars makes it possible for Star Wars fans of all ages to delve into immersive Star Wars experiences. In addition to the previously announced Jedi, Podracing and Rancor modes, Xbox 360 and LucasArts have today unveiled new additions to the game, including:

  • New experiences within Jedi Destiny Mode, including:
    • Space battles: As you travel the Galaxy to face an evil that threatens to undermine the fabric of the Republic, you’ll engage with forces of the Empire in intense space battles
    • Speeder Bikes and Landspeeders: Pilot iconic Speeder Bikes and Landspeeders on your epic journey.
    • New duels: Battle opponents like Count Dooku and Darth Vader on your journey to become a Jedi.
  • New Duels of Fate mode, a battle-by-battle experience to sharpen your Jedi skills against the Dark Side.
  • New Galactic Dance Off mode loaded with Star Wars-themed pop tunes where those still honing their Jedi skills can take a break to battle Darth Vader on the dance floor or bust a move “Solo style.” (Note: Buyers of the special console will have the ability to play C-3PO in this mode.)

Do you think this is promising to shape up to be a must have for Star Wars and Xbox fans alike? Is this another cash grab by LucasArts? Was the dance mode really necessary? Why didn’t they throw in a Cantina Band mode as well? I know I won’t personally be buying it as one special edition is enough for this household. Will you?

Sources – Major Nelson/Xbox.com

item.title: Hawken Beta and Release Dates Announced
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: It’s been some time since I have checked on the fast paced, mech fighter Hawken. It appears some very welcome news has given us something to look forward to with the Unreal powered game.
item.content:encoded:
It’s been some time since I have checked on the fast paced, mech fighter Hawken. It appears some very welcome news has given us something to look forward to with the Unreal powered game. Sign-ups for the closed beta have finally opened up for participants! If the trailers have inspired you, it would be wise to submit your intent to play as soon as possible. As it stands right now, Hawken is advising possible players to invite friends in order to reserve your chosen callsign before the actual launch. According to an e-mail received after signup:

PILOTS WANTED.

Congratulations, Soldier.
You have elected to take part in the Hawken closed beta.
Enlist three friends by sharing the link below and we’ll reserve your callsign before training begins.

You are free to fight 12.12.12.

Not only have beta signups started for Hawken, but two greatly important pieces of information have been released as well. First, the announcement has been made that the game is going to go into the free-to-play model. A wise move on the part of Adhesive Games, as that is becoming the go to model for online games these days. The second is perhaps the biggest announcement of all, a release date. Slated for 12/12/12, the game is looking to make an impact before the end of the year.

Could 2012 be the return of the mech? Need some video to remind you why? I can accommodate.

Source – Hawken website

item.title: EverQuest Goes Free-to-Play in March 2012!
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: In an announcement that brought out the inner school girl in me, Sony Online Entertainment announced today that the ageless MMO EverQuest will be headed to free-to-play status in March. Calling for current players to look ahead in the next step of online play, as well as sounding the trumpets to players of yore, SOE looks to inject life into older world of Norrath.
item.content:encoded:
In an announcement that brought out the inner school girl in me, Sony Online Entertainment announced today that the ageless MMO EverQuest will be headed to free-to-play status in March. Calling for current players to look ahead in the next step of online play, as well as sounding the trumpets to players of yore, SOE looks to inject life into older world of Norrath. What makes this announcement even more special is that it will be going free-to-play in the month that marks its 13th year running. Think about that number for a moment, 13. That is a staggering number for any game, especially considering that it was one of the founding games to truly craft what we know as massive multiplayer.

Taking on many of the traits that its sibling EverQuest 2 took on, EverQuest is headed towards a tiered system of play options. While still paying $15 a month will grant you everything you had in the game before, playing for free will limit you to fewer options. You’ll be limited in character slots, available classes and races, spell tiers and others playing factors. I highly doubt my Iksar Beastlord will be one of the character races and classes that will be available as free on launch. However, the one thing that won’t be restricted is content. Players can elect to pay the $5 upgrade fee to silver in order to bump up various things. Older raiders will laugh that silver only bumps you to 1000 alternate advancement points.

EverQuest producer Tom “Phathom” Terrazas had some kind words about the upcoming changes. “Free-To-Play is the best fit for EverQuest and we are looking forward to supporting the game and our dedicated fans for years to come. This is a great year for everyone associated with EverQuest and SOE. We think you’ll be pleasantly surprised at what’s coming in 2012.”

Now if you’ll excuse me, I think I need to change my pants.

Source – Everquest.com

item.title: 20SON Food Review – Burger King Delivery
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: I’m in an interesting time in my life where my regular food avenues aren’t routinely available. Right now, I’ve got a nice microwave, a small hotplate, and that’s about all. Not up to exactly Iron Chef or Top Chef spec.... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
I’m in an interesting time in my life where my regular food avenues aren’t routinely available. Right now, I’ve got a nice microwave, a small hotplate, and that’s about all. Not up to exactly Iron Chef or Top Chef spec. There are routine and decent food delivery options available to me, but they run out of appeal after a while. No matter how good, the same options day in and day out just aren’t appetizing after a while. While working, in the background I heard an ad for Burger King delivery on ye olde television. So, I thought I’d give it a shot.

14:07 : Found the website. Minimalistic design, but functional. Took a minute to figure out how to not get tomatoes on my sandwich, but after locating the “customize your order” button the process was simple. Nothing a bigger checkbox wouldn’t fix. The service requires an $8 minimum order, and adds a $2 delivery fee. Have you seen fast food prices lately? It takes very little effort to get to $8 so this isn’t an issue.

14:11 : Decided to write this review. Hit submit on a custom Whopper, fries, 20 oz coca-cola product, and a pie of some sort. Got an email immediately confirming my order. Estimated time of delivery read “ASAP” which was a bit troubling, but I thought I’d ride it out.

Now here’s where it goes to crap.

15:02 : No order. Called the convenient 800-adjacent number to wonder what the deal was. Got put on hold for about 20 seconds before speaking with a human.

15:05 : Finished conversation with “Michael”, the handy operator at BKdelivers.com. He said he’d call the store and somebody would be in touch on the phone in a few minutes. No call arrived. However…

15:22 : Food arrives. The food wasn’t in quite the same Burger King containers, but rather in cardboard for the fried products with adequate venting to prevent steam from making the food soggy. Nice touch. The whopper itself was in a styrofoam container vaguely reminiscent of the intentions McDLT container of old- you know, “keeps the hot side hot, the cold side cold”. The meat and bottom bun were in one pocket, and the vegetables, topping, and top bun were in their own compartment of the same container. The lettuce was fast-food fresh and amazingly still crisp. I would have been more pleased with the temperature of the food if it wasn’t apparent that the food was only made after my call fifteen minutes prior, but it beats the food being an hour old and showing up late, so that’s kind of a wash.

71 minutes from order to delivery. I’m not super-pleased about that, but the service is only in testing and in limited areas. It was also pretty clear that the call from corporate to the store preparing the order shook the order loose, and got it to me within 20 minutes of making the “where’s my food” call. With time, I’d like to see the delivery time at 30-45 minutes, and that’s what the phone operator said the normal delivery time was. A quick internet search has revealed that people in my area are experiencing about hour-long delivery times, so my experience wasn’t out of the ordinary by any stretch.

If you’ve got to have a Whopper and can’t get out, then the delivery service or something like it is the only game in town. Right now, it’s hard for me to recommend it without qualifications unless you’re okay with waiting an hour for your food to arrive

item.title: 20SON Review – Oh No…Zombies! (Tabletop)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Did your family embrace your geek side this holiday season, but didn’t know what to get you? Instead did they give you some gift cards or a certificate for our favorite online retailers? If they didn’t give you enough for a fancy Star Wars product or if canned unicorn meat doesn’t look all that appealing to you, I might be able to help you out. Do you like board games? How do you feel about zombies? What if I told you that there is a board game out there that pairs the two of those together in one fun, cheap package? It sounds great, right? Let me tell you about Oh No…Zombies! then.
item.content:encoded:
Did your family embrace your geek side this holiday season, but didn’t know what to get you? Instead did they give you some gift cards or a certificate for our favorite online retailers? If they didn’t give you enough for a fancy Star Wars product or if canned unicorn meat doesn’t look all that appealing to you, I might be able to help you out. Do you like board games? How do you feel about zombies? What if I told you that there is a board game out there that pairs the two of those together in one fun, cheap package? It sounds great, right? Let me tell you about Oh No…Zombies! then.

The board is pretty easy to setup for Oh No…Zombies! Everything is marked to make the game start off with little time wasted setting up complicated scenery or units.

As with most things in zombie filled situations, the object of Oh No…Zombies! is to stay alive. Imagine that you and your friends are trapped in a small shack with no way to reach help because your radio lacks battery power. There are four stores in the area that would most likely have what you need. Going outside of the cabin presents a small problem. Your disheveled hovel is surrounded by a graveyard that just happens to be full of the risen undead. I don’t think anyone knows how they got there. Everyone has to admit that it is a pretty bad situation. Someone must venture out to get the batteries otherwise you’ll surely perish once the zombies figure out how to get inside. Two to four players will have the pleasure of maneuvering across the field of the dead. Hopefully you will make it back without being bitten. How complicated could that be?

In typical undead uprising fashion, you and your friends have found yourselves trapped in a shed with no way of contacting help. Why would you need help? Because the shed is in a graveyard of course!

It turns out it really isn’t that hard. Zombies is quite possibly the easiest game I’ve played in a tabletop setting. Obviously there are more mechanics to it than Don’t Break the Ice or Operation, but this isn’t a kiddy game folks. Though, I can certainly see my daughter being able to grasp the concept. In the box you’ll find three dice, six zombie figures, eight player figures (four human and four zombies), game board, weapon and battery cards and a stack of action cards to draw from when players encounter a zombie. Playing the game is actually pretty simple. The player whose turn it is rolls one of the dice (all are D6s) to determine how far they will move. Whoever the player is to their immediate right rolls the other normal die, plus the six-sided die with shades of green squares on all sides. The idea here is to determine which zombies will move on that turn. Zombies get turns after every player turn, but only the shade of undead that match the rolling result. As a way to keep players from playing favoritism towards their own piece, zombies must move towards the closest player at all times. It is a mob mentality after all. This just supports what people commonly think of how zombies will act.

These rolls keep playing out through the course of the game. There is only one action that supersedes movement rolls, and that is fighting. If a player or a zombie ever comes to occupy the same square on the board, combat must take place to resolve it. This could be in the middle of your movement or even at the start of a zombie’s. Combat is resolved in one of two fashions. The first is through the drawing of action cards that will determine the outcome. Sometimes the humans will be able to run away, sometimes they can kill a zombie, but they also risk the chance of becoming a zombie themselves. From playing, it does seem like there are more opportunities to get away than turning into a creature from beyond, but remember it is chance. The cards do have a wry sense of humor that makes the end result comical no matter the result. During one turn I was able to kill a zombie by kicking it. I thought that was pretty entertaining.

The cards can play as terrible outcomes or humorous getaways. Who knew you could kick a zombie dead?

A second option in getting away presents itself with the weapons scattered around the game board. Whenever you land on one of the spaces you occupy, you can pick the weapon up to use against a zombie should combat arise. Shovels,cricket bats and torches can be used one time to dispatch your brain hungry attacker in order to run away. Once used, they return to the board to have the chance to be used again. There is a more exclusive weapon, the coveted zombie slayer itself- the shotgun. If you were lucky enough to enter a store with batteries, a shotgun lies in wait. Be careful how you use it though. Once used it does not return to the board. You only get one shot to fire.

Getting to the store is only half the battle! Good thing for this player, the batteries and a well needed shotgun were inside.

If you do get turned by undead it doesn’t mean that you are out of the game. Being undead does have its perks in Oh No. After being nommed on, the player can replace their human player piece with the zombie piece of the same color. You retain your turn without interfering with the existing zombie turns, but with a slight difference. You are now out to eat the other players. The rules for moving a zombie are the same as when you started- you must move towards the closest player going to battle whenever you make contact. The great thing about being turned is you can still win the game as an undead player. All you need to do is be the actual zombie that eats the last man standing (sorry ladies, all the figures are men). Otherwise winning is just done by getting back to the shed with the batteries. Though, an interesting mechanic in that is you must roll exactly the number of spaces to get back in. None of this rolling over stuff.

This player was able to win with ease as the zombies were busy shambling after another player that had managed to find one of the stores.

For all the good in the game, there were a few bad things about it. In the copy that was provided to me, the playing board was severely warped. I don’t know if this was because of shipping or manufacturing, but the first few games did see some zombies falling over. It can be fixed though, so it isn’t a game breaking matter. The biggest issue of all was how quick the games could be. Depending on how you see this, this could be considered a win. Tabletop games to me are part of a greater culture that has people gather at the table, entertaining each other with the game being the tie that binds. While it does accomplish that, it doesn’t do so for long. Our first run was literally only a few minutes long. That brings me to the next point as well. Much like Steve Jackson Games’ Cthulhu Dice, it is possible that there is no winner at the end of Oh No…Zombies!. The original zombies can just chomp on everyone and simply end the game. You do have to balance odds you face when considering number of foes. I guess that could be a good reason for it to end fast.

As you can see the board was clearly warped. Sad thing is, as it came out of the box like this, the other side had a mirrored flaw as well.

Oh No…Zombies! is a game was will be easy for anyone to get into. If zombies were actually a “thing” that I could keep from gnawing at my skull for a short duration, I’m pretty sure that they would be able to play. I really won’t like to be the one to test the theory, but you get the idea. It might be a little offensive to them, but they are fictional so who cares. Come to think of it, is the politically correct term for zombies “life impaired?” At any rate, given a cost of $21.99 it isn’t that bad when considering how fun it is. The simple play and short list of rules will make it a game that anyone can get into. However, I do feel like the shortness of each played game will subtract some of that value for most players. Knocking $5.00 off the price would put it in a better range for most people to respond to. Though, you have to consider this isn’t a game you can exactly walk down to your local big box store and snag up either. There is usually nerd luxury taxes applied to these sorts of things. Oh No…Zombies! is worth that little extra cost of admission. Especially if players are looking for something that everyone can enjoy.

Game provided by Thinkgeek.

item.title: 20SON Review – Skydrift (PC)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: As gamers, sometimes we just want something to kick back with that doesn’t involve tedious strategy or the competition of shooters. Every now and then we need something that allows us to cool off, but still be entertained. For some it could be a simple puzzle game like Bejeweled. Others will kick back and hit some flash games to pass a few minutes. What do I like to do when I get to that point? I love to throw in a racing game. Something about them clears my mind and brings on a sense of calm. Plus, who doesn’t love a good looking car? Generally I’ll stick to a car racing game of sorts, but recently Digital Reality put out an interesting title that I thought was just different enough. Swap cars for planes. Race others around on tracks. Blow up the competition if they get in your way. Add those up and you get SkyDrift.
item.content:encoded:
As gamers, sometimes we just want something to kick back with that doesn’t involve tedious strategy or the competition of shooters. Every now and then we need something that allows us to cool off, but still be entertained. For some it could be a simple puzzle game like Bejeweled. Others will kick back and hit some flash games to pass a few minutes. What do I like to do when I get to that point? I love to throw in a racing game. Something about them clears my mind and brings on a sense of calm. Plus, who doesn’t love a good looking car? Generally I’ll stick to a car racing game of sorts, but recently Digital Reality put out an interesting title that I thought was just different enough. Swap cars for planes. Race others around on tracks. Blow up the competition if they get in your way. Add those up and you get SkyDrift.

For those of you thinking that SkyDrift is nothing more than a racing/exploding airplane game, I have some news for you. It’s a little more than that. With three racing modes (speed, elimination and power) in single player, each stage you play gives you a little variety in what you need to pole at in order to move on to the next. In speed mode, rings are placed in sequences around the track that you need to use to maximize your speed. Elimination puts you at odds with others around you as when the timer reaches zero the last place flyer meets an unfortunate end. Power gives you the guts of the game. You get to fly over power ups, defensive and offensive, in order to dogfight your way to first place. Think of it as a more grown up version of tossing turtle shells at others in Mario Kart. Another interesting piece is that there are eight planes to race with that you unlock as you progress. Each has a different strength or weakness be it the ability to fend off more gunfire, hit higher top speeds or have gross power in the afterburner department.

Speed is key in all aspects of SkyDrift. The real fun of controlling a plane begins when you go super sonic.

SkyDrift really hit a sweet sport for me when it came to presentation. I don’t know what it is, but I have always loved racing games that have an arcade feel. Be it the SEGA games of old like Daytona USA or even the mass of Crusin’ games, the look and feel made me take them in non-serious manners. For this style of game it is a great mindset to have. It is quick to jump into and easy to play. The graphics are slightly cartoony and shiny, but create unique takes on what you’d expect to see in reality. The planes in SkyDrift are a great example of this with their outlandish paint jobs and multiple wing layouts. Some planes even have both jet propulsion and propellers. The great part about SkyDrift is that it keeps you pumping as you pull through the twists and pulls with your plane of choice. It really reminds me of how Moto Racer felt for me as a kid. I don’t even remember the hours I logged in that game. You know, minus shooting rockets at other racers.

Stunts are also another important part of your success. As you complete more skills such as overtaking, drifting or hugging the ground, your meter for speed boosting energy grows.

There were some problems with the game that were hard for me get over at first. Mostly, the default keyboard controls bothered me quite a bit. The Xbox 360 origins of the title are clearly there so if you do have a wired Xbox controller, it will allow you to use it. I highly recommend that you go the controller method. While it is perfectly possible to play that game with just the keyboard, trying to navigate with tighter turns and maintaining basic controls while maneuvering while using boost is troublesome at best. Invisible walls don’t help either. If you turn late and try to roll to the sky in order to keep off the walls, you are promptly shoved back into the “track.” This generally results in a crash anyway as you were still trying to fly out of it in the first place. Then there is the length and re-playability of the game. While I can personally get miles out of a title like this, the average gamer will dump it after finishing the campaign. After 33 races, I can see that being a stopping point since the play is rather repetitive.

Trying to play multiplayer matches turned up a lot of situations like this. People that want to try it out, but end up leaving their computer after being frustrated by the wait.

That isn’t to say there isn’t a few more options for the game. Multiplayer is available to pit you against other wannabe pilots. Problem is, you really can’t tell the difference than if you were playing the single player racers. Without a new experience players are left shrugging off the multiplayer. Creating a situation where you potentially burn out your gaming audience before even getting to the player versus player battles leaves the queues empty. However, there were two DLC packs put out to help ease the problem. The first, the Gladiator Pack, introduced deathmatch and team deathmatch modes into the multiplayer. With this, six new arenas were introduced to go head to head with your sky ace rivals. They are off course based off of the existing maps in the game, as is standard for multiplayer spaces these days. It is worth noting that these modes are only available in multiplayer. Digital Reality did wise up a bit and give players a reason to step back into the head to head portion. The second pack dubbed the Extreme Fighters Pack, added three new planes that are unlocked to use in any race. The Vanguard, Sparrow X1, and Triwing Vintage are actually some of the more fun planes to race with, so kudos to the developer for putting those out.

The Extreme Fighters DLC added easily the most enjoyable planes to pilot. Now if they would have included a tower to buzz…

When you take stock of all the time you spend in the skies, you’ll look at it in a very polarizing manner. Either you will have fun just racing around and chasing down other planes, or you’ll curse the game for being so simple and short. The perk of the PC version of the game in that regard is the price tag. At a cost of $9.99 ($6.69 on Steam currently) vs. 1200 MS points, the sting can be reduced a bit if you purchase it on Steam rather than Xbox Live. The player will have to determine if the cost savings is actually worth it though. Personally while I prefer most things on PC, the lack of players on Steam in multi modes is a huge issue. I acknowledge that it is a problem of the platform. The DLC prices are low ($2.99 vs 400MS points for the Gladiator Pack and $1.49 vs 160 MS points for the Fighter Pack), but if you aren’t going to be able to play with others purchasing one of those doesn’t make a whole lot of sense. Giving a recommendation on this title is a rather touchy thing to do. My gut says to bite the bullet as I had a lot of fun with SkyDrift. It looks great and didn’t give me one bit of trouble ever being able to just jump into it. If you like a simple, fast paced racer that gives you the bonus of mowing down your fellow flyers, you will love every minute of it. If not, I hear there is a major American pizza chain that will sell you a pie for as much as you’ll spend here.

item.title: 20SON Review – Playback for OSX
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Without add on software, Mac OSX users were out of luck streaming media to the xBox or DLNA devices. Yazsoft has a solution for this dilemma in Playback.
item.content:encoded:
In recent years, video streaming in the home has become a bit easier. Not all that long ago it was a mishmash of applications, transcoders, and frustration. There have been a few products and software packages to facilitate watching video on assorted and sundry home devices, AppleTV, Roku, GoogleTV, Stream To Me, and Airplay just to name a few. Some out of the box solutions are available as well, such as Windows Media Server to the xBox 360 or other DLNA devices. Without add on software, Mac OSX users were out of luck streaming media to the xBox or DLNA devices. Yazsoft has a solution for this dilemma in Playback.

Playback is a small, lightweight application that runs quietly in the background. If you’re sharing the videos that lurk in your iTunes library, it’s two-click simplicity. Alternatively, if you’d rather share a folder of videos, photos, or music, that’s pretty simple too. Click once to enable this feature, then navigate to the folders in question using standard OSX GUI conventions. Simple. Any DRM restricted files won’t play using Playback, naturally. That’s not a limitation of the software, but rather the industry as a whole.

As you can see, Playback offers a straight forward user interface that anyone looking to stream videos at this level should understand.

All of the heavy lifting is done underneath the hood. It doesn’t really do any transcoding. Instead Playback repackages existing video without transcoding so it’s compatible and quickly available to the device that it’s going to be played on. As such, there are periodic compatibility issues. For instance, movies with a file size of over 4 gigabytes in size won’t play on the xBox 360 because of a 32 bit storage address limitation on the console. Nor will H.264 video work with any other audio selection that isn’t simple stereo. Simply, 5.1 and 7.1 audio mixes aren’t supported by the uPnP H.264 video playback codec on the xBox 360. I’m not sure there’s a technical reason for this, but rather apathy. The Microsoft xBox codec available on xBox Live hasn’t been updated since 2007. I can think of no reason why the codec shouldn’t technically support it as the xBox itself supports surround sound in hardware. In fact, videos in the marketplace can be purchased that have 5.1 and 7.1 mixes. Neither the file size nor the audio mix limitations apply to other DLNA devices that we were able to test such as the Playstation 3.

Most of the options you should need for a home theatre situation should be covered for streaming options.

Playback does one thing and it does it well. Any limitations to the software are more a function of the playback hardware rather than the software. What you serve to your DLNA device using Playback effectively depends on what hardware you’re using to display it with. This even extends to whether or not you’re willing to transcode video that doesn’t comply using Handbrake or other such tool. At $15, it’s a decent deal if you need the functionality. It is the right tool for the right job after all. At press time, Yazsoft has two promotions running- if you just buy Playback, you get two other utilities free. Alternatively, they have a December Megabundle sale running where you get multiple licenses for just about all of their software for use or for gifting including the very useful Sharetool 2. If you’re using a Playstation 3 or other device listed on the Yazsoft compatibility list other than the xBox 360, it’ll handle just about anything you want to toss at it smoothly. Large files, or files with surround audio, don’t stream will to the xBox 360. Again, that’s not the fault of the software. If you stick with using .AVI files on a xBox 360, then you’re set.

Application provided by developer.
