item.title: 20SON Review – SYBA SD-SATA2-2E2I PCI Card
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Syba has a PCI (not -X or -E) card called the SD-SATA2-2E2I. Positioned as a budget card, is it a wise purchase or should you spend the $35 or so on a newer machine?
item.content:encoded:
While old PCs don’t have feelings of despair when they are replaced by newer gear, even machines nearly a decade old can have some utility. Sometimes, there’s issues with the chipsets, only allowing 128 gig or smaller drives (LBA48 compliance). Other times, even with LBA48 support, only Parallel ATA drives can be installed natively. At first glance, this may be a deal breaker for resuscitating older hardware. This doesn’t have to be the case. Syba has a PCI (not -X or -E) card called the SD-SATA2-2E2I. Positioned as a budget card, is it a wise purchase or should you spend the $35 or so on a newer machine?

SATA is the (current) wave of the future as the replacement for PATA. If the benefits were just limited to fewer individual conductors per cable, much higher peak data rates, and reduced cost SATA would be the clear choice. With the addition of the E-SATA (External Serial ATA) protocol, overall the SATA protocol is plainly superior to even casual observers. The 2E2I card has two internal SATA ports, as well as two E-SATA ports, allowing for ease of both internal and external applications. When utilizing an older piece of hardware, this allows for two large capacity internal drives as well as some RAID cases, allowing a truly tremendous amount of drives to be added for applications like a home media or backup server.

The 2E2I in all its unboxed glory. Were you expecting much else for a SATA card?

We ran some tests on the 2E2I card on newer and legacy hardware to determine it’s applicability for older hardware as well as some slightly newer equipment. A Pentium 4 2.4 gigahertz system running Windows XP was used for the older hardware. A Core 2 Quad 9550 system running under Windows Vista, OSX, and Gentoo Linux was also utilized for testing. This card isn’t intended for high-end utilization or RAID subsystems for speed, rather it seems positioned for inexpensive data warehousing. After a little bit of BIOS fiddling (specifically, setting the PCI clock rate for 33 MHz), the drives popped up immediately for formatting under Windows XP. Transfer speeds seemed limited to SATA I speeds and peaked at about 44 megabytes per second, rather than coming close to the advertised SATA II speeds. Windows XP will either migrate or be installed on a drive installed using the card as an interface, but won’t boot the OS. As I mentioned before, perfect for a data warehouse on an older machine

When the card was moved to the Windows Vista system, the card wasn’t immediately recognized by the operating system. After flashing the card to a newer firmware revision, the drives were spotted by the hardware wizard and installation completed normally. On the newer machine, speeds exceeded the SATA I max theoretical speed routinely, and came within 30% of the peak theoretical SATA II speeds in bursts. This suggests that the data transfer on the older system was either CPU or bus-limited. When two drives were installed in a striped RAID configuration (RAID 0), the transfer speeds didn’t increase, suggesting a bus speed data transfer limitation from the 33mhz vanilla PCI bus. It is important to note that if you have a PCI-X system, installing a vanilla PCI card will slow down the entire bus, which may be a problem depending on your hardware expansion needs. Both Vista and Linux machines booted from a clean install on a drive using the card as the interface. Migrated existing OS installs weren’t tested, but I see no reason why they wouldn’t work, given that the fresh OS install did.

There is no native support under OSX of any flavor for this card. The system profiler will see a card freshly installed, but have no idea what the card is. The 2E2I card is a 3124-2 Silicon Image chipset based card. It adheres to the reference design closely enough that the chipset manufacturer has OSX drivers available all the way back to server X.3.9 and client X.4. In theory, you can install this card in a 5 volt PCI G4 based machine like the Mirrored Drive Door or xServe G4 running X.4 or X.5. However, our rather limited testing lab has no fully functioning machines of that vintage to test and be certain of the results. OSX wouldn’t install on a drive installed through this card, and a migrated OSX install kernel panicked the machine. The vendor has no official support for this card in an OSX machine, so proceed at your own peril.

External SATA implementation is good. The card supports port multiplication, allowing for external RAID cases to be utilized with no issues. Hotswapping was tried with both single drive external cases, as well as RAID cases with four drives installed. Windows XP didn’t care for the hot swap very much. We saw a couple of blue screens of death, but importantly not every time. More so no data was lost. Windows Vista and Gentoo Linux did very well with the hot swap. Not surprisingly, since the OSX driver wasn’t written by the vendor, the test machine booted under OSX didn’t perform perfectly during the hot swap test. While the OS didn’t crash, both the RAID case and single drive refused to mount on the system after removal. Again, no data was lost. Following a reboot, both external drive cases mounted fine.

Note the tight clearance here. This is worst case, another case I had had very slight improvement over this.

From a physical standpoint, I did have two minor problems with the card. As shipped, the metal bracket wasn’t quite the right shape for either case I had to test it in. Some minor bending with a pair of needle nose pliers fixed the problem. More problematic was the location of the E-SATA ports- they were far too close to the edge of the card and there was some obstruction when inserting one particular E-SATA cable with a seemingly short plastic tab. Another cable I had with a slightly longer plastic tab was easier to insert and connection was made reliably. If the E-SATA ports were closer to the center of the card this wouldn’t have been an issue. Either of these issues aren’t show-stoppers. Frankly, if you’ve ever installed PCI cards before then this kind of manipulation probably isn’t that foreign.

The SYBA SATA2-2E2I shouldn’t be considered a replacement for a high end PCI-E card, or even onboard SATA2 ports. RAID performance isn’t fantastic, but is ideal for data storage or even a RAID 1 or 5 backup solution with or without parity. The retail price on this card is $54.99, but at the time of this writing, it’s available at Amazon.com for $39.99 and at Newegg for $52.99. We’re not Tom’s Hardware- we aren’t going to give you a hard number saying how fast or slow the card is- we review hardware the same way we review other products. Our reviews will tell you what the device is good for and what it isn’t. There are cheaper SATA cards available, but few with the Silicon Image chipset. This card won’t turn a five year old machine into an uncompressed video editing powerhouse, nor a speed demon. It’s fantastic for a media server for something like a Roku box or an AppleTV, redundant storage, or just packing a older machine with storage well in excess of what it was originally intended to hold for whatever purpose you may have.

Card provided by manufacturer.

item.title: 20SON Review – Defense Grid: You Monster (PC)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: As researcher for the GLaDOS development team, I would like to think that she was misunderstood. Thankfully after years on the shelf, the GLaDOS project received another chance. An order came from high up to transfer the project to Hidden Path Entertainment in order to aid their new development of Defense Grid: You Monster.
item.content:encoded:
==BEGIN TRANSMISSION==
————————————
TIME – 08:30 4137 AD
LOCATION – ABANDONED TESTING FACILITY UNDER WORLD XF3215
OPERATION – CODE NAME YOU MONSTER
AUTHOR – |REDACTED|
————————————

As a former employee of Aperture Science, I never understood the contempt that ex-test subjects had for our AI GLaDOS. There might have been a few flaws in her programming that lead to some unfortunate accidents, but what piece of software doesn’t have a few bugs to work out? As researcher for the GLaDOS development team, I would like to think that she was misunderstood. She knew that in order to push the limits of our volunteers, sacrifices had to be made. It just so happened that most of those “sacrifices” happened to be the test subjects. Sure they tried to tell us that “she was crazy” or that “it was trying to kill them,” but this is a high stress environment. The team came to the conclusion that it might merely have occurred because she was out of her intended element. Thankfully, the order came from high up to transfer the project to Hidden Path Entertainment to aid in the new wing of their Defense Grid initiative. After the unmitigated disaster of our last round with the AI, we were happy for another chance with Defense Grid: You Monster.

In typical GLaDOS fashion, sometimes the things that she throws at you are just not winnable.

Our parent company, Valve, leased GLaDOS out to be part of a new testing facility under Defense Grid simulator codenamed You Monster. As the old reliable AI, Entity, wasn’t providing enough challenge for the expectations of the shareholders, an outside team (my own) was brought aboard shortly after the project was launched. In fact it was a little awkward as we started to replace the existing team while a subject was in the middle of their testing run. Rather than let them know, we just kept on with our install and tried quietly to replace Entity with GLaDOS. For those who are not acquainted with the great strives that the team behind Defense Grid has accomplish, I’ll fill you in a little as to why their work was so important.

It just wouldn't be the same if GLaDOS wasn't there to insult you ever step of the way. Don't let her hurt your feelings.

Defense Grid is an initiative based on protecting assets to ward off offensive agents from XF3125. Originally developed as an entertainment simulator to the people of the 21st century, the idea of the game was to protect the last remaining resources of a war torn world from alien invasion. These remaining resources or power cores remained in order to power the grid, but were endangered from the invasion forces coming back to claim them. The player’s job was to build a series of towers to exterminate these forces as they came to steal the power cores. Towers like machine gun to lightly chip away at passing aliens or concussion grenades to damage and disorient. Through strategy and cunning, the tester is gradually inserted into an escalating scenario in which he or she will be able to fend off the masses by placement and firepower. The intelligence was as accurate as could be, which turned out a rather difficult setting. Due to the success of the game, it was looked into for viability in a military setting. It would be launched later as part of a long distance space reconnaissance mission and developed into a full-fledged defensive platform in 4092.

The AI will throw things at you at every turn. The new map designs make it a challenge to keep up with it all.

The best part of all of this is that GLaDOS fell right into place with the program. Her humor was a good way to ease the existing test candidate into the new simulations. That was of course until she started to take the testing rooms as more than just what they were meant to be. There was great pride in creating Aperture labs that shared the same aesthetics and textures again in the new facility. The thought behind it was to help to keep GLaDOS in a familiar environment as to not shellshock her with new surroundings. The team did however take an opportunity to improve upon the towers and test subject’s interface used in each mission, and in turn all of the older products in the Defense Grid catalog. The changes were subtitle, but helped create a more polished look. As the finishing touches took place on all the pieces, it looked right at home with the existing assets. Most importantly the unparalleled intelligence of GLaDOS offered an extraordinary new take on what it has in store for any volunteer that dares to step up to the challenge. To say she has a few surprises appears to be a gross understatement.

Graphics in the test chambers have been updated along with the aliens, but something looks very familiar about them..

I wonder if there were steps that could have taken to make the trial a tad less forceful of the endeavor overall. GLaDOS has a personality that takes some time to warm up to. In only eight different testing scenarios that scale upwards in difficulty, you not only get her heartwarming personality to interact with over the duration, but also her full intellectual might. The idea behind adding her to the simulation was to use clone commanders in specific situations to result in no actual loss of human life. However, all tests came to the same conclusion. It doesn’t matter if it is a clone or an actual person going up against the system, the play of the Defense Grid is exactly the same as it was before, only kicked up a few notches. Further testing would conclude that the level of difficultly would exceed what a clone could process therefore human subjects would have to remain. Comment cards indicated by the undamaged subjects that the testing did present itself as more tedious. To read the comments from one such card stated, “There was flair to the new facilities for You Monster, but in the end it was the same old thing. The only thing that added to the experience was that damn voice that kept trying to kill me. Seriously, why did you put me in a room with that thing?”

It seems that the testing might have gone a little to far at this stage.

From what I’ve witnessed in Defense Grid testing, it appears to have meshed very well with GLaDOS’ personality. While she still has some of the bugs to work out and presents some of the same personality issues that folks may consider “aggressive” or “borderline sadistic” I still think that she is undervalued. I will say that perhaps it may have been best if we had only made an add-on to the 21st century entertainment game to be sold to the general public. You Monster ideally would have been be released as a downloadable content (or DLC) addition I’m told. Something around $4.99 would have been an appropriate price considering the economic times. There did seem to be an abundance of these “tower defense” entertainment simulators, but the You Monster DLC would have only strengthened the value of the Defense Grid game. Sadly, I don’t know if we could have conveyed the complexities of what we’ve accomplished in this timeline. It may have been simply more of the same. Even worse, GLaDOS may not have lived up to her potential. Sure, GLaDOS might have accidentally included real aliens that might endanger the colony planet in the case that things weren’t handled properly. I just think it was a small oversight. Stop overreacting about it already.

In conclusion, it is my professional opinion that w…

—CORRUPTION IN DATA FILE DETECTED
—SWITCHING TO AUDIO LOG FOR CONLUSION—
—START PERSONAL AUDIO LOG DR. |REDACTED|—

————————————

Game was provided by developer for review. Audio file includes use of GLaDOS character as voiced by Ellen McLain. GLaDOS is property ofValve Software

item.title: MMO Developers, Take a Lesson from Trion
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Since release, Rift has had a strong grip on my household. However, there comes a time when players have to evaluate what the want to play. With Star Wars: The Old Republic coming out, we had such a decision. While the die was cast against Rift, there were a lot of the things Trion did right with it.
item.content:encoded:
Everywhere gamers turn there are different massively multiplayer games attempting to grab our attention and hold it. From the realms of free to play titles to the more costly pay per month models that we’ve been more accustomed to, with each new game comes a choice- either stand by your tried and true tested or give the new one catching your eye a chance. Sometimes the loser of the battle for time just has to be the game that you’ve put some significant effort into. It would be nice to play them all, but it just isn’t financially viable to do so in all cases. Recently for my household, the die of fate was cast bringing our time in Rift to a close in favor of the upcoming Star Wars: The Old Republic. Being the nerd that I am, there is a gravity well that surrounds anything Star Wars that just draws me in. I fell for it with Galaxies, but here I go again potentially repeating my mistake. With the bulk of my friends heading to the game, it makes it hard to say no. Rift made one hell of a case though.

Since March, Rift has had a strong grip on my household. Having tinkered with it at PAX 10 a bit, I didn’t walk away feeling that impressed. However, once my significant other started getting into the game, I started to notice just what was trying to be accomplished. It became a struggle for me to keep my distance from it as I was trying to stay away from another stint in an MMO. Rift managed to reel me in as I eventually succumbed to purchasing the collector’s edition. I even sprung for larger payment chunks instead of the month to month buy in that’s my normal modus operandi. Both of us would go on to inspire others to play with the tales of how fun the game was and the new experiences it brought. She would go on to level four characters to the level cap, with one achieving rank eight PvP level. I would meddle about playing all the classes, but never having the time to max any of them out. The urge to come back and play in spite of my other responsibilities kept me at the game even if it was only for an hour here or there.

To get to the point of all of this, Trion sold me on Rift from launch. What I didn’t intend to see was how they strove to create and keep new players in the crowded online scene. Out of the gate Rift had a strong PR push. It seemed like most places I would turn would have some sort of banner, background or ad promoting the game. It didn’t stop there either. In a move that would appeal to the WoW haters, TV ads were created calling out Azeroth. Little things here and there tried to keep the title on the tips of potential players’ tongues. Things only got bigger and bigger over time. Moving from free to play weekends, quick price drops, perks for inviting friends to play and even free trials pretty soon, it was clear that Trion was putting their faith behind the title. And for good reason. The content was there to support the title.

Getting the players there was only part of the game though. Keeping them there was a whole different thing entirely. Trion was pulling this off through the numerous events and content that it was providing. World events took place constantly that would add bonus quests and tasks for players to do. Specific rewards for each event would even help the casual player fill gaps that would usually take raiding to accomplish. Even better, content was being added to the game constantly for no additional fee. How many times can that be said for an MMO? Trion recognized that they had to compete not only with the big dogs, but also with the up and coming free to play games. Doling out everything they could, they reached over a million subscriptions. A significant portion of that was drawn from the biggest dog, World of Warcraft, if you are to believe what Trion claims as well as Blizzard’s quarterly reports. I think the biggest success of all for the company was their customer service. Triton has done everything they can to respect their player base and that will go far in this industry. When closing out accounts, I was greeted with an e-mail that I didn’t expect. For me the following this sums up just how far Trion is going to go to be stand up with their players:

“We’re sorry to see that you’ve recently canceled your RIFT subscription because you couldn’t find people to play with. We understand that RIFT is a social game, and that it’s more fun to have your friends there.

Please accept this complimentary thirty day game time code which you and 5 of your friends can use to check out our most recent update – RIFT 1.6: From the Embers.

[...]

We hope to see you and your friends in Telara soon!”

Even with this, I still have to wave goodbye to Telara. Fear not, because in reality I don’t think it will be the last time we’ll meet. Trion has done far too much to earn my respect with their outstanding dedication to making Rift perfect and respecting their players. Actions that the developer has taken to work with consumers, especially with things like the above e-mail, just go to show that building a brand is better than doing it for the money. That is certainly a rarity in this world. For now, despite my love for you, Rift, you should go out and meet other people. There are plenty of others out there that will like you for who you are. I have no doubt that you will continue to have a long, fruitful life. Don’t worry though, this isn’t goodbye for you and I- only see you later.

item.title: WitchBlade / Red Sonja Crossover to Hit Shelves February 2012
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Dynamite Entertainment and Top Cow Productions are teaming up in 2012 to bring forth a crossover that pairs two staples from their studios into one comic. Look forward to WitchBlade/Red Sonja #1 to be hitting your favorite comic outlet in February 2012.
item.content:encoded:
Dynamite Entertainment and Top Cow Productions are teaming up in 2012 to bring forth a crossover that pairs two staples from their studios into one comic. Look forward to WitchBlade/Red Sonja #1 to be hitting your favorite comic outlet in February 2012. With it comes the promise of something different that your typical cross over. Instead of combining two title characters to do nothing other than fight, writer Doug Wagner is bringing a more engrossing story to the book. The comic will instead put the two female leads together in a fight for humanity in their own ages, but connected over the vast difference in time. For either to fail could result in dire consequences for the entire world.

Wagner states, “There’s no time traveling, no merging of universes, no soul swapping, and no messages in a bottle. The first issue won’t have the two heroes fighting against each other until they figure out who the real villain is. If that’s what you’re here for, you’ve come to the wrong place. WitchBlade/Red Sonja #1 is the beginning of a grisly trial for both characters. Red Sonja and Sara Pezzini are about to plummet into despair and hopelessness, both physically and emotionally. Their beliefs and courage will be tested, and it will take more than just either heroine brandishing their fabled weapons to overcome this threat. Humanity as they know it is at risk. And if one fails, they both fail.”

It should be interesting to see how these two characters are brought together. Being from completely different eras of time, Sara Pezzini of modern times and Red Sonja of the Hyborian Age makes this an interesting crossover to put together. The promise to drive the characters to the dark side of emotion and physical torment does have an interesting feel. In an interview with Comicvine, Doug Wagner teases that they are fighting a common foe, but that each character is doing it in their own period in time. That gives a whole ‘nother layer of complexity that should be ripe for some good writing. Hopefully this crossover only helps draw attention to both characters in their respective comics if only to bring more attention to the content rather than their looks.

Source – Dynamite

item.title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes Actor Cashes In Big
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Never mind the fact that 20th Century Fox grossed $481 million dollars with a prequel of a film our generation probably didn’t find relevant. Instead, let’s look at what it took to bring in that cash- the stellar acting of a primate. Through his eyes, we saw the birth of a revolution and the fall of a civilization. Eyes that oddly enough, have a strange human quality to them. Not because of any script or digital manipulation, but because there was actually a man behind the ape. I’m talking about none other than motion capture artist extraordinaire Andy Serkis.
item.content:encoded:
Never mind the fact that 20th Century Fox grossed $481 million dollars with a prequel of a film our generation probably didn’t find relevant. Instead, let’s look at what it took to bring in that cash- the stellar acting of a primate. Through his eyes, we saw the birth of a revolution and the fall of a civilization. Eyes that oddly enough, have a strange human quality to them. Not because of any script or digital manipulation, but because there was actually a man behind the ape. I’m talking about none other than motion capture artist extraordinaire Andy Serkis.

Serkis, for those unacquainted with the name, first came to our eyes through the vile, transformed hobbit know as Gollum. Since then Serkis has gone on to be the go to man for action in front of the green screen. When it came to building a strong base to work upon for a primate to develop a hatred of humanity, there was no one else to turn to. Fortunately for Serkis, that turned into big bucks for him once Fox claimed it a winner for the year.

While nothing has been set in stone for the next installment of Planet of the Apes, Serkis was the first to be solidified when assembling the pieces. Agreeing to a salary in the range of seven figures, it became clear just how important he was to the studio. While the producers, writers and director had already signed into a contract for another film, Serkis had only signed on for the first flick. Incredibly smart move on his part as the film could have just as easily turned into a massive flop. Instead, on the back of his performance, he was able to have firm ground to stand on when negotiations started. Serkis is no doubt worth whatever fee he is asking for if for his flexibility to mold the illusion of another through his mannerisms. Hopefully he’ll continue to pave the way for this to become a standard for performances in Hollywood.

Source – Deadline

item.title: Under the Dome Finds Its Writer
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Have you had enough of Stephen King media projects flying around lately? No? Well that’s good because it looks like Showtime is throwing another our way. DreamWorks will be producing the adaptation of Under the Dome from book to TV for the cable channel. The acquisition came back in 2009 as it purchased the rights to the work shortly after release of the novel. What’s taken so long to get it going you might ask? Apparently, when the show was announced in August, it seems that they had still been searching for a writer to cross the bridge from print to script.
item.content:encoded:
Have you had enough of Stephen King media projects flying around lately? No? Well that’s good because it looks like Showtime is throwing another our way. DreamWorks will be producing the adaptation of Under the Dome from book to TV for the cable channel. The acquisition came back in 2009 as it purchased the rights to the work shortly after release of the novel. What’s taken so long to get it going you might ask? Apparently, when the show was announced in August, it seems that they had still been searching for a writer to cross the bridge from print to script. Luckily, it seems that they have found a good man for the job. Deadline reports that the chosen writer will be none other than multiple Eisner Award winner Brian K. Vaughn.

Vaughn, who isn’t a stranger to working with and respecting established properties, is seemly perfect for the task coming from a background in comics. For those of you that might be a little on edge about a comic writer taking the reins, really don’t worry. Telling the tale of humanity gone to hell for the residents of Chester’s Mill in the face of the unexplained is right in Vaughn’s ballpark. In his own master work, Y: The Last Man, Vaughn dug deep to show the sways of human emotion, punchy dialogue, and the know how to keep a story compelling. Couple this experience with his time as a writer on J.J. Abrams’ Lost, and you can begin to understand just how his interpretation of King’s material will evolve into a thriller worthy of the horror author’s approval.

I’m hoping that as things progress we’ll hear nothing but good things coming into play for this adaptation. I must admit that I have al feeling that it could swing the way of the prematurely cancelled Jericho did or even as high as The Walking Dead. Most of that will ride on how the frame work will be carried over and stretched from the novel to fit a long running series. The potential is there, but accelerating the original progression to move onto written for TV filler will easily cripple the entire production.

As we wait for filming to begin, how about someone gets to making Vaughn’s Y: The Last Man into a film or TV show?

Source – Deadline

item.title: Sad News for Campbell Fans – Role in Next Raimi Film Axed
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: If you are a big Bruce Campbell fan like me, we all know that there was a little light of happiness that kicked on for us when Sam Raimi’s next film was announced. When it was released that Raimi is directing a visit back to the world of Oz in Oz the Great and Powerful, the wheels in my brain started churning.
item.content:encoded:
If you are a big Bruce Campbell fan like me, we all know that there was a little light of happiness that kicked on for us when Sam Raimi’s next film was announced. When it was released that Raimi is directing a visit back to the world of Oz in Oz the Great and Powerful, the wheels in my brain started churning. It is a well-documented fact that Raimi often includes Campbell in his productions in a cameo facility. Most recently you might remember him as Peter Parker’s real nemesis in each of the Spider-Man films. Going from ring announcer, to snooty usher, followed by maître d’, Campbell had the tasks of being just enough of a jerk to give Parker problems in his real life through trivial actions. As was the case with each of these cameos, Campbell brought his trademark brand of humor as a bright spot for the films (and narration of the video games).

Unfortunately, it looks like our hopes were dashed rather quickly when Bruce took to Twitter to let his fans know that his role had been cut from the film.

We can ponder on just what kind of sass he would have brought to the film, but it appears that it just wasn’t meant to be. In the mean time, we still get to watch him as the unflappable Sam Axe in USA’s Burn Notice. Who knows, we might even be treated to a brief appearance in The Evil Dead remake.

Source – Twitter

item.title: 20SON Review – Peel Universal Remote Control (iOS)
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: There are many IR Blaster technologies available for changing the channel from a different room, but only one or two for the iOS. The Peel is one of those iOS IR Blaster technologies.
item.content:encoded:
Once upon a time cable came into your house. All you had to do was plug a coaxial cable into your television. Depending on the limits of your television’s own tuner, you probably had channels 2-13 for cable. Times have obviously changed, and Bruce Springsteen’s “57 Channels and Nothing On” is off by at least an order of magnitude. Modern times and cheap televisions have lead to situations where you may not need or be able to afford a cable box on every television. Due to this, the old method of a simple coaxial (or HDMI) cable to another room is having a bit of a renaissance. Some tuner boxes make this easy with radio frequency remotes, but most don’t. There are many IR Blaster technologies available for changing the channel from a different room, but only one or two for the iOS. The Peel is one of those iOS IR Blaster technologies. This hardware and software combination reaches quite far with it’s feature set. Is it too ambitious, or just right?

The Peel is a three-component system based on IR Blaster technology. The trio of parts are the Peel fruit which does the blasting, the cable which plugs into your network and broadcasts to the fruit, and the iOS app that controls the pair. Setup is pretty simple. Point the fruit at the devices you wish controlled and plug in the cable into your router. The documentation does address that this needs to be plugged into the router. Thinking outside the normal setup, in the interest of testing, I tried plugging it in elsewhere in my wired network. The Peel cable doesn’t work properly if plugged in elsewhere. After the rudimentary device installation is complete, the iOS application will take you the rest of the way.

Application configuration is by far the most complicated, but not that difficult by any stretch. Initially the devices you wish to control with your Peel are configured. Lost the unique remote codes? No problem. The Peel application will look them up for you by make and model, and even go through a basic functionality testing- on/off, volume control, et cetera. The Peel controls much more than a television and a tuner box. You can configure just about any other IR remote based device, like many receivers, even an AppleTV or Roku box. Following hardware configuration the app uses location services to pinpoint which television guide it should download for you based on your selection of cable provider.

Show selection on the Peel application

The promise of the device is mostly met- one iDevice as a universal remote without any dongles attachéd to the phone itself. There are a few flaws that hold the device back just a bit. While I found the interface usable, my iDevice proficient inlaws found the non-standard interface conventions a bit obtuse for regular use. They limited themselves to favorite channel switching and didn’t really use the guide functionality that often. The app is just for the iPhone and is designed as such. When enlarged for the iPad, the sensitivity of some of the manual controls seems lessened somewhat. When left at original size, everything seems fine. Not having an iPad specific version of the application seems like an opportunity lost. I did speak with Peel PR regarding an iPad version of the app, and they reported that “(the) iPad is definitely on the roadmap, but there are a few things ahead of it.” With any luck, the larger real estate will be fully taken advantage of.

"Joystick" for manual control

The biggest issue I had with the Peel is the Peel Cable. Communications between the Peel Fruit and the Peel Cable use a custom wireless solution. Getting the 802.11 signal to the cable isn’t a problem, but the distance from your router to the Peel Fruit might create one. I had no problem in a fairly standard split-level house from the basement to the kitchen, but communications between the cable and fruit were inconsistent a bit farther away in an extension to the house. This may have been distance or a brick wall, I’m not sure. If the cable functioned properly plugged into a network switch closer to the Fruit, then range or RF shielding effects wouldn’t have been a problem. As noted earlier though, it doesn’t work at all plugged in anyplace else but the router.

Our review primarily focused on controlling a cable box in an adjacent room from the viewing space. We did test it as a universal remote with a surround sound system and a DVD player with no problems. If all you’re looking for is simple cable box control, then there are easier alternatives available. Many cable providers have options for your smartphone, especially if you have bundled services and compatible routers. Cable provider’s smartphone solutions limit your home networking options, forcing you to use their routers. The Peel does exactly as advertised- it simplifies your remote situation as well as makes television a more customized experience. With it you get a more interactive TV guide on the remote, rather than what the cable provider force feeds you with your cable box. There are positively problems that call out for this elegant and attractive solution. Overall, we liked the Peel, and see where in the future further software updates would benefit the advanced and casual user alike. There are other universal remote control solution available, but the more flexible ones cost more than $99 (not including the cost of the iDevice, of course). I’m not sure technically why the Peel cable needs to be plugged into the router only and I’d like to see this resolved in the future, but I do recommend the Peel for just about every universal remote control application from both a functionality and stylistic standpoint.

Item provided by developer for review.

item.title: The VGA Awards and You – Or, Why We Can’t Have Nice Things
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: First of all, I'm going to come right out and say that my viewpoint may not be popular, even with my co-host. I spent a little while watching the VGAs last night (On Spike, which they seemed to keep having to remind us), and I'm not sure of this particular show's relevancy.
item.content:encoded:
First of all, I’m going to come right out and say that my viewpoint may not be popular, even with my co-host. I spent a little while watching the VGAs last night (On Spike, which they seemed to keep having to remind us), and I’m not sure of this particular show’s relevancy.

I know broadcast television is all about money making, selling commercials, and turning a profit, and I don’t begrudge them that. What I begrudge is a teabag skit. What I begrudge is the presentation. I know I’m not the VGA award’s prime demographic, but I’m not sure why I’m not. The average gamer age is closer to my age than to the apparent target of the VGA awards was. Plus, while gaming has taken great strides in the public perception in the last 10 years, we’re still fighting for wider gamer representation in the population as a whole, and even in the government. How is a blatant misogynist and homophobic show on a major cable network (regardless of the primarily male oriented channel programming) going to enhance the view of the pubic at large of us as gamers?

Don’t get me wrong- we need public awards. We need a show. We need a voting block, whether it be gamers or industry luminaries. We don’t need any -isms. There are plenty of -isms on the internet, pointed out by Gabriel’s GIFT. Breasts are trivial to see in other venues than a video game award show. We don’t need two hours of upcoming game trailers during the awards show. Trailers are easy to find on the internet, on G4, before movies, or even on commercials during major network prime time programming. This show, more than any other before it felt like an extension of the marketing arms of any one of a host of video game companies and a ill-humored sexist hour plus of television.

item.title: Eureka’s Fifth Season to be the Last – Another Syfy Error
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: On the eve of Syfy’s original winter showcase, I’m again reminded of how I loathe the decision makers of the cable channel. Not just because of some of the eye-gouging films and reality TV shows they feed to hungry science fiction loving nerds, but because of the continual mistreatment of their popular franchises. Instead of nurturing their shows and allowing them to rise or fall on their own, they hack them off seemingly out of nowhere. While they may give their show runners the leeway to do fun things like actually being able to produce Christmas themed episodes, they force the shows to take a bow before it is really their time to move on from the lime light. The most recent show to have the proverbial axe brought down upon it by the hands of poor judgment happened to be Eureka.
item.content:encoded:
On the eve of Syfy’s original winter showcase, I’m again reminded of how I loathe the decision makers of the cable channel. Not just because of some of the eye-gouging films and reality TV shows they feed to hungry science fiction loving nerds, but because of the continual mistreatment of their popular franchises. Instead of nurturing their shows and allowing them to rise or fall on their own, they hack them off seemingly out of nowhere. While they may give their show runners the leeway to do fun things like actually being able to produce Christmas themed episodes, they force the shows to take a bow before it is really their time to move on from the lime light. The most recent show to have the proverbial axe brought down upon it by the hands of poor judgment happened to be Eureka.

For those of you that might not know, Eureka is town off the beaten path imagined around the hills of Grants Pass, Oregon. As a typical small town, they like to keep to themselves. It might not be the reason you think though. A bastion of discovery sparked by Einstein himself, Eureka is a breakthrough scientific mecca that manages to create the impossible on a daily basis thanks to the best and brightest of the world. While transporting his handful of a daughter back to her mother’s home, the bumbling hero Agent Jack Carter stumbles unwittingly into this small town. Helping stop a catastrophe from wiping out the town, Carter finds a place in the town as sheriff. He’s surrounded by those of vast intelligence, only rivaling their level of knowledge with his own street smarts. The show has evolved over time to keep the plots running and the twists going outside of the emergency of the week episodes that are at its core. In 2012, the fifth and final season will wrap on the cable channel.

The whole handling of the eventual cancellation of Eureka was a botched job from the top down. Just touching the surface of how badly this was handled, the show runners were completely in the dark about the show being in trouble. With the flip-flopping of the cancellation, then the ordering of six more episodes, followed by the cancellation again (but this time with one episode to wrap it all up), it appeared as a bumbling mess. Fans, cast members and creators alike were being thrown from emotional side to side as Syfy ultimately decided the fate of our favorite advancement pioneers. In a statement once the final decision was cast, Syfy had this to say about the closure:

“After painstaking consideration, we have had to make the difficult business decision to not order a season six of Eureka. But Eureka is not over yet. There is a new holiday episode this December and 12 stellar episodes set to debut next year, marking its fifth season and six memorable years on Syfy. The 2012 episodes are some of the best we’ve seen, and will bring this great series to a satisfying end. We are very grateful to Bruce Miller and Jaime Paglia, their team of incredible writers, and an amazing cast and crew who have consistently delivered a series we continue to be very proud of. We thank the fans for their support of this show and know they will enjoy its final season in 2012.”

Now you might wonder what exactly brought on the demise of the once most successful show on the channel. Rumor is that due to the rising costs of the show, the possibility of a sixth season actually was slapped from their hands due in part to the Comcast-Universal merger. In an interview with executive producer Bruce Berg done by Screen Rant, he states, “we could not maintain the quality of our show with the cuts it would take to make us profitable for Syfy’s new parent company.” He goes on to say that it wasn’t as if the executives at Syfy just rolled over at the decision. If that’s the case, is there more this or other show endings that Syfy (or Sci-Fi) have put us through? We may never know the real reasoning behind some of them, but from the sources I have to think that there is some truth to this.

It strikes me that the cost to produce each episode had been going up at a larger scale than most shows do over time. Looking at how much the effects seem to have improved and the list of higher profile actors being brought in after the third season, one can clearly understand how the budget would escalate. Part of me has to wonder what else could have been going on in the background with the show’s budget. Ratings for the show have been quite good considering the decay over time for most original cable shows. Ranging from 4.1 million during the series premiere to 2.5 million for the fourth season starter, the decay hung around a 2.2 household rating for the series. I know it isn’t the ratings killer that wrestling might be or as cheap as any number of reality shows to produce, but that isn’t bad. This just shows how eventually all networks are going to succumb to the bottom dollar rather than put something out that has lasting power. Of course this is the case with our country’s entertainment industry. The difference is when you look at the number of shows that come and go on a regular basis; you know that just sticking with a show would be more appealing to advertisers over time.

In the end, if you enjoy the show, I behest you to watch it while you can. As shows go, Eureka has managed to keep things fun, entertaining and interesting through the course of the show. Thanks to Syfy’s big brother Comcast we won’t be seeing a season past five in the immediate future. By no means does that give us the luxury to give up on it. Continue to support it until the end, folks. I have no doubt that the show won’t come to a satisfying close. When you see the fun that was had in the Christmas special, it lets you know just how much the show was loved by the entire body of people that stepped on the sets. You never know, it might continue on life in another media as other past Syfy shows have.

Sources – Syfy / Screenrant / Deadline / TV by the Numbers

item.title: 20SON Review – AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA: For The Awesome
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Enter the extreme sci-fi base jumping / faux-protest game AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA: For The Awesome (henceforth known as AAA:FTA) by Dejobaan Studios and Owlchemy Labs. If I needed a shot of adrenaline into my life, I've got it now. The question is, do I want another hit?
item.content:encoded:
I haven’t been an enormous risk taker during my life. About the scariest thing I’ve ever done was swam across a narrow channel to get to an old castle while I was overseas nearly two decades ago. Enter the extreme sci-fi base jumping / faux-protest game AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA: For The Awesome (henceforth known as AAA:FTA) by Dejobaan Studios and Owlchemy Labs. If I needed a shot of adrenaline into my life, I’ve got it now. The question is, do I want another hit?

One of the more perilous places to jump…

What does one do in AAA:FTA? You launch yourself off of buildings with the intent of not dying on the way down. If avoiding turbines, buildings, and other structures wasn’t enough, you collect kisses and hugs by tagging a building or staying close to a building for extended periods of time respectively. Protesters line the course, giving you the pleasure of communicating with them in a vulgar manner if so you choose. Government buildings need spray paint defacement on the way down since they’ve outlawed your extreme sport of choice. See a bird? Angle into it for impact to be awarded big points! At the end of the course, you pop your chute and aim for a landing target. You can miss the target but unless you miss the ground completely, you’re not dead. Incentive to play levels you’ve already completed comes in the form of kneecaps. Score well on an already completed level and be rewarded with this currency which allows you to unlock more of the 125 levels included with the game. Progress through the levels isn’t linear. You just have to select one that’s adjacent in the map to one you’ve already unlocked, so there’s not one true path through the game.

Level selection. Pithy wisdom!

Word to the wise- this game is pitiless and without remorse. Whether by accident or design, it assumes you have some familiarity with the gameplay concepts from the first AAA and you’re just thrown into the game with little tutorial or fanfare. There is an escalation of difficulty as you progress, but there’s just no beginning handholding at all. I will confess, I did end up splattered on the top of many a building until I got a better feel for the controls. That’s not the fault of the game. I had no difficulty with controls, it was just my own brain not pre-plotting my path correctly and executing accurately. This game is a the stereotypical example of practice making perfect, and in many ways it reminds me of a bizarre variant of the SSX series in both presentation and attitude.

See those guys on the right? Give them "the salute"

Graphically, the game is intense. Almost every action game has some sort of falling mechanic, whether it just be a Mario jump arc or gravity’s effect on a skateboarder. In no other game have I felt the momentum. My wife is prone to video game motion sickness, and we’ve taken steps throughout the years to minimize her exposure to first person shooters and the like. While I was playing this game on a 15″ laptop screen, she couldn’t even so much as glance at the screen while I was playing without inducing a bit of nausea. Mission accomplished! Sound presentation is fine, nothing to complain about. There’s enough aural feedback to let you know when you’ve accomplished a task. That’s a good thing, since taking your eyes off of your flight path pretty much means instant death.

I do have a complaint with the game, but really only one. I think this game would benefit significantly from the motion sensitivity of a tablet rather than keyboard and mouse commands. Dejobaan released this game in conjunction with Owlchemy, who’s most famous contribution to gaming is the well-publicized iOS release Smuggle/Snuggle Truck. Make it so!

AAA:FTA’s predecessor was nominated for all kinds of awards, and featured at PAX East’s indie showcase a while back. This incarnation is newer, flashier, and contains the original game in it’s entirety as well as 45 new levels. There is a demo available on Steam if you’re on the fence. Unlike most recent demos, it gives you a perfect feel for the game. Word to the wise- if you’re prone to gaming motion sickness, do not play this game under any circumstances. At $10 regular price, if extreme sci-fi sports are your thing, go get it now. I haven’t seen a sale other than a launch sale, but still- two large Starbucks coffees is a small price to pay if this is the kind of game you enjoy. If you’re a fan of the original, or have ever put SSX or SSX:Tricky into your console and enjoyed it, then you’ll also like AAA:FTA.

Game provided by developer for review.

item.title: Episode 41 – Podcast Recording Gang
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Anubis joins us in one of our sillier podcasts in recent memory. The dynamics of three podcasting recorders are unique, and perhaps we need to get uniforms going to celebrate this. We better be careful about that though. Slap a name tag on our group and wandering in packs in Second Life and we might arouse suspicion. In any event, topics covered include: Brein being sued for piracy, EA's Tetris Pass, US Judge orders sites deindexed from Google, Congress versus Blackwater, the South Park MMORPG, the Legend D20 system, Anonymous and Robin Hood style attacks, and the Geneva convention versus video games.
item.content:encoded:
Anubis joins us in one of our sillier podcasts in recent memory. The dynamics of three podcasting recorders are unique, and perhaps we need to get uniforms going to celebrate this. We better be careful about that though. Slap a name tag on our group and wandering in packs in Second Life and we might arouse suspicion. In any event, topics covered include:

  • Anti-Piracy group Brein is being sued for piracy.
  • EA pulls another fast one with a Tetris community annual pass on the iOS.
  • A US judge orders sites de-indexed from Google, etc. What?
  • Congress versus Blackwater/Xi. Fight!
  • Do we really need a South Park MMORPG?
  • Legend, a D20 based RPG is available, pay what you want to benefit Child’s Play.
  • Anonymous is threatening banks with Robin Hood-style attacks.
  • How and why should the Geneva convention apply to video games?

If you listen carefully, you might hear the beginning of the 20 Sides of Nerd Christmas giveaways! Enjoy folks!

item.title: 20SON Review – Serious Sam 3:BFE (PC)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Let’s all be honest with ourselves, the Serious Sam franchise has never been anymore more than the gaming equivalent to a summer popcorn flick. A film that’s sole purpose is to bring in the patrons for action, gratuitous violence, massive explosions, cheesy dialogue, questionable story, and most importantly overwhelming odds. For those reasons, my brain connects Serious Sam 3 and the Sylvester Stallone et al mega action hero flick, The Expendables. Sounds like a kooky idea right? It might not be as out there as you think.
item.content:encoded:
Usually whenever I’m writing, I tend to have something going on in the background to ease me along. Be it a movie, TV show or some music, it helps me keep the magpie part of my brain occupied. When I sat down to write about Serious Sam 3: BFE, I managed to pick a film that embodies perhaps what the goal has been for Croteam all along. Let’s all be honest with ourselves, the Serious Sam franchise has never been anymore more than the gaming equivalent to a summer popcorn flick. A film that’s sole purpose is to bring in the patrons for action, gratuitous violence, massive explosions, cheesy dialogue, questionable story, and most importantly overwhelming odds. For those reasons, my brain connects Serious Sam 3 and the Sylvester Stallone et al mega action hero flick, The Expendables. Sounds like a kooky idea right? It might not be as out there as you think. Each of these vie for our entertainment dollar, often rivaling each other in price, so why shouldn’t we draw comparisons between the two?

The scenery might look great, but you won't have many moments outside of this to take a good look at it.

For awhile now Hollywood has been developing vehicles, aka films, for specific stars. Be it ones they want to pander to, fast track or build upon, actors have been specifically primed in some cases. Otherwise why would we be seeing the trend of film franchises going way past the acclaimed trilogy idea, or basically continuing on or telling the same story as some older film with the same actor? This is very apparent when you contrast films and video games. From Jason Statham, Sylvester Stallone, and Jet Li in films to Commander Keen, Ezio Auditore, and Mega Man in video games. As pop culture goes on, we’re fed the same stuff like whether we like it or not. The only difference is as movie star ages they tend to get a reprieve in what they are asked to do. Video game stars just go on and on. Sam “Serious” Stone is a prime example here.

If you weren’t familiar with the Serious Sam franchise, this is as good a place to jump in as any. An evil alien overload named Mental wants to destroy Earth with his twisted alien creatures. In order to stop him, humanity decided to send a man through a time lock device left behind by another race of aliens that battled Mental and his minions long ago. There was only one man thought tough enough to be able to get the job done- Sam Stone. Jumping into the skin of Sam, it is your job to shoot your way through anything that gets in your way. You want plot? Forget it. What I described above is about all you get. Serious Sam’s plot is just like the paper thin plot of The Expendables involving over the hill mercenaries for hire who destroy whatever they are paid to do so, seemingly for the hell of it. Really, what was the point of it besides getting these idle action heroes a pay check? And like the summer film, you can invite your friends along to for the devastation in Serious Sam 3.

Gratuitous blood too much for you? Think it is just too much for your kids? Don't worry, the game allows for other options like slime blood, hippie flowers and confetti!

At the heart of it all the only promise you can expect from a Serious Sam title is the promise of mayhem. Serious Sam 3 delivers it in spades. Taking cue from the earlier titles, it jumps right back into the madness that Croteam strove to accomplish in the first place. Styled like early first person shooters like Doom and Duke Nukem 3D, it has the feel that many people that have been fighting the PC fight will be right at home with. Circle strafers rejoice! Monsters will be thrown at you constantly until you master the ability to mow evil down with your weapon of choice. The game won’t make this an easy task either. I mean sure, click, point, boom…not that hard. What makes it more difficult is the fact that the game will continuously throw things at you for the sake of doing it.

And this is a light case of the bodies that will stand in your way…

Even though it seems like I am down on the action, let me assure you this isn’t the case. Action is predominately what both The Expendables and Serious Sam 3 set out to have. There were never going to be any awards given out for the stellar script in either case. The campaign will keep you busy for some time, especially if you are a completionist. The real gold can be found in the multiplayer. Unlike many shooters out there, Serious Sam has kept its co-op feature. Not many FPS games out there in the PC world hold onto this feature, let alone allow you to do it with 15 others online or split screen on one computer. That isn’t the best part. Once you start your first deathmatch game, your adrenaline will start bubbling in your veins while drool drips from your lips. This is the style of play from the days of yore. The rush hits as you gib your enemies as they rush for the coveted rocket launcher. Double barrel shotguns will once again rule the day. By far, this is the best the game has to offer- pure, unhinged annihilation. Not only that, but it offers six different modes of head to head play. The only catch is a limited selection of both maps to play on and players to actually go up against. During my play time I was actually only able to find under populated deathmatch servers to play on. Those were enough. I missed the fast paced play of games like this. No cover mechanics, no gimmick abilities or regenerative shields to screw around with, no bullshit.

Climbing those crates won't do you much good, bub.

The Serious 3.5 engine is no joke. Once again advanced with the rest of the game during development, the developers have really outdone themselves. The engine looks great on any setting. It seems that just about anything can be destroyed. Not only by the players, but mobs play a hand at leveling things to wreckage. Even the monsters you fight have been given a wonderful makeover by the art division. Why don’t more developers approach Croteam to license their engine? It has plenty to offer. The only thing I’d like to see is a little more detail put into the player models. For some reason they look out of place with the grotesque beauty of everything around them.

Buildings crumble, walls are tore down, and spaceships explode. Just a small sample of what the Serious 3.5 engine is capable of.

With the good, I have to jump back a little to the point of doing reviews in the first place. We all know that shooters don’t have the greatest track record when it comes to inspiring us to play. I mean, Doom 2’s story was that demons from hell killed your rabbit. I can relate to that story as a bunny owner myself, but if we’re using that to set the bar- it’s pretty damn low. Literally it seems like the action connects the dots for Serious Sam 3, just like its film companion I watched as I wrote this. There are clip scenes where Sam is talking back to command, but they are extremely disconnected. You get a brief idea of what is going on, but only enough to set everything up. You are supposed to know what was going on from the other games that came before, but remember that this release is actually supposed to be a prequel. This is just what The Expendables did as well though. You take a page from the successful things of the past and wrap a shoddy story around them. Take a little dash of martial arts from Once Upon A Time in China, a little jungle action a la Rambo 2, let Randy Couture do MMA against “Stone Cold” Steve Austin and you have a good base going. Toss in Eric Roberts (or someone just like him) to play generic evil villain stereotype-A and give everyone else in the movie a gun and boom, you’re practically 80% there. Everything is done for thrill value instead of plot and character advancement. It is just something to keep your eyes busy. To be fair, it isn’t like any of us were expecting Shakespearean dialog from either of these titles though.

The depth of the puzzles is running around collecting keys. Through it, you get to see some of the best level design the game has to offer.

When you get to characters and acting, it doesn’t really get any better. The voice of Sam, John J. Dick, is fingernails on the chalkboard. He lacks the even mock enthusiasm that Sam should be saturated in to the point of it dripping on the floor. I don’t know if it is for lack of trying on his part, the poor dialogue writing, or if he was just getting tired of doing satire of Duke, but the parody excuse can only be taken so far. Writing has to play some element here. Once we compare it to our handy action movie again, it’s clear that they really didn’t have to strive for much. Even when breaking the fourth wall, Sam has a hard time cracking a laugh out of the player. His one-liners are hideous. Then again, if you look into the depth of dialogue that The Expendables has to offer, you can see how many won’t regard this as much of a problem. Think of the poem that Jason Statham’s character Christmas recites at the end of the film. It is absolutely wretched. When you look at the sum of the actors, they all do what they are good at. All of which seems to be trying to look good hitting people. True to form, Sam Stone seems no different.

It should do you wise to actually read the information given to you by your "heads up" computer.

At $40, I question if this title is worth it. If you are a fan of what has been done with the Serious series so far, then by all means it will be a good bet. With the outstanding graphics engine, retro homage to FPS days gone by, and addicting multiplayer all wrapped in a modern shell, you’ll be in love. However, you’ll have to deal with the frustrations of endless cannon fodder situations that can and will overwhelm you at times regardless of skill or arsenal. On top of that, the fast paced murderfest known as deathmatch won’t shine that bright when you have problems even finding others to play with. Let’s not even speak about getting co-op together. Can you convince 15 other people to buy it with you? Hell, do you even know that many people who’d want to play? Twenty bucks seems like a sweet spot for this title. Hopefully it won’t take long for it to get there. In the mean time, it will be a nice intermediary title that you can waste a weekend on and still get some good value on afterwards. If massive, repetitive slaughtering is your name, then Serious Sam 3 is your game.

PS – Croteam, more rocket splash damage please. Thanks!

Game provided by developer for review

item.title: Haven Continues Its Tales of the Troubles: Picked Up for Season 3
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Fans of Syfy’s Haven will be happy to know that the cable network has decided to pick up the show for a third season in 2012. Averaging 2.55 million viewers (a 1.9 household rating), the show has done nothing but rise in viewership over the first season.
item.content:encoded:
Fans of Syfy’s Haven will be happy to know that the cable network has decided to pick up the show for a third season in 2012. Averaging 2.55 million viewers (a 1.9 household rating), the show has done nothing but rise in viewership over the first season. Based on the short story The Colorado Kid by Stephen King, Haven focuses on the strange events of the small town Haven, Maine. I know a Stephen King story based in Maine is such a foreign concept, right? The show tells the story of FBI agent, turned local cop Audrey Parker coming to Haven to track down a fugitive. She ended up getting more than she bargained for when she started digging around in Haven, raising questions about her own past. Parker has an ability that allows her to help the residents afflicted by the supernatural “troubles” that plague the town.

Mark Stern, President of Original Programming had nothing but kind things to say about the renewal. “The superb cast, led by Emily Rose, Eric Balfour and Lucas Bryant, along with the terrific production team, delivered a successful season in both critical acclaim and rising viewership. We’re very excited to see this compelling series return for a third season of supernatural intrigue in 201,” said Stern in the announcement.

With Eureka’s unfortunate departure from the network, it is clear that SyFy is going to have to fill in the gaps. Still reeling from the conclusion of Battlestar Galactica, the subsequent cancellation of Caprica, and the unknown nature of Blood & Chrome, there seems to be a lack of drama tinged series on the network. Not to mention the disappointing sinking of the Stargate franchise with Stargate Universe. Alphas may have earned a second season pick up, though I question why. I suppose any original series is better than more wrestling.

With that, Syfy has little to pull out of the development tank. New shows may have been announced, but with the development slate the way it is with the channel, who knows if we will ever see any of them. One thing is clear though. Syfy needs to keep their audiences where they have them, so picking up Haven was really a no-brainer.

Read Syfy’s official announcement here.

Source – Syfy

item.title: Farscape Ends Again – Ongoing Comic Series Reaches Its Finale
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: In a bit of news that truly saddens me to the core, it was announced that the on-going Farscape comic series put out through BOOM! Studios came to an end with issue 24.
item.content:encoded:
In a bit of news that truly saddens me to the core, it was announced that the on-going Farscape comic series put out through BOOM! Studios came to an end with issue 24. Now this shouldn’t come as a shock to those who are fans of the series. We’ve been dealt this heartache not once, but twice during the life of the television show.

Now before anyone goes on to start another Save Farscape campaign, let me remind you that we’re lucky to have another look into the universe after the television series conclusion with The Peacekeeper Wars. While it wasn’t nearly what the originally promised season five would have been, it was a conclusion nonetheless. When it was announced that Farscape would live on in comics, ‘Scapers as a whole were beyond thrilled. When we learned that it was going to be tied to canon as Rockne S. O’Bannon would be involved, along with Keith R.A. de Candido (author of the tie-in novel, House of Cards), there was no doubt that the series would pick up right where we left off. What we probably never expected was that it would lead to a three year run, along with seven other mini-series books.

Don’t be too disappointed in the wrap up of the series though. It had a fantastic run, even if it did leave us with some unanswered questions. However, that doesn’t mean it will be the end. Remember that BOOM! Studios were the second company to run a Farscape comic (after WildStorm). As with all sci-fi shows, death is never really the end in comics. It’s possible that down the line we might see another run of mini-series from BOOM! or even another publisher (webcomic anyone?). Be thankful, given the state of the comic industry, that we were blessed with even a little more Farscape. For now, let us look up towards the future. Maybe now The Jim Henson Company can get on those webisodes they’ve been promising for years.

On a side note- If you’ve been waiting to buy the full series once it hit Blu-ray, you are in luck. The collection just hit store shelves on 11/15, right in time for your favorite ‘Scaper’s holiday gift.

Cover for Farscape issue 24 – The final of the series.

Source – BOOM! Studios / Irish Comic News

item.title: World of Warcraft Embraces Chuck Norris Meme in New Commercial
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Just when you think that the Internet has finally had enough of as meme, Blizzard had to go and breathe new life into one. The newest in the "What's Your Game?" celebrity commercial features none other than your favorite champion of the Internet- Chuck Norris.
item.content:encoded:
Just when you think that the Internet has finally had enough of as meme, Blizzard had to go and breathe new life into one. The newest in the “What’s Your Game?” celebrity commercial features none other than your favorite champion of the Internet- Chuck Norris. Taking on the guise of a hunter brings new meaning to abilities like Raptor Strike with Norris behind the keyboard. Since Chuck Norris jokes have been made for years in the various chat channels (you remember Barrens chat?), it was a smart PR move to pull support from the man himself. Some might say this is a further move towards jumping the shark after Mists of Pandaria or “selling out” by Norris. However, I think that it was only a matter of time before these two finally got together.

Do yourself a favor and hide if you see a human jump kicking various people around town. I’d really run if you play a gnome or a goblin. Yeesh, he doesn’t take too kindly to the smaller folk of Azeroth.

Source – Blizzard

item.content:encoded:
