item.title: The Walking Dead’s Hunger Grows: Season 3 Renewal
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: In a move that shouldn’t come as a surprise to anyone who has been watching the show, The Walking Dead has been given a third season pickup by AMC. Following reports of unheard of viewership for a cable show, the network was quick to give the series more life on the small screen.
item.content:encoded:
In a move that shouldn’t come as a surprise to anyone who has been watching the show, The Walking Dead has been given a third season pickup by AMC. Following reports of unheard of viewership for a cable show, the network was quick to give the series more life on the small screen. The stir around this groundbreaking show has pulled tremendous weight with the previous audiences, whom only ten years ago may have ignored the channel altogether.

“Today we are pleased to announce that the ‘dead’ shall live as we proudly renew The Walking Dead for a third season on AMC and, globally, with our terrific partners at Fox International Channels,” said Charlie Collier, AMC’s President. “We are thankful for everyone’s contribution in front of and behind the camera as we continue to make The Walking Dead a unique television experience[...]“

With TV degrading into the festering gene pool of reality television and re-hashed scripted dramas that it is, is it any wonder that a show like The Walking Dead has tremendous force behind it? More so, is it not amazing that this is an idea that has evolved from the comic industry into something that isn’t immediately panned into oblivion? With the ending of Breaking Bad this year, and the show lending its lead out slot to new shows like Hell on Wheels, you can bet that AMC will ride The Walking Dead until it has nothing left to give. The undead may be slow to rise, but they sure do keep going. With the comic coming up on issue 100 in 2012, there will be plenty of meat to keep it that way. Now Kirkman just needs to keep them more on track.

Source – AMC

item.title: Community Isn’t Cancelled – But Probably Will Be
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: NBC's midseason lineup was released this last Monday, and the internet rage was swift and fierce. Community didn't have a place on it.
item.content:encoded:
NBC’s midseason lineup was released this last Monday, and the internet rage was swift and fierce. Community didn’t have a place on it. No Troy and Abed, no Inspector Spacetime, no Señor Chang, probably not at least until the Fall of 2012 and then I expect it’ll just be to air the rest of the already filmed episodes. A twitter show-saving campaign started (look for the hashtag #savecommunity), but I don’t think it’s going to matter much.

A quick look at the numbers for Community‘s airing plainly shows the problem. Viewership is terrible and getting worse even including Tivo and on demand numbers. At press time, the last episode of Community was watched by 3.5 million viewers. This may not seem like much, but consider that The Big Bang Theory routinely draws 16 million viewers in the same time slot. Season to season, average numbers and rankings are dropping as well. The first season of Community averaged 5 million viewers, the second 4.5 million. Advertising dollars per 30 second spot are down as well year to year.

Community is one of the first examples of a critically admired show that’s peripherally in our genre of television. It’s also no shock looking at the numbers that it’s about to be cancelled. Television is about money making. If a show isn’t making money, it’s not going to be continued. A prime example is Jericho. While a brief reprieve was given to the post-apocalyptic drama after corporate headquarters were inundated with peanuts, I don’t think the same or a similar trick will work again.

Want to save Community? Watch it now, and when it returns. Watch it legally when it airs, on Tivo, or on Hulu, so it can be counted by the suits at the television studios. Consider that networks suits rarely care about fandom or critical acclaim, it’s all about the bottom line- total viewership and the advertising dollar.

Source – CNN

item.title: 20SON Review – Halo : Anniversary
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Our very first topic on the podcast was the rumor that there was a HD remake of Halo: Combat Evolved in progress at 343 Industries. We've missed the target a few times, but not this time… This last Tuesday, Halo Anniversary, the HD remake of Halo: Combat Evolved hit the store shelves. Do gameplay tropes that the title introduced a decade ago count against it now, as it's been done a million time since, or is there a pass since the original title was the proto trope?
item.content:encoded:
We’ve come full circle. Our very first topic on the podcast was the rumor that there was a HD remake of Halo: Combat Evolved in progress at 343 Industries. We’ve missed the target a few times, but not this time… This last Tuesday, Halo Anniversary, the HD remake of Halo: Combat Evolved hit the store shelves. The review process has been both fascinating to read and participate in. Do you review the game like it’s a new experience, or does it get some credit for being ten years old? Do gameplay tropes that the title introduced a decade ago count against it now, as it’s been done a million times since, or is there a pass since the original title was the proto trope?

Captain Keyes and the Chief

I know that in the parlance of reviews I’m supposed to discuss the setting and scenario in detail during the second or third paragraph after the introduction. I’m not going to waste a lot of words here. Master Chief is the ultimate bad ass space marine. It’s been a long war, humanity is getting pounded, and Master Chief’s escape from Reach with the artificial intelligence Cortana was a very near thing. Things go pear shaped, his escape ship is forced down on the ringworld and he’s got to shoot his way out. Sounds like just about every other space marine game published in the last 10 years doesn’t it? Yeah, there’s a reason for that. Like it or not, Halo cast a very long shadow on the gaming industry. While it wasn’t the first to implement vehicles in a shooter, Bungie executed them very well. A regenerating shield mechanic had been used before, but less as a player aid and more as a plot point hindering player progress.

Master Chief is making his rounds through the corridors blasting all in his path.

Halo Anniversary is Halo: Combat Evolved for the next decade. Gameplay remains unchanged. All the little quirks, tricks, and exploits you used in the original Xbox game still exist. Need to get the Warthog past the narrow channel in The Silent Cartographer? Fine, no problem. That game behavior that prevents an Elite from hopping in a banshee on the final bridge in The Assault on the Control Room? Still works. It’s all still there. The selling point on Halo Anniversary is the graphical layer on top of the 10 year old engine applying a HD and widescreen sheen to the gameplay. It shouldn’t come as a surprise that it’s very well done. Covenant surfaces are shiny and, well, purple. Human equipment is suitably gritty in a sci-fi war machine kind of way. I think that the Forerunner structures don’t feel quite as grand after the graphical makeover, but that may be my imagination and detail filling from many hours in the campaign of the first game playing tricks on my mind.

Nothing bad can be said about the original score by Marty O’Donnell. The chanting monks in the opening theme is emblematic of Halo making the score easily recognizable by even a casual fan. The score has been given the full orchestral treatment and feels…different. Not deeper or grander, just different. It’s worth a separate listen. If you’re a purist, selection of the original score can be done in the options menu. Both scores have their merits. Further audio work has been done on all of the weaponry and for the first time since Halo 2 the weapons feel suitably beefy. In my co-op playthroughs, my co-op partner remarked that they truly feel like some sort of space cannon. Honestly, it’s a bit jarring, but in a good way. Blasting a dozen grunts with the full discharge of the 60 round assault rifle clip while running down a hallway is more than just an assault on alien scum- it’s a treat for the senses of the player.

Blasting away in multiplayer.

Early on in the press cycle for Halo: Anniversary, a lot of noise was made about how the multiplayer was going to work. I predicted that it would be in only Halo:Reach, and I was partially correct. If you launch multiplayer from the Halo:Anniversary disk, you are in your own matchmaking hopper, but it’s still in the Reach engine and matchmaking playlist designed for it. It was just mashed with old school Halo gameplay as best as they could manage. It’s very close, but not quite identical. The three-shot pistol is back, and with it comes a serious balance issue in multiplayer. Each retail copy of Halo:Anniversary comes with a token for Xbox Live to allow download of the new maps into the main Halo: Reach multiplayer. Remakes of Beaver Creek, Hang ‘Em High, Damnation, Prisoner, and Headlong are included on the disk and with the install over Xbox Live, as well as a Firefight map based on part of the campaign level “Halo.” It was about time for a map pack for Reach anyway. The fan community around the game is pretty vocal about every issue that changes the beloved franchise, but I think that the integration of the old maps into the Reach multiplayer engine is the best case scenario that will irritate the fewest amount of people. Having very specific and discrete Halo Anniversary multiplayer isolated from Reach multiplayer would have raised hell with the online matchmaking population that’s already heavily split between many AAA titles.

More dramatic Halo pummeling

Halo is the first game series that I think has been unjustly painted by gamer hipsterism. There is no reason to dislike a game simply because of it’s popularity. There is a great deal of room in the industry for blockbusters, ongoing series, little indie titles, retro gamers, music game enthusiasts, and JRPG players to name a few. As such, Halo: Anniversary isn’t going to be for everybody. Other reviews have complained that there’s not a lot to the package for your $39.99. I disagree. For that price, the Halo fan gets six multiplayer maps and a firefight map for Halo: Reach as well as a campaign that while painted as repetitive, still offers a great deal of gameplay variety and replayability. As an added bonus, the campaign is longer than modern single player campaigns as found in titles such as Battlefield 3 and Modern Warfare 3. Who should buy this game? Even at the lower than normal holiday release price point of $39.99 if you don’t like Halo for whatever reason you may have you won’t like Anniversary. If you’re going to get the maps for Reach you may as well drop the extra cash on the campaign too. Gaming’s path over the last ten years has been driven by the effects of Halo on the console ecosystem. If you were too young to have appreciated how the story actually started, now’s a good time to get on board.

Game was purchased by the reviewer

item.title: Dark Horse and Bioware Team Up for Dragon Age Digital Comic
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Have you had a hankering for a little more Dragon Age lately? Perhaps the recently launched DLC Mark of the Assassin and Dragon Age: Redemption webseries featuring Felicia Day wasn’t enough to hold you over? Good news for you then faithful Ferelden fan. Bioware and Dark Horse Comics recently announced that a digital comic series will be coming down the pipeline in February 2012.
item.content:encoded:
Have you had a hankering for a little more Dragon Age lately? Perhaps the recently launched DLC Mark of the Assassin and Dragon Age: Redemption webseries featuring Felicia Day wasn’t enough to hold you over? Good news for you then faithful Ferelden fan. Bioware and Dark Horse Comics recently announced that a digital comic series will be coming down the pipeline in February 2012. At the low price of $0.99 per issue, the six issue series will be easily affordable. The issues will cover some of the more well-known and often lusted after characters you’d be familiar with (We’re looking at you Alistair).

Written by David Gaider, leader writer and creator of Dragon Age brings forth tales of a group of heroes traveling to Antivia a far off land ruled by assassins. Don’t let it frighten you that some of your former companions are teaming up for a new adventure. As Gaider has been the lead writer on the property since the beginning (on top of writing novels in the universe), I’m sure that everything is in good hands. Chad Hardin is handling the art duties. With titles like Farscape and The Web of Spider-Man under his belt, I think the pages will be looking fantastic.

In the mean time, keep playing away in the universe of the Gray Wardens with your friends through the tabletop RPG from Green Ronin. Tabletop not your thing? The next book by Gaider, Dragon Age: Asunder, is set to release at the end of the year. If the thought of reading puts you off a little, Bioware has planned an anime produced in conjunction with Funimation. Dragon Age: Dawn of the Seeker should be making its way to your eyeballs sometime in 2012 (pushed back from a 2011 release).

It’s an all out multimedia blitz by Bioware in order to make a strong brand out of Dragon Age. If they keeping offering us all of these options, I think they won’t have any problem keeping us hungering for more.

Source – Dark Horse Comics

item.title: American Horror Story Scares Up a Second Season
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: American Horror Story may only be six episodes into its first season, but FX made the decision to make an early renewal for a second season of the fright-fest.
item.content:encoded:
American Horror Story may only be six episodes into its first season, but FX made the decision to make an early renewal for a second season of the fright-fest. Signing on for a second season of 13 episodes this early means that the cable channel has some high hopes for the show. The Wednesday night horror series is tracking to become the highest-rated series ever for FX. This isn’t a surprise for a show coming from the two people who were pivotal for the success of Nip/Tuck, one of FX’s first smash hits.

The renewal may have felt a little like a leap of faith for the FX Network as they were in the middle of possibly losing one of their largest carriers- DirecTV. If you were watching the show as the episodes were airing at the time, you would have seen Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk pleading with viewers during commercial breaks. Thankfully, Fox and DirecTV made a last minute deal to keep all of the channels under the Fox banner on the air.

If you haven’t been watching American Horror Story yet, it is definitely worth giving it a moment of your time. Upon moving to a new home in Los Angeles to escape the troubled life in Boston, the Harmons find themselves with a more complicated set of circumstances with their new home. Unbeknownst to them, the home came with some things that previous owners left behind. I can’t recommend just jumping into it as you will be lost beyond belief. Without going into depth why, let’s just say that the writing is aimed for the long run. We have just begun to see how deeply disturbing the tale of the Harmons is.

Read the full press release below:

AMERICAN HORROR STORY FANS GET HALLOWEEN TREAT, NOT TRICKS

New Hit Drama from Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk Gets Second Season Order

Tracking to Become Highest Rated 1st Season of Any FX Series

Four-Episode Halloween Marathon Airs Tonight at 10:00 PM ET/PT

Nine All-New Episodes Remain in Season One

LOS ANGELES, October 31, 2011 – Fans of American Horror Story got a Halloween treat today from FX as the network placed a second-season order of 13 episodes from Twentieth Century Fox Television, announced John Landgraf, President and General Manager, FX Networks.

American Horror Story, created by producers Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk, is the eighth FX drama series to earn a second season order. Nine all-new episodes of AHS remain in the first season airing Wednesdays at 10:00 PM E/P, with the final two episodes airing December 21.

“It’s one thing to have the ambition and guts to reinvent a genre in a way that makes it captivatingly fresh for a broad audience–it’s something else entirely to have the craft to back that ambition up,” said Landgraf. “Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk have hit the trifecta with Nip/Tuck, Glee and now American Horror Story, which will be scaring FX’s viewers to death for many years to come.”

AHS is producing outstanding ratings, growing though its first four weeks in the network’s target audience of Adults 18-49. On a Live+7 basis, through two weeks, first-run episodes of AHS are averaging 4.2 million Total Viewers, 2.9 million Adults 18-49, and 1.7 million Adults 18-34. It is currently tracking to become the highest-rated first season of any series ever on FX, certain to surpass Murphy’s award-winning hit drama Nip/Tuck in Adults 18-49 and Adults 18-34 (2.1 million Adults 18-49; 1.0 million Adults 18-34 – 2003), and also above the award-winning drama Justified in Total Viewers (3.4 million P2+ – 2009).

On a Live+3 basis, last week’s fourth episode was the highest-rated episode of the season in delivery of Adults 18-49 (3.1 million) and Adults 18-34 (1.85 million).

The premiere episode of AHS (most current available) delivered a multi-run telecast audience of 8.0 million Total Viewers, 5.4 million Adults 18-34 and 3.0 million Adults 18-34.

The series premiere episode of AHS (Oct. 5, 10:00 PM) ranked as the #1 for the network among its target demos of Adults 18-49 and Adults 18-34. It delivered 3.14 million Adults 18-49 and 1.77 million Adults 18-34, which marked enormous gains of +54% and +49% in those demos when compared to the Live+Same Day premiere data. The debut episode of AHS also ranks #1 all-time among FX series premieres in delivery of Women 18-49 and Women 18-34.

Tonight beginning at 10:00 PM E/P, FX will air a special Halloween marathon of American Horror Story featuring the first four episodes. In this Wednesday’s (Nov. 2, 10:00PM E/P) fifth episode, “Halloween, Part 2″, Halloween night concludes with Tate (Evan Peters) coming face-to-face with his past, and Ben (Dylan McDermott) and Vivien (Connie Britton) are haunted by one of the house’s newest guests.

American Horror Story revolves around the Harmons, a family of three who moved from Boston to Los Angeles as a means to reconcile past anguish. The all-star cast features Dylan McDermott as “Ben Harmon,” a psychiatrist; Connie Britton as “Vivien Harmon,” Ben’s wife; Taissa Farmiga as “Violet,” the Harmon’s teenage daughter; Jessica Lange in her first-ever regular series TV role as “Constance,” the Harmon’s neighbor; Evan Peters plays “Tate Langdon,” one of Ben’s patients; and Denis O’Hare as “Larry Harvey.” Guest stars for the series include Frances Conroy as the Harmon’s housekeeper; Alexandra Breckenridge as the Harmon’s housekeeper; and Jamie Brewer as Constance’s daughter.

American Horror Story was co-created by Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk, who serve as Executive Producers along with Dante Di Loreto. The series is produced by Twentieth Century Fox Television.

Led by Chairmen Gary Newman and Dana Walden, Twentieth Century Fox Television is the prolific producer of a wide range of award-winning blockbuster network and cable series including “Glee,” the two-time Golden Globe winner for Best Series, Comedy or Musical and “Modern Family,” the two-time Emmy winner for Outstanding Comedy Series. Twentieth Century Fox Television comprises the flagship studio, as well as sister companies Fox 21 and Fox Television Studios, and currently has more than thirty series on the air domestically and around the globe.

FX is the flagship general entertainment basic cable network from the Fox Networks Group. Launched in June of 1994, FX is carried in more than 98 million homes. The diverse schedule includes a growing roster of critically acclaimed and award-winning original series, an established film library with box-office hits from 20th Century Fox and other studios and an impressive roster of acquired hit series. For more information about FX, visit our web site at www.FXnetworks.com.

Source – TV by the Numbers / New York Times

item.title: 20SON Guest Post – Midnight Game Store Events Protocol
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Gameflood, Gamepocalypse, Gamevalanche, call this typhoon of titles what you will, it’s overwhelming. As a student, I barely have enough money for all these games, let alone enough time. As the employee of a gaming retail store, I barely have enough patience.
item.content:encoded:
Gameflood, Gamepocalypse, Gamevalanche, call this typhoon of titles what you will, it’s overwhelming. As a student, I barely have enough money for all these games, let alone enough time. As the employee of a gaming retail store, I barely have enough patience.

No, not just because of customers. I deal with difficult people on a daily basis, it’s part of any retail job. The real thorn in my side is a subset of a subset of customers. The larger subset is those who attend midnight launches, the smaller subset are those who partake in some atrociously frustrating activities while attending these midnight launches. So, if you’re going to a midnight launch (like the many occurring this evening), I’ve got some helpful do’s and don’ts to make sure you don’t get on the bad side of your local game store employee.

DON’T bang on the front doors before the store opens.

Seriously. When you do this, you don’t look like an obnoxious tool, you are an obnoxious tool. How would you like it if someone came to your house before you were ready to wake up and just started ringing your doorbell and banging on your door? You wouldn’t, and while we’re not sleeping in there, we’re still working, and if we aren’t working, we’re inhaling before we have to repeat the same schpiel 200 times over the course of 2 hours. Cut us some slack. We may not be a skilled trade, but retail is a shitty job sometimes, and it makes us feel good when the person on the other side of the counter isn’t a dick.

DON’T be indecisive.

I hate this type of person the most. Most corporate instructions state that you are actually allowed to browse around for whatever you want, but as the person who has to wait for you, I hate your guts. This goes for being indecisive about most anything (for example, collector’s edition, console, scratch guarantee). We have to serve lots of people other than you, and normally it’s OK to browse, but now is not the time! Know what you want, get in, get out, and go home to play your damn game so that we can do the same!

DO be friendly.

I cannot stress this enough. We’re tired. It’s midnight, we don’t really want to be here for very long. We’re doing this as a courtesy to you. In fact, a large majority of midnight launches are done at the discretion of the manager and staff, so a “thank you” wouldn’t hurt. Being chatty but not overbearing is also a plus. Everybody likes to be engaged at work so it’s perfectly fine to make jokes, talk about the games, all that stuff. We often thrive in environments where we can engage with our own culture, so the time passes by faster, and you (usually) get some good conversation.

DO be patient.

Really, this should be in a shopping 101 textbook. It isn’t limited to midnight launches, but it’s especially important at them. We have an immediate influx of customers, but we still have to tell you about all of our add-ons and whatnot. Honestly, most of us will suggest things that we think would be of use to you, so don’t interrupt us (again, we want to get out of there as much as you), and politely say “no” if you’re not interested. It’s really that simple, there’s no need to tell me how stupid those gaming glasses are, or how expensive the headset is. I KNOW. I recommended it either because a) there’s a promotion to save YOU money, b) because I believe it would enhance your enjoyment of the game, or c) both. (editor’s note: there are situations where the employee is required by corporate direction to suggest an add-on, like Applecare at Apple Stores. If you don’t want it, don’t be a dick about it, just politely say no)

DON’T say I’m only recommending something because I want your money.

We’re a god damn retail store, of course we want your money, what rock have you been living under? Wanting your money does not preclude wanting you to have the best possible experience with your new game. I take pride in knowing that people are getting an enhanced experience by means of a product I recommended. We live in a society fueled by money, expecting me to not care about making money is ridiculous, but don’t think that wanting your money means I’m blind to what you actually want (though I did see you eyeing that Hello Kitty DS case, It’s only 24.99!).

DO have fun.

This is definitely the most important thing. If we aren’t creating an environment for fun, then why are we doing a midnight? I know some stores are different, choosing to be apathetic about the new games, but specialty gaming stores like mine take a lot of pride in fostering a community of customers and creating an event for them. That’s what midnight launches should be about: celebrating the launch of your anticipated game with fun, (maybe) food, and friends.

So whichever game you’re picking up tonight (there are about 7 of them coming out), or whenever you go to a midnight launch, remember these rules, and you’ll be well on your way to becoming a fondly-remembered customer, which is a lot better than being the grumpy storm cloud that all your local game store employees curse. Happy gaming.

-Das Kalk

item.title: Ratfist Collection Taken to Print By Image Comics
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Now that Mr. TenNapel as put a wrap on his story of human exploration, it has been announced that it will be going into print. Image Comics stepped into to publish Ratfist as a 176 page graphic novel with all of the glory of the comic as it appeared on the Internet.
item.content:encoded:
If you haven’t heard of Doug TenNapel, think back to some of the days of your childhood. Had you owned a Sega Genesis, you would definitely remember a body of work that he was responsible for. A mutated worm living in a space suit perhaps? Ringing any bells? If you were at all interested by Earthworm Jim, you’ll be happy to know that his creator’s newest comic creation found a home on the web. Ratfist, a 150 page opus, tells the tale of Ricky (aka Ratfist) and his misbegotten super hero adventures with partners Milt and his uh, rather unique form of conscious. In a story that combines comedy, deceit, action, and a heaping pile of weirdness, Ratfist should entertain just about anyone.

Now that Mr. TenNapel as put a wrap on his story of human exploration, it has been announced that it will be going into print. Image Comics stepped into to publish Ratfist as a 176 page graphic novel with all of the glory of the comic as it appeared on the Internet. TenNapel had this to say when asked how he felt about it being put out by Image, “I’m so thrilled that this can join the line up of books I’ve brought to Image,” said TenNapel. “I hope those that missed it when I was publishing online get to pick it up now in print!” For those of you who think that they’ve seen everything offered on the comic’s website, you’ll be a little mistaken. Art by some other big names, including Ethan Nicole and Skottie Young, has been added to the collection. Look for it at shop near you starting December 14th.

Regardless if you are interested in Ratfist coming to print or not, you need to read it. As in go do it right now. It’s a comic on the web for free. What’s stopping you?

Source – Image Comics

item.title: 20SON Review – World of Keflings and It Came From Outer Space DLC (XBLA)
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Kings in video games are dicks. Go here, fetch that, kill rats, make a massive ball of things you roll over, go save the princess. What does the King in World of Keflings want you to do, and is it any fun?
item.content:encoded:
Kings in video games are dicks. Go here, fetch that, kill rats, make a massive ball of things you roll over, go save the princess. What do you get for your service to the crown? Usually a trinket or two, maybe a pittance of gold. World of Keflings has a King. Perhaps if he realized the non-trivial nature of his castle building tasks, maybe he’d throw you a freaking bone or something. World of Keflings, the second title in the series from NinjaBee was released in January, well before this podcast even started. Just before Halloween, the first downloadable content for it, the “It Came From Outer Space” alien-themed world pack shipped. We already know from a previous title that the Keflings are all about doing your bidding so you can provide a palatial estate for the King, but how deep does the game get?

Most of your game is here in the forest world. At least mine was.

Any given Keflings title is an exercise in resource harvesting and management. Any Keflings title can be simply described as a light version of later Sim City titles. Playing as your xBox Live avatar you send your minions, the Keflings, out to collect, harvest, or otherwise gather construction materials so you can ultimately build a castle for the Kefling King. While accumulating these materials your goal is to build your buildings and advance along a rudimentary technology tree. During all of this gathering and building, various tasks pop up allowing you to collect more advanced blueprints to construct fantastical structures on your way to build the castle. As far as construction sandboxes go World of Keflings is low-stress. There are no significant disasters, no alien invasions, or dragon attacks (although one will perch menacingly forcing you to shoo it away to build what and how you want). Nothing else really goes on to disturb your path to victory.

There are resources to be had in the desert too.

All is not total harmony. Keflings are lazy creatures. If your charges are being slothful, a swift kick or slap atop the head will set them right. In an interesting feature, if a slap atop the head is delivered properly, it can level up your builder! About the most trouble you can have in the game is if a miscreant joins over xBox Live and decides to destroy your buildings. If you are hosting, you have the power to dispatch the miscreant from whence they came. If you as the host quit or are disconnected, whoever is selected as the host gets to save the progress and call it their own. Seems reasonable, but please, don’t feed the trolls. Don’t rage quit on griefers and reward their behavior- just boot them! If you’re not feeling like hitting the wilds of the internet for companions, World of Keflings does allow you to venture forth split screen with buddy. I heartily endorse this method- face to face communications are simpler and less prone to miscommunication. Plus, if you’re a guy trying to get his gaming-hostile girl into gaming, a Keflings title is an excellent starting point.

Keflings in Spaaaaace!

With the release of the October DLC, there are now four primary Kefling worlds. You start the game frozen in an ice block in the tundra, and gradually repair the portals to the other worlds. The Forest world is the most similar to Kingdom of Keflings. The desert has been added to the main game. It Came from Outer Space has been added by the DLC, and has it’s own goals unique to itself. Rather than directly influencing the castle construction underway, you have to gather different resources than in the main game to assist in the repair of a crashed space ship. I found that even with the space world’s goal being right in my gaming wheelhouse I spent most of my time in the Forest world, if for no other reasons than plentiful large trees and the overarching goal of building the King his castle. I found the desert too sparse and small to be that productive, and the new space world, while entertaining, was a bit arduous to build on given it’s convoluted layout and odd placement of resources. I found myself, for lack of a better term, strip mining resources or clear cutting space forests to be able to access the entire map. NinjaBee is pretty good at checks and balances in game design, so this is probably a design choice. As a player, I felt a bit constrained by this.

If you own one Keflings title, and are just a casual fan of no conflict world building games, you’re probably set with the version you have. If you’re on the fence, then World of Keflings is the go-to title between the two. If you’re a fan of NinjaBee or the Keflings, then it’s probably worth owning both titles. If you’ve got to have violence with your world building, avoid any Kefling title- it’s just not how NinjaBee is rolling with this franchise! The It Came from Outer Space DLC, while not a perfect add-on world does as it promises. For 320 points, it adds about three hours to the overall length of the game. As a bonus, it is graphically interesting and differentiated from the other worlds. World of Keflings is a good God-style game, regardless of which version you own, be it Kingdom or World.

item.title: 20SON Review – Sengoku (PC)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Every now and then I see a hardcore strategy game that looks appealing to me. I don't know why it is, but there is something that pulls me into the depth of the world that they create. When I noticed Sengoku came in for review, I decide that I would give it a go. I had been eyeing it for sometime as I had let Total War: Shogun II pass by earlier in the year. Feudal Japan is one of those points in history that feels just ripe for today's market. I couldn't wait to see what it would be like to have my own kuni and fly a clan banner. Thing is, I think that Paradox Interactive might have gone a little too far with this one.
item.content:encoded:
Every now and then I see a hardcore strategy game that looks appealing to me. I don’t know why it is, but there is something that pulls me into the depth of the world that they create. When I noticed Sengoku came in for review, I decide that I would give it a go. I had been eyeing it for sometime as I had let Total War: Shogun II pass by earlier in the year. Feudal Japan is one of those points in history that feels just ripe for today’s market. I couldn’t wait to see what it would be like to have my own kuni and fly a clan banner. Thing is, I think that Paradox Interactive might have gone a little too far with this one.

In Sengoku you take on the role of clan leader in this point in history, around 1400 AD to be more specific. You rule your demesne that you’ve chose based on location in the country. Your goal – to control 50% to Japan in order to be granted the title of Shogun. This is done through a variety of diplomatic endeavors, gift giving, war, and even assassination. How you choose to do it in the end will be up to you. Just don’t expect to be able to avoid diplomacy.

Attempting to battle for new lands isn't as simple as walking over to them and attacking. Balancing defenses, army size and type, as well as morale become parts of the equation.

Firing up Sengoku for the first time made everything seem really simple and straight forward. The menus are simple- select your option and move forward without any fuss. Even when setting up a single player game, it gave you a lot of the information you would need to know. You could launch a scenario that would have presets already figured out for you. Land was already divided among the clans, tensions between clans were calculated, and difficulties were figured with those items in mind. Controls could also be considered just as easy as most things were controlled by the mouse, with hot keys and alt-clicks to cover all of your other needs. So everything seemed good to go, right? Click start and get to your land ruling. Not so fast, there seems to be something missing. A full tutorial.

Windows such as the one pictured often appear when clicking through random things when you start playing Sengoku. This is about all you get for guidance from the title- a mash-up of half information.

Most games have a tutorial built into the beginning missions or a part that must be completed prior to moving on to the real parts of the game. This ensures that the player has a rudimentary understanding of how the game is to be played. There is no such thing in Sengoku. You are tossed into your region with no idea what the hell to do. To be fair, there are tool tips that cover just about every option you can click into in the control bar. The problem is, there are some things it just doesn’t explain to the person at the keyboard. After tinkering with it for a few games, you can get the gist. I’m sure a bit more assistance would have helped at the start though. Even the power of the Internet yielded few tips other than suggested build paths.

And that takes us to the crux of what I would say is wrong with Sengoku. The learning curve is brutal. This goes beyond the previous problem of not knowing how it functions, but into the heart of the game. There are over 400 unique characters in the game. Guess what- you are going to have to maintain your relationships with them all. There are some easy fixes like marriage, land and title grants, and the almighty gold coin. Then you have examine the perks of the characters and how you view them to see if there is risk for revolt. That only solves so many problems. Then, if you are at war, there are whole different sets of things that you need to hand hold; such as searching for wandering ronin to bolster you armies, creating plots against other clans, and even inciting discontent in your neighbor’s lands. You only have three cabinet members to help you do all this. Each cabinet member holds a specific skill set for homeland development/defense, creating favorable faction relationships, and trying to undermine other provinces. It almost makes the whole thing overwhelming. Way too many things to micromanage. So many in fact, that it makes it seem like all you are doing the entire game.

Menus will probably be the thing you end up looking at the most as you start your eternal diplomatic balancing act. Good thing they are clear, easy to read, and offer all the details you could want.

That isn’t to say that everything is horrible or wretched about Sengoku. Most of my complaints about the title would most likely be seen as something positive to the people that this game is marketed to, and that is probably the biggest problem. Sengoku will not find a home with casual players. It is a deep, deep strategy game. Meticulous and long term planning are actually encouraged to ensure victory. In the future, it would have paid off to plot in order to gain footholds with other territories. I would think it creates a scenario to be a hardcore strategist’s wet dream, especially if they are history buffs.

You'll find out many times that you bit off more than you can chew when you start trying to take over by force. You can choose to retreat or wait for reinforcements to arrive. Remember that your troops are traveling across Japan, so it will take some time to get there.

Everything is aimed to be period accurate, from the music to the artwork. Even the UI is weathered a little to make it appear not so out of time and place. They often are clear and a bonus to the point enough to add to the experience. Provinces are split to the appropriate political and geographical boundaries. Characters are even dressed for the times. The look and feel of the game is well beyond what a person would normally expect for such a title. The maps that everything takes place on are beautiful. That goes for all of the five different options you have to look at too. Be it color coding by empire or the very well detailed topographical look.

The maps created for Sengoku were just beautiful. By spinning the camera around and getting different views of the scenery, you really developed an appreciation for them.

From the start I could tell that Sengoku was going to be a title that had a very niche audience. While I could see the strengths for the title, I considered many of them to be a negative from my personal standpoint. That said, this is from someone who spends their working life in a finance department. The last thing I want to do when I get home is start plugging away at something that reminds me of working on spreadsheets. To really appreciate Sengoku a gamer will have to have the copious amount of time it takes to learn and master, and the will to manage everything down to some of the finite details that have been implemented. Does that mean it is a bad game? No, not at all. It just lacks some of the basics to make it accessible for everyone. Paradox has a tendency to create these limited scope games. I really wish they would look towards gamers as a whole. Sengoku has the ability to be the next logical step from RTS games into something with a little more thought. Until the curve is somewhat less steep, it may as well to the honorable thing and throw itself on its sword.

Game provided by developer for review

item.title: 20SON Review – Delve Deeper (PC)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: There is something that I don’t get when it comes to our societal love for the characters we create in fantasy settings. It seems like often people aim to be elves, other worldly creatures, or even great human heroes that they could never been in this day in age. You know who always gets left the short end of the stick? Dwarves. You hardly see anyone playing our fierce-hearted bearded brethren in a serious manner. Sure, The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings series had their share of dwarves. Ask yourself this though; didn’t they just play second fiddle to the Hobbits? With the sheer number of characters you would have thought that someone would have been important enough for some face time. And those dwarves with Snow White? No chance either. Even the Kender from the Dragonlance universe got more dues. It is possible that they might have a shot at redemption. Lunar Giant Studios aimed to garner them some respect with their adventure/strategy game Delve Deeper.
item.content:encoded:
There is something that I don’t get when it comes to our societal love for the characters we create in fantasy settings. It seems like often people aim to be elves, other worldly creatures, or even great human heroes that they could never been in this day in age. You know who always gets left the short end of the stick? Dwarves. You hardly see anyone playing our fierce-hearted bearded brethren in a serious manner. Sure, The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings series had their share of dwarves. Ask yourself this though; didn’t they just play second fiddle to the Hobbits? With the sheer number of characters you would have thought that someone would have been important enough for some face time. And those dwarves with Snow White? No chance either. Even the Kender from the Dragonlance universe got more dues. It is possible that they might have a shot at redemption. Lunar Giant Studios aimed to garner them some respect with their adventure/strategy game Delve Deeper.  

Well, respect might not be the correct word in this case. Not since Dwarf Fortress have we had the focal point of a game feature our hearty warriors and workers from under the mountains in anything resembling a starring role. The King pulls the focus back to himself– I mean his people with a royal decree! In his gobbledy goop sort of language he demands to his subjects that he is in need of more wealth! As he is your liege, the duties fall upon you and your group of five miners, scouts and fighters. Where does one go to get said wealth for the King? The natural place for dwarves to look, mines! You will dig deep into the mountains, creating tunnels, harvesting precious gems and metals, and discovering long lost treasures. Piece of cake, right? Not so! There are other teams of subjects trying to lay claim to the vast riches. They’ll be all rough and tumble about it too as all bets are off when it comes to getting the King what he wants. There will also be a fight coming from the denizens of the underground consisting of goblins, gnomes, evil dwarves and even dragons.

Relics can deliver a bigger bonus to the King's coffers. They could also been a boon to your existence.

Delve Deeper is a really straight forward turn based strategy game. Each team alternates a set of three different phases in order to gather the most glistening purities for their newly commissioned, kingly coffers. First is the digging phase where you must select a pre-set tile to place on an appropriate blank spot on the map. There are three different tiers of tunnels depending on the ground you are tunneling into. Those make up depths of dirt, stone and deep. Step number two is where all the strategic positioning takes place. During this time, you move around your five guys to either be in a position to pick at the walls to collect wealth, fight, explore, or turn in the trip’s haul. Once you are done there, you move to the third and final stage- collection! Here all your items are added to your dwarf’s inventories, counted when they are turned in at your lift or gnome exchange, or remain on their person if the squad members are slackers. Depending on the map, you can start at 14 turns or stretch it as far as 25. Fighting comes after the monsters take their movement. Pretty simple turn order wouldn’t you say?

The board gives you plenty of options when placing a tile during the first phase of your turn. Remember, your object is to get the richest minerals from the deepest parts of the map.

To go along with a simple game play, the graphics are easy on the eyes. Delve Deeper doesn’t need to be the flashiest thing on the planet. It only needed enough graphics to get the point across. Using a traditional 2D look with animated characters does just the trick. The best way I can describe how the characters look is Super Nintendo-era sprites just punched up some more. I’d almost liken the dwarves and their actions to that of a fancier version of Golden Axe on the arcade. Textures, like the dirt and stone, is not unlike many games from the late 90s. They are much better looking, but have that classic clods of dirt thrown together look. Overall the shading, lighting, and coloring are better than what we’d expect from something almost 20 years ago.

This is not a bad thing.

The fighting portion of the game moves through pretty quickly. The King will heckle everyone along the way, but really it is in good fun.

The best part about Delve Deeper has to be that it doesn’t take itself too seriously. If you can imagine if a gerbil and murloc had a baby, that’s what the King sounds like. Yeah, that’s right. Get that image out of your head. To go along with that, Delve Deeper isn’t afraid of a cheap joke or bad pun. Dwarves are assigned random names like Tom and MacDuck, but also some common dwarf names from fiction. Every team name the game comes up with is just silly. It even extends as far as the relic names and abilities. The game reserves the special kind of naming hell for the gnome wizards though. Sir Bedwetter? Tell me he wasn’t mocked at wizard school. The King is always cracking wise when things happen as well, like death or if a player turns in a treasure. Even with how goofy the game can be, the comedy doesn’t distract from the simple strategy. Thinking out your steps rarely goes past the actual movement phase. It is a smart move to make sure that you end up at something you can mine at the end of your movement points. AI is setup so the computer controlled players will always seek out a fight if it is something they can reach during their movement phase. The touch here adds that little spark of excitement where it is needed.

This is the perfect example of just how obsurd some of the naming can be in Delve Deeper. I'm shocked the team name wasn't "My Five Bruces."

Thankfully, Delve Deeper doesn’t suffer much at the hand of flaws either. During my testing, there were only two that I ran into. The first will be a big one if people don’t choose to take sixty seconds or less to do some Internet searches if bought on Steam. For whatever reason, Steam doesn’t like to launch the C++ distributable package after you download and launch for the first time. The files are downloaded to the game directory, just not executed when you start the game. The other flaw is a very tiny one. During the review every time I would take a screenshot the game would switch from a windowed mode to being full screen. A command to bring the game to full screen is bound to the universal Steam screenshot key. Doing it too many times will also make the game crash. Correcting this is as easy as re-assigning the command in your Steam settings to something that isn’t used in the game.  

Hooray, confetti! I won! Notice how even the losers get a nifty title.

All in all, Delve Deeper is a tremendously fun game. It’s a game that will have you laughing at just how harebrained it can be. The value of such fun looks even greater when you look at the piddly amount it costs. On Steam you can pick up the original game with the Treasures and Tunnels expansion for only $5.49. Treasures and Tunnels added 10 levels and 25 new relics to the game. Not bad for $1.00. If you’d like to get it from other sources, look no further than direct from Lunar Giant for $5.00. It is well worth that price. It makes me a little sad that this isn’t on the iTunes store. Delve Deeper would easily make a killing as an iOS game. We have spoken with the developer regarding this, and while there are no plans to make Delve Deeper an iOS title, they are in the opening stages of its sequel Delve Deeper: The Deepening. The Deepening may end up on the iOS. Graphics, gameplay, and comedy have most any other casual title beat with just those features. Also, this game can be setup in a window on a second monitor. You could easily take your turns while your raid prepares for a fight or are waiting for everyone to run back after a wipe. Lunar Giant struck it rich with Delve Deeper. An accessible game was built that is easy to grasp, fun, and should have you chuckling as you dig on. Dig in! (See what I did there?)

Game provided by developer.

item.title: Episode 38 – Should We Really Talk About This?
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description:
Man. Sometimes, it's better to talk about controversial topics at the end of a podcast to inject humor into the situation, sometimes it's not. You be the judge, and apologies in advance. Mr Meyagi from the Spirits of Fire joined us for just about an hour of tomfoolery.
Topics covered include: Nearly $1800 for Call of Duty, a day early, Mr. Meyagi's Battlefield experience, Call of Duty Elite not ready for the PC on ship date, We talk about the iSpank again, for some reason, Thinkgeek is giving away a $1000 shopping spree, Front Towards Gamer is doing Veterans Month and what this means to you, The Humble Voxatron Debut (bundle for charity), Lots of Minecraft sold with resultant Draeno lamentations, Righthaven is finally being taken to task for being douchebags, Nook tablet leak (as it turns out, is correct), Stories of the Pawnshop, starring Mr. Meyagi, Kindle Amazon Prime ebook lending, Welcome back fake Mars astronauts, We ponder AOL lifers, A devout Star Wars fan strangles his wife to death for damaging his collection

item.title: 20SON Manifesto – How We Do Our Reviews
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: A few big name game journalists are lamenting the state of our hobby and their profession. I'd like to clear up a few points about how we do things here at 20SON.
item.content:encoded:
I’ve had a few emails from listeners after we “aired” the most recent episode of the podcast in regards to our reviews. A couple of big-name game journalists are lamenting the state of our hobby and their profession as well. So, I guess it was an interesting week to talk about how we do reviews here at 20SON. I’d like to clear up a few points.

What We’ll Review:
Honestly, we try and find time to review everything we get our grubby little mitts on, whether it’s been provided for us for review or we purchased it. We do try and acquire review product for the site by emailing press contacts to see what we can get that either we’re interested in, or we think our readership/listenership might find entertaining to find out about. We do not change our review methodology between products we received for review from the publisher or products we purchase ourselves. We do state at the tail end of a review if we purchased the item ourselves, or if it was provided to us by the publisher as required by 16 CFR Part 255.

How We Review:
Both Draeno and I grew up knowing that anything was worth playing, if even for a single moment of fun. Sure, we’ve played some overall turkeys, but even the turkeys have some good points- it’s just a matter of finding them, and knowing what we’d want to pay for them. There are good games and bad, just like there are good movies and bad, but good and bad is all relative. The difference between a good movie and bad is whether or not you catch it in the theater, rent it from iTunes, buy it on DVD, or wait until it’s on HBO. We here at 20SON think that there’s a similar equation for games. We do try to let you know what the ideal market for a game or product is, and who should buy it now, and what groups or tastes should wait to buy on sale, on steep sale, or just play the demo.

“Why no scores, man?”
Scores are arbitrary. Besides, what’s the scale? Does a scale of 1-5 equate to the 50-100 percent ratings on most sites, or is the 1-5 scale equate to the 1-100 scale. How do you judge the scale? What’s a game that rates a 1 or a 5? Is there even a perfect game? Will a “perfect” game today still be perfect in a year? All of these factors make percentages, starts, skulls, or what have you completely arbitrary and of little use. If we do a review this week, we want you to be able to google the review in a year, and it still have applicability, and we don’t think a percent/star system makes this any clearer. It is true that some of our reviews are syndicated on other venues and they do have stars or percentages. Those are applied as per the requirements of the syndicated site. We retain our value and market paragraph on reviews of ours that you see elsewhere.

“You’re very positive with your reviews.”
Every product we review here is looked at with the same critical eye, regardless of source. We’re a small outfit, with many demands on our time both personally and professionally outside of the 20SON website. Draeno and I are the primary writers, with periodic help from a few others who we clearly identify. If a review says “20SON Review”, then Draeno or I wrote the review. The writer of a guest review is clearly stated. These reviews are edited by either Draeno or I prior to publication. We do prioritize products we purchase or request for review on existing interests, the same as you do. We won’t buy anything we don’t want to personally play. While we’ll still review Barbie’s Horse Adventure III if we’re provided it, we’d prefer to be reviewing something like Dungeon Defenders or Space Marine as they’re more our cup of tea. As such, we don’t have many negative sounding reviews, at least not yet. We’re not listed in Metacritic, nor are we likely to ever be.

The Bottom Line:
We’re two guys on the internet, writing about what appeals to us. We’ve got opinions about stuff, and we hope you like reading them or hearing us discuss them in the beginning of your week. Neither of us are particularly fond of scores on reviews, so we don’t do them here, but we do periodically have to add them depending on demands from us from other press outlets. You won’t see scores here, though.

We’re going to tell you what we think about something, no matter where we got it from. We’ll tell you if we think it blows, even if it’s an unpopular opinion.

item.title: 20SON Review – Fisher Price Laugh and Play Apptivity iDevice Case
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: This "toy" has caught a lot of flak from parenting groups saying that giving your toddler a $300 iDevice isn't a good idea, but let's look at it a little closer.
item.content:encoded:
There’s a child in the house that covets my iPhone like nothing else. He has an assortment of favorite toys and other things, but as soon as the phone comes out, it’s like he’s possessed by the ghost of Steve. He lunges, he dives, and throws a bit of a fit if he isn’t allowed to at least handle it for a minute. I don’t have dropped calls from AT+T, I have disconnections caused by little fingers grasping at the device. We do have some apps for him that he greatly enjoys so this longing isn’t entirely his doing. I suppose we could give him an old original iPhone that’s laying about but I’m not comfortable with the amount of time he thinks that the noise of any toy hitting the nearby hard floor is a good thing. Enter the Laugh and Play Apptivity case by Fisher Price. This “toy” has caught a lot of flak from parenting groups saying that giving your toddler a $300 iDevice isn’t a good idea, but let’s look at it a little closer.


Just bear with me for a few paragraphs before you go all nutty on me and think that this case isn’t really good fodder for review here at 20SON. Both of your primary hosts here are parents of reasonably young children, and we probably are impressing our nerdiness on them as we go. I suspect the aforementioned lust for the iPhone is related to this impression. The case is well built like nearly everything Fisher Price makes. A soft removable carriage holds whichever iPod Touch or iPhone model you may have. Depending on orientation of the phone in the carriage, the home button is either accessible or blocked until the phone is removed from the case. Since our primary tester isn’t even two years old, we’ve chosen to obstruct the home button. The carriage is mounted inside the case proper. A thin plastic conductive sheet protects the device from “accidental” milk or juice spills as well as fingers covered with any manner of kid goo. A few chew rings adorn rubberized handles for the device. These handles also serve as additional shock protection in the (likely) event of an airborne case.

The case disassembled. iPhone or iPod touch not included.

Overall, just about every consideration for young people’s use of an iPod is taken into account, minus a couple. There is no way to charge the device while in the case. Also, the sleep/wake button is completely obscured. A simple hole lined up through the case allowing insertion of the old standby, a straightened paperclip or other such thin spudger would have been great to allow for routine shutdown of the device. The plastic block for the home button is mounted above the protective screen coating. So, in the event of the juice spill we spoke of before, liquid will, and does, get in between the screen coating and the home button blocker. There’s a lot of plastic between the speaker and the outside of the case, so you really have to jack up the volume. None of these are deal breakers. If you need this case, there is literally no other alternative.

The gorilla in the room is the appropriateness of an iPhone like device for a toddler or young child. Whether or not your kid can use and be enriched by an iPhone and the iOS application ecosystem is an exercise for you, the reader. I’m certainly not suggesting you give your child full unrestricted use of the internet at a tender young age, but I’m also not going to suggest what that young age might be. This device is the ultimate in ruggedized cases if you choose to allow your child to have supervised access to an iOS device. There are steps you can take to limit your young one’s use, and with any media or technology, I suggest making a calm and rational decision based on the facts and developmental age of your child. Child specialists (or technology bloggers) have no business making these decisions for you. In any event, the Fisher Price Laugh and Play Apptivity case will protect the device that you insert in it from normal abuse, but will still require you to supervise the user. In our case, it didn’t completely prevent the tackling that we get when we use an iPhone in the vicinity of our little boy, but it does cut down on it, and just for the cost the case and a first generation iPhone not in use that one of our podcast guests said that all we’d get for a trade in is a “nod and hug from a smelly (technology store) employee.” I’m happy to repurpose this device for the educational needs of my child in conjunction with this case.

item.title: Guest Review – Rocketbirds: Hardboiled Chicken
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Rocketbirds straps you onto a jet pack, starts up some energizing rock music and let's you loose in this 2D flipscreen game. In Rocketbirds, you play Hard Boiled Chicken, a seemingly invincible revolutionary figure, fighting back against the oppressing, Communist Penguin regime. A good looking, though seemingly short game, Rocketbirds is an enjoyable game with a few downfalls.
item.content:encoded:
Rocketbirds straps you onto a jet pack, starts up some energizing rock music and let’s you loose in this 2D flipscreen game. In Rocketbirds, you play Hard Boiled Chicken, a seemingly invincible revolutionary figure, fighting back against the oppressing, Communist Penguin regime. A good looking, though seemingly short game, Rocketbirds is an enjoyable game with a very few downfalls.

Get Putzski!

The first thing you’ll notice when you begin to play Rocketbirds is its clean animations, overlayed with some trendy rock music. Thanks to it’s partnership with New World Revolution, a self-proclaimed Science Fiction Rock band, Rocketbirds has a pretty neat soundtrack that fits right in with the game. Rocketbirds uses these scenes between levels to help flesh out some of the backstory of Hard Boiled Chicken’s and does a good job at it. Despite not having any lines during these parts, the animations were well thought out, and you quickly begin to realize what Hard Boiled has been through. Unfortunately, there are a few scenes of dialogue, which is disappointing because the voice acting, whether intentional or not, is terrible and is a stark contrast to the rest of the game.

Gameplay for Rocketbirds is split up into two different parts; travelling on foot and jet packing. For the most part, though, you’ll be on foot, travelling throughout a few different locales, fighting off the Penguin menace, and solving a few, rather easy puzzles that only seem to serve to break up the pace between combat, not to offer a challenge. You’ll be required in almost every level to find key cards, which will unlock other doors, to find different colored key cards, which will finally open a door that ends the level. Even with this backtracking gameplay, Rocketbirds just feels short, allowing you to unlock a few different chapters in what seems to be no time at all.

BOOM! Shotgun!

The combat in Rocketbirds may also leave something to be desired. You’re given a few different weapons, starting out with a pistol and leading up to a machine gun, with which to take out the Penguins and their thugs. This essentially leads to you standing on one side of the screen, shooting across and “juggling” one or two baddies with your weapon of choice or running away when you’re outnumbered. The problem is, if you get shot, you fall over. If you happen to have enemies on both sides of you, you’ll die quickly in an unstoppable barrage of bullets and the inability to stand for longer than half a second. It does try to introduce a cover system, using darkness to blend in with a wall, and therefore stand on a different plane, which allows you to not be hit by oncoming bullets. This is used sporadically in the first few levels, and a couple levels at the end, leaving you to try and roll your way to one side of the screen, and attempting to juggle every enemy you come across. Near the end of the game, Rocketbirds introduces elite penguins. These penguins are armed with assault rifles, and have the annoying ability to be able to shoot past their comrades, leaving you to quickly take them out, or else die over and over again.

You will also get grenades, though they take so long to aim, that they’re only useful when the designers decided to place a penguin in the position with the full intent that you use your grenades at this point. A cool mechanic that they added, though, are a type of parasitic bug that you can toss to take control of a bad guy. This allows you to unlock doors or call of elevators that would otherwise be inaccessible to Hard Boiled, but mostly I found myself using it as a tactic to take out the enemies without the threat of losing my own health or ammunition.

For a couple of the levels, Rocketbirds sends you off, careening around the sky with a large rocket strapped to your back and a sub-machine gun in your hand. For these levels, you have to take out a squadron or two of crafty rocket and helicopter penguins. I took great pleasure in leading their heat seeking rockets right back at them. After defeating your flying adversaries, you’re tasked with landing on their blimp and sending it crashing down. That will teach the Penguins to use gas inflated blimps with easy to reach self-destruct sequences!

Rocketbirds also comes with a co-op portion of the game, which, much to my dismay, is only playable in the same room. An online co-op, even if it lacked a matchmaking feature, is practically expected in any cooperative game nowadays.

The one part that Rocketbirds does exceptionally well is the graphics. The 2D game looks painted, but moves just a little bit as you walk across the screen, giving you a cool sense of depth. This, coupled with the sharpness of the musical animations, makes this game look great. All the characters are given their own, unique characteristics, from the tall, proud Cardinals, to the pot bellied Penguins. The art, coupled with the music, creates a fantastic world to play in.

Rocketbirds is a beautiful, though short game. It’s entertaining for the time that you get with it, but ultimately leaves you wanting a little bit more depth gameplay-wise. The lack of online co-op is a tough pill to swallow. The end of the story leaves it open for sequel, which, if made, will hopefully allow for more refined gameplay. All-in-all, though, Rocketbirds is enjoyable, and certainly beautiful. Try the demo and if you want more, pick up the full game.

Game provided by developer for review. Review written by Xerone.

item.title: 20SON Review – 15″ Macbook Pro Root Case
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: I've found the dichotomy of a finely crafted wood construction to enhance many a technological item including my iPhone. Recently, I contacted Root Cases to inquire about their products after seeing a review of their iPhone case on TUAW. A few days later a Bamboo 15" Macbook Pro case showed up at my door.
item.content:encoded:
I’ve dabbled with carpentry off and on throughout the years. When I was young, I tried using an omnidirectional handsaw with my Father that we picked up at the Big E in Western Massachusetts with mixed results. I’ve assisted in limited furniture making, and done some building framing. I’m comfortable around woodworking tools of many varieties, while buzzword compliant with the rest of them. Most of my own projects are on the macro side like home improvement, but I do have a genetic knowledge of fine woodworking. I’ve also found the dichotomy of a finely crafted wood construction to enhance many a technological item including my iPhone. Recently, I contacted Root Cases to inquire about their products after seeing a review of their iPhone case on TUAW. A few days later a Bamboo 15″ Macbook Pro case showed up at my door.

The 15" Mac Book Pro Root Case, lid open. Note the hinge and latching peg and socket.

Wow, is this thing nicely crafted. It’s not a clamshell case like I was expecting, but rather a hinged top flap about an inch in length lifts to expose enough Macbook to grab. Metal pegs and sockets keep the case closed. The inside is lightly padded with thin felt. The case appears to have been constructed by gluing thin strips of bamboo wood together, then routing out the interior compartment. Running my fingers over the wood seams reveals no jagged edges, no protrusions anyplace. There just aren’t any flaws in the finish at all.

No flaws in construction at all. Amazing quality.

The Root Case is more of a sleeve than an actual case. The design and size of the case don’t allow for a Speck skin to be installed on the Macbook. There is no room for a magsafe adapter, nor any door to thread a charging cable through either. The top hatch where the Macbook enters and exits the case isn’t quite large enough to allow the Macbook to be inserted fully and still charge. This isn’t really the intention of this case, though. There is some impact resistance from the felt, but I don’t think I’m going to be drop testing the case to see how well it protects. I’m confident that minor impacts will be fine, but anything major will be a problem. The felt exists more to protect the aluminum case of the Macbook from being scratched than anything else.

Overall, the Root Case is more of a style statement than anything else. It excels at what it does. If you need the style and impact resistance, use it like a sleeve in a backpack rather than a true case on it’s own. If you are going to go this route with an additional bag, realize that the case adds about an inch to the width and height of the case (about a half an inch in thickness), so a bag that accommodates a 17″ laptop is probably your best choice.

As with any other Apple product there are more choices in cases and protective gear than you get with initial configuration of your device in the first place. I do admit, I’m a sucker for a finely crafted wood product like this. At $100, it’s not cheap. There are many cases that cost more and either don’t look as nice or don’t provide any protection to speak of at all. The Root Case is both stylistic and provides some protection. I recommend it if you need both, or even just style by itself.

Case provided for review by company.
