item.title: 20SON Review – War of the Worlds (XBLA)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: It is hard for me to imagine just what might happen if the Earth was ever invaded by another species. Between the fact that humans seem to be a war torn race capable of doing all the wrong things and our susceptibility to fear, it isn’t a far reach to see how bad it could be. With all the forms of fiction we’ve created about the experience, easily you can understand why this might be a problem. I’d like to think that the father of science fiction, H.G. Wells gave us one of the truest possibilities back in 1898, with The War of the Worlds. If you aren’t familiar with the classic H.G. Wells novel, you should go to your local library, online retailer of choice or even EPUB and read it. Don’t worry, it’ll take you less time to read than you’d spend playing the game. In order to garner a full understanding of the situation you are being thrown into in War of the Worlds, you need to understand what happened.
item.content:encoded:
It is hard for me to imagine just what might happen if the Earth was ever invaded by another species. Between the fact that humans seem to be a war torn race capable of doing all the wrong things and our susceptibility to fear, it isn’t a far reach to see how bad it could be. With all the forms of fiction we’ve created about the experience, easily you can understand why this might be a problem. I’d like to think that the father of science fiction, H.G. Wells gave us one of the truest possibilities back in 1898, with The War of the Worlds. If you aren’t familiar with the classic H.G. Wells novel, you should go to your local library, online retailer of choice or your favorite e-book vendor and read it. Don’t worry, it’ll take you less time to read than you’d spend playing the game. In order to garner a full understanding of the situation you are being thrown into in War of the Worlds, you need to understand what happened.

You can’t start to talk about War of the Worlds without first talking about the story. In fact, why didn’t this game come with a copy? Here’s the quick notes. Meteors fall from the sky in Victorian-era London. Martians appear from what we thought were falling rocks to start decimating the planet. Humanity goes into a panic as we are being wiped out at every turn. Hope turns into a guiding light for those with something to fight for. As Martians feed on humanity, we fight, hide and scamper for a chance to survive. Rather than try to try to replicate what has already been done via print and radio, Other Ocean Interactive took a different approach. The protagonist, Arthur, told his own tale. Literally, his journal was narrated in character by Sir Patrick Stewart himself. The good thing, it didn’t step on the Wells’ toes- it merely just lived in his world. The modern film equivalent would to be Cloverfield without the vomit inducing shaky cam. You see what Arthur sees. The player guides him through his 2D, on the edge platforming experience, one terrifying step at a time. This experience plays right to the heart of the game.

Even just mistiming your step or pausing for just a split second will punish you in War of the Worlds. Even one touch from their heat rays will lay Arthur to waste.

Let’s set everything straight. War of the Worlds is a unforgiving game in difficulty. Within an hour it had me howling at the television insisting all sorts of things were wrong and how much bull***t the game was feeding me. I was loathing every death more and more as I played on. The tolerance room for error when it comes to movement and puzzles is well beyond what one would expect. Literally, there is next to no allowance. Your timing needs to be flawless within milliseconds. Once you get a look at the achievements, it comes together. I’ll leave you to discover them, but here’s one solid reason why you get that message. In one of the loading screens it states that only 1 in every 163,000 people will get all of the achievements associated with the game. It only takes a few hours of playing it to realize just how true that statement rings.

After a good night’s sleep, I actually came to a better understanding of what was trying to be accomplished with War of the Worlds. Waking up in the morning I started to process more of the experience. The lighting strike of inspiration hit me in the shower, of all places. There should have been an achievement for beating War of the Worlds in one sitting without taking a bat to your television. Well, once the crappy first caffeine free realization was out of the way the real picture emerged. You are rooting for Arthur and, in turn, humanity. It is through hardship and tenacity that the human race would survive this war from beyond. Those who chose to fight, not just the aliens, but the world crumbling around them would be the ones to live. This element is translated through the pain War of the Worlds delivers through your emotions. It digs at our core instincts to survive. It makes us push on through the mind melting frustration to ensure that the sprinkling of hope wasn’t false. We want there to be a light at the end of the tunnel.

The build and release of events provides just enough to push you down, but bring you right back up again with little victories. Having a powerful voice like Sir Patrick Stewart lending his voice to the story only adds to the intensity. The music hits peaks and lulls in ideal places to add that adjustment that one would expect as the need for adrenaline hits or fades. While the game is short, if you doubled the length or halved the difficultly, you wouldn’t feel these emotions with as much intensity. And the difficulty is far, far away from what one would be used to in a platformer. Without it though, the heart wrenching agony that the game needs to drive it wouldn’t be there. Such thoughtful design went into this title all the way around.

Jumping from roof to roof to survive is just a prime example of how the game inspires you to push on. You want Arthur to succeed so badly, that you push on through the frustration to see him survive.

Visually War of the Worlds is an amazing feat. I know that people judge Live Arcade titles in a different light, but really to do so to this game is unfair. It isn’t a throw every bit of graphics and computing power at it to pump through the frame rates. As an inquisitive puzzle adventure it needs to fulfill certain ambiance in order to pull off the whole package. It far and away blows away the tiny expectations most people would have for an indie title. Rotoscoping was by far the way to go for the characters. As you begin to throw herds of them together they smoothly bend together in the madness. It also helps provide contrast between the environment as well as your Martian invaders. When you start to add on the layers of 2D things going on, it really sticks you into the atmosphere. You have multiple levels of action playing from the foreground to background that create an engrossing experience. It just adds another level of feel to the whole game.

Graphically great, doesn’t mean that everything is all fine and dandy though. Controlling Arthur feels a bit clumsy. With the simple, class 2D approach it feels like the controls are straight out of the Nintendo-era. They seem slow to respond, especially when it comes to attempting to start movement towards a timed element. It is almost as if they lag a little bit. This can be overcome, but because of the placement of some 2D elements and camera shifts it compounds the issue. Lighting flashes and foreground elements due to these movements, will often give you problems with puzzles. The shifts are done with purpose, but the speed of them isn’t the best. You notice this a lot when dropping from heights.

The environment in War of the Worlds just adds to your appreciation of the game. However, those pretty things can cause a lot of headaches when trying to navigate through puzzles.

War of the Worlds, you rage inducing, dark little, side scrolling platformer. You pull at me emotionally with your alternate view to the story in the H.G. Wells penned Martian attack. Yet, I can’t feel more than a sigh upon beating it. If it is a sigh of relief or a sigh of happiness, I can’t fully tell. The insane tolerance threshold you have to operate in left me with frustration levels so high, it had me walking away from the game for fear of embedding my controller in the wall more than once. In the end though, it provided one hell of a challenge. Even while it was short, the difficulty had purpose to the scale. I felt like I was left with a genuine sense of accomplishment when I beat it. Rolling in at a low 800 point cost, you can’t help but second guess the title a little. It makes it hard to know what to think about it. When you let everything soak in, you’ll know that for such a low price it is a must play. If the possibility of frustration scares you from this title, stay away. War of the Worlds will put you in a fit of rage. However, the rage is what makes you appreciate the game. A weird balance, but it wouldn’t be the experience it is without it.

item.title: Guest Review – Toy Soldiers: Cold War (XBLA)
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: War is a pretty ubiquitous topic when it comes to video games. Rarely, however do games incorporate it in a way that doesn’t involve some more mature subject matter. The Toy Soldiers series is the exception to that rule, it seems, and Toy Soldiers: Cold War, as part of this summer’s Summer of Arcade promotion, aims to iterate once more on the strategy-shooter mashup formula that made the first Toy Soldiers such a success.
item.content:encoded:
War is a pretty ubiquitous topic when it comes to video games. Rarely, however do games incorporate it in a way that doesn’t involve some more mature subject matter. The Toy Soldiers series is the exception to that rule, it seems, and Toy Soldiers: Cold War, as part of this summer’s Summer of Arcade promotion, aims to iterate once more on the strategy-shooter mash-up formula that made the first Toy Soldiers such a success.

The keytar really sells it. Toy Soldiers is a period piece.

There is nearly no story to speak of in Toy Soldiers, and that’s actually a good thing. The lack of any narrative lends itself to the idea of a toy box. Because you’re not told why everything is happening, you can put yourself in the shoes of a kid playing with the soldiers in his toy box. This is perhaps the game’s greatest strength, recreating the feeling you had as a kid on a Sunday afternoon, playing with your toys. Sadly, the historical context of the game defused this nostalgia for me to a small degree – simply because I grew up in the 90’s, so much of the humor derived from American patriotic stereotypes from the 80’s was lost on me (perhaps also because I’m Canadian). To be sure, this is a microscopic gripe with the game, and perhaps a selling point for those of you who do have those particular memories. Nostalgia is a powerful marketing tactic.

Where Toy Soldiers earns its stripes is most certainly in gameplay, offering a satisfying mix of both shooting and real-time-strategy elements. Each match is broken down into waves of enemies who spawn at pre-determined intervals. You can allow waves to arrive early for bonus points. Also, killing multiple enemies in quick succession will grant you point multipliers and potentially a bonus power. These powers range from a Rambo-esque howling commando, to an AC-130 gunship, to an artillery barrage. They’re useful in the thick of things, and immensely rewarding when you manage to take out a batch of infantry as the points roll in.

Rambo-clone will run around the battlefield screaming like a maniac when you call him in.

But how to get these perks in the first place, you ask? Well, each map has a number of plots on it. These plots – either large or small in size – house your units. The game’s perspective is one typical of real-time strategy games, with a reticule in the center of the screen on the ground. When you move over a plot, you can select a unit type to place there, and subsequently repair, upgrade, sell (to open the plot up to a different unit type), or control the unit. Controlling each unit type adds another layer of fun to the game, with each one having strengths and weaknesses. These strengths and weaknesses as singular units also enhance the strategy elements of the game, forcing you to constantly re-assess what units you’re going to need, and where you’re going to want to put them. In addition to these units, most maps also have battery-operated toys on the map. These are toys that can only be used for a certain amount of time, since their batteries will run out (though you can collect batteries on the map to extend your time), but they are mobile, and generally much more powerful than your standard units.

More mobile units such as tanks or helicopters can be devastating, but their availability is limited, and should be used strategically.

The game allows you to play it strictly as a strategy game, or toss in more action elements if you choose, and these additional options mean that if you’re going to best your friends on the leaderboards you’ll have to be savvy about how you play. The options granted to you instill a sense of choice that many games struggle to achieve. You never feel as though you have no recourse, since one of your options is always available to you. That’s not to say the game isn’t difficult, because it definitely can be. You’re not penalized for losing units beyond having to buy a new one, but if any enemy units reach your toy box (usually located behind your plots), they will knock some health off depending on their unit type. This isn’t a problem on earlier levels, but once the waves start consisting of close to a hundred attack choppers, things get, well, choppy.

Hordes of choppers will descend upon you – be sure to have at least one anti-aircraft turret.

Toy Soldiers: Cold Wars weaknesses are few and far between. Nothing comes to mind when I ask myself what I don’t like about the game. I have a few minor gripes with the controls of the jet (one of the battery-operated vehicles in the game), and the historical context can potentially alienate some, but these pale in comparison to the all-out fun that the rest of the game offers. It’s not the longest XBLA game out there, but the replay value it offers in the scoring system as well as a handful of mini-games is enough to keep you periodically booting it up for some solid action-strategy any day of the week. For those looking to enjoy solid strategy elements mixed with fun action-shooter influences, with pangs of nostalgia, Toy Soldiers: Cold War is certainly worth your time.

- Das Kalk

Title was provided by the developer for review.

item.title: ‘The Punisher’ Picked Up by Fox
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: In a move that perhaps perplexes fans of Marvel comics, Fox has decided to buy an hour long drama based on the character of Frank Castle, better known as The Punisher.
item.content:encoded:
In a move that perhaps perplexes fans of Marvel comics, Fox has decided to buy an hour long drama based on the character of Frank Castle, better known as The Punisher. Developed by ABC Studios, The Punisher will be the fifth live-action television show produced by the studio. The Incredible Hulk, Cloak & Dagger, AKA Jessica Jones and Mockingbird being the other four. However, this is the first to be sold outside of the ABC family. The pilot, which has been given a commitment to film, puts a different spin on Marvel’s most well-known vigilante. Castle be a detective that rises through the ranks of the New York Police Department during the day, but the justly corrective force known as The Punisher by night. It will be built as a police procedural style show, brought to us by Ed Bernero (Criminal Minds).

What makes it even more troubling is that it was Fox that picked it up. As a viewer, it is going to be awkward seeing two shows from opposing comic titans on the same channel. While not a big deal, I can easily see Fox dumping The Punisher for The Spectre or vice versa. Let us not forget, that only in the last season Fox dumped Human Target, a Vertigo adaptation, that had been heavily modified from the original premise. Low ratings lead them to do a reboot of the show for the second season even. How they could get rid of a show as entertaining as Human Target though, boggles my mind. Especially when you have a fantastic actor like Jackie Earle Haley playing such an interesting role. I digress, but given the track record with Fox and anything resembling genre television can you blame me? We’ll just have to cross our fingers and hope Frank Castle has as much vengeance as ever.

Source – Deadline

item.title: Mark Hamill is The Joker No More
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Last week Mark Hamill announced that he would be handing up the reigns of Batman’s twisted, oft comedic nemesis - The Joker.
item.content:encoded:
Last week Mark Hamill announced that he would be handing up the reigns of Batman’s twisted, oft comedic nemesis – The Joker. Since 1992 with the introduction of the highly popular Batman: The Animated Series, Hamill has been voicing the Ace of Knaves over multiple cartoons, television series, and video games. After doing the voice work for Batman: Arkham Asylum, Hamill told IGN in May 2010 that he would be returning for the sequel, Arkham City. However, he would be hanging up the reigns afterwards. Sadly, this week Mr. Hamill confirmed that Batman: AC would indeed be his last time boarding the crazy train for this iconic villain over Twitter.

While a definite sadness to lose such a prolific voice actor for Gotham City, what could this mean for the future of The Joker? Will we see John Di Maggio return the role he played in Batman: Under the Red Hood? Could it be Brent Spiner who voiced the Harlequin of Hate in the latest cartoon iteration of the Justice League- Young Justice? Will DC Comics decide to bring back any of the seven other voice actors to assume the role in the last ten years? Or will we have a chance to see someone else chime in with their own brand of madness? We’ll just have to wait to find out. With a game that is garnering rave reviews, the DC reboot, and the overall popularity of all things Batman, I’m sure we won’t be waiting that long. All I know is, the poor sap they choose will have some massive, well-worn wingtips to fill.

Source – Comic Book Resources / Twitter

item.title: PS Vita Gets North American Release Date
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Been drooling over the PS Vita? Is the anticipation of being able to caress the device in your hands already causing your palms to get sweaty? Or maybe you’ve been searching for things to sell on Ebay to be able to get one shipped from Japan early? Well hold on to your action figure collection because the release date for North America, Europe, and Latin American has been announced. We’ll be seeing the PS Vita hit the shelves on February 22, 2012. Only two months after hitting the market in Japan!
item.content:encoded:
Been drooling over the PS Vita? Is the anticipation of being able to caress the device in your hands already causing your palms to get sweaty? Or maybe you’ve been searching for things to sell on Ebay to be able to get one shipped from Japan early? Well hold on to your action figure collection because the release date for North America, Europe, and Latin American has been announced. We’ll be seeing the PS Vita hit the shelves on February 22, 2012. Only two months after hitting the market in Japan!

Setting up to have an impressive launch, there are already 100 titles in development with 26 said to be released at launch. Not interested in any of the titles that will be out? Well the Vita will include its own social app to connect with other Vita owners, as well as apps for the most popular social applications. I can’t wait to see “tweeted by PS Vita” myself. In addition, the new handheld will offer backwards compatibility to PSP download titles, and allow other game and media downloads from the PlayStation Store.

Look out for pre-orders soon! Let’s hope those $249 (Wi-Fi) and $299 (Wi-Fi & 3G) don’t scare people off.

See the blog release information below!

This afternoon on stage at the Web 2.0 Summit in San Francisco, I shared some very exciting news that I know the PlayStation Nation has been anticipating since we unveiled PlayStation Vita back in January. For those looking to get their hands on the ultimate in handheld entertainment, I’m thrilled to let you know that starting on February 22, 2012, PS Vita will be available at major retailers in the United States, Canada, Latin America, and Europe.

Our first-party studios and army of publishing partners have been extremely hard at work to ensure that PS Vita launches with a vast library of titles that deliver unique gameplay experiences that go beyond any handheld or mobile device on the market. We have more than 100 games currently in development globally that span many different genres, including Sound Shapes, Resistance: Burning Skies, Uncharted Golden Abyss, Capcom’s Ultimate Marvel vs. Capcom 3, Ubisoft’s Assassin’s Creed, EA Sports’ FIFA, Activision’s Call of Duty, and numerous others that you’ll hear about in the months ahead.

I’ve had the chance to spend some time with several of these titles and I think you’ll be blown away by how each takes advantage of the technology packed into PS Vita to deliver amazing gaming experiences. With its vibrant 5-inch OLED screen, dual analog sticks, dual cameras, and front and rear touch panel, PS Vita will deliver rich, immersive games with stunning graphics, which simply can’t be found anywhere else. Now you’ll be able to play shooters and action titles on-the-go with controls that are familiar, and you won’t have to block out the gorgeous screen to interact with the games.

In addition to the deep portfolio of games, you’ll also have access to native social applications – near and Party – that help you connect with your friends and fellow PS Vita owners. We also recently announced that PS Vita will have your favorite social networking applications like Facebook, foursquare, Skype, and Twitter, so you can share and connect with friends. With PS Vita, you can enjoy the best handheld gaming experience available and stay connected to the people and interests you care about.

It’s never been a better time to be a part of PlayStation Nation and I can’t wait for you to experience this revolutionary handheld system. Stay tuned for more exciting updates as we near the February 22, 2012 launch!

Source – Playstation.Blog

item.title: Tribes: Ascend Closed Beta Starts 11/4
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Last week, Hi-Rez Studios announced that closed beta for their upcoming title Tribes: Ascend will be beginning on November 4, 2011.
item.content:encoded:
Last week, Hi-Rez Studios announced that closed beta for their upcoming title Tribes: Ascend will be beginning on November 4, 2011. The beta will be by invitation only, so it is probably wise to start looking into registering if you want to get in on it. According to their press release, the beta will only be covering a small portion of the content for the free to play game. This is to be expected, but shouldn’t be a reason to deter one from trying. Old fans still wanting a better title after the Tribes: Vengeance disaster, and new ones coming aboard from Hi-Rez’s Global Agenda should provide some competition. Given the buzz that has been surrounding the game since PAX, it may be one worth taking an early look at.

As a special bonus, Hi-Rez is offering a guaranteed spot for those dedicated Tribes fans who purchase the VIP Starter Bundle. In said bundle you get VIP status (whatever that is), a 30 day booster, and 800 of their in game currency.

Visit their website to pick up the bundle or chance being selected via the open registration.

Source – Hi-Rez Studios

item.title: 20SON Review – GP2X Caanoo Handheld
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: There are a few options for handheld emulation. Some easy, some not. Where does the GP2X Caanoo unit range on this scale?
item.content:encoded:
As a child desperate for his arcade fix, I’d find games in the unlikeliest of spots. The bowling alley had a cigarette-charred Space Invaders and Pac Mac machine. The local mall sported an arcade in the Dream Machine chain. Sure, I had a home computer earlier than most, had a buddy that owned an Atari, and a second friend had a ColecoVision, but the only place to get some of the pure arcade experiences was actually at the arcade. There was nothing quite like dedicated hardware for each game. At the time, input devices for computers and consoles were either too low fidelity like the Atari joystick, complicated pads with required cardboard inserts or very precise almost scientific in quality (and price!) analog joysticks like most for Apple II computers. Consoles and portables have gotten loads better at the arcade experience. In may cases arcade-perfect versions of games are available from their original manufacturer. A few custom devices exist to facilitate this now- one of them is the latest in the GP2X line, the Caanoo.

Design
The unit is comfortable when held and in use, and feels solid in the hand. If you’ve used a Playstation Portable, you’ve got a pretty good idea of how the device is laid out. A diamond shaped ABXY button panel, left and right shoulder buttons. A d-pad in previous incarnations of the GP2X has been removed in favor of a surface mounted analog stick with integral button. There are two buttons underneath the analog stick normally used for emulation when the unit is turned 90°. For storage, the Caanoo uses a SD card up to 32 gigabytes. A single port is used to charging and for data transfer. I think the port is a cellphone standard, but I’m not positive. I’ve never owned a phone that has used this connector. A female USB 1.1 port is used for installation of a 802.11g/n wireless dongle, if need be. The unit sports a 533 mhz processor. Technically, the screen is a bright and clear 3.5 inch 320×240 resistive touch screen, but it’s only charitably described as such- the sensitivity on the screen is very, very bad.

Caanoo bottom right, smaller than the DS Phat, bigger than an iPhone

Ethical Dilemma
The Caanoo is a device that does technically have other uses than piracy, which brings us to the primary issue with the device. Let’s be frank here- the device’s primary use is retro emulators. There is a Caanoo store, but the games and applications in the store aren’t fantastic, nor any reason to buy the device. In order to utilize the device to it’s fullest extent, you must be both technically savvy and comfortable with hunting down ROM files for the console or arcade ports you’re looking to play. This device isn’t Atari’s Greatest Hits on CD. To find these ROMs you’ll be digging though the underbelly of the internet looking for this site or that, which may or may not yield anything that works. If this is something that makes you uncomfortable, then this device is not for you.

Software
The Caanoo uses a custom Linux build for a basic OS. This allows for easy and quick porting of many emulators, and other games like Quake to the Caanoo. Installation is as simple as downloading the application to your computer, and copying the application folder and .ini file to the CF card. I installed SNES, NES, and Genesis emulators, as well as a Caanoo specific version of Quake. All have many configuration options, sometimes as fine as individual settings for specific games. In my trials, I found the SNES and Genesis emulation to be the smoothest. After I dug out my over a decade old Quake CD, extracted the PAK files, and tweaked the configuration file a bit, Quake was buttery smooth. For whatever the reason, the NES emulation, while faithful, was a bit stuttery and slower than the original hardware it’s based on.

Final Verdict
I like the Caanoo. It’s a small unit, I don’t have to deal with the strangeness associated with hacking/cracking a PSP. There is a technical barrier to entry, and it’s all about being comfortable with finding and using the ROM files. It’s a simple choice- you’re either comfortable downloading them from usenet or a torrent site or you’re not. If you are, and are looking for a unit to play them on, this beats those $10 at Walmart devices you plug into the television. If you’re not, then it’s probably best to stick with the reimaginings or the disks of classic games for modern consoles.

Caanoo provided by ThinkGeek for review. If you want one, buy it from them!

item.title: Trion Sells Edition Upgrade for Rift Event
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: A new event has come to Trion’s MMO Rift. Ashes of History sets the Ascended (players) in a race to collect Magma Opals through daily quests, rifts, and invasion events to fight off the Golden Maw and the Wanton. The stones are needed to repair traveling stones to be able to head them off on their turf. To coincide with the new event, Trion decided to launch a new special edition upgrade for sale.
item.content:encoded:
A new event has come to Trion’s MMO Rift. Ashes of History sets the Ascended (players) in a race to collect Magma Opals through daily quests, rifts, and invasion events to fight off the Golden Maw and the Wanton. The stones are needed to repair traveling stones to be able to head them off on their turf. To coincide with the new event, Trion decided to launch a new special edition upgrade for sale. Included in the pack is a new Spindrel (spider) mount, a banker than you can summon, and a new shiny tabard for your characters. The cost to you? Only $10 dollars. This isn’t unheard of from Trion, as they still sell the Collector’s Edition upgrade from the original launch for the players that didn’t catch it the first go round. If you are in the dark about that pack, you got a Tartagon (two headed turtle) mount, a larger bag for carrying loot and a special Bogling pet. I’m starting to notice a trend here. Don’t want to pay for digital items? New gear and augments drop as well. Even a new pet and Ash Strider (raptor) mount were added!

The new event was supposed to kick off on 10/12, but was delayed to 10/13 “due to concerns over possible performance issues that arose during the opening in EU.”

Let’s hope that Rift isn’t getting a taste of what World of Warcraft started doing. Though, for $10 you get way more than you would if you bought in-game items from Blizzard. If it puts Rift in a better place to topple the king, I’m all for it.

Don’t have Rift yet? Don’t worry you still have through 10/19 to pick it up on massive sale. For $5, you can’t go wrong.


Source – Rift website

item.title: 20SON Review – Dungeon Defenders for xBox Live
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Real time strategy metaphor and history? Written and discarded. Tower defense game summary? Been there, done that. Game hybridization lecture? No point I've probably written and deleted more paragraphs for the beginning of this review than any other review I've ever written. After many launch delays, promises to players, and shipping date slips, Dungeon Defenders by Trendy Entertainment hits the Playstation Network on October 18th, followed by xBox Live and Steam on October 19th.
item.content:encoded:
Real time strategy metaphor and history? Written and discarded. Tower defense game summary? Been there, done that. Game hybridization lecture? No point. I’ve probably written and deleted more paragraphs for the beginning of this review than any other review I’ve ever written. After many launch delays, promises to players, and shipping date slips, Dungeon Defenders by Trendy Entertainment hits the Playstation Network on October 18th, followed by xBox Live and Steam on October 19th.

Setting and overall scenario is nothing new. Four medieval-adjacent heroes vanquish an ancient eldritch evil, but can’t destroy it. Complacency sets in, the heroes depart leaving their progeny behind to defend the stronghold. Things go terribly wrong, leaving the unlikely heroes to step up to save all of creation. Nothing new, but Dungeon Defenders executes it fairly well in the intro video. Character design trends toward cell-shaded chibi archetypes of a Monk, a He-Man Orko-like Mage, a saucy thief-type Huntress, and a well-armored fighter called the Squire. If this seems a little sparse to begin with, more classes are promised in the future as DLC. At press time, the results of a community poll point towards the release of a summoner class, but this wasn’t available at time of review. Class selection determines the basic degree of difficulty, but this is pointed out at time of selection. No nasty surprises there. A first level squire is no different than any other first level squire- the only differentiation comes as you play the game, equip yourself, and level up.

Plotting your towers is quite an easy thing to do.

The tutorial is a must-play. In it you get a feel for the game’s progression, and the layout of the first level the game is played on. This includes how many bad guys are coming, and which entry they are going to come from. Your goal is to protect your Eternia Crystal from enemy assault. Prior to this assault, every combat turn begins with a setup round allowing you as much time as you want to complete your defenses. Time allowed for defense configuration is configurable to a set amount of time if desired. When you’ve got your defenses set up as best as you can with the resources and towers you have at your disposal, you touch the Eternia Crystal. Afterwards, it’s time to fight off the masses of evil. I didn’t care for the default camera angle while I was setting up my defenses as I didn’t feel like it gave me a good local picture. The camera angle is a minor complaint, though. As is the case with most of the hybrid shooter/tower defense games, you don’t have enough towers initially to defend your objective with just static defenses. Of course, that leaves you to just wade in and get your hands dirty. This balance of not enough resources changes as the level progresses to a state where you can’t defend the crystal without adequate defenses, so a good plan going into the level is vital.

As you can see the item box provides a simple display where to keep the items you've upgraded over time.

An interesting gameplay mechanic is the forge. It is the centerpiece of the customization of the game. At the forge, accessible during the setup phase, you can swap in and out your characters. Do you like the Huntress’ towers but prefer your Squire for the face smashing? Fine. Start with the Huntress and set up your defenses. You can then return to the forge and swap out for the Squire. If you find a particularly nice piece of weaponry that you want to keep around, you can invest mana in the Forge to enhance it’s abilities. If you max out an item, it’ll be forever branded with your user name to tell the world no matter who ends up with it who the original forger of the item is. The developers see this as an opportunity for individual forgers to be known for their items. How well this feature pans out remains to be seen.

The group gets ready to take on all comers as the fight begins anew.

As with most reviews, I initially wade into the game in single player mode. I rapidly learned that this game isn’t an ideal single player experience. The scaling of the level difficulty and the near impossible tasks to juggle with one player made it glaringly obvious that this game is intended for co-op play over the long run. In this day of ubiquitous internet connections, the Playstation Network, xBox Live and Steam, there shouldn’t be a big problem with that for any gamer. The lack of an experience optimized for single player is just something you need to be aware of before purchase. Split-screen co-op is possible, and I’ve seen a video of it on the PC version. I wasn’t able to test this functionality on the xBox in time for this review. I did have the opportunity to play multiplayer on xBox Live, and it was very smooth with no synchronization issues or other network related problems. On the xBox, there’s no good trade mechanism for gear or forged items other than the old school “dropping it on the ground” method. I have been informed that a secure trading mechanism will be implemented in a patch as soon as possible.

Spell effects and text flies as spells and defensive hurl all their might at the oncoming mobs.

As far as I know, Dungeon Defenders is the first tower defense game to integrate a roleplaying game class level progression. As enemies are slaughtered, you gain experience. After X amount of points are accumulated, your character levels up allowing you to purchase additional skills. These skills are either personal buffs like character speed or rate of fire, or enhancements to your defense towers you place. Other skills are unlocked as you go, either as a direct relation to your character class, or as a side effect of other stats increasing. For instance, you can’t upgrade towers until your maximum accumulated mana skill is greater than 100. Pets are unlocked at level 6.

Yes, in addition to gear you find, trade for, or buy, there are pets. These are purchasable at the tavern- the gathering place between levels. Pets provide stat boost to your character, enhance your defenses, and even lay the hurt down on the enemies trying to break your crystals. Pro tip- you can buy or lock down a pet before you’re able to use it. Items in the tavern store are randomized every visit, so it is possible to see a pet that fits the vision of your character. Not high enough level to use it? You can lock it in the store, preventing the loss of it to the gods of randomness. Of course, you still have to purchase it at some point, probably after level 6.

Use special abilities such as the Huntress' Invisibility to aid your battle strategy.

Dungeon Defenders is a mix of game styles and gameplay mechanisms. Defenses trend more towards shooters of varying varieties, rather than launchers and physics based traps like Orcs Must Die. Regardless of the chibi-cute graphical style of the player characters, the game takes itself and it’s tweakiness very seriously. Gear and player enhancements feel very much like old-school Diablo in it’s statistical finickiness and customizability. I’m concerned that people don’t associate deep gameplay on the xBox with titles purchased on the xBox Live arcade service. I am primarily a console gamer, more for convenience than any other reason. I think that Dungeon Defenders will find life and a persistent home on Steam rather than on xBox Live just given the nature of Steam and xBox Live gamers.

Overall, I did have a lot of fun with Dungeon Defenders. However, this fun didn’t really kick in until I found a couple of other reviewers throwing themselves into the game. Before I started with two other players, some stages of the game felt very much like work. If loot tweaking, character build modification or gear customization are unwelcome added layers of complexity, pick up the faster and less serious Orcs Must Die and skip Dungeon Defenders. On the other hand, if you both have a posse of players you can reliably play with and are fine with or even prefer some of the more gearhead aspects of RPGs, then Dungeon Defenders is a title in your wheelhouse.

item.title: 20SON Preview – Diablo 3 Beta Class Breakdown
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Diablo III offered a few different things in terms of classes to play. Instead of the base class evolving to whatever degree of magic you wanted in the first game or the skill tree of the second game, the initial class decision forces different roles and play styles. Passive skills were added to help balance player style, but were limited to experience in the beta. Barbarian and Wizard are carried over from previous games in the series. Demon Hunter, Monk and Witch Doctor have been added to Diablo III. These offer a new flavor to the series, as they are different than anything we've seen in the past.
item.content:encoded:
Diablo III offered a few different things in terms of classes to play. Instead of the base class evolving to whatever degree of magic you wanted in the first game or the skill tree of the second game, the initial class decision forces different roles and play styles. Passive skills were added to help balance player style, but were limited to experience in the beta. Barbarian and Wizard are carried over from previous games in the series. Demon Hunter, Monk and Witch Doctor have been added to Diablo III. These offer a new flavor to the series, as they are different than anything we’ve seen in the past.

Speaking of the past, gone is the option to select your skills based on trees for the class. Instead spells and abilities are unlocked at different levels. Also, Diablo III only allows a player to have up to six active abilities at level 24 and three passive ones at 30. It leaves the ability to upgrade your actions of choice a little up the in air. There are new items that upgrade or change skills scattered through the game. Augmentations called rune stones are available that you tie to specific skills rather than equipment. Gems are still available for armor and weapons. The old generic mana pool is practically gone as well. It is now replaced by class specific pools: rage (Barbarian), spirit (Monk), hatred and discipline (Demon Hunter), arcane power (Wizard), and mana (Witch Doctor).

Barbarian
It was very clear to me that the Barbarian was going to be Diablo III’s easiest and most over powered class. The Barbarian has been given cleave which with one swing attacks multiple enemies unfortunate to be standing in front of you. Cleave is an area affect attack awarded very early in the game. It makes managing hordes almost too easy as you switch to your cleave as your primary attack. While not as powerful or efficient as some other rage generating attacks, it pans out over time since you are doing damage to multiple monsters at once. Once you get a two-handed weapon things get really nutty. Due to the higher damage on the larger weapons, cleave murders common monsters in one or two swings. Rage building slows because of it. It isn’t fully apparent if the balance of this will change over time, but all the way through the beta I was having this problem. What it all boils down to, is this is a front and center class. You will build to take hits and take out packs of mobs with ease.

Monk
Playing the monk will appeal to those of you are that familiar with the hybrid style classes. That is, melee classes that are spliced with spell casters weakening both, but giving benefits of both. Most commonly a paladin or ranger would fit into this description. The monk can heal, which puts it at an importance for grouping scenarios. Solo situations are another story though. The monk is sort of squishy. They can do OK damage, but you’ll rely on secondary healing skills and stuns heavily to be as effective as others. It is important that you use a spirit generating attack as your primary to make full use of your abilities. Otherwise you’ll have to depend on potion healing. With a new cool down timer on potions, that makes that path troublesome. Monks are traditionally thought of as using martial-arts style weapons only. Diablo III breaks from that a little here as I was able to equip daggers and axes. It leaves me wondering why Bo staffs are touted for them though. Sure, damage is higher, but with the spirit draining issue for heals and what not, I would think you would want to be hitting as fast as possible. It’ll come down to personal preference.

See the Demon Hunter, Witch Doctor, and Wizard on the next page!

item.title: 20SON Preview – Diablo 3 Beta: The Overview
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: A few weekends ago I was awoken by an familiar sound. On my bedside my phone had chirped at me, proposing that I should take a look at it. The announcement indicated a message from my podcasting co-host, asking me what I thought was a cryptic message at the time. Perhaps it was just the simple question asking me if I had a Battle.net account or the fact that his damn e-mail rose me from a nap, but I hastily replied before collapsing once more onto my bed. A few minutes later, the phone chirped again. He mentioned to me that he was going to try and get us a beta invite for the Diablo 3 beta. Thinking that it was a one in a million shot for a small outfit like ours, I said "Good luck" in less than kind words and tried to sleep for a little longer.
item.content:encoded:
A few weekends ago I was awoken by an familiar sound. On my bedside my phone had chirped at me, proposing that I should take a look at it. The announcement indicated a message from my podcasting co-host, asking me what I thought was a cryptic message at the time. Perhaps it was just the simple question asking me if I had a Battle.net account or the fact that his damn e-mail rose me from a nap, but I hastily replied before collapsing once more onto my bed. A few minutes later, the phone chirped again. He mentioned to me that he was going to try and get us a beta invite for the Diablo III beta. Thinking that it was a one in a million shot for a small outfit like ours, I said “Good luck” in less than kind words and tried to sleep for a little longer.

Come to find out, we did get an invite. Mmm, crow. Yummy.

Loading the game up after a seamless download through Battle.net, I couldn’t help but find a lot of things similar to the previous games Blizzard has released. The launcher looks the same as with World of Warcraft, but one really can’t expect Blizzard to move away with something that works. The title screen opened to a haunting background with ominous music. Again, looking very familiar to the layout of the starting screen for WoW, it was easy to navigate through. One thing that Blizzard continues to excel at through all of their games are coherent user interfaces with easy menus that don’t aim to confuse the player or lose them in complicated options.

As you can see, nothing outside of the gender selection button was added for character customization.

I was offered a taste of disappointment when I went into character creation. Diablo as a series has bottlenecked players into pre-set characters that never offered any customization. Diablo III isn’t really any better in that regard. Sure they made it so you could actually select the gender of the class, it still leaves one wanting more. Considering the level of options you have in World of Warcraft, you’d think that there would be some carry over. Not much changed from before.

Diablo III plays out like we never stepped out of the story for the previous two games. All the familiar tropes are there, slaying monsters, collecting loot, and helping the helpless. The lore and world building remain second to none. Little gems are sprinkled all over that tip their hat to fans of the franchise since the beginning. The old physical traits of playing the game are much the same as well. The two button mouse system of clicking carried over from Diablo II. You assign abilities to primary and secondary buttons, as before. You then proceed to click yourself into carpal tunnel syndrome. Combats will eventually boil down to spamming mouse button clicks. I’d hoped that they would get away from that. Again, why break what isn’t broken?

The lore in Diablo 3 remains as strong as ever. Bringing back characters like Deckard Cain and King Leoric show that they want to keep true to what they've been doing.

Ten years in the making should mean that we should be killing it in the graphics department. There is no doubt that everything looks better than before, but not as much as one would expect. Destructible physics have been added for the beta, but some other expected features like anti-aliasing have been skipped and will wait for the release. Gone are the polished, shiny look that stuck to every player model from Diablo II, but something is still off. I just can’t quite put my finger on it. The textures look pretty good, especially when you compare them to other games in the genre. Perhaps they just don’t look as great on the NPCs due to the holding back of some of the graphic options to shrink the size of the beta. The lighting engine seems to be done to perfection. Fantastic radiance envelops abilities that neither distract nor overwhelm from the animations. The highlights and shadows play well to the atmosphere and textures as well. Simple things like lanterns and torches seem to glow appropriately, but still have that soft, warm light you’d expect from fire.

Click over to the next page to see what else Draeno thinks about his time in the beta.

item.title: 20SON Preview – The Monk’s Path in Diablo 3 Beta
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: As I walk an eerily twisting path in this wretched land, I cannot help but feel that I've been here before. The undead torment the living. The monsters come out to unleash their frustration in the world. Commoners hide within the shells of the city that they used to call home. What set this off? The falling star I've been sent to investigate has stirred something in this land. Why do the horrors haunt this region so? New Tristram, its predecessor freed from torment so long ago, now faces its own brand of troubles.
item.content:encoded:
As I walk an eerily twisting path in this wretched land, I cannot help but feel that I’ve been here before. The undead torment the living. The monsters come out to unleash their frustration in the world. Commoners hide within the shells of the city that they used to call home. What set this off? The falling star I’ve been sent to investigate has stirred something in this land. Why do the horrors haunt this region so? New Tristram, its predecessor freed from torment so long ago, now faces its own brand of troubles.  

The path towards my goal is littered with the feeding undead. I must quickly dispatch them before I become food myself.

Arriving at the gate I can see that this new barrage of the creatures from beyond has taken a toll on the men that protect this city. You can see the horror flicker in their weary eyes as they stand on their last nerves to defend their town. Captain Rumford, the last pillar of leadership for this aching town, speaks to me, warding me from the walls. He agrees to allow my entrance into town once he witnesses my fighting prowess against a large wave of undead. Walking through the gates you can tell that even protected, the town is losing its nerve. Family members have been lost, while others are missing or ran away. Rumford directed me in the direction of the Slaughtered Calf Inn to start my search for answers. Within, a local townswoman- Leah, tells me of her lost uncle, Deckard Cain. I agree to aid her in looking for him as I work towards the cathedral where I was told the fallen star had landed.  

At the gates of New Tristram, I show my fighting abilities to the Captain of the guard. After seeing that I can easily dispatch these monsters, I am allowed into town.

I walk, punch and bash my way through this wretched wilderness. It seems that the evil in this land works against me as I inch closer towards the church. This land literally puts me in a path of harm’s way. Each step brings something from the woods or under my feet in an attempt to dispatch me. Pushing on I come into the remains of the original Tristram, the town left behind from the troubles long ago. The buildings are falling apart. The moss is thick on the brick walls, eroding at their foundations. Time has not been kind here. Griswold’s smithy offers some weaponry charity among its piles of rock and tinder. Impeccable timing, as the new denizens decided it was opportune to come for my flesh. They pose no challenge to my overwhelming spirit, even their Wretched Queen.   

Few memories remain in this decrepit town. There are few things left behind but the dead themselves.

As the Captain tasked me with slaying the Queen in the shambled village, I head back to New Tristram to see if anything new had to be offered from the townspeople once done. The woman I spoke with before is now clearly anxious to find her lost uncle. Together we agree to strike back out towards a local hut that belonged to her mother. We come to find more than we bargained for. Beneath this shanty lies the remains of the guard set to protect the people of this area. Instead they perished and their undead remains are now left to protect a key to enter the cathedral. Once the soldiers were put to their final rest by our hands, Leah finds the journal left behind by her mother beside the key. She hands me the key, but remains to flip though the journal. I carry on out of the cellar only to be greeted by more foes. They press against my advance towards the church. When I cut the last of them down, I make my way into the holy temple. The only entrance to the depths below was caved in when the meteor crashed down, leaving me to enter through the crater. Whatever caused this furrow seems to have stirred something deep inside the earth. The further down I crawl, the more hideous things I’m greeted by- animated skeletons, corrupt flying creatures and even exploding abominations that provide a fight after death. Upon my entrance to the second level of the underbelly, I spot a old man fleeing for his life. This must be the Deckard Cain I was sent to look for. Unfortunately, it seems that he has brought something along with him. A skeletal king follows him ordering minions to end his life. I stave off the gang of skeletons allowing me to be able to bring Cain back to the safety of the town.

The deep, glowing light trailing behind the impact of the falling star offers little but an omen of what trouble lies beneath.

When we arrive via portal to town, Leah welcomes back the uncle she thought was lost. As they talk, Cain informs us that the king was indeed old King Leroic who had succumbed to the evils of this land some time ago. To bring an end to his newest undead reign, Cain sends me to find his blackened crown in a far away graveyard. Before I depart, I must locate the town’s blacksmith to see if he will help me in reforging the crown. Upon finding him, I am welcomed with a plea for help. The poor man’s wife has been infected with the ailment that has been turning average people into the undead. Unable to end her suffering on his own, I agree to help him end her suffering. Once the deed is done, he agrees to help me. I set off through the northern gate of the town only to run into more of the same creatures standing in my way. Even some strange beings that try to distract me with promises of treasure before stepping into a portal to the unknown. As I finally make my way to the gates of the cemetery, I can’t help but wonder how much longer this will go on. My body aches, my knuckles bleed, my will falters. It takes inner reflection to remind me just how important it is that I go on. The graveyard is full of crypts making this retrieval job just a little more tasking. After pushing on through three different tombs, I finally come to the altar of the fabled black crown. There seems to be something stopping me. A Chancellor of days gone by guards this crown even in death. Not wanting some unsuspecting fool to raise the skeleton king again, he fights me to the death. Unfortunately, it was that specter’s undoing. I take the crown in hand and prepare to transport back to the smith by an odd, portal opening stone I found along the way.  

Want to see the end of the monk’s journey? Turn to the next page!

item.title: The Walking Dead Comes to Netflix
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Zombie fans rejoice! Or groan and shamble towards your next meal. Whatever it is you folks do. Friday, the newly divided Netflix announced that they had worked out a multi-year deal with AMC that would bring the hit show The Walking Dead to their online streaming service.
item.content:encoded:
Zombie fans rejoice! Or groan and shamble towards your next meal. Whatever it is you folks do. Friday, the newly divided Netflix announced that they had worked out a multi-year deal with AMC that would bring the hit show The Walking Dead to their online streaming service. Now available, the show based on Robert Kirkman’s graphic works by the same name, shows up just in time for the second season premiere on October 16.

As you may have noticed, other hit AMC shows like Mad Men and Breaking Bad have been streaming on Netflix for some time. With this new announcement, viewers can expect to see more shows from the cable channel launching previous seasons online just before the newest season begins airing on TV. Not only does this cover AMC, but also grants non-exclusive deals for shows from IFC, Sundance and WE.

PC Mag reports that “[Adding shows to Netflix] brings our content to a wider audience, and it provides additional revenue to support production of new shows,” said AMC Networks President and CEO Josh Sapan.

Now if only The Walking Dead would stop killing off its show runners and writers, we might be able to keep the show’s head attached.

Source – PC Mag
