item.content:encoded:
Love Minecraft? Have a need to play it on the go? Disappointed that it was released for the Sony Xperia Play, but wasn’t playable on other Android phones? Fret not, early today Carl Manneh announced that as of today Minecraft Pocket Edition is available for all Android 2.2+ devices (though marketplace says 2.1+). Currently running at $6.99 on the market place, it seems a fair price to pay for itching your creative needs when you aren’t able to sit down at the computer. Still not convinced? Download the demo first to see if it is worth the price!

Carl Manneh tweets about Minecraft Pocket Edition available for all 2.2+ phones.

As of 10/8, 11:00PM Pacific time the app wasn’t available on the market place through T-mobile, but shows as purchasable at the Android Market online and through Verizon.

Source – Mojang

item.title: 20SON Review – Burnout Crash
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: I think crashing Matchbox or Hot Wheel cars together is a requirement to pass some birthday as a young boy. The seventh, maybe eighth. For some, the glee of virtual crashes never ceases, and this market is what Electronic Arts... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
I think crashing Matchbox or Hot Wheel cars together is a requirement to pass some birthday as a young boy. The seventh, maybe eighth. For some, the glee of virtual crashes never ceases, and this market is what Electronic Arts and Criterion Games is targeting with Burnout Crash. Cutting through the crap, Burnout Crash is an arcade crash simulator. Any other pesky game elements in previous Burnout titles like car racing have been excised, and I’m not sure that’s a good thing.

I’m going to get this out of the way first. I’m not a fan of most auto games, racing or not. I do like the Burnout series overall a great deal. Burnout has never been a serious attempt to simulate street racing, it’s not a Grand Turismo or Ridge Racer by any stretch of the imagination. The series has always glorified speed and the physics poetry defined by the meter of automobile crashes. Burnout Crash eschews the normal 3rd person or windshield views that previous games in the series have used, and have gone straight to the top down style. Think the viewpoint of the first two Grand Theft Auto titles, rather than Carmageddon. Straight up, you start in the bottom of the map with the intent of causing as much destruction in your wake as possible.

This is the screen you'll be staring at most of the time. Can you find your car?

It all starts with a single crash- your car into a bus, or other such mundane accident. Once the carnage begins, your Crash Breaker bar starts to fill. The more damage you cause, the faster it fills. After your crash breaker bar fills up completely, you can detonate your car, and you have a modicum of control over it’s trajectory with the return of the aftertouch mechanic from previous Burnout titles. Ideally, you want to ricochet off as many items as possible, and bank those cars, dumpsters, what have you into other objects. Repeat until the parameters of the game type are fulfilled.

In Road Trip mode, you can keep this cycle going as long as five cars haven’t escaped, or until you’ve destroyed a set amount of cars per stage. If the five cars escape, the level ends without fanfare. If you’ve maxed out the destruction, a level-clearing apocalyptic event like a hurricane or UFO visits the remaining undamaged surrounding structures adding to your point total. If an ambulance escapes, then one car is subtracted from your total, but as the gents from penny-arcade implied, the Ambulance seems to be made of cardboard soaked in gasoline. This is not a good thing. A little more durability from a player support mechanism would have been welcome.

Pile-Up mode starts with a high score modifier that drops from 5x to 1x as cars escape your clutches. So, your goal is still to prevent the escapes. Regardless of how many cars escape, the level ends with an inferno that can theoretically continue forever, as long as something is burning on the map.

Rush Hour is time based, challenging you to destroy as much crap as possible in 90 seconds. This also ends in fire- when the time is up, your car explodes with massive force, launching local items into the surrounding countryside, and hopefully causing untold damage.

The Pizza Wheel. It's not all good news.

Burnout Crash is entertaining, and inherently frustrating. It is the epitome of a game that feels like work sometimes, and the level design seems oriented towards the “one true solution” method of game design. In Road Trip mode, the crash breakers not only propel you towards other targets, but it more often than not scatters your existing carnage you relied on to prevent the traffic from getting through. Some may call it a tactical decision to set off the crash breaker, but it’s less tactical than necessary to thump that button as often as possible. Pile-Up mode has a heavy reliance on a pizza truck coming through the level to deliver a spin on a wheel of prizes to you upon it’s destruction. This wheel delivers power-ups like a temporary score multiplier or serious penalties like a bulldozer coming through. I don’t think some of the score targets the game requires you to make to collect stars for better vehicles to be even possible to obtain without these multipliers.

I’ve never been a big fan of grinding to unlock what you want to play in a game. Grinding for the perfect +5 amulet of destruction in some sort of hack and slash is one thing, but when a game feels like work to get to the good parts, it’s not fun to play. I found Rush Hour to be a very satisfying mode, but to get there I was forced to play Road Trip and Pile Up modes as well. Multiplayer mode is either the leader board challenges that your friends can give you over xBox Live or a strange Kinect implementation with a gesture that a second party has to do to invoke the crash breaker explosion. There’s no way that this was included as anything more than an afterthought to put the Kinect integration icon on the marketing materials.

I bought Burnout Crash because Mike at Penny-Arcade spoke pretty highly of it. I bought Guitar Hero and a few other titles for the same reason, and I wasn’t ever disappointed. I don’t blame Mike- all of my irritations with the game he spoke about. I just didn’t think they’d be that bad, since i had so much fun with previous Burnout titles. Burnout Crash feels incomplete. Game design decisions were made that impede the good times that are possible with this game. The levels are sometimes frustrating, random chance has way too much influence on your fate with certain goals, and grinding game types you don’t want to play to release game types you want is irritating. This all sounds very harsh. Burnout Crash is a decent game through it all but I just can’t recommend you spend 800 points for it. At 400, it deserves some thought If it ever hits the 200 point range in a sale, I think that’s the sweet spot for purchase.

Game was purchased by reviewer.

item.title: Red 5 Studios and Webzen Games Reach Agreement
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: It was recently announced that Red 5 Studios and Webzen Inc. reached an agreement to bring to a close all of the legal issues that had been filed against one another.
item.content:encoded:
It was recently announced that Red 5 Studios and Webzen Inc. reached an agreement to bring to a close all of the legal issues that had been filed against one another. In the agreement, Red 5 received global publishing rights to Firefall, the free to play online shooter announced in 2008. The cost for Red 5 is to compensate Webzen for development fees that were paid to them under a prior arrangement. While Webzen will not be involved in the publishing or marketing arm of the game (which is now in the hands of Red 5 Singapore), they do have something else to look forward to in Firefall’s future. Red 5 will have to share future revenue that the title generates with Webzen for an undisclosed amount of time.

Mark Kern, CEO of Red 5 Studios said, “Given the resolution of all disputes and conflicts between our two companies I would like to ask for our fans, especially Chinese and Korean gamers,’ continuous encouragement and support in Firefall and Red 5.”

Where does this leave the progress for the game? Hopefully in a positive direction. Given the fact that Red 5 is looking to make a large impact with Firefall in the Asian markets, does striking out without Webzen on their side give them the best chance? It might not turn out as bad as you think. With The9 acquiring a majority share of the Red 5 Studios back in March 2010, hopefully their experience with titles like World of Warcraft (after Webzen had their go at it) should hope to pay off.

See the press releases below:

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

RED 5 STUDIOS AND WEBZEN HAVE AGREED TO END THE DISPUTE

[Provided by Red 5 Korea] – September 29th, 2011 – Red 5 Studios, Inc. (“Red 5”) announced that it has entered into a settlement agreement with Webzen, Inc. to resolve all the legal disputes between them, including withdrawal of all pending legal claims against the other.

Under this agreement, Webzen will receive compensation for the prior development fees paid to Red 5 and also will share in future revenue generated from Red 5’s game entitled Firefall for a certain period of time. Red 5 and its affiliated company received the global publishing rights under the settlement agreement. Webzen will no longer be involved in marketing and publishing Firefall in any territory as a result of this agreement.

Mark Kern, CEO of Red 5 Studios said, “Given the resolution of all disputes and conflicts between our two companies I would like to ask for our fans, especially Chinese and Korean gamers,’ continuous encouragement and support in Firefall and Red 5.”

From now on, please contact Red 5 Studios and Red 5 Korea for more details regarding Firefall.

About Red 5 Studios
Red 5 Studios, Inc., an online game developer located in California, is founded by Mark Kern, former team lead for World of Warcraft. Red 5 is dedicated to bringing together millions of gamers across the world by creating immersive worlds, intriguing stories and compelling characters. Red 5 believes that online games and persistent worlds are the future of video games. Visit www.red5studios.co.kr for more information.

Red 5 Singapore Pte. Ltd. will substitute Webzen, Inc. for Publishing Firefall

Shanghai, China – September 30, 2011. The9 Limited (NASDAQ: NCTY) (“The9″), an online game developer and operator in China, announced today that The9, Red 5 Singapore Pte. Ltd. (“Red 5 Singapore”), a wholly-owned subsidiary of The9, and other subsidiaries of The9 have entered into a series of agreements with Webzen, Inc. (“Webzen”), pursuant to which Webzen will assign the license of Firefall, a team-based action shooter computer game developed by Red 5 Studios, Inc. (“Red 5″), to Red 5 Singapore.

The transactions among the parties will be closed upon satisfaction of several conditions, including withdrawal of the claims made by Red 5 and Webzen in the United States and Korea. Upon closing, Red 5 will continue to have the publishing right in the United States, Canada and European countries, Red 5 Singapore will be substituted in full for Webzen as a party under the Game Development and License Agreement between Red 5 and Webzen, including the publishing rights in all of the countries worldwide other than the United States, Canada and European countries, as well as all the intellectual properties related to Firefall. Webzen will no longer be involved in marketing and publishing Firefall in any territory.

Under the agreements, Webzen will receive compensation for the prior development fees paid to Red 5, and The9 will guarantee the payment. Webzen will also share in future revenue generated from Firefall for a certain period of time.

About The9 Limited

The9 Limited is an online game operator and developer in China. The9 directly, or through affiliates, operates licensed MMORPGs including Soul of The Ultimate Nation™, Atlantica and Kingdom Heroes 2 Online in mainland China. The9 has also obtained exclusive licenses to operate other online games in mainland China, including Seoyugi, Planetside 2 and Free Realms. In addition, The9 operates its proprietary MMORPG World of Fighter, web and social games Tiny Kingdoms and Winning Goal in mainland China and overseas. The9 is also developing various proprietary games, including ShenXianZhuan, Firefall and other MMORPGs, web and social games. In 2010, The9 established its Mobile Business Unit to focus on mobile internet business.

item.title: Steve Jobs 1955 – 2011
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: I didn't know Steve Jobs personally. His company and products have weaved in and out of my life since the original Apple II launch when my prescient parents saw the writing on the wall and only wanted the best for me. It was so early in the run, the odds are his fingerprints were on the case someplace.
item.content:encoded:
So long, Steve.

Emdee
I didn’t know Steve Jobs personally. His company and products have weaved in and out of my life since the original Apple II launch when my prescient parents saw the writing on the wall and only wanted the best for me. It was so early in the run, the odds are his fingerprints were on the case someplace.

Mr. Jobs’ design philosophies have influenced computing, and me along the way. I am who I am, from a technological standpoint because of his design decisions. I’ve (briefly) spoken with him on two occasions. Say what you will about the man, his company, their practices, their products- the computer and media industries wouldn’t be where they are today without his hand on the reins. The industry will feel this hand for probably a decade, whether or not they know it.

Whether or not your view of Steve is Think Different, For the Rest of Us, One More Thing, or the Power to Crush the Other Kids, we are all poorer for his loss.

Draeno
I cannot deny the innovator that Steve Jobs was. His products were always around in my life, be it if I wanted them there or not. Through out my school days we were always surrounded by the Apple IIe, Macintosh, and iMac computers. I was even introduced to the fantastic world of graphic design through the use of Adobe products on his machines. You can’t deny that with the creation of Apple, the computer market had to step up its game. We might not even have Windows had he not had the tenacity to find his own path to happiness. He was a man that constantly pushed the boundaries in a consumer market that was always hungry for more. The world was touched and influenced by his contributions. Now you can’t walk five feet in any direction without seeing something that he had a part in, great or small.

Let us not forget his contributions to the film industry either. Without him being ousted by Apple in 1986, Pixar may not have grown to be the power house that it is. From Toy Story to The Incredibles to Wall E, Pixar developed films for everyone. These films will be around for our children’s children to enjoy as they all have staying power in them that pulls at our heart strings.

Eventually, even stubborn people like me started to come around to his vision world. I eventually bought two iPod shuffles quite late into the game, but found them to be necessity. More recently I was wowed by the iPad, which will become a staple in this home. Even still before that I was able to enjoy Pixar films with my family. Steve had an eye for both design and perfection. My thoughts and wishes go out to his family. Let it be known, that he had the power to sway even the most stubborn converts like myself.

item.title: BBC Cancels Doctor Who Confidential
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: It wasn’t bad enough that Doctor Who had its budget cut down significantly this year. Nor did the show smooth anyone over when it went out with a whimper this season. Nothing was getting any better when we were told that we wouldn’t see new episodes for it until Fall 2012 either. Announced last week, the BBC is now halting production on the behind the scenes portion of the show, Doctor Who Confidential.
item.content:encoded:
It wasn’t bad enough that Doctor Who had its budget cut down significantly this year. Nor did the show smooth anyone over when it went out with a whimper this season. Nothing was getting any better when we were told that we wouldn’t see new episodes for it until Fall 2012 either. Announced last week, the BBC is now halting production on the behind the scenes portion of the show, Doctor Who Confidential.

According to The Guardian, BBC controller Zai Bennett decided to put a stop to the show which aired on BBC3, as part of further cost cutting for the network. Instead of carrying on with the documentary style show while faced with 20% budget cuts, the network decided to shutter the show in order to use the funding towards new, original shows as part of their Delivering Quality First initiative. The strategy of the initiative is to be unveiled on October 6th, so we’ll see just what diverting the funding from a popular segment will do for the channel.

A BBC spokeswoman had this to say about the decision:
“The Doctor Who spin-off series, Doctor Who Confidential, has been a great show for BBC3 over the years, but our priority now is to build on original British commissions, unique to the channel.”

This does leave a few questions hanging out in the wind for fans of the current iteration of Doctor Who. Will this effect the quality of extras that have been coming on the DVD releases? Will this mean the next season will have a little more funding that the skin and bones of the just ending Series 6? Could this be another sign that the BBC pulling away from its flagship title? We have a long wait ahead of us to find out.

Hopefully this isn’t a further sign of what is to come for the future of Doctor Who. Fans, if I were you, I’d stop rallying to save Doctor Who Confidential. Not to say that it wasn’t a great insight into the show, but I’m starting to think that the energy would better be stored away for a time when we will need to convince the BBC to keep Doctor Who running. It is a fantastic show that we all love, but as with all modern era TV shows it lives in a finite window for audience interest and studio funding. It just might be a good idea to let this small part of the show fade into the black for the greater good of the franchise.

Source – The Guardian

item.title: 20SON Review – Orcs Must Die!
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Tower defense. The industry is full of it. No, really. Seriously, there's like hundreds of them. I've popped balloons, blasted scribbles, fried demons, reduced geometric shapes to particle effects, and yes, even blasted some orcs. What I haven't done until Orcs Must Die by is both set up tower defenses and shoot Orcs in the face up close and personal, third person style! Orcs Must Die by Robot Entertainment is the latest entry in the crowded tower defense genre, available now on the xBox Live marketplace.
item.content:encoded:
Tower defense. The industry is full of it. No, really. Seriously, there’s like hundreds of them. I’ve popped balloons, blasted scribbles, fried demons, reduced geometric shapes to particle effects, and yes, even blasted some orcs. What I haven’t done until Orcs Must Die by is both set up tower defenses and shoot Orcs in the face up close and personal, third person style! Orcs Must Die by Robot Entertainment is the latest entry in the crowded tower defense genre, available now on the xBox Live marketplace.

Enter grizzled old War Mage, stage left. He’s got the full Gandalf beard with voice stylings like Deckard Cain of Diablo. Yeah, the whole trope, it’s all here. Many orcs died at this man’s hands and the traps he laid to get the job done. You get the idea. However, permanently exit grizzled old War Mage via back of the head brain smash to the edge of the stairs. He wasn’t pushed by an orc, no. He slipped on a pool of blood. You, the not-so grizzled square jaw broski War Mage apprentice must then defend the Order’s Rift Fortresses, home to the magical rifts that connect the worlds. In the beginning you just have a few tools at your disposal. A sword staff thing that defies rational description and crossbow for personal dispatch. Tar traps and floor spikes for keeping your hands clean. Defend the rift at all costs with every tool you have available to you. Quite literally, Orcs Must Die!

The Wind belt, tossing orcs around. Good for launching them into deep holes!

Fortunately, more defenses become available as time progresses. It doesn’t take long to get exploding barrels. Convenient Orc Launchers, or snooty elf archers to assist you in your quest. Generally, any device you can imagine that will help you spindle, fold, mutilate, and otherwise poorly treat Orcs and their fellow minions is unlockable and improvable as you progress in the 24 level campaign. Defenses aren’t limited to the floor only. One of your first unlockables is an arrow wall, capable of destroying many orcs with one volley of arrows if properly placed. Crushers splatter from a nearby ceiling. Autoballistas shoot large arrows from higher ceilings. Even the environment helps. Drop chandeliers onto unexpecting mobs. Launch orcs into lava or water, or just into the deepest pit you can see by trap or magical device you unlock and can wield.

Nobody ever has infinite resources to set defenses. Before the orcs break down the door or doors leading into your complex, the tasking has already begun. You’ve got to decide from your available tools what you’re bringing to the fight. While there’s no obvious “knife to a gunfight” problem that I’ve seen, your choices given the level geometry can make things easier or harder. If you’ve unlocked them, you can use the Weavers. Weavers (for the right price) allow the purchase of advantages for your traps or yourself like quicker resetting traps, or fire damage for your crossbow. You’ve got a finite amount of coins to set up your initial attempt to repel the hordes. Maybe there’s an easy choke point, maybe there isn’t. Maybe you can make a maze with barricades but whatever you’ve got, you go to war with what you have and not necessarily what you want.

Wall blades, doing what they do best.

As you murder the incoming masses, you collect coins depending on the style or manner in which they’ve been dispatched. Kill a bunch at once? More coins. Kill with combos, like launching orcs with a launcher trap into a blade wall? That’s more coins than just whacking one over the head with your sword staff thing. Shoot an orc in the skull? More. After each minor wave, you’ve got at tops 15 seconds to drop down more defenses with your hard earned sponduliks. Periodically, there’s a big payout and an equally large horde to follow. You have as much time as you want to build your traps up or visit the Weavers with the coins you have on hand before you release the hordes to try and breach your defenses once again.

Unlocking. More tech or magic. It’s the inevitable march. As you complete levels in Orcs Must Die you’re awarded skulls for your performance. One orc hits the rift? Minus one of five skulls. Take too long? Bam! There goes another one. Generally, the less you suck, the more skulls you earn. If you wimp out and play a level on an easier difficulty, you’re capped at 2 out of the max 5 skulls. It behooves you to play on as difficult a level as you can muster. These skulls can be saved or cashed in at the end of each level to upgrade your defenses or magical devices. Some devices become cheaper, like barricades for making a defacto maze for the orcs to pass through as you place them. Some do more damage like blade walls, or do it farther away like arrow walls. I do have to say, you don’t get a good indicator of what your bonus is for upgrades- I saved 12 skulls for cheaper barricade walls. The benefit for saving my skulls? The barricade cost went down from 800 coins to 700. Hardly a bargain. I really should have dropped the cash at the time on better arrow walls, which seem to be my primary Orc deterrent even late in the game.

Read on to see if the Orc massacre was worth the wait!

item.title: 20SON Analysis – Whither the iPhone 5?
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Japan. Home of Godzilla, pocky, and animation of many flavors and tastes. Like French Halo early "releases", Apple Japan spilled the beans a bit early on the iPhone situation. As I've been predicting for months on the podcast, the new iPhone is a 4s, and not a revolutionary teardrop 4G iPhone 5. There's a method to my madness, and a certain logic to how Apple releases iPhones. It's easy to see if you look for it.
item.content:encoded:
Japan. Home of Godzilla, pocky, and animation of many flavors and tastes. Like French Halo early “releases”, Apple Japan spilled the beans a bit early on the iPhone situation. As I’ve been predicting for months on the podcast, the new iPhone is a 4s, and not a revolutionary teardrop 4G iPhone 5. There’s a method to my madness, and a certain logic to how Apple releases iPhones. It’s easy to see if you look for it.

To really get a good feel for Apple release cycles, you have to go back to the iTunes store, and it’s integration with the iPod. In Apple’s eye, products beget new, related products. In 1999, this chain began with iTunes. Then there was the iPod in 2001, which relied on iTunes to do it’s thing. iTunes begat bigger iPods, and the iTunes store in 2003. In 2007, Apple spawned the iPod touch in it’s initial form, which really didn’t seem to fit at the time. Then the 2nd version of the iPod touch operating system was released, with appstore hooks, and an easy way to add more functionality to the device. Only after the iTunes store and the applications were in full swing, did the true iPhone (not the ROKR) come to life later in 2007. This in turn spawned the iPad in 2010 with it’s own set of untrue rumors about it over the summer of 2011 in regards to a new device less than six months after it’s second revision which was a major one in a similar vein to the original iPhone versus the iPhone 3g.

The original iPhone was a decent device, at decent but not amazing speeds. Wifi was great, but the EDGE network didn’t pump you the data that quickly on the device. The second iteration was much better with the faster 3G network, but the same processor and RAM. Released third was the iPhone 3gs, with a 50% greater clock speed and double the application RAM, but overall, it was faster but not amazingly faster than it’s previous revision. With the release of the iPhone 4 came a matching A4 processor to the then new iPad, the higher resolution retina display, a 33% processor speed increase, and another doubling of the application RAM. The iPhone 4 was the first phone since the first iteration of the 3g released two years prior to be a significant upgrade over the previous version. Each iteration has improvements, but major leaps seem to happen every two years. Not coincidentally, the length of most contracts with wireless providers is two years, and Apple knows this.

This brings us to the just announced (single model, thanks anyway, Mr. Gore) iPhone 4S as announced by Apple’s new CEO Tim Cook in somewhat less flamboyant fashion than Mr. Jobs would have. It’s an improvement, yes. It sports a dual core processor, the A5. The A5 is the same processor that’s made the iPad 2 a significantly faster machine than the original iPad. There is a camera increased to 8 megapixels with better optics in the new phone. Cook provides some Apple benchmarks of graphics seven times faster, but as with any manufacturer provided advertising speak, it should be taken with a grain of salt. It is now a “world phone” with user switchable GSM and CDMA. The rumored voice assistant feature, Siri, is included in beta form in the iPhone 4s, but I’m not going to qualify it as an true success until it sees some field time and how well it performs under different acoustical environments or the strain of regional accents. No other super fast wireless network other than some discussion of a better antenna and the potential for a faster theoretical maximum download speed because of it. No new teardrop case. No thinner. Same size screen. The price points remain the same with the addition of a 64 gigabyte model for $399, and all three capacities available starting October 14th. The 8 gigabyte iPhone 4 is available for $99 with a two year contract. Surprisingly, the the 8 gigabyte iPhone 3gs is available for free with a two year commitment to AT+T. The iPod revisions or iOS applications Cook and company talked about accompanying the iOS 5 release on October 12th like News Stand, the new Camera app, Apple’s own Foursquare killer, Twitter integration, or Cards are fine and probably as good as the Apple hype suggests but really beyond the scope of this discussion. Regardless of the hardware, there will always be apps that do cool or interesting things.

Regardless of my apparent griping, this event has overall been a good one for Apple. The iPhone 4S is a solid device, but it’ll be analyzed by the media as disappointing because of what they gleaned from analysts like the almost always wrong Piper Jaffray and various other rumor sites. Related to the disappointment, it’s always dangerous to put too much stock in the Apple rumors sites for a couple of reasons. Apple is known to seed unique prototypes and leak news so they can track it to it’s source and nuke it from orbit, as it’s the only way to be sure. This is all a vicious cycle. A new Apple product is rumored to have revolutionary feature X, and when X isn’t delivered or worse when it’s revolutionary feature X minus 2, the fans (and sometimes the stock price) goes berserk. I give you the same advice that I’ve given people for ten years. Go to the rumors sites for fun, but expect the least dramatic feature improvements that you read about. I’m sure that the rumors reported will all eventually come true and we will see an iPhone 5 and the teardrop shaped phone at some point in the future. Plainly stated, rumors aren’t always in the current product iteration. If you need a rumored feature X, and have to have it, just wait. It’ll be released eventually. For now, if you’re eligible, the iPhone 4s is a great upgrade over your two year old iPhone 3gs in much the same magnitude as the 3gs was a fantastic upgrade over the original iPhone. If you have an iPhone 4, it may not be worth the contract device upgrade fee.

item.title: 20SON Review – Neuroshima Hex! for the iOS
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: I have many failings, not the least of which is my inability to learn any other languages other than English fluently. There is a roleplaying game in Poland with no English translation called Neuroshima, and it sounds like a pretty rich system and setting to play in. The setting is a post-apocalyptic United States after the machines have killed off most of humanity. Sure, it has shades of Terminator's SkyNet, but the fiction diverges from there. Nature has gone wild, the few remnants of humanity are at each other's throats for scarce resources. An AI Moloch responsible for the initial carnage wants to finish the job. Firmly set in this universe is the iOS game Neuroshima Hex for the iOS, developed by Big Daddy's Creations.
item.content:encoded:
I have many failings, not the least of which is my inability to learn any other languages other than English fluently. There is a roleplaying game in Poland with no English translation called Neuroshima, and it sounds like a pretty rich system and setting to play in. The setting is a post-apocalyptic United States after the machines have killed off most of humanity. Sure, it has shades of Terminator’s SkyNet, but the fiction diverges from there. Nature has gone wild, the few remnants of humanity are at each other’s throats for scarce resources. An AI Moloch responsible for the initial carnage wants to finish the job. Firmly set in this universe is the iOS game Neuroshima Hex for the iOS, developed by Big Daddy’s Creations.

Critical to success or failure is your army choice. The starter game priced at $4.99 comes with the mutated cybernetic Borgo, the feudal gang Hegemony, Moloch’s forces of destruction, and humanity’s last general standing army The Outpost. There are two in-app $1.99 purchases for additional armies- New York and their police state forces of order, and Neojungle’s carnivorous plants. Each has their own benefits- New York’s troops adjacent to the headquarters are extra tough, and the Hegemony’s adjacent units have extra melee strength to name two. You can either pick your favorite army or let the iOS pick one for you. Your choice. I found success easiest with The Outpost and the Neojungle, but I’m sure your mileage may vary.

Blue team deciding where to place tiles, early in the game.

Once more into the breach we are hit with the simple to learn, difficult to master paradigm. Neuroshima Hex is played on a 19 hex grid, much the same as the original Settlers of Catan is. Each player starts with a tile representing that faction’s home base. Your goal is the same as up to three other player’s goals – destroy the opposition’s base! Following base placement, the players take turns drawing 3 tiles from their hand and placing 2 of the 3 drawn tiles on the map and selecting which direction they face. Tiles drawn are either unit tiles that represent the various armies in your factions, action titles such as friendly (or hostile!) unit move or start combat, or special effect module tiles like a sniper shot or some sort of combat bonus to attached friendly units.

Same game, a few turns later.

Combat has no random element other than the initial draw from the hand. Each combat unit has iconography representing what combat phase they act in (higher is better), what their fields of fire are, whether they have ranged attacks striking distant hexes or just adjacent hexes, and how much damage they do. Modules have similar iconography showing what adjacent hexes they aid, and how, be it a higher initiative number, better or more attacks, or just a one-time healing effect. No rolls, no tables. When the shooting starts by play of a drawn combat tile, individual battles are resolved counting down from whatever tile has the highest initiative. Damage is applied, and tiles are removed as appropriate before progressing to the next lower initiative number

Sample unit. Two guns, acts on initiative round 2.

No doubt, Neuroshima Hex is complex for an iOS game. The first few games the game’s AI kicked my ass soundly until I remembered the oft held maxim to “do unto others before they do unto you.” That and paying attention to the module effects as they can stack! If you’ve got a powerful gunman opposing you and the tile has a module applying an additional action in the next combat phase, as well as another module supplying extra damage, it’s in your best interest to either destroy the gunman or take out the supporting modules before they can blast away at your forces.

Every wargame has some level of math. Some make you break out the rulers, protractors, and other geometric torture instruments. Some don’t. While the math in Neuroshima Hex isn’t complex as wargame math can get, I can see where playing on an iDevice might simplify and speed the game. Unfortunately, this speedup and simplification comes at the expense of player customization. The inherent lack of user expansion is one major gripe I have with the game. However, it seems to be a complaint I have with most computer strategy games particularly on the iOS or other mobile platforms. There are many player-created armies on the internet, and no way to import them. It’s not hard to learn how to play. The tactical options presented are a bit difficult to get a good handle on. Also, the game doesn’t make a point on educating players on some of the finer points of tactics other than “here’s your units and what they do, now go kill each other.” This is good or bad, depending on your point of view. For some, the joy of discovery is welcome, for others, not having a tactics primer is a major annoyance. Furthermore, multiple human players are pass and play one one device only. Good for car rides, not so good when your buddies are scattered all over the internet. Big Daddy’s Creations reports that the next update released before the end of the year will add asynchronous multiplayer, rectifying this gripe.

I went into Neuroshima Hex blind assuming it was just an abstract strategy game in the vein of Steve Jackson’s Illuminati just for the iPad. I was ridiculously wrong in my assumption. Not only is Neuroshima Hex based on the large and well supported RPG universe I mentioned earlier, but the tabletop game the app was derived from was published in 2005 and itself has a large player base. This makes for a rich, relatively balanced game environment. So, at $4.99 plus $1.99 for each of two armies, is Neuroshima Hex worth 9 copies of Angry Birds? As tactical games go on the iPad, Neuroshima Hex excels, but to some extent makes the new player suffer for this excellence. How different is that from a tabletop strategy experience, though? A buddy wants you to play his or her favorite game, shows you the basic rules, and then kicks your ass all over the map until you either get frustrated and never play again or figure out some of the tricks to the strategies, rules, and units. If a steep learning curve is a problem, or you’re looking for a ten minute fix, then don’t bother. If you’ve got the time to learn the system or are an existing player of the Neuroshima Hex tabletop game, then it’s worth every cent. There is a lite version and unless you’re a devoted strategy gamer or a Neuroshima fan I do strongly recommend you try that first, if for no other reason to see if the learning curve is something you can climb without tossing your expensive iDevice out a window.

Base application was provided by the developer for review. The in-app purchases were made by the reviewer.

item.title: 20SN Review – Enter Corporate War: MERCS (Tabletop)
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: The lair of tabletop gaming can be a hard sell to convince people to enter, if you don't have a key already. Often large army style games have huge buy ins; expensive metal models, environmental elements, paints and so on. Even though the games look beautiful and overly complex compared to your run of the mill board game, they are just out of reach to routinely play on a normal basis. Warhammer in any flavor is a prime example of a great game out of reach for most folks. Finding thousands of dollars to build the perfect army is almost going to be as hard as convincing your friends to do the same with their spare cash. However, I think I may have found a good solution to the problem. Not to the generating funds or begging your friends part mind you, but to another avenue to scratch your miniature wargaming itch.
item.content:encoded:
The lair of tabletop gaming can be a hard sell to convince people to enter, if you don’t have a key already. Often large army style games have huge buy ins; expensive metal models, environmental elements, paints and so on. Even though the games look beautiful and overly complex compared to your run of the mill board game, they are just out of reach to routinely play on a normal basis. Warhammer in any flavor is a prime example of a great game out of reach for most folks. Finding thousands of dollars to build the perfect army is almost going to be as hard as convincing your friends to do the same with their spare cash. However, I think I may have found a good solution to the problem. Not to the generating funds or begging your friends part mind you, but to another avenue to scratch your miniature wargaming itch.

Paint a picture in your mind. It is now almost 200 years into the future. Politics have finally withered to dust to make way for the new ruling classes – corporations. As we’ve suspected all along, they finally made their push for full control of countries making way for mega conglomerates. The world was now divided under the banners of 16 different “MegaCons.” Through bitter battles, economic strategy and corporate sabotage these numbers would eventually ebb, leaving four major players to stand out in the world. The CCC (Eastern North America), KemVar (Central South America), FCC (Southwest Eurasia), and the USCR (Northern Eurasia) floated to the top of the global pool. With these new MegaCons came a new necessity for militarized forces to defend the corporation’s holdings and fight for greater stakes. Enter the Military Economic Reconnaissance Counter Security or MERCS for short.

These dystopian corporate states combined their police and military forces to create a superior legion in which to fight with in the name of their benefactors. These city-state armies break down into squads. You are the commander of one of these squads. You place your team of five on the field to exert dominance over the opposition. Enhanced by your corporate abilities and armed to the teeth, each side battles it out to the death until one side is left standing over the bodies of their prey. In the name of workplace efficiency about 90 minutes of game time is allowed unless the crushed bodies of your foes litter the ground before then. The key to success is tactics. MERCS invites you to play at a level of which requires thought and planning to come out the other side of your conflict alive.

Here is the core of everything you need to play <em>MERCS</em>: Your own set of MegaCon minis and a ton of D10s.

Even if you’re a seasoned veteran of various tabletop battlefields, MERCS doesn’t brow beat you with a rule book. The rulebook is equal opportunity for the veteran and rookie alike. As you would expect, each unit has unique sets of stats such as movement points, blood (hit points), and armor values among other stats and skills. All of these values are given to you on a non-collectible card for each figure. Each turn breaks into two phases- initiative and action. If you are familiar with D20 ruleset games, initiative shouldn’t be foreign. Both players roll a D10 (the only die used) for a initiative value for each member of their squad. After each solider has their assigned number, you then proceed to the action phase for each MERC in order from highest to lowest. As you move through each soldier you have the option to move, attack or hold. These actions should be pretty self explanatory. During your turn you call your action and proceed through the steps.

Each unit starts off a card length off of the edge of your playing board. In this case that was just a table.

If you planning to move your MERC, you have to consider the movement points listed on the card. The nice thing about movement is there are cut outs in the cards that you use to measure your movements. No more grabbing the tape measure to see how far you get to go. Do you need to turn a little to accomplish that? You can do that without having to spend a movement point, unless you are turning more than 90 degrees. Does your designated movement spot leave you just shy of the wall you were hoping to get to? You might be in luck if you are within a miniature base from it. The rules specify a nifty ability called “snap to cover” that you can use anytime this occurs. If you chose to do nothing, just declare a hold. How’s that for making things simple?

In the thick of it you'll quickly start to use up space on your 2" x 3" or 3" x 3" battlefield. Card decks come with a few terrain cards, but why not make your own too?

As with most games, attacking is a little more complex. Thankfully MERCS doesn’t make it near to impossible and force you to wade through paragraphs of rules to try and get things accomplished. There are numerous things that play into your potential for damage. Things such as range to target, cover and weapon strength play into each chance at a hit. The great thing about it that you aren’t completely depending on the random roll of the dice to see if your strike connects. Instead a predetermined firing number for the weapon you’re using, plus the aforementioned modifiers, gives you a number to aim for with your roll. In essence, you are rolling against yourself. Even if you succeed, just because you hit the opposing forces doesn’t guarantee damage. Choose the wrong method and end up never piercing armor. Coordinate and pick correctly to deal the real damage. Some abilities have multiple hits that balance out weak weapon damage. However, you can only dole out the pain once per attack that connects.

For the review the MERCS Minis folks provided us the CCC and KemVar factions. The faction choice provided showed a good contrast between the MegaCon factions. The Yellow Jackets (CCC) have superior armor capabilities and a medic, while the KemVar have a unique stealth system that always allows them to be at half cover. It makes both sides somewhat difficult to actually hit, especially from a distance. Each MegaCon is designed with specific pros and cons between them. This makes tactics and smart player choices play a huge part in winning a battle. In the case of the sets provided, you could tell that the CCC were meant to stand the test of time, taking punishing damage only to let their armor and medic to the work. As for the KemVar, their cloaking/cover ability made them difficult to him from a distance. For someone to do damage, they’d have to work their way in. The problem with that is that the KemVar soldiers want you to do the work of moving in. With classes like the assassin, their melee abilities reign supreme. Figuring out which corporation suits your play style is a matter of personal opinion, but many options are there. Recently MERCS Minis added a fifth MegaCon, the Sefadu. A sixth, the Keizai Waza, are also in production slated for an mid-October release giving the prospective MERCS player two more choices than presented in the “basic” set.

Read on to see how we rank this corporate war game!

Farmer Rick joins the nerds for this slightly longer than average cast. Hailing from the tundra of Nebraska, Rick adds a certain flair to tonight's proceedings.

Farmer Rick joins the nerds for this slightly longer than average cast. Hailing from the tundra of Minnesota, Rick adds a certain flair to tonight’s proceedings. Be it the fellowship of a companion home brewer or the brotherhood of the military, he definitely accents this episode. You might think we’re a little bit of crazy talking about farming on a nerd podcast, but we promise there is method to the madness. Take a listen, if anything it might help you during the zombie apocalypse.

Topics covered include:

  • A recap of this week’s reviews at 20SON, and why games can be a challenge to review.
  • Draeno discusses his participation in the Diablo III beta.
  • The Star Wars blurays sold $84 million in just a few days.
  • The Big Bang Theory has restarted. Congrats to Jim Parsons on his second Emmy!

  • Neil Armstrong is ashamed of NASA, and he should be.
  • Meg Whitman is the new CEO of HP. Couldn’t be any worse.
  • Facebook is changing, again. Raaaage!
  • Netflix/Quixster’s continuing swirl down the bowl.
  • Al Gore blabs the coming release of the iPhone(s). It’s no blue stained dress.
  • Everygame and Apple’s ongoing saga.

Until next week!

item.title: 20SON Review – Shock and Awe: Red Orchestra 2
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Over saturation in the shooter market has always been a problem. Again and again publishers churn out scenarios in titles that they think we want, but in reality they are mostly unwelcome rehashes of things we've already seen. When yet another World War II-era game was proposed to me, I couldn't help but to roll my eyes a little. Between all the Medals of Duty, Battle of Honors and Callfields could it be that we'd be stuck with just another assault on our wallets? Could it be that a shooter was produced that would step outside of the norm, or should we prepare for another in a long line of the cliché? Tripwire looks to persuade us with their most recent offering, Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad.
item.content:encoded:
Over saturation in the shooter market has always been a problem. Again and again publishers churn out scenarios in titles that they think we want, but in reality they are mostly unwelcome rehashes of things we’ve already seen. When yet another World War II-era game was proposed to me, I couldn’t help but to roll my eyes a little. Between all the Medals of Duty, Battle of Honors and Callfields could it be that we’d be stuck with just another assault on our wallets? Could it be that a shooter was produced that would step outside of the norm, or should we prepare for another in a long line of the cliché? Tripwire looks to persuade us with their most recent offering, Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad.

Running might seem like a trivial thing in games, but keep your eyes peeled. One shot can take you out if you aren't paying attention.

Red Orchestra 2 puts you on the front lines of the World War II conflict. For a change of pace, it places the player on the side not often explored by video game culture- the German/Russian conflict. Single player doesn’t push you through thick scenarios or pivotal moments that you’d typically recognize from video game history. Red Orchestra offers a different path. It pits you at odds against the Axis or Allies forces with an end goal of taking key strategy points to the war. Moving from point to point you push through the dredges holding out for reinforcements in the shattered remains of buildings.

At first it is a different feeling when jumping into playing Red Orchestra. I’m not afraid to say this caught me a little by surprise. With every new shooter that comes to market, we assume that everything will be just the same. Basic movements, actions, weapons and so forth. What we never seem to expect is a game that brings an ounce of realism to the table. The scenarios sometimes come to the surface for a brief moment during the campaign, but a moment is generally all we get. Instead in Red Orchestra we’re faced with a more realistic approach to how things would have been. Instead of bursting into every room guns blazing and jumping around to avoid incoming fire, it is more prudent to pick and choose when to run and gun or when to sit back. Taking hits isn’t as simple as waiting for your shield to regenerate either. There are actual consequences to taking fire and the adjustment as a player is infuriating sometimes to say the least.

Weaponry plays a huge aid to the realistic feel as well. Firearms don’t have unlimited clips. No round count is on the interface. You aren’t going to fire off 300 rounds a second, then immediately blast them with a phosphorus grenade as a secondary firing method. The only weapons you see are true to the period and act like they should. Being a person with a Mosin Nagant in their household, I have a profound respect for Tripwire keeping it that way. You want to check and see if you gun is still loaded? You have to actually hold your reload key to see if there are bullets in it. I can truly appreciate the thought put behind that. There were a few times because I wasn’t keeping track of what I fired, a perfect shot was marred by a hollow click.

Unlike many shooters out there, you have assistance in the form of an army. It creates a different impact on the player, because it will carry on without you. If members of the squadron perish, timers start to when reinforcements will arrive. As long as one solider remains, your army will fight on. A odd side effect comes out via this perpetual replenishment as well. It is possible to win via attrition. Not the soundest of strategies, but it does carry a weight of truth to it as befitting the setting. Both German and Russian leaders disregarded human life in the name of victory. At the end of the war, the resounding number of casualties in the Eastern Conflict reflected this. I don’t know if it was intentional by the developer to capture that essence, nor should it be taken lightly, but it plays well into the style of the game.

A tank mode is offered as another multiplayer feature. While it breaks up the trench warfare a little, it doesn't always seem like it belongs.

Not everything is fine and dandy with Red Orchestra 2. There was something off as I was planning on bouncing from single player to multiplayer. I couldn’t shake the fact that both offered very similar experiences. I’ve come to expect an exhilarating, fast paced push through the solo portion from experience playing every other franchise in this overpopulated segment. As short as these other game’s missions may have been, they were offering at least a difference to playing against others. With Red Orchestra, other gamers are taking the place of your squad members that in the single-player mode you had an opportunity to command. The overall feel doesn’t really change from single to multi. Generally speaking the similarity isn’t a terrible thing, but it almost feels like $10 could have been knocked of the price to make it an online only title.

Move forward to catch the conclusion!

item.title: Guest Review – Dead Island (xBox 360)
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Dead Island takes place on the fictional island of Banoi, a luxurious paradise where the rich go to relax and party. Recently a mysterious infection has spread throughout the island causing people to die and then rise up as flesh craving undead. You wake up in your hotel room and immediately feel that something is wrong. As you head outside you see bags strewn about and hear an emergency message playing over the intercom. You make your way to the bottom floor and are ambushed by the infected. From there on you explore the island looking for a way out and helping other survivors along the way. Despite the undead stalking you, should this trip to Banoi be on your itinerary?
item.content:encoded:

You make your way to the bottom floor and are ambushed by the infected. From there on you explore the island looking for a way out and helping other survivors along the way. Despite the undead stalking you, should this trip to Banoi be on your itinerary?

As you progress throughout the campaign, you have main quests which further the story and side quests. These quests reward you with money, items and experience as is fairly standard for RPG/Shooter hybrids. Many of these quests are simple fetch and deliver quests, which can get repetitive and boring. Fortunately, there’s always undead adversaries to keep you on your toes while you’re fetching widgets for somebody’s snipe hunt. You may also encounter more than just zombies out there. While some of the quests were pretty similar and some seemed tedious to do, the story itself was interesting to experience. Things get more and more complex as you make your way through the island, right up until the finale.

At the start, you don’t have many options when it comes to weapons. Pick up an oar here, a pipe there, nothing really powerful or useful. You’re mainly just looking for something to smash zombies in the skull. As you progress and level up, you gain access to better weapons such as machetes and baseball bats. Furthering your engine of destruction, modifications become available to trick out your weapons with electricity and fire. Nothing is more satisfying than watching a zombie dance around as it is electrocuted to death. You even get access to guns at one point, but don’t get too used to them due to almost Bungie-esque ammo scarcity. This is more of a melee game.

The zombies themselves are pretty tough as well. As opposed to Left 4 Dead, where you can mow down zombies with an SMG, these zombies can take quite a beating before they go down. Going one on one with a zombie is fairly easy, but watch your back because if you find yourself fighting 5-6 at a time, they’ll take you down faster than you might think. Occasionally you may be walking through the resort, when a zombie grabs you out of nowhere and gives you a close up of its fugly face as it tries to bite you. That caught me off guard on more than one occasion.

Stamina also plays an important role in this game. You can’t just mindlessly hack away at everything that moves. Eventually you’ll wear yourself down and leave yourself vulnerable to attack. Running and jumping takes out stamina as well, but this usually isn’t a problem unless you’re in the middle of a fight. It was never a huge problem for me, but that said, it did cause my death on more than one occasion as I mowed down zombies.

Something I must mention is the co-op. This game can be fun solo, but can also get pretty boring as well. If you want to really experience this game, you have to play with a friend over xBox live. You can travel together or be up to 700 meters apart taking on different missions. Having more players also ups the number of foes for you to fight, so separating might not be the best course of action. I’m going to quote a tagline for Left 4 Dead, which also works really well here: “It’s the zombie apocalypse. Bring friends.”

The controls felt really smooth and natural, from weapon selection to using said weapon and navigation. I loved fighting the tough zombies (though on occasion I wanted to throw my controller at the wall).

Lastly, the graphics. If you’re looking for Crysis, look elsewhere. This game isn’t too high end in this department. While you have a huge area to play in with few obvious loading areas like the Mass Effect elevators, the graphics still are sub par for this console generation at best. NPC’s all look similar to each other, with little detail and terrible facial expressions. In addition, while loading some areas the detail might take 5-10 seconds to fully load leaving you looking at solid shape buildings and shapes while dealing with the texture pop. This is probably the worst area of the game. I prefer solid gameplay to beautiful graphics so I personally don’t mind, but if you need epic lens flare and other graphic staples of this generation, this is not the title for you.

This game definitely requires a demo if you don’t pick it up. It’s an enjoyable RPG with plenty of enemies to fight and quests to complete. I easily spent 30+ hours on my first play through completing all the various quests. If you love RPG’s and zombies, you’ll love this game. Dead Island is one of the best games of the 2011 season.

-CrazedOne

*Game was purchased by the reviewer.

item.title: 20SON Review – Rock of Ages (XBLA)
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Rolling item games have come into a bit of a resurgence since the Marble Madness days with the advent of the iPad and other such motion sensitive devices. They don't typically result in the kind of destruction that Ace Team's and Atlus's Rock of Ages deals, though. Does Rock of Ages satisfy in only the way a massive ball of destruction can, or does the rolling path lead nowhere.
item.content:encoded:
Rolling item games have come into a bit of a resurgence since the Marble Madness days with the advent of the iPad and other such motion sensitive devices. Though they don’t typically result in the kind of destruction that Ace Team’s and Atlus’s Rock of Ages deals. Does Rock of Ages satisfy in only the way a massive ball of destruction can, or does the rolling path lead nowhere?

God Gave Rock and Roll To You
Literally, you have a Sisyphean task to accomplish, considering you’re actually the eponymous Sisyphus. There are boulders to be eternally pushed uphill, and minions harassing you at every turn. After too many pokes in the butt by a minion you get the bright idea to use your massive boulder as a tool for escape- thus begins Rock of Ages. At the end of a (mildly) torturous path lies Hades’ front door. You have to beat down this front door with your boulder to escape. The first few tutorial levels proceed in similar fashion, adding more game complexities as you go. First, just the gate beatdown. Second, defenses you and your opponent can place to slow your progress. Third, an opposing force boulder intent on beating your own gate and forces down.

I Wanna Rock
Upon completion of the tutorial levels, the meat of the game begins. Varied paths, collectibles, enemies, and opposing defenses (as varied as herds of pigs, catapults, and war elephants) wait for you to smash them flat with your boulder. It’s your choice to smash them and accumulate cash for your own defenses and boulder upgrades, or to avoid them completely. The more damage your own boulder takes on the way down the less of the effect you have on the the enemy’s gate, so sometimes discretion is the better part of valor. Boss battles break the gate-smashing routine from time to time, but those aren’t much more than a variant of find and pummel the weak spot, like most games. Multiplayer is exactly the same as the game’s single-player mode with the welcome addition of split screen play, a rarity these days.

Rock You Like a Hurricane
Not feeling quite so competitive? Two other game modes await your menu selection- time trials and skeeball. I’m of a mixed mind about the two. Time trials were an an obvious choice for this game. Less defensive hassle, more speed. Some of the time goals selected for medals seem a bit arbitrary, and depend on just the perfect ricochet or bankshot of your boulder to even come close to competing the track in the allotted time. The Skee-Boulder mode I thought I’d have the most fun with, but regretfully, not as much as I had hoped. Smashing stuff at your leisure on the way down, or as much leisure as a downhill track can muster, is great fun, but the actual skeeball landing area on the bottom is a bit of a letdown. With enough patience and time, you can jump your boulder into the maximum reward multiplier unless your initial aim is truly, truly terrible. The simple removal of the jump button after a certain point in the level would make this phase of the skeeball mode much more enjoyable.

Rock Me Amadeus
The graphics and presentation in Rock of Ages are…unique. Drawn in a 2D Monty Python adjacent art style, five ages of mankind are presented humorously with nods to pop culture. Spartans want to kick you down a hole, and aren’t afraid to say so. Bearded wizards announce their determination to stop you from proceeding. You get the idea, I’m sure. Take it or leave it, Rock of Ages doesn’t take itself too seriously.

Rock and a Hard Place
Rock of Ages not taking itself too seriously is part of the problem with reviewing the game. The lack of “balance” for lack of a better word in the Skee-Boulder mode is an issue. Not not a show stopping one, because more gameplay is better than less. Like other titles boss battles are present, but seem almost incoherent compared to the rest of the game. The graphical style and nods towards pop culture can be viewed as heartily welcome or to be avoided like a poisonous snake. There is both strategy to be had as well as a dose of twitch reflex gaming. If you suck at one or the other, it won’t break the game for you. Rock of Ages isn’t a classic, but it doesn’t have to be. At press time, Rock of Ages costs 800 Microsoft points, or $10 on Steam. Whether or not you want to pay full price depends on if light strategy, smashing things with a giant boulder, and a quirky sense of humor all appeal to you. Two out of three? Get it on sale. Only one of the three? Maybe wait for a steep sale. As for this reviewer, I enjoy it, and I think the 800 points is a fair price for an accessible and entertaining game.

*Game was provided by the publisher for review.

item.title: 20SON Review – My Tropico 4 Vacation
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Ages have passed since I enjoyed a world construction experience. Perhaps not even since grade school have I even dared to spend slivers of my free time in such a fashion. It might not be the longest in terms of actual years, but think about the time when Sim City 2000 was a popular game. In sheer terms of computer technology, there an enormous gap of time has passed since then. When Tropico 4 was laid upon me with the promise of a kick back to this bygone age of games, I admittedly looked at it with trepidation. To sweeten the pot, a dash of Civilization style strategy was promised to give Kalypso's title its own bit of flair. In the end does it leave you with a mellow feeling like a day on the beach, or are you going to be holding your head reeling from too many Caribbean cocktails?
item.content:encoded:
Ages have passed since I enjoyed a world construction experience. Perhaps not even since grade school have I even dared to spend slivers of my free time in such a fashion. It might not be the longest in terms of actual years, but think about the time when Sim City 2000 was a popular game. In sheer terms of computer technology, there an enormous gap of time has passed since then. When Tropico 4 was laid upon me with the promise of a kick back to this bygone age of games, I admittedly looked at it with trepidation. To sweeten the pot, a dash of Civilization style strategy was promised to give Kalypso’s title its own bit of flair. In the end does it leave you with a mellow feeling like a day on the beach, or are you going to be holding your head reeling from too many Caribbean cocktails?

Who out there hasn’t thought of owning their own island in the tropics at one point in their lives? It’s one of those steps everyone wants to take the day the money comes in. Buy a fancy car, a house, then an island. Why not? Tropico takes that idea a step further throwing you into the shoes of your own mock dictator. Will you be a kind leader who takes into account the needs of your people? Do you lust for cash, greedily turning your countries profits into your own? Or maybe you want to live harmoniously off the lands and commune with nature? Any of these are a viable solution for you to build upon your own chunk of tropical beauty. Be careful though- just because it is your way doesn’t always make it the right way.

Don't like the look of the beloved El Presidente? Don't worry! Outside of having a few presets to choose from, you can even create your own!

When you first start up Tropico players can’t help but notice just how easy it is to play. Take your tried and true formula of building to raise capital, spending money to make money, and balancing just what the population needs won’t be a foreign concept at all. You build your farms to make food. Housing is built to accommodate your villagers. Basic infrastructure needs are installed like police, government and markets. What might be new is the idea of variance in the types of buildings and where you can place them. On every generated land, there are prime spots to raise animals on grazing land, better climates for certain plant crops, and even optimal locations for wind generators. Making the best of the plot you were given does play an important role. Food and education are always free. In fact, the basic amenities are almost an afterthought as you play on. With a few corn fields and cattle ranches, the only thing the player has to keep up with is housing. Simple is good, especially for a game that aims to keep you busy through task after task.

Heat maps are offered to the player to indicate things such as resource placement for optimal growth, population density and crime areas.

Another great discovery upon loading up Tropico 4, was the great job Kalypso did in creating a beautiful world for gamers to play in. The graphics for an overhead style builder game are phenomenal. Even when zooming in upon items, you really get a appreciation for how much was put into it. Specific world details were obviously a big project taken on by the studio in an effort to really get into the game. If you wanted to know the name of each worker on a farm, you could. If a specific citizen was unhappy, you could find out exactly why. How many games out there go to the sort of detail of generating feelings and personalities for virtual neighbors? The various advisors are also painted with a caricature style look that makes you want to laugh a little. You’d think it doesn’t fit, but it does. The little whimsical look of them adds to just how much the game doesn’t take itself seriously. It wants to be fun. It wants players to hum along with the authentic feeling music. To Kalypso’s credit, they pulled this aspect of it off amazingly.

Continue on to see just how much of a vacation this is

item.title: Batman: Arkham City Soundtrack Might Be Worth A Listen
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Game soundtracks make you think of chiptunes and ambient music. It isn't often that you run into a full blown original album featuring some of the more unique bands on the scene now. With the announcement of the feature track "Deranged" by Coheed & Cambria my excitement shot through the roof.
item.content:encoded:
Game soundtracks make you think of chiptunes and ambient music. It isn’t often that you run into a full blown original album featuring some of the more unique bands on the scene now. With the announcement of the feature track “Deranged” by Coheed & Cambria my excitement shot through the roof.

Coheed & Cambria – left to right Mic Todd (recently removed), Travis Stever, Claudio Sanchez, & Chris Pennie

New ground has been breached by the band in the inclusion of this music accompaniment. Instead of their typical music story telling writing modus operandi revolving around Claudio Sanchez’s epic science fiction story told musically in each album and in comics, a brand new song outside of that world has been crafted specifically for Arkham City. Sanchez was able to draw deep on the influences of the Batman mythos to create a dark vibe with the epic punch one has come to expect from this prog rock juggernaut.

Coming out October 4th, only two weeks before the game’s release, this music should go far to get you ready to take on the hordes of villains on the mean streets of Gotham. If you were considering ordering the collector’s edition, you’ll be happy to know that a download code will be provided within!

Still torn on the album? Check out the track listing below:

1. Panic! At The Disco – Mercenary
2. Coheed and Cambria – Deranged
3. The Duke Spirit – Creature
4. Black Rebel Motorcycle Club – Shadow On The Run
5. Blaqk Audio – Afterdark
6. The Raveonettes – Oh, Stranger
7. ††† (Crosses) – The Years
8. The Damned Things – Trophy Widow
9. Daughtry – Drown In You
10. The Boxer Rebellion – Losing You
11. Serj Tankian – Total Paranoia

*Source – http://music.ign.com/articles/119/1194288p1.html

item.title: 20SON Review – iPad Ticket to Ride Version 1.1
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Over the last few decades, there have been a few board games that populate people's closets and toy boxes. In the past, games like Sorry, Monopoly, Battleship, and the Game of Life have been the primary inhabitants of family game shelves. In the last 10 years, there's been a trend toward slightly more complex games carving out a niche, supplementing the old classics. The late 20th century and early 21st century has brought us Carcassone, Settlers of Catan, and other games labeled with a "Eurogame" moniker. This summer Days of Wonder released their contribution to the Eurogame scene, Ticket to Ride for the iPad. Not everything is well suited to a smudgeware implementation. How easily does Ticket to Ride adapt to this new iteration of technology?
item.content:encoded:
Over the last few decades, there have been a few board games that populate people’s closets and toy boxes. In the past, games like Sorry, Monopoly, Battleship, and the Game of Life have been the primary inhabitants of family game shelves. In the last 10 years, there’s been a trend toward slightly more complex games carving out a niche, supplementing the old classics. The late 20th century and early 21st century has brought us Carcassone, Settlers of Catan, and other games labeled with a “Eurogame” moniker. This summer Days of Wonder released their contribution to the Eurogame scene, Ticket to Ride for the iPad. Not everything is well suited to a smudgeware implementation. How easily does Ticket to Ride adapt to this new iteration of technology?

You'll see this screen a lot. Keep tabs of your own hand, and basics of everybody else's

The basic Ticket to Ride game is widely considered a classic family game after only a very few years of release. It’s a great example of the oft-repeated marketing line “easy to learn, difficult to master” popularized by Mastermind in the seventies. Summarizing a scant few pages of game manual, Ticket to Ride’s subject matter is the railroad rushes of the early 20th century starting with the basic USA map included in the $50 boxed set. A non-collectible card mechanic provides both the random and resource gathering element of the game, leaving the overall strategy of when and where to build tracks to complete route cards completely up to the players. Up to five players can play.

Every player starts with four railroad cars, and up to three route cards. Each turn, you can either draw a single card from the five visible railroad cars, pick two railroad cards blindly from the deck, build tracks, or pick new route cards. Picking cards from the deck is self-explanatory. Each card has a color, or is wild. Routes between cities are built by having the appropriate number of colored or wild cards to complete the track. More than one track completed between cities may complete one of your route cards. Points are scored by completing tracks, the longer the better, and completing routes. Don’t pick too many route cards- incomplete route cards at the end of the game count against your score. Depending on the rule revision you’re using, either the longest continuous stretch of track or the most route cards completed get a point bonus. Whichever player accumulates the most points, wins!

On the iPad, the initial Ticket to Ride purchase is $6.99. Most iDevice games are priced well below this, but I feel that the cost to benefit equation on this purchase is pretty clear. I’ll be succinct- The $6.99 initial purchase gives you 100% of the basic Ticket to Ride set. There are no omissions. Yes, the 1.1 revision fixed a major issue with the game in adding pass and play to the game, which was lacking in the original 1.0 release.

Given the $6.99 cost of admission, let’s to do some quick Amazon.com math. At press time the basic boxed set of Ticket to Ride costs $35.48. The Europe Expansion costs $40.27, the 1910 expansion runs $16.20, and the out of print Switzerland map expansion is available from one seller for $125. Not even including the collectible Switzerland expansion the basic sets and all the expansions will run you $90. All told, the iPad versions of all these expansions and the basic set cost around $14 total. Buy the entire collection for the iPad and come out at least $75 ahead! I was fortunate. I found my basic meatspace boxed set of Ticket to Ride at our local super-sized thrift store for not much more than the iPad version of the game. Even though it was at the thrift store, it’s still important to note that it still cost more than the iPad version!

Gathering your buds for a game

The artificial intelligence is passable for a quick game for when you’re out of range of your internet provider. Where Ticket to Ride shines is it’s integration with Days of Wonder’s Ticket to Ride online opponent matching service which has been available for the PC and Mac for some time. I’ve signed onto the service at many times of the day and night over the review period, and there’s always been somebody available to play. I didn’t experience any inadvertent (or intentional!) disconnects in my trials. In-game communication is a little rough, with a “speech bubble” popping up that’s often truncated, appears and disappears too quickly, or has an overzealous automatic profanity filter interacting with what’s said. I’m 41. I know it’s hard to enforce online, but I think I can deal with seeing the occasional profanity pop up in this bubble and not be psychologically scarred.

Screen summarizing the expansions you can get for your iPad Ticket To Ride.

As I previously touched on there are many, many more expansions for the Ticket to Ride tabletop version available. If I have to point out a flaw in this game for the iPad, it’s that more of these expansions aren’t available. Specifically Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries, the Europa 1912 expansion, and Alvin and Dexter. I did ask Christine Goutaland, our contact at Days of Wonder about this specifically. Her response to me was:

“We are always considering upgrades, improvements and add-ons based on demand from our customers. Although it is too early to tell what is coming next, I can tell you that we are working hard and very excited about our next digital releases!”

Considering that the addition of pass to play in revision 1.1 was solely generated by user feedback, and very quickly after release, I’ll take the quote as very hopeful for future expansion of this game.

I’ve said this in a previous review about another strategy title, but this is not Angry Birds. Quick reflexes play zero part in success or failure at this game. If you’re a strategy gamer in any aspect be it the occasional game of Stratego or Risk, or a more hardcore grognard who delights in D-Day or Advanced Squad Leader, I cannot recommend Ticket to Ride on the iPad strongly enough. The basic game, and all three available expansions will set you back less than a large pizza, so there’s no excuse to not hit the “purchase” button if you’re the owner of any generation of iPad.

*The basic game was provided by the developer for review. The in-app expansions were purchased by the reviewer.
