item.title: 20SON Review Space Marine – A Blessing from the Machine God
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Games Workshop has one hell of an IP on their hands and they eventually saw the light of day when it came to expanding the empire. After all, the Warhammer properties are perhaps some of the strongest in tabletop existence. It wasn't until they wisely bestowed the creation honor to Relic and THQ that titles came out truly doing the name proud. The Dawn of War series was probably one of the greatest lines to comes out in the real time strategy market since its inception. With Space Marine though, THQ was taking a small gamble giving their RTS heroes the reigns to a third person shooter platform.
item.content:encoded:
There is something that always impressed me about Games Workshop’s Warhammer 40k universe. Be it the rich background, the dark, gothic environment or the fantasy of battling aliens for a greater cause, an allure was crafted around it for me. In this gritty world, it just struck me that something had been lacking. It could simply be the fact that I couldn’t exist in this fictional world, but more likely it was that our perceptions of this galaxy were stifled by the multitude of authors that contributed to it’s being. It isn’t to say the writers gave an appalling interpretation, but rather that fans lacked a exciting, tangible experience. With the induction of Space Marine, THQ made a push to correct this oversight.

Games Workshop has one hell of an IP on their hands and they eventually saw the light of day when it came to expanding the empire. After all, the Warhammer properties are perhaps some of the strongest in tabletop existence. It wasn’t until they wisely bestowed the creation honor to Relic Entertainment and THQ that titles came out truly doing the name proud. The Dawn of War series was probably one of the greatest lines to come out in the real time strategy market since its inception. With Space Marine though, THQ was taking a small gamble giving their real time strategy heroes the reigns to a third person shooter platform.

From space we see our intended battle grounds. Impressive Imperium world is it not?

In this iteration you thrust into an immediate conflict on a forge world. A xenos infestation has endangered a key strategic asset on this factory planet that cannot be lost under any circumstance. Rather than level the planet from orbit, a strike team is ordered to secure it by any means necessary. Who would the Emperor choose to send on this likely suicide mission? None other than a squad of his finest, bravest, elite soldiers – the Ultramarines. You play the role of Captain Titus. A born blue space marine from the start. You and the squad that follows you are tasked by your God-Emperor to purge the Xenos from the forge world. Together you collect your array of both familiar and new weapons of destruction to stop the Orks from decimating the Imperium factory.

Nothing can stop an Ultramarine from carrying out his task in the name of the Emperor.

Space Marine does a fantastic job showing you just what it is like to be the right hand of the Emperor. The sheer brutality that is pressed upon you enlightens you to just what kind of hell an Ultramarine is asked to routinely jump into. It isn’t enough that the game plays these scenes out for you, but that you play an intricate hand in inflicting it. Of course it doesn’t help that the player is encouraged to execute their opponents in bloody, violent ways to bolster their own life to illustrate that. With that excessive maliciousness comes a profound respect for death. It is an honor to be given the life you were by the machine God. To do anything other than return that gift is beyond reason. Captain Titus, our protagonist, makes it a point to remind you. So do the swarms of AI foes that constantly berate you. Orks can be unforgiving as they are endlessly tossed from all directions in an attempt to end your blessed existence. Fortunately, Titus is adept at dispatching the impure through bullet, blast and blade.

Was it mentioned that as a Space Marine you really dislike Orcs?

Graphically the Imperial Forge World Graia is wondrous and deserves praise unto itself. Relic crafted a thing of beauty with the engine that immerses you into the urgency of stopping the onslaught from progressing any further. The industrial atmosphere of the Warhammer universe plays a huge part in that. You spend time looking around every corner, making sure you see the start of the horde encroaching on your position before they find you. Campaign stages are repurposed quite well to develop competitive maps for multiplayer similar to what Halo: ODST and Halo: Reach did. As breath taking as it can be, the world also plays a functional role in balancing firefights when gear gaps can be large. There’s nothing quite like rocket jumping over a heavy gunner to drop a pile of grenades on his head.

Carry on to the next page for the conclusion!

item.title: Mini Critique – Crimson Steam Pirates
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: First of all, if you’ve got an iPad go download Crimson Steam Pirates (CSP). I’ll be here when you come back. Yes, it’s a genius turn-based strategy game with a luxurious fictional universe built up around it. Yes, the first... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
First of all, if you’ve got an iPad go download Crimson Steam Pirates (CSP). I’ll be here when you come back.

Yes, it’s a genius turn-based strategy game with a luxurious fictional universe built up around it. Yes, the first chapters are free, and the additional two sets of 8 chapters will run you all of a dollar each. What it isn’t is perfect. Here’s what I’d like to see in future incarnations of this game:

A) A “Next unit” button. Sometimes in the furballs the user interface elements overlap and it can be quite confusing, regardless of zoom level. A simple “next unit” button with a clear indication that you’ve given all your units new orders for the turn would be very welcome.

B) Mission and vehicle editor. CSP is a 2D game with relatively simple gameplay elements. It’s ripe for a custom level and unit creation tool. Sure, it’s probably got to be a Windows or OSX application, but the iTunes file sharing used in such mundane applications as PDF readers should be sufficient to load a user-created level or unit.

C) More scenarios. I think the 8 levels that are going to be in each chapter might be a little sparse, given the fiction that’s been generated already for the universe. Such things are par for the course in a Jordan Weisman created universe (think anything by FASA or any given Battletech product).

D) More freeform gameplay. The scenarios are terrific but are stand alone. Harebraned Schemes, call Firaxis, get the rights to insert your units and fiction in the Pirates-style of gameplay with a semi-persistent world and an overarching plot, rather than just single scenarios. Build your officer crew as you go depending on who you hire or who’s loyalty you earn by deeds. As new labs or technologies are discovered, more equipment can be installed in your steamships!

E) Horde/Firefight mode. Bring on the baddies until I’m dead! No super-deep thought, no plot. Straight out bad guy blasting. Let me pick the map, let me pick my starting unit or units, and let’s rock!

F) Point based ship construction. This goes with point E above. Wargames for years support their combat systems with some sort of checks and balances system. Points, tons, spaces, or what have you to prevent rules lawyers from taking too much advantage of the system. While an unlimited system in point A is great for scenario designers, this would be a blast to have. A system in the relatively ancient Naval Ops: Warship Gunner is a bit overkill, but something more pen and paper war-game style would be excellent.

Don’t take my requests as serious reasons why you shouldn’t play Crimson Steam Pirates. All in all, CSP is one of the more simultaneously deep and accessible iPad strategy games I’ve played in quite some time. Even though the external mechanics are simple, the depth of gameplay isn’t. A mostly clean user interface allows for precise enough ship handling and efficient bludgeoning of your foes. What’s more the first 8 chapters, including multiplayer combat, are free, so there’s no excuse to not hit download today!

item.title: Guest Review – Crimson Alliance (XBL)
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Summer has come to a close, the kids are going back to school, and Microsoft’s highly successful xBox Live Summer of Arcade is drawing to an end. The cherry on top of this summer’s onslaught of downloadable games is the... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
Summer has come to a close, the kids are going back to school, and Microsoft’s highly successful xBox Live Summer of Arcade is drawing to an end. The cherry on top of this summer’s onslaught of downloadable games is the aptly titled Crimson Alliance, a title coming from the map pack maestros at Certain Affinity. Crimson Alliance is free for anyone who bought all 5 other Summer of Arcade titles, and for others, it adopts a unique pricing model in more ways than one. If you want to buy Crimson Alliance, but didn’t buy the other Summer of Arcade titles, you can purchase the game by either paying the full 15$, or, if you only want to play one of the 3 classes, you can shell out 10 bucks instead. The big question is, even at a reduced $10 for one class, is the game worth playing?

Crimson Alliance centers on the return of a presumably long-gone sorceress named the Soul Siren, and the quest of 3 (or 4, if you’re playing co-op with a few more friends) heroes on their way to stop her. It’s a more than adequate plot that does well to push the action in different directions, offering varied locations, new enemies, and tougher challenges throughout. Each character at your disposal has his or her own personality; the wizard is wise, the Assassin is wise cracking, and the Mercenary; levelheaded and deliberate.

Each character also offers uniquely diverse combat styles. The Wizard is primarily a ranged combatant, the Mercenary a close-quarters brawler, and the Assassin, a mixture of the two. Playing these classes solo offers everything you’d expect from a hack and slash game. There’s plenty of hidden areas to explore, and some light RPG elements in the form of new gear to be found or purchased, along with some very simple puzzle areas and boss fights. Solo combat is moderately rewarding, but over time becomes slightly repetitive owing to the lack of any combo system. This never halts the game, but it detracts from some of the more hectic moments of the final levels. This sluggishness is luckily offset with great level design, which offers many hiding spots, and engaging combat areas. In addition, the game boasts some great sandbox items to play around with, such as usable items for damage, distraction, or healing, and lots of destructible items in the environment encourage you to take a break from traditional button mashing by tactically blowing some explosive or corrosive barrels.

Where the game comes into its own is when you have at least 2 other people playing the other classes. Combat becomes more dynamic with the more varied range of attacks at your party’s disposal, especially considering the absence of combos. There are many hidden areas that are only available to a specific character class, and most of the puzzles in the game require two or more people to complete. At the end of the day, this is a game best played with friends, and luckily, Certain Affinity has made it easy to do, allowing four-player co-op both over Xbox Live (including matchmaking with random strangers) and locally.

In what’s bound to be a controversial move on xBox Live is the advent of micro transactions. Vendors will have a large ornate chest, and for the low low price of 80 microsoft points, players can purchase 40,000 in-game gold. The purchase isn’t mandatory, but given the knee-jerk reaction of the internet to things it’s worth mentioning in advance. The developers at Certain Affinity have thought deeply about this, and I’ll leave this paragraph with a quote from their development blog:

…while you can purchase in-game gold to get an early head start on your gear, ultimately the only advantage that this gives you is requiring less time to get better gear. This is due to several things. For starters, you have to unlock merchants in the game, so not everything available to purchase is accessible to someone wanting to advance solely based on buying gold. More importantly, however, buying gold does NOT ultimately give you any advantages over someone who puts in time instead of money. In addition, buying gold does NOT ultimately get you access to all of the best gear in the game; instead some of the very best items are reserved for in-game rewards (hint: find all secret areas and beat all challenge levels).

Crimson Alliance is a wholly entertaining piece of software; it offers something that many Xbox Live Arcade games lack, and it does it at a level of polish that few others attain. I’ve been asked what the game is like by many people. Some asking if it was like Torchlight, others whether it was like Baldur’s Gate: Dark Alliance, and a few have asked whether it is more akin to Diablo. The truth is, while all these games have common threads, Crimson Alliance stands alone as a unique experience on Xbox Live Arcade. Sitting down with some friends reminded of me of playing Gauntlet many years ago, and this is a testament to the strength of how well the co-op works in the game. For anyone looking for an addictive co-op hack and slash or even someone who is looking for a fun single player campaign without the burden of excessive loot management, then Crimson Alliance is worth your $15 any day of the week.

-Das Kalk

Title was provided by the developer for review

item.title: Kroll – Bashing the Gods Via iPhone
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Draeno reviews Digital Legend's revenge themed beat 'em up Kroll for iOS devices. Does it live up to this God's expectations? Read on to find out!
item.content:encoded:
It has been some time since I decided to sacrifice an entire world to the Lesser Gods. I mean, when was the last time that you’ve seen a good global eradication to show the world who possesses the power? It’s true – in my in my profuse free time I am indeed an elder God. At least that’s what all the voices chanting my name tell me anyway. I rule over the pitiful ants from my tower above doing whatever it is that may amuse me. Regardless, I still find some of their paltry offerings quite appealing. Take for instance the iOS game Kroll. It makes a tiny attempt to bring glory to killing would be creators of the cosmos.

That said, Kroll is a heart-warming tale of vengeance that I can fully appreciate. The character that you play, Delon, is furious. Long ago, all but one Mage-lord was wiped from his world. The solitary survivor was trapped in a rather unique prison, where his body and spirit were stripped apart. Whether true or not, Delon blames the incarcerated Mage-lord Kroll for the death of his loved ones. What did these deaths translate into for our mournful hero? A need to eradicate the final lord, even if it meant the final end of all he knows. Sounds bat shit crazy if you ask me. Silly humans, so impulsive and rash that you never can quite tell where their emotions will take them.

Boss fights add a nice twist that you wouldn't otherwise see in a normal brawler.

With the admirable concept of handheld game, I can’t help but be entertained by its simplicity. Not since the halcyon age long past of Streets of Rage on the Genesis has a brawler kept me so enthralled. The controls are simple enough that anyone can pick it up and go without any instruction. On the off chance the rudimentary controls are a little strange for you, Kroll was kind enough to offer a FAQ in the title screen. The screens, I may add, are lovely with the quality artwork that was thoughtfully included. To that end, being as cruel as I may be, I chose to play this humble game on an iPhone 3G. Kroll ran flawlessly even with it running on version 4.2.1.

A brawler is nothing without handheld weapons, and Kroll has its own shining cudgel. As you press on and smash things with your mace cunningly ego-named “The Surma” it gains in power. (Cunning name, right?) More power equates to more damage. Those harder hits earned in play are big part in moving forward in some of the dog piles that are thrust upon you. The neat area of effect damage burst comes in handy as well. Shaking the iDevice or tapping the center of the screen yields a tremendous mace slam with damages everything and knocking them back. With these high notes, you can really tell that Digital Legends tried to bring something new to the market.

Here you can see the beginnings of dogpile that you'll have to smash your way out of.

As quaintly entertaining as Kroll is, it isn’t without its flaws. Humans made it, so flaws are to be expected. They can’t be a perfect as an elder God you know. In some instances you’ll find yourself overwhelmed by the creatures that for some reason or another are trying to violently persuade you to bring an end to your quest. As much as you bludgeon them, they just continue to hurl themselves at you as their siblings stain the ground beneath your feet. When you stop at certain points along the fixed path that Delon travels, you seem to get stopped in a sort of endless loop of perpetually spawning mace fodder. Not a huge issue, but it can get a tad annoying. Another issue this higher power notices is the light mapping. In some spots you can hardly tell if something is attacking you. Depending on the illumination in your setting, tilting your iDevice will only result in glare that makes it worse. Lastly, the sergeant boss-battles at the end of each sub phase can be a smidge unforgiving. It isn’t enough for them to hit you, sometimes they have to repeatedly spear you in the gut to get the point across. Even with these minor flaws though, Kroll is an entertaining enough title.

This stage really shows off the lighting engine issues in the game. Too many objects in the way of the light renders.

All in all I choose to spare the lives of these Digital Legends humans that created Kroll. While they dream fancifully of tearing out the heart of their superiors, I can’t help but judge their title in a favorable light. There are a few minor complaints that this deity points out, but it doesn’t hamper the overall enjoyment of the title. I shall spare the smiting for today as Kroll has managed to fill my need for that aforementioned sacrifice. Does that mean I shall spare ye all for your fleeting other attempts to gain my favor? Perhaps. Keep diverting my attention with games like Kroll though and ye may live to see old age.

*Disclaimer – Game was provided for review by developer.

item.title: Firefall: Your New Online Shooter
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Draeno gets a hands on demo for the hotly anticipated massively multiplayer online shooter, Firefall by Red 5 Studios. Does it live up to expectations? Did it warrant the massive advertising campaign at PAX Prime? Read on to find out.
item.content:encoded:
When I was attending PAX Prime 2010, a true edge of excitement was etched into my brain by a title that touched on everything I’ve wanted in a massive multiplayer online game. Combining elements of a shooter with not only a huge science fiction world, but also making it free to play out the gate was something that really piqued my interest. The floor demo blew me away as the team playing pushed us through a Starship Troopers-esque event. When I heard that finally it would be available for actual play at PAX 11, I knew that this was something I had to get my hands on. Walking into the expo hall, I figured out pretty fast that it would not be too much of an issue for me to find a way to quell my hunger for Firefall.

Red 5 showed off an enormous booth at Penny Arcade Expo Prime 2011 this year.

Making my way to their enormous footprint on the show floor for my allotted time, I had the pleasure of meeting David Williams, Lead Class Designer on the project. As he was walking me through the game elements he summed up Firefall about the best I’ve heard anyone put it. “Think of it as Shooter+++,” said Williams. You might have been under the impression that Firefall was a typical massive multiplayer game. “Think of Firefall as a shooter first, but with the holy trinity of MMO elements,” he put a little more bluntly. Firefall loads up the three most importa core elements of MMOs; a huge persistent world, advancement, and the social dynamic one has grown to expect. You want a little World of Warcraft style instanced content? Yeah, they got that. Perhaps you wanted to roam the vast expanse of Earth and run into dynamic events as you scout? You bet they have that there, too. You like blowing things up with your friends? Come on, you didn’t think they’ve leave that out would you? All the best parts without any of the miserable rat-slaying from the typical persistent online game is included.

Guard that turret engineer!

Another point that won me over during the demo was the fact that Firefall favors skill over power. Unlike most games where you build up experience in alternative methods to power up or raid endlessly to gain gear supremacy over one another, the game is what you make it. If you are better with a certain gearhead battleframe and weapon combination, there is a place for that. Battleframes allow you the luxury of filling out specific roles like medic, assault or recon. Unlike other popular games, one specialization doesn’t seem to favor over another in situations. Since everything is technology based as well, character skills come and go with what you have equipped. For example, the engineer battleframe I played had a primary weapon that repaired items with its main skill. The secondary bit of it offered a rapid laser blast for offensive power. There are other weapons out there (not just this class) that have different powers, but balance out in the long run. You can deal a massive blast, but aren’t able to do it fast enough. Don’t want to stick to one? That’s fine! You’ll be able to customize different battleframes all you like without the complexity of most other games out there. In player versus player battles, this will really play a huge part. It didn’t seem that any class had a huge advantage over another, so you’ll have to actually learn your given frame rather than game the system. Given the fact that this is a shooter first this play style is true to form, while still having the promise of customization and advancement.

Click over to the next page to read more!

item.title: Top 10 Games That Should Get the Tablet Treatment
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Due to my advanced gaming age, my generation of games is primarily from the 1990s. Unfortunately, without jumping through some hoops it’s a little challenging to get games designed for sub-gigahertz machines functioning on today’s multicore speed demons. Personally, I... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
Due to my advanced gaming age, my generation of games is primarily from the 1990s. Unfortunately, without jumping through some hoops it’s a little challenging to get games designed for sub-gigahertz machines functioning on today’s multicore speed demons. Personally, I think there’s an obvious platform for some of these classics- your tablet of choice. Here’s a list of 10 games I think would make an obvious migration to smudgeware platforms, be it the iOS or Android. Games are presented in no particular order, and were selected based on my own fond memories with a mind towards a touchscreen interface being suitable for optimal game control. Games parsers such as SCUMM or classic console emulators available on Cydia or other similar channels are regretfully not included in this list.



10) Civilization II: An early touchscreen game was Civilization: Revolution. While a good game in it’s own right, I don’t think that it’s truly a Civilization game in anything more than name. Civilization II ran on a 386 and had a remarkably simple interface as compared to later entries in the series. A graphical makeover is all it needs, as it’s had years and years of balancing! Civilization II remains firmly in the hands of Firaxis.


9) Fallout, Icewind Dale, Baldur’s Gate. All three were published by a division of Interplay known as Black Isle, and all three use a very similar game engine for their presentation. In an era of full motion video, these three games minimized that and used the resources otherwise filled by FMV for rich, expansive worlds. Key commands could be used as shortcuts, sure, but the game could be completely played using only the mouse. I don’t foresee any of the three hitting the tablet scene- Bethesda currently has a stranglehold on Fallout. Titus Interactive briefly owned Interplay, and as such, the intellectual property rights to Icewind Dale and Baldur’s Gate. Titus shut down Black Isle, before itself folding releasing Interplay from the shackles of ownership, leaving the rights to Icewind Dale and Baldur’s Gate somewhat up in the air.


8) Star Fleet Battles – While as a pen and paper grognard from way back, I’d love to see a full-on implementation of Star Fleet Battles or it’s simpler cousin Federation Commander. I honestly don’t see the Amarillo Design Bureau allowing it to happen. Once upon a time Taldren released the Starfleet Command series loosely based on the Star Fleet Battles ruleset, with the best title of the series being Starfleet Command II – Orion Pirates. Taldren’s game eschewed the turn-based nature of the source material and went more towards a real-time strategy title, albeit with a time progression slider to accelerate or decelerate the pace of the action. Star Trek purists may chafe a bit at the Star Fleet Battles universe, as it has limited rights to the Trek universe source material. A Star Fleet Battles game universe isn’t an optimal solution for the Trek purist, but what is?


7) Master of Orion II : While there are a couple of excellent 4x space games on the Apple Appstore, probably the longest lived one is Master of Orion II. Developed by Simtex and Published by Microprose in 1996, it won the Origins Award for best Fantasy or Science Fiction Computer game of 1996. Once again, I’ve included it in this list for the predominantly mouse-based interface of the original as well as the depth and quality of the gameplay. On this list, I’ve probably got the most time spent on this game over any others.


6) Myth II – Pre-Halo, Bungie had a couple of other games. Marathon hit the iOS store this year, and the other most notable series in the Bungie catalog is Myth. The Myth series rewards tactical thinking over mass production- in fact, there’s no production mechanic. You go to war with what you have. Keyboard commands were somewhat limited, so any user interface modification needed would be similarly limited. Remember, be careful with the Dwarf grenade tossers!


5) Populous, Powermonger. Bullfrog was an early powerhouse in video game development. In fact, Populous is considered the first PC god-game. Simply stated, Populous puts you in the role of a tribe’s deity, responsible for leading your followers to victory over an opposing god by direct manipulation, terraforming, and straight-out divine intervention. Powermonger, also developed by Bullfrog, took a more combat-oriented approach to the genre, with less god-like intervention. Both games were in the early days of mouse-based control, but the simple utility and clean interface of both lend themselves easily to tablet controls.


4) Maxis Robosport – Maxis is better known for it’s assorted Sims series than Robosport. If you’re looking for a quick and dirty squad-based four on four robot carnage game, then look no further. Tragically, it’s nearly impossible these days to get it to run on anything more modern than Windows 98 or OS 7.5 on the Macintosh. A straightforward movement pre-plotting phase really demands the players execute with good tactics, rather than just superior firepower.


3) Mech Commander. While FASA released an awful lot of products during their lifetime, their Battletech property was probably the best known. One of the offshoots of the universe was the Mech Commander series. Mech Commander 2 was released to retail in 2001, and the source code was released in 2006 for use with the XNA platform and compilers provided by Microsoft. Rather than the cockpit view of Mechwarrior, Mech Commander places you in charge of a lance of mechs and assorted other units in either defense of an objective, a periodic escort mission, or an all out assault on an enemy objective. It seems the most likely for this to see the light of day on a future Windows tablet.


2) Harpoon – The Harpoon miniatures war-game by Larry Bond was released in 1980 and was an amazingly complex game. It wasn’t until the computer version was released by Three-Sixty in 1989 that the game took off in circles other than official Navy ones. The game is completely based on statistics and performance of real world vessels and units, so as such, there is no inherent balance or gamesmanship possible straight out of the box. The game is currently available on the PC and Macintosh by Advanced Gaming Systems (http://www.computerharpoon.com/), but a tablet version would be a welcome addition and help educate the public on the true complexity of modern naval warfare. Of all these games, Harpoon is the likeliest to suffer from a slow tablet.


1) Warhammer – Any Warhammer game universe is an obvious addition to a tablet. A basic set can be implemented with two or three armies or factions, then additional supplements can support the base purchase with an in-app purchase. While this is probably the one franchise I’d love to see happen the most, it’s also categorized as “a snowball’s chance in hell” of happening. While other tabletop games might have rights limitations or be hard to adapt for a touch screen, Warhammer in any incarnation doesn’t have either of these problems. However, it does present its own unique problem – a set of overzealous guardians. THQ guards the computer rights, and has yet to make a faithful adaptation of the Warhammer rulesets. In the physical world. Games Workshop zealously guards the miniatures aspect. That’s probably the rub here- there’s a lot of money to be made with miniatures. If a computer counterpart were to be introduced, that market would start to see an erosion that tore away at the foundation of their profits. Besides, I fear an ecosystem with unique single-redemption codes printed on each miniature, requiring you to buy the miniature out here in meatspace and enter the code to use in-game.

There are loads more that could be included on this list. The AD+D Gold Box adventures, X-Com UFO Defense, or many miniatures games from the past in the vein of Car Wars or Ogre by Steve Jackson Games. To this I ask- why are there so many soundbox or copycat applications? I fear that with all the acquisitions, mergers, and bankruptcies, many of the licenses to a large number of classic great games are lost to the mists of time.

item.title: 20SON Review – Logic Factory’s Ascendancy for the iOS
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: Long ago, when computer clock speed was measured in double and sometimes triple digits, a deep game experience had to utilize the chestnut of wargaming- a turn based game mechanic. Before you roll your eyes, there's nothing wrong with turn based games. Classics like the entire Civilization series and the original X-Com games use turn based play to great effect and have earned longevity in the marketplace. A hair over a decade into the 21st century there are not that many turn based games left. Back in 1995, Broderbund and a host of others, published the original version of Ascendancy for DOS. Earlier this year, it was re-released for the iOS by the Logic Factory. Is there a place for a hardcore turn based strategy game on the iDevice of your choice?
item.content:encoded:
Long ago, when computer clock speed was measured in double and sometimes triple digits, a deep game experience had to utilize the chestnut of wargaming- a turn based game mechanic. Before you roll your eyes, there’s nothing wrong with turn based games. Classics like the entire Civilization series and the original X-Com games use turn based play to great effect and have earned longevity in the marketplace. A hair over a decade into the 21st century there are not that many turn based games left. Back in 1995, Broderbund and a host of others, published the original version of Ascendancy for DOS. Earlier this year, it was re-released for the iOS by the Logic Factory. Is there a place for a hardcore turn based strategy game on the iDevice of your choice?

Ascendancy is at it’s heart a 4x game set in deep space, much like the more well known Master of Orion series. Pick your people well, as your particular path to galaxy domination should be lead by your race’s particular strong points. Ignore your weakness at your own peril! As always with this genre after race selection, you start small with one tiny outpost and your tendrils of weak exploration units reach out to other star systems to look for resources to build your empire, and ultimately, the bad guys. Science is developed over time, colonies are built up into mega worlds, star ships are designed and built, diplomacy is hashed out, and almost inevitably wars are declared. How and where you explore, attack, and build is completely up to the player, and the galaxy is random each time you start a new game.

I’m a veteran of the 4x type of game. I’ve got many hours logged in Master of Orion II and a few others. I didn’t play Ascendancy the first time around, though. I thought I’d jump right in with my normal first game tactic- total military oppression of the enemy. To this end, I picked the Snovemdomas, known for their double strength hulls. Using my standard overwhelming force buildup, Zerg-rushesque in it’s lack of subtilely, I thought I’d have the normal successes that I had in Master of Orion. In theory, I’d have massive losses, but military gains worth the losses. I hadn’t considered that the first race I’d run into was a race of extreme scientists, and they drove me off and followed me back to my home planet to finish the task. So, following a restart, I picked the same tactic, and managed to pound the Oculons into the dirt. Same race, same tactic, but the galaxy’s randomness was the determining factor between my success and failure. The first play through took about three hours, the second much longer before total victory. I did try other methods, and while valid for victory, for me nothing is quite as satisfying as driving the enemy before me, and hearing the lamentation of their mating pairs.

A typical Ascendancy Play Screen

There is a key point to this review – Ascendancy is originally from 1995 and it shows. Games were different then and these differences are accentuated in the modern port of the game. The interface is sometimes obtuse but no more difficult than the original. The graphics are primarily simple and representational, but again no more so than the original. In a world of Angry Birds, 3d shooter engines, and retina displays some gamers will be turned off by the intentional retro look, feel, and play of the game. This is not a “5 minutes on the subway” kind of game as most of the iOS games trend towards. Rather, Ascendancy is a “4 hours on the sofa during a Red Sox-Yankees game” experience. There’s no penalty for an ill-timed interface action like there would be in an action game. Play the game, look up, watch the play, look back down, play more Ascendancy.

20SON’s Verdict? Ascendancy caters to a particular breed of strategy gamer who is perhaps disenchanted by the prevailing crop of flick and forget iOS games. That said, Ascendancy isn’t for everybody. If you’re turned off by retro gameplay and interfaces, maybe you should look at Catan or Carcassonne instead. In my opinion, there is no deeper strategic experience than Ascendancy to be had on the iOS for your gaming dollar.

App was provided by the publisher for review.

item.content:encoded:
This week’s action packed episode of the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast comes to you fresh off the presses. No hops-based social lubrication this week, so we’re a bit crabbier than normal.

Topics this week include:

  • Eureka is renewed, then cancelled. Fret not, lots of episodes remain
  • Do we think Alphas is going to survive?
  • Torchwood- still good or treading water?
  • Penny-arcade.com and PVPonline release Trenches, a new webcomic based on the video game testing “industry”
  • Johnathan’s card shut down. Actual social experiment or viral marketing gone crazy?
  • Planning on buying Rage used? Don’t count on using the sewers to get around. How long will we put up with publishers squeezing the second hand game market for more dough?
  • Post office wants to lay off 120,000 people, and planning some “manifest destiny” crap for solutions in small towns.
  • Valve announces a new Counter Strike, with a new hat trading mechanism
  • Firefox 6 released today, but Firefox 8 will block auto-toolbar installers
  • Want a thorium powered car? So do we, but we don’t think we’ll ever see it.
  • Falling Skies season 1 is over. Is it worth watching, or more of the same crap?
  • Draeno reviews Mercs. Go buy it!

Until next week!

item.title: It Was Not So OK – Episode 26
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: On this edition of the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast, Emdee and Draeno bring you some random happenings in the geek world that have come out of GenCon as well as am update to some things we've touched on before. We promise, you're not stepping back in time hearing some things again. Unlike some other crazy folks out there, we don't dabble in nuclear power. We leave that to those with disposable income and the need for a dangerous "hobby." Topics covered include Margaret Weis' Marvel license, Villains and Vigilantes, Fantasy Flight's Star Wars license, the Cenarion Hatchlinbg pet, OSX Lion experience update, and gravestone QR codes.
item.content:encoded:
On this edition of the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast, Emdee and Draeno bring you some random happenings in the geek world that have come out of GenCon as well as an update to some things we’ve touched on before. We promise, you’re not stepping back in time hearing some things again. Unlike some other crazy folks out there, we don’t dabble in nuclear power. We leave that to those with disposable income and the need for a dangerous “hobby.”

Topics for this week include:

  • Margaret Weis Productions is granted the Marvel license for 14 RPG books. First book will be out next year based on the Civil War saga.
  • Villains and Vigilantes looks towards a rebirth by the original developers. Defunct publisher says “Woah, there buddy.” Lawsuit ensues.
  • Fantasy Flight Games is getting the Star Wars license. Look forward to more card games and collectable games like X-Wing vs. Tie Fighter.
  • Blizzard lets the bomb drop about requiring an internet connection for Diablo III and the new real cash market place. Rage erupts over the internet from people that will still buy the game anyway.
  • Cenarion Hatchling pet for World of Warcraft raises $2 million for Japan relief. However, they lost 300,000 subscriptions between May and July. Look forward to buying more things and burning through content even faster until Titan.
  • Emdee updates his experiences with OS Lion. USB stick with the OS on it will be arriving soon.
  • A study from Copenhagen Business School and the University of Waterloo say that better rated games are pirated more. No shit. If people are going to steal, why would they steal something they know is terrible?
  • News surfaces that Mars may have water.
  • QR codes are now available on gravestones. Connect with people on your Facebook page from beyond the grave!
  • Man tries to build nuclear reactor at home. Hobbies are fine, but really this is just plain crazy.
  • Mike Capps, President of Epic Games, ponders the point of next generation consoles when we have powerful mobile devices.
  • We get lost a little on shopping for furniture at Ikea.
  • Thunderbolt vs. USB 3 – Both are good. No reason to be upset. Eventually both will be an option on PCs and Macs.

Enjoy folks!

item.title: 20SON Review – Stream to Me iApp and Server
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: We’ve been Apple junkies for years, regardless of the effect it has sometimes on the wallet. All told, the tech has been pretty good to me. I’m sure I’ve made more money supporting it out in town than it’s cost... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
Stream to Me on the iOS

We’ve been Apple junkies for years, regardless of the effect it has sometimes on the wallet. All told, the tech has been pretty good to me. I’m sure I’ve made more money supporting it out in town than it’s cost me overall. My inner cheapness prevents me from buying the whammerdyne max-capacity iPhones. Staying on top of the curve isn’t so cost effective and we often make do with old tech long after the rest of the tech enthusiast world has moved on.

Our video library is hosted on an older machine crammed full of relatively ancient hard drives, honestly, well in excess of what the laws of physics and heat dissipation should allow. I’m fairly sure I can cook a turkey with the waste heat coming off that machine. Because of the stone-soup nature of the server and the capacity it holds these days, the DVD rips we store on iTunes for the AppleTVs in the house far exceed the capacity of any given portable iDevice we may have in service. Apple has made great strides in streaming to iDevices with AirPlay technology, but there are still some glaring omissions, namely in non-Jobs blessed containers and codecs.

I did some research, tried some free alternatives, then I found Stream to Me. Stream to Me, by Matt Gallagher’s Projects With Love is a combination server application for your OSX Mac or Windows PC that holds the media, and either an app for your iDevice (iPhone, iPad, iPod Touch) or Macintosh for playback. The PC or Mac server application is free for download- it’s the iDevice app that will inexpensively impact your wallet for the princely sum of $2.99. At press time, the Macintosh playback client for the Stream to Me pair is free. Even given my limited budget, I splurged for the iOS app some time ago.

Since I originally purchased Stream to Me, Apple integrated a similar technology in iOS 4- they call it AirPlay. Airplay is a revision of a proprietary “standard” that Apple would like more widely integrated in digital receivers and the like. For now, it’s primarily limited to Apple-friendly containers, like MP4 and M4V with an H.264 encoded video. Stream to Me extends that utility as well as reverses the direction- instead of sending a video from an iDevice to another device, Stream to Me sends from a common server to an iDevice on the network or across the internet, router and ISP depending.

Overall, Stream to Me is an amazing, seamless after initial setup solution for streaming entire libraries over 802.11g (or faster) or 3g networks to an iDevice regardless of video format container. The server application runs quietly and with very little resource footprint on our overtaxed media warehouse computer running OSX Leopard. The server part of the application pair has transcoded on the fly many different containers. I’ve fed the server MP4 H.264, AVI, and MKV files, all in 720p resolution and streamed them to the iPhone/iPad application with minimal pre-processing delay and no hiccuping in the video waiting for the 802.11g stream to catch up. Of course, the pre-transcoding time may vary depending on the ferocity of the iron that you host the content.

TL;DR? Looking for a way to stream all those miscellaneously formatted videos you’ve acquired in your travels across the wilds of the internet without time consuming and processor slamming lengthy transcoding processes? I highly recommend Stream to Me as your one stop shop for universal video streaming and viewing for both your iOS device as well as your OSX based machine.

Stream to Me was purchased by the reviewer.

item.title: Hydrophobia: Prophecy Fails to Make Waves
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: In what seems like a millennia ago, I spent the majority of my time in a business of antiquated venture called a video rental store. Between helping people with their rentals, I would run across some films of questionable worth as I totaled them out. When you work in any sort of movie retail market you learn that with every big movie release comes a wave of lesser known films trying to cash in on the subject matter. Movies lined the walls ranging from the big titles you see in theaters to ones that someone filmed with too much red-tinted Karo syrup and a handy cam. Often I find myself thinking back to those days when I see an indie game that piques my interest. There just always seems to be something that makes you want to chance the terrible to find an unknown gem. Hydrophobia: Prophecy was one of those games that I hoped to pull from the middle of the road to obscurity and be bathed in unexpected wonder.
item.content:encoded:
In what seems like a millennia ago, I spent the majority of my time in a business of antiquated venture called a video rental store. Between helping people with their rentals, I would run across some films of questionable worth as I totaled them out. When you work in any sort of movie retail market you learn that with every big movie release comes a wave of lesser known films trying to cash in on the subject matter. Movies lined the walls ranging from the big titles you see in theaters to ones that someone filmed with too much red-tinted Karo syrup and a handy cam. Often I find myself thinking back to those days when I see an indie game that piques my interest. There just always seems to be something that makes you want to chance the terrible to find an unknown gem. Hydrophobia: Prophecy was one of those games that I hoped to pull from the middle of the road to obscurity and be bathed in unexpected wonder.

The view from Kate's apartment aboard the Queen of the Ocean.

Place yourself in the not too distant future. At first sight, everything seems to be well in the world. That is of course until you unravel the lie you’ve been shown to uncover the true fate of humanity. Earth is actually in a state of disarray due to an overwhelming population growth. While things around the planet fall apart corporate kingpins use their wealth to stash themselves away on a floating utopia, avoiding the global catastrophe. Aboard this vessel, this Queen of the Ocean, you take on the role of Kate Wilson- a security engineer whose accomplishments have been buried by a tragic event in her past. You wake from a terrible dream to find that during the 10th anniversary of the vessel, things are mysteriously fading. Being the model employee Kate is, it is decided (on her day off no less) that she is going to take a look into it. As soon as she steps into the elevator things begin to go to hell. Explosions rock the ship and cascades of water begin to pour from every imaginable port, tear, and breach. Enter a terrorist group known as the Malthusians who envision saving the world through the mass slaughter of humankind. Hoping to make a statement, they hone in on the Queen of the World looking to destroy those who have been spared the suffering of the rest of the planet.

The face of the Malthusians causing terror on the Queen.

That seems like that should be the basis of a pretty good story right? Sadly, it really isn’t. It might as well be a plot for a bad Billy Zane or Jean Claude Van Damme film. The potential for Bioshock-esque thrill is there, but as the plot line evolves it all falls flat. Even though Dark Energy fixed a majority of the plot for Prophecy, it is still desperately lacking. The main problem is that you have no reason to care about Kate or anyone else aboard the magnificent city barge. There is a short glance into the troubled past of our protagonist, but that’s all it is – merely a short look. Picking through the relics of her former life in her apartment, we get a feeling that she was an accomplished swimmer. However, at some point a tragedy had befallen her ambitions. We’re left with only the dream sequence at the start, the mysterious haunting laughter and almost entirely missed utterance of a name let you know. With only superficial evidence of a greater meaning to the arc of the game, it is no wonder that one would have issues caring about anything going on. Your next best sliver of empathy would come into play with the residents of the ship. Really though, while any loss of life isn’t something to smirk at, how long can you feel for a group of people that ran out on the rest of the world?

In addition to the flat characters and overall lack of story, there are some annoyances that are hard to move past. The controls can be a bit awkward at times. Once you become altered to commune with water, you ultimately have a choice. You can use water to ultimately try to drown everything or continue shooting through the rest of the game. Using both tends to be a problem as you can no longer aim at what you want to shoot. All shots end up being a blind fire towards the vicinity of whatever the water is bobbling at the time. Not enough of a headache? Try picking up an object while swimming then activating the water powers. Oh? You don’t like camera lock in unplayable angles? Never mind then. It can’t be put past anyone that this may have been a side effect of porting from a console game. As a distraction a point system was put into place. Kate’s side goal becomes collecting points by finding objects and documents objects to gain medals and to add to your overall score. Why? There is no purpose to it other than to bolster your bragging rights to your friends (if they purchased the game). Sure you can become incentivized to kill villains in more creative way to rack up the total some more, but even that becomes stale. AI in this game is far from challenging or dynamic. Compounding the AI problem, the so called variety of deaths, isn’t very varied. Add the aforementioned aiming and locking issues and things can get a tad frustrating when trying to execute the kills. It leaves one to wonder why did they have to do so many re-workings and additions of levels to the game when these facets of Hydrophobia should have resolved first?

Read the conclusion on the next page!

item.description: In a rather casual atmosphere this week, Emdee and Draeno welcomes back Mr. Meyagi of The Spirits of Fire to chat about the happenings of the week. No censors this week as everyone involved has no problems speaking their minds. Due to this, the explicit tag is implied with force. F-bombs just kept falling! item.content:encoded:
In a rather casual atmosphere this week, Emdee and Draeno welcome back Mr. Meyagi of the Spirits of Fire to chat about the happenings of the week. No censors were involved this week as no one had any problems speaking their minds. Due to this, the explicit tag is implied with force. F-bombs just kept falling!

While refusing to hold back their tongues, the crew talked about the following topics:

  • Fox is putting their programming behind a pay wall starting August 15th. Here comes the networks’ attacks on Internet video.
  • Time Warner blames the downward trend of their video on demand service on flash based porn sites. Huh?!
  • Mr. Meyagi and Emdee talk a little about Halo: Combat Evolved Anniversary.
  • Humble Indie Bundle 3 is out. Go get it folks! Free time on Minecraft if you purchase it soon!
  • Original maker of Stormtrooper armor for Star Wars, Andrew Ainsworth, won his legal battle against Lucas Arts in UK courts. Lawyers play it off as the United Kingdom being a bastion for piracy that doesn’t protect works of art. The crew has some arguments about who is right in this case.
  • Apple has more cash in hand than the US Government. What. The. Hell. People. This leads to a little rant on the state of the economy and how people cope with it.
  • Nintendo 3DS has a price drop from $249 to $169. Were you a first adopter? Don’t worry! You get some old games you won’t want to play for your support. A discussion ensues about the handheld game market and the impact and convenience of the mobile phone market.
  • We get sidetracked about the nostalgia of games that used to be hard. Games are starting to make a come back to that with titles like Catherine and Bayonetta. Draeno still never found that Unreal map name.
  • Raspberry PI $25 HDMI device is being released. While a great piece of technology, will anyone actually have a use for it?
  • RIM laid off 2000 people. Is this their own fault due to lack of innovation?
  • An off comment about E.R. leads to a short discussion on messed up statistics, doctor mortality rates, and guns. Looking forward to that Fox News spot!

Enjoy folks!

Don’t forget – PictoChat at PAX is a bad idea.

item.title: Is OSX Lion Worth Doing?
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: OSX was introduced in 2000 as the future of the MacOS with the intent of leaving the old architecture of OS9 and before well behind.  Eleven years later, the seventh major revision of the UNIX and NextStep based operating system... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
OSX was introduced in 2000 as the future of the MacOS with the intent of leaving the old architecture of OS9 and before well behind.  Eleven years later, the seventh major revision of the UNIX and NextStep based operating system was released- OSX Lion.  Does this big cat have teeth?

As with any OS revision on any platform anywhere, there are pros and cons for upgrading depending on the age of your hardware and a few other factors.  Prohibited from upgrading is any Core Solo or Core Duo equipped mac- any Core 2 Duo and beyond machine is upgradeable.  So, you can safely assume that any mac manufactured after mid-2007 is eligible for upgrade.  As long as you have 4 gigabytes or more of RAM, some rudimentary speed trials suggest that Lion is worth installing purely from an OS speed perspective.  If you don’t have the 4 gigabytes, then it’s either time for a new Mac or more RAM.

Prior to the major Macintosh hardware shift from PowerPC architecture to Intel processors in 2006, Apple developed Rosetta.  Rosetta is a stopgap software compatibility layer allowing the older PowerPC developed software to run on the newer Intel based hardware.  Some software took ages to migrate- notably Quicken and just about every Adobe product all the way from the creative suite down to the humble flash player.  Under Lion, the Rosetta layer is completely gone.  For clarity, PowerPC designed software will not run under Lion.  Still using Adobe Creative Suite 2 and don’t want to upgrade?  Don’t upgrade to Lion.  As with any new OS, research compatibility of mission critical software first.

Nearly the entire OpenGL driver codebase has been replaced in Lion.  In real world applications gamers will experience about a 6-10% increase in performance (including the Source engine) but your mileage may vary.  OpenGL 3.2 is included versus 2.x in Snow Leopard, but 3.2 must be explicitly supported in your application.  OpenGL 4.0 is still regretfully not included, but internet hearsay suggests before Lion’s lifecycle is complete version 4.0 will be included.  OpenGL 3.2 versus 4.0 doesn’t imply poorer performance than it could be- OpenGL library revisions do not equate enhanced performance, but it is an improvement overall.  Apple literature speaks of a “clean break” between previous versions of OpenGL and the new libraries- so code monkeys, take heed for the future.

From an overall user perspective, the OS is flashier.  This is good and bad.  If you like Apple’s iOS, then you’ll like Lion and the nods in that direction.  If you like graphical flash, then you’ll like Lion.  Speaking from the perspective of an old-school user, Lion is a bit over the top with unnecessary presentation.  It’s a bit harder from a user troubleshooting perspective to get to critical folders as the OS is installed, but it’s fixable with some command line wizardry.  Some Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices are incompatible or not completely compatible with Lion due to Apple’s inclusion of Netatalk 2.2 rather than including some backwards compatibility.  The fault for this lies with the NAS vendors, Apple, and the Netatalk codebase maintainer.  The vendors could have upgraded to the newer DHX2 authentication method some time ago.  The cleanest and most obvious solution would have been Apple not removing DHCAST128 support for older authentication methods.  Capping the issue off, NetAFP, the maintainer of the Netatalk library, closed the source for the driver releasing it to only to customers who pay for support.  At press time, Synology devices have a beta patch, but many LaCie and Iomega devices remain crippled.  DHCAST128 support is addable with some command line wizardry as well.  In my opinion, both of these omissions are fairly critical and should have been at least selectable with a checkbox.  Being forced to hit the sometimes arcane command line to enable a critical feature for many users seems contrary to the simplifications that have been introduced with this version of OSX.

From an IT perspective, the $50 add-on to turn Lion into Lion Server is a bit of a mixed blessing.  Some options are moved, some libraries have been upgraded to compatibility’s detriment, a few older features are gone without a trace, and many new options are included.  Lion Server seems more intended for a home server application rather than a corporate or business implementation.  Time will ultimately tell on this, but for now, I recommend that IT departments stick with Snow Leopard server, rather than upgrading to Lion Server.

I’m not historically an early OS release adopter.  There are older machines that I’m responsible for running Leopard, and since they do what I need them to do without any fuss there they will stay.  I didn’t even move to OSX until Jaguar, the second major revision after initial release.  Lion is a substantive and mostly solid upgrade over Snow Leopard, and a worthy one at that, but to be clear it’s not for everyone.  As I mentioned earlier, every OS release has it’s share of bugs, “upgrades” that aren’t, and oddities.  Lion is no exception.  If you’re going to upgrade to Lion, do so with full awareness of the caveats involved.

item.content:encoded:
This week Das Kalk and Anubis join us this week on the 20 Sides of Nerd of podcast for the release of OSX 10.7 Lion. As excited as most of the team was about the new release things eventually came back around to the normal way of things. We started talking about the new bells and whistles of the operating system, but things just started going downhill from there.

Topics for the week boiled down to:

  • Apple OS 10.7 Lion came out this week. Emdee, Das Kalk, and Anubis go on about their first impressions of the new operating system. Some of the fixes we mentioned are here and here.
  • Changes are being made the future of the Mac hardware line ups, including Thunderbolt and lack of CD media drives.
  • Emdee reviews Best Baby Monitor for iOS devices.  The Best Baby Monitor application was provided for review.
  • Star Wars fan movie awards shows deleted scenes that will show up in the Blu-Ray release.
  • Star Wars: The Old Republic pre-order bonuses were announced. How much did your wallet get hit for?
  • Borders is going away finally. If you are shopping at the liquidation sales, make sure to check your prices.
  • Somehow we start talking about warranties and cable qualities. Do yourself a favor and don’t buy Monster cables.
  • A computer AI was given FreeCiv, learned to read the manual, and elevated to an 80% win rate before it started to learn from the game play itself. Be afraid.
  • We share some thoughts on the Amazing Spider-Man and The Dark Knight Rises trailers.
  • Emdee says to play Kerbal Space Program.

Enjoy folks!

item.description: A tale of two podcasts continues! Das Kalk joins us and we discuss the final installment of Harry Potter, Torchwood, Alphas, Eureka, True Blood, Netflix price increases, $10 online passes, and the upcoming Evil Dead remake.
item.content:encoded:
A Tale of Two Casts continues with “American Needs a Sandwich” – Episode 23
Das Kalk joins us on episode 23, which is one of our typical recordings. After the mess that was the previous episode, the return to the normal format was welcoming.

Regularly scheduled topics were as follows:

  • The final installment of the Harry Potter movie franchise hit theaters this week. Most successful movie in history? Is it more successful than Star Wars for previous generations?
  • We hit on some new genre TV: Torchwood, Alphas, Eureka, Warehouse 13, Haven, and True Blood. Someone it turns into Emdee and Draeno going off on a Doctor Who tangent.
  • Netflix raised the price of subscriptions across the board. Still one hell of a value folks. Stop being so angry about it.
  • Video game industry is down 10% in June 2010 and 2011. No kidding. Release some titles we care about and quit pushing people to the cheap mobile market. Is Steam partially to blame?
  • Ubisoft joins the $10 online pass club with Driver: San Francisco.
  • We give a brief preview on MERCS.
  • The Evil Dead remake is coming around again. If that wasn’t enough, Diablo Cody is coming aboard to work on the script. Why?! STOP HOLLYWOOD. STOP. There was nothing wrong with it! There is no need to remake it!

item.content:encoded:
Due to some set backs in the lives of your hosts in recent history, we unfortunately had to delay putting the finishing touches on episode 22. I’m sure that Emdee was thankful for the extra time since he edits ours casts every week. As it was something of an odd cast to record, it can only be imagined that there were some troubles piecing it together. Instead of holding it back for another week, we decided to hit you with two podcasts this week!

A Tale of Two Casts Starts with “Forgot the Waiver” – Episode 22
On the slowest news week we’ve ever encountered, we decided to wing a podcast. Leetum joins us again as we scour sites for news and whatever drifts into our minds as we are recording the cast.

The crap we came up for as “topics” on this show were:

  • iPhone patents indicate that in the future you may be able to pour data from your phone to your tablet inspired by beer pouring. Sign us up!
  • PSN Japan finally is going back up. Too bad that so many people lost out on free games.
  • TSA agent in Florida stole $50,000 worth of electronics. Why didn’t anyone notice laptops in his pants?
  • Google+ buttons supposedly has more presence than Twitter buttons on websites. We take this as a good sign to look at our own website.
  • Space travel is going commercial now that the final shuttle launch has taken place. Why?
  • British sci-fi has been embraced by Americans. Will the new season of Torchwood be accepted as much as the Doctor Who revival was?
  • Paypal says the wallet is going to go away by 2015.
  • Class action lawsuit is being formed against Sony for shutting down Star Wars Galaxies.
  • Public sourced photography project in Apple store gains the artist the attention of the Secret Service. ‘Cause you know, accessing computers that aren’t yours and taking pictures of people without permission is always a good idea.
  • Award for the most useless phone add-on goes to, the DSLR lens attachment for the iPhone.
  • Two cancelled soap operas are just going to continue online. Apparently someone didn’t get the memo.
  • First pictures of the dwarves from the upcoming The Hobbit film were released.
  • Civilization makes its way to Facebook. Congrats on getting out there more, but shame on you for turning it into a Facebook game.

item.title: Are You Ready for the Miracle?
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Ever since getting the first glimpse of John Barrowman as a rogue time agent Captain Jack Harkness in the Doctor Who episode The Empty Child, I had a feeling I was watching something great unfold. Harkness appeared to be a complex character with more to him that was willing to be told to the usual fans of the Doctor Who serials. This made me realize that there was something that Who had been missing all along. It was missing an edge. Sure, there was a push towards the darker depths of The Doctor towards the end of Sylvester McCoy's run, but I knew that Capt. Jack would be the character that would fill that niche. If you've been watching Doctor Who since its revival in 2005 you might have had an idea that something was going to come across the horizon. Lo and behold, Russell T. Davies derived a spin off featuring Capt. Jack called Torchwood.
item.content:encoded:
Ever since getting the first glimpse of John Barrowman as a rogue time agent Captain Jack Harkness in the Doctor Who episode The Empty Child, I had a feeling I was watching something great unfold. Harkness appeared to be a complex character with more to him that was willing to be told to the usual fans of the Doctor Who serials. This made me realize that there was something that Who had been missing all along. It was missing an edge. Sure, there was a push towards the darker depths of The Doctor towards the end of Sylvester McCoy’s run, but I knew that Capt. Jack would be the character that would fill that niche. If you’ve been watching Doctor Who since its revival in 2005 you might have had an idea that something was going to come across the horizon. Lo and behold, Russell T. Davies derived a spin off featuring Capt. Jack called Torchwood.

Torchwood leader and star of series Captain Jack Harkness

Evolving the idea of the previous iterations of the Torchwood Institute, Capt. Harkness wanted to track down, use, and learn from alien technology to better prepare the human race for what was coming. The title sequence breaks it down simply as we hear Jack telling us that the “21st century is when everything changes.” The show starts out as a police style procedural jumping from alien hunting to conspiracies to worldwide emergencies week by week. Instead of looking at the humdrum of what it is to deal with the ever stressful life as an officer, Torchwood places us in a rather weird yet human position. Characters take us to a place where we see the black hole one faces when looking into the reaches of our souls, our interactions with one another. What we ended up with was a show that not only pushes the limits of modern sci-fi, but also explores the ideas of an pansexual character, what happens when we’re alone, and the consequences of keeping secrets. Best of all the height of what it can show us as yet to be reached.

Starting out as a late night show, it was able to have a pretty open reign on what some folks might consider offensive. As popularity grew though and it worked its way up the BBC ranks, some the overtly sexual and physicality had to be toned down. Eventually it ended up on BBC One for the last series, Children of Earth. Each time it moved, it seemed that it grew a little bit softer on the barriers. However, this is when the writing really began to shine. Season three was touted as being a special arc that would only last five episodes. What we were shown in spite of this was a concise, rich, nothing short of amazing bit of storytelling. Out of the success from Children of Earth a new dynamic was born. Instead of the case of the week episode, it matured into the longer serial style that carries on into Miracle Day.

What the viewer is faced with in Torchwood: Miracle Day is quite different than subjects that have been touched on in science fiction before. The idea of a world without death. Aging carries on taking its toll, but never realizing an end. The sick remain sick and the injured, no matter how gruesome, continue to be so. Imagine if you will a place where a person that has been impaled by sign or someone that had been caught in an explosion had to carry on their days in constant pain. Sadly, that is what is taking place after the event starts. All of human kind is faced with the idea of life eternal. What makes it even worse is that it is revealed that due to this boom in population, it is putting a strain on the resources of the planet putting us at an inviable position in a mere four months. Faced with the impossible reality of the unknown while fighting their new found roles in life, the Torchwood team strikes out to set things right.

Continue the preview of Torchwood: Miracle Day after the break

It has been awhile since we've featured a fourth guest during recording, but it was nice to revisit it. It sure made for some interesting things happening in the background to say the least. Topics covered include Bungie Aerospace, World of Warcraft free up to level 20, the ProtectIP act, Prince no longer recording due to music piracy, Starz's Camelot, and Star Wars: Galaxies shutdown.
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes I wonder what goes through our minds when we record the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast. On another sidetracked podcast Leetum joined in, with the addition of Mr. Meyagi from Spirits of Fire. It has been awhile since we’ve featured a fourth guest during recording, but it was nice to revisit it. It sure made for some interesting things happening in the background to say the least.

This week, even with random desk related activities in the middle of everything, we ran across the following list of topics:

  • Bungie Aerospace is revealed as an indie game incubator.
  • World of Warcraft is free to play up to level 20 now. The pusher man is getting you hooked.
  • RIAA says that Protect IP is needed now in lieu of the Lulzsec and Anonymous attacks. The RIAA apparently lost their marbles again. Just change your model guys.
  • Prince says that he will no longer record music because of piracy. According to him, piracy is akin to car jacking.
  • Camelot was canned. Was it because of Game of Thrones or Torchwood?
  • Star Wars Galaxies has announced its cancellation. No one is shocked or saddened by this.
  • Amazon dumps all of its California affiliates because of new Internet tax laws. Is this sound reasoning? Why wouldn’t you tax Internet purchases? If we tax it, where are our infrastructure improvements?
  • Trouble is brewing between Apple and Samsung once again. Even with Apple moving their processors away from Samsung, this is something that will go on for some time. Hope that you weren’t looking forward to any new products from Samsung any time soon.
  • Capcom makes Resident Evil: Mercenaries with only one save slot possible with no way to wipe it. Is this a new trend in trying to kill the used gaming market?
  • Emdee gives a preview of Ascendancy by Logic Factory for iOS.*
  • MySpace was sold to Specific Media for $35 million. News Corp. lost money. We’re not sad about that.
  • Google lost in the Nortel patent bid against a consortium of companies (Sony, Microsoft, Apple, RIM, Erickson, and EMC). There was no reason why they should have lost this. Is this evidence of a loss of confidence in Android?
  • Geek Projects – We speak about the idea of building your own computer rather than purchasing a pre-made box.

Enjoy folks!

P.S. – Emdee wants all your Marathon swag.

*Disclaimer – Game was provided for review by publisher

item.title: 20SON Review – Trenched (or Iron Brigade) by Double Fine
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: In the beginning there was Warcraft 3. Warcraft 3 begat mods. One of these mods was the proto-tower defense game. Once the first tower defense game arrived, the floodgates were open for more. Desktop Tower Defense. Bloons. Hordes of Orcs. Defense Grid: The Awakening. The list goes on and on, and the varieties of gameplay options afforded by each variant does as well. As part of their Amnesia Fortnight initiative spawned by the (quite tragic, in my opinion) collapse of the Brutal Legend franchise, Double Fine developed and released Trenched with the assistance of the Microsoft Game Studio. As with most Tower Defense (TD) games, Trenched is hard to simply classify. In a grossly oversimplified nutshell, Trenched is tower defense pureed with a savory helping of customizable giant stomping robot and garnished with a powder of RPG progression. Is the blend satisfying and refreshing, though?
item.content:encoded:
Editor’s note- when Trenched ships in the EU in October or November, it’ll be called “Iron Brigade” worldwide. We’re not changing the review, but where you see “Trenched”, perhaps you may want to substitute “Iron Brigade”

In the beginning there was Warcraft 3. Warcraft 3 begat mods. One of these mods was the proto-tower defense game. Once the first tower defense game arrived, the floodgates were open for more. Desktop Tower Defense. Bloons. Hordes of Orcs.  Defense Grid: The Awakening. The list goes on and on, and the varieties of gameplay options afforded by each variant does as well. As part of their Amnesia Fortnight initiative spawned by the (quite tragic, in my opinion) collapse of the Brutal Legend franchise, Double Fine developed and released Trenched with the assistance of the Microsoft Game Studio. As with most Tower Defense (TD) games, Trenched is hard to simply classify. In a grossly oversimplified nutshell, Trenched is tower defense pureed with a savory helping of customizable giant stomping robot and garnished with a powder of RPG progression. Is the blend satisfying and refreshing, though?

At it’s core, Trenched is about the war between the Monovision and the Mobile Trench Brigade. You are the heroic, patriotic, square jawed trench pilot who must keep the hordes of the Monovisions at bay. At some point, you must fight off kamikazes, snipers, riflemen, melee specialists, heavies, and so forth. At first glance, the general classifications of enemies feels fairly standard, but the sinewy technology unchained art direction of the Monovision baddies really sets them apart from the rest of the tower defense games I’ve played.

Lock and Load!

In defending your objectives, you have a large variety of custom options for your giant stomping robot- your mobile trench. There are long range and short range weaponry, mines and anti-aircraft cannons just to name a few. You can pick heavy weapons for your trench, or a large variety of emplacements to drop- but not both. The pre-mission briefings give you a pretty good idea of what weapons load out you’ll need, but won’t completely prevent you from taking a completely inappropriate one to your own detriment. Pay attention to the mission briefings!

Fight the Good Fight!

Following trench customization, the battle begins! While you can equip up to four emplacements, depending on your Trench chassis selection, being able to place them is another matter entirely. Trenched currency is scrap, blasted off of your monovision foes. You typically have enough scrap to place a single turret or two, and this initial placement makes all the difference in the opening phases of each level. Do you need area denial in the form of mines, or a shotgun turret? Would a repair tower be in your best interest or a sniper tower? As you collect scrap as the level progresses and the bad guy destruction accumulates, you can drop more towers or upgrade existing ones in real time. This isn’t a game that allows you to pause it and build your defenses! There’s a brief window after you call for a tower or upgrade where your purchase isn’t available as it’s constructing, so plan your time wisely!

Here’s a public service announcement for the heavy tower defense game players- Trenched doesn’t allow you to build a torturous maze for the baddies to progress through as some tower defense games do. Offsetting this somewhat is the level design that rarely allows the baddies a straight shot at your objective.

Collector or Hoarder?

The game keeps track of all manners of statistics. Weapon kills overall. Shotgun kills.  Machine gun kills. If you can kill tubes with it, then it’s counted. This count applies towards two different totals- both your own, and your entire regiment’s total. The game spits out rewards for you both as an individual and as a regiment as your totals grow, even if you as a player aren’t with the rest of the regiment on any particular game session. Yes, if the rest of your group are off blasting tubes, and you are offline with mundane real life tasks to perform you do share in the spoils. Unfortunately, there’s no way to form a static regiment so the game counts the last nine players you played co-op with. Fair trade!

When the mission is over and you’ve driven the enemy before you, the regiment returns to your carrier to re-outfit and reap the rewards of your victory. Equipment you collected during the battle Diablo-style for your trenches is added to your inventory and cash is collected in proportion to the level of enemy brutalization.

Gameplay

Controls are tight. I saw no flaws in the technical aspects of single player combat with the monovision menace. Multiplayer suffered a bit from player dropouts and serious lag during the first week of play, but a title update that my console downloaded for the title on June 28th helped a great deal with network conditions. I experienced no graphical glitches or frame rate issues while playing both single player and with three other co-op players regardless of the quantities of explosions or baddies.

It’s Not All Good, Is It?

I’d really like there to be pre-built Trench slots that you as a player can quickly switch between. Different levels often have vastly different requirements all the way down to which legs to use on your Trench making the quickswap Trench slots a gameplay convenience issue. Also, Trenched begs for a survival/firefight/horde gameplay mode and more equipment. Maybe in the future? None of these issues are showstoppers, but more of a “I’d like to have” situation.

In Conclusion:

I’m not a star or percentage rating kind of guy. To me, and to anybody who enjoys either tower defense or giant stomping robot style play, the 1200 Microsoft point cost is well worth the price of admission. If you’re on the fence about either genre, the gameplay is rewarding enough to still warrant a purchase on sale for 800 points.  I still think it’s worth any gamer’s time at 1200. Go buy it now!

I will say this- Trenched is probably the best game I’ve ever downloaded from xBox Live Arcade, with Toy Soldiers being a close second. Bring on the DLC, Double Fine!

Disclaimer- Game was provided by the developer for review.
