item.description: We made it! Finally we're able to bring you the hardly imagined episode 20 of the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast. Emdee and myself could hardly believe we'd make it this long. We'd like to toss out a thank you for all our listeners. You guys make it happen for us. Now that the mushy stuff is out of the way, I can deliver some bonus news. Leetum joined us this week to lend some of his knowledge as we launch a new feature of the podcast, Geek Projects. Here, we hope to inform your faithful listeners of some of the things you should be doing, might be interested in doing, or at least informing your of our mistakes. Pretty sweet, right? In any event, topics covered include Team Fortress 2 free to play, Hellgate London's open beta, Eve Online's micro transactions, iPad Marathon, the iCloud and how it affects iWeb and MobileMe services, Pottermore, and the Green Lantern movie review.
item.content:encoded:
We made it! Finally we’re able to bring you the hardly imagined episode 20 of the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast. Emdee and myself could hardly believe we’d make it this long. We’d like to toss out a thank you for all our listeners. You guys make it happen for us. Now that the mushy stuff is out of the way, I can deliver some bonus news. Leetum joined us this week to lend some of his knowledge as we launch a new feature of the podcast, Geek Projects. Here, we hope to inform your faithful listeners of some of the things you should be doing, might be interested in doing, or at least informing your of our mistakes. Pretty sweet, right?

On top of launching the Geek Projects feature, we gleefully marched into these topics:

  • Valve has made Team Fortress 2 free to play! Why did it take so long?
  • Hellgate: London open beta launches soon.
  • EVE Online riots start over the inclusion of game changing micro payments.
  • Details from a class action lawsuit details how Sony fired security personnel prior to the PSN attacks.
  • Marathon is coming to the iPad as a free game on July 7th. Pick it up!
  • With the launch of iCloud, iWeb and Mobile me will be going away in June 2012.
  • Dropbox left everyone’s account open to access with any password for four hours. Shouldn’t they be using two party authentication for this by now?
  • Verizon brings an end to unlimited data plans in July. Cloud computing is getting more costly everyday.
  • Pottermore. Additional writings for the universe, exclusive digital book copies, and the blatant rip off of the “webcomic” business model.
  • Newest iteration of Marvel’s Ghost Rider is a woman. Looking forward to it.
  • Prelude to Draeno’s Green Lantern movie review. A discussion ensues about the placement of origin stories in comic to film adaptations.
  • Emdee previews Trenched from Double Fine on XBLA.*
  • Geek projects – We start a new feature on the podcast covering some of the things you as a geek should be doing. This week we go over hard wiring your house for your Internet/network over relying on wireless connections.

Enjoy folks! Thanks for letting us have a week off!

*Disclaimer – Game provided for review by developer.

item.title: Beware Green Lantern’s Blight
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Here we are in yet another summer chock-full of blockbuster movies. Looking across the spectrum, one can’t help but to let out their inner fan boy. Yet again we find ourselves at a convergence of films based on comic franchises that are all fighting for your movie going experience. While three of the softer impact films rolled in before the solstice (Thor, Priest, and X-men: First Class), the harder hitting films started firing off last week. DC Comics rolled out their only offering of the season with Green Lantern.
item.content:encoded:
Here we are in yet another summer chock-full of blockbuster movies. Looking across the spectrum, one can’t help but to let out their inner fan boy. Yet again we find ourselves at a convergence of films based on comic franchises that are all fighting for your movie going experience. While three of the softer impact films rolled in before the solstice (Thor, Priest, and X-men: First Class), the harder hitting films started firing off last week. DC Comics rolled out their only offering of the season with Green Lantern.

For those of you that aren’t familiar with the history of the Green Lanterns don’t fret. We’re here to help. To put it very simply, the Green Lantern Corp was created by the Guardians of the Universe, an ancient race of thinkers and scientists, as an intergalactic police force. The Guardians divided known space into 3600 sectors, assigning a living being of strong moral standing that possessed strength of will and fearlessness to defend it. To aid the Lanterns, each was given a power ring of immensely advanced technology that was able to manipulate and create objects that were only limited by their imaginations and willpower among other things. The only catch being that they were unable to affect items of yellow in color (dependant on which era of the comic) and had a need to be recharged by a power battery. Hal Jordan, the most well-known Green Lantern, came to be the first modern era human member of the Corps upon the death of Abin Sur.

Group shot of the Lanterns at the core of the story. (Left to Right: Hal Jordan, Tomar-Re. Sinestro, and Kilowog)

Thankfully, the script stuck to the basic story that’s been given to us since the 1940s. As a comic fan I must admit that I applauded this. There has been far too many times that you find that writers just plain ignored important details in these pre-existing characters. With that, one has to realize that a movie is just a snapshot in the entire existences of these creations. As comics are constantly re-launched with alterations to their history, it can be hard to accurately portray all events. Especially considering that Green Lantern has over 60 years of history, it is amazing that they stuck as close as they did. The entire story is a mash up of mostly Silver Age origins with points taken from the 2008 rebirth of the title by DC Comics. Add in the fact that all of the Green Lantern comics have such undergone relatively minor changes by comic standards and you’ll notice that a faithful creation was bestowed upon us.

Besides sticking to the majority of the mythos surrounding the comic by the same name, there were a few other things that the movie seemed to get right. The CGI worlds and effects that were generated were great (minus the suits, yuck). It looks like the extra $9 million Warner Brothers dumped into the film for effects at the last minute paid off. Once you see the Lantern’s world of Oa, you’ll see why. There was no shortage of different aliens that were created to show off on the gathering scenes. This was an important thing for them to do since the Corp is made up from species of the entire universe. The impending doom that was Parallax was greatly represented in his graphical form. While different from the comic, there was still that oozing sense of fear that just seemed to roll off of him. The human struggle was also properly represented. First we notice Hal Jordan, played by Ryan Reynolds, wanting to give up because it is just too hard. Later on, he turns around with the true face of humanity, the will to survive at all costs.

The CGI on the villain Parallax was stellar. You can even make out creatures in the blob which are closer to what he actually looks like.

Unfortunately, Green Lantern got far more wrong as a movie than it did right. Even with the fact that the background was carried out well, the rest of the movie suffered from a real lack of plot. It seemed as if the writers lost the idea of what the story was going to be a quarter of the way through the film. It leaves the viewer with questions about its intent. Was it to be a background story? Or was it going to be a one off so they needed to cram more stuff into it? Were the elements of the relationship between Jordan and Ferris in the script originally? Why is so little learned about Sinestro? What it ended up being was a relatively actionless, slow crawl of a film with no clear villain focus. Parallax is represented a distant cry of the evil force it is from the story in the series, so it presents a problem if things were to move on to more films. As if that wasn’t bad enough, the ridiculous chain gun construct idea is bleeding over to the new re-launch of Justice League #1.

Whose ridiculous idea was the chain gun? Idea is now bleeding over to modern comics.

Read the conclusion on the next page!

item.title: Review – iPhone 4 Jackback
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: iPhones are funny devices. They're made by a company that espouses individuality and creativity, but the devices are ubiquitous. Apple's walled garden applies as much to the technology as it does the software purchasing mechanism, even if the walls aren't all that high.
item.content:encoded:
iPhones are funny devices.  They’re made by a company that espouses individuality and creativity, but the devices are ubiquitous.  Apple’s walled garden applies as much to the technology as it does the software purchasing mechanism, even if the walls aren’t all that high.

Adam Baumgartner has crafted an excellent way to individualize your iPhone 4.  Jackbacks are a combined plastic and wood product that replaces your existing back panel.  It’s not a cheap laminate product- the wood is securely fastened to an original equipment manufacturer’s (OEM) plastic back panel, just like the glass panel that is secured to the panel on the back of a stock iPhone 4 bezel.

I’ve taken some measurements.  The iPhone following installation of a Jackback is exactly the same thickness, and 4 grams lighter.  Considering that you’ll likely remove any external case or bumper following installation, that removes some weight as well- in my case, 15 grams.  We’re not talking a relief for armstrain or anything, but the difference in weight, while sleight, is still noticeable.

To be clear, this isn’t an inexpensive Ikea knockoff product- they’re all crafted and finished by hand.  The Jackbacks start at $90 and work their way up from there.  Various bamboos, walnut, cherry, maple, mahogany (which is what was supplied to me), bird’s eye maple, lacewood, wenge, and walnut burl are available, as are custom etching jobs.  Backs are available for both the AT+T and Verizon versions of the phone.

There are many iPhone accessories, some crap, some not.  A Jackback is certainly not crap, and is one of the few iPhone add-ons that I think are worth buying if you’re looking to stand out from the pack.  If you’ve got the extra sponduliks laying about, I highly recommend the Jackback.

item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Space. What a vast and wonderful playground. A place, that even in our youth, we never could quite fill it up with our imaginations. Not exactly in a way one may think though.
item.content:encoded:
Space. What a vast and wonderful playground. A place, that even in our youth, we never could quite fill it up with our imaginations. As a society we’ve dreamt of it, built stories featuring it, and have even expanded to it. We continuously look up at it acknowledging its very existence, but are reminded in the same way just how little we are in comparison to it. Why then has it taken me so long to play a tabletop game based in it?

Enter Starmada by Majestic 12 Games. Starmada takes the basics of what it is like to be a fleet commander and locks you into an epic encounter capsule. You and a friend (sworn enemy in this case) take the stage in your very own slice of galactic pie. Face to face you wage war letting the harrowing mistress, better known as space, decide who will ultimately be victorious. Turn by turn each commander see his victory chances unfold. Not exactly in a way one may think though.

Each turn breaks into four different parts: orders, movement, combat, and ending phases. To begin, the game launches into the orders phase, as indicated by well, the order of operations. Here players plot out the movement of their vessels based on their engine speed. Once each player has plotted their courses, movements play out at the same time in the following movement phase. Movement is actually quite unique in Starmada. Unlike many games, Newton’s First Law of Motion actually plays a role here. Players must remember that objects will keep their momentum when they first start moving. Otherwise, you could face losing a ship’s turn in a round or quite possibly their ship. All moves are completed at the same time allowing for space placement conflict to be resolved at it comes. Once completed, combat begins! Combat is another feature with plays into a different situation that most war games. Rather than battle out in opposite turns, all battle is done in one large phase ship after ship. This way no one player can dominate in their first turn. This keeps the game going in a fair way, rather than having the victory determined by the first dice roll. Damage is tracked and all tallied during the following phase, which is aptly named the end phase. Here points are awarded to the victors for destroying ships and all destruction is assessed to the appropriate targets to prepare for the next turn.

When you first sit down to play/make war with your “friend” you need to decide in which way you are to play the game. Starting could be as simple as selecting pre-made, simpler versions of ships or as complex as creating your own war machines from the literature provided. Using a fleet building technique not unlike that of building an army in Warhammer, you build your force around a point structure. Each ship has its own combat rating based on what it is and what options it has installed. To stop would be galactic expanders from using “The Ultimate Ship,” the game prohibits the use of any ship that would be greater than the half the total of your entire fleet total. For instance, if you were to agree on a battle of each side totaling up to 1000 points, no ship could be greater than 500 in combat score.

A sample frigate ship card from Starmada

For the sake of testing, the simplest approach was taken for creating an armada. Pre-generated ships from the book were given a random number and dice were used to determine which would be used. In the end, six ships were given to each side with a point total of 1020. Ships were broken down as follows:

Swiftsure-class Destroyer (96)
Swiftsure-class Destroyer (96)
Volhard-class Cruiser (168)
Victory-Class Heavy Cruiser (220)
Victory-Class Heavy Cruiser (220)
Wraak-class Battlecruiser (220)

Apparently this captian likes to navigate by the horns.

Playing the game was actually extremely easy after the passing of a few game turns. There are no complex tables to memorize or overtly impossible weapon statistics to reference every time you attempt to make an attack. Actions are smooth and fluid as they play out. This results in very few instances of bickering over rules. The only important things to remember are the movement restrictions, as well as, range bonuses and penalties. All ranges are built as multiples of three, so it is really easy to know which third of distance you are from your would be assailant. There are some silly rules, but if you think of them in terms of reality they do make sense. Things such as not calling which target you are firing upon results in a ship firing into blank space. If you aren’t aiming at something, it’s a tad hard to actually hit anything isn’t it?

Continue the review after the break!

item.title: Sickness Abroad – Episode 19
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: This week we bring you a special treat on the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast. We bring you the plague from both sides of the coast! Both Emdee and Draeno managed to catch different variations of the flu on their respective coasts. That doesn't stop us from bringing you another invigorating episode of the podcast though! With the Electronic Entertainment Expo bringing us such a plethora of topics, there is no way we could deny you faithful listener! To top it off, you get to listen to only the dynamic duo this week. No third wheel to add off color commentary. No couch jockey bringing you their version of events. Only us...doing that anyway! Topics covered include iOS 5, iCloud, Lion, the average gamer age, the E3 expo, Razer's upcoming peripherals for the Old Republic, Halo Combat Evolved Anniversary, Halo 4, inaccurate submarines, the WiiU, the Nyko Kinect sensor, and a review of Majestic 12's Starmada.
item.content:encoded:
This week we bring you a special treat on the 20 Sides of Nerd podcast. We bring you the plague from both sides of the coast! Both Emdee and Draeno managed to catch different variations of the flu on their respective coasts. That doesn’t stop us from bringing you another invigorating episode of the podcast though! With the Electronic Entertainment Expo bringing us such a plethora of topics, there is no way we could deny you faithful listener! To top it off, you get to listen to only the dynamic duo this week. No third wheel to add off color commentary. No couch jockey bringing you their version of events. Only us…doing that anyway!

We scraped up enough energy to cover these topics this week, hopefully not getting you sick in the process:

  • Apple announces iOS 5, iCloud, and Lion.
  • Developers raise their voices at Apple copying features from their submitted applications that have now been incorporated into the new version OS. Those wi-fi sync logos sure look mighty similar.
  • Average age of a gamer is actually older than you think.
  • We speak about a few things that popped up during the Electronic Entertainment Expo.
    • Saints Row put on a bikini car wash. Wasn’t this supposed to be a press event?
    • Razer has some new interesting peripherals coming out for The Old Republic.
    • Halo: Combat Evolved Anniversary will be coming out this year! Check it out!
    • Halo 4 was announced to fan boy criticism. Just wait folks it’ll probably be different than the rendered teaser trailer.
    • Emdee lets loose his gripe with game developers making inaccurate submarines.
    • Wii U was announced. Nintendo brings out a new console that shies away from what made the Wii successful to appear to the “hardcore” market. Will gimmicks win the crowd over or will this be another flawed offering?
    • Nyko has a new Kinect sensor that allows players to use less space. Why didn’t this happen in the first place?
  • Draeno gives his thoughts on the Duke Nukem Forever demo. In all honesty folks, based on what the demo offers we cannot recommend this for purchase.
  • The team gives a review on the tabletop starship combat game, Starmada by Majestic 12 Games. Heartily approved by both Emdee and Draeno.*
  • Tennessee passes some odd laws about sharing account information with people you know and offending people on the Internet with images. How are citizens letting this stuff happen there?!

Enjoy folks!

*Disclosure – Item was provided by company for review. Look for a writeup in the days to come.

item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Another fabulous episode of 20 Sides of Nerd comes to you right before the media blitz begins for E3. Even while you're bombarded with nerd and gaming stimuli, we hope that you'll still be able to squeak some time in to listen to our particular version of babble. Be prepared for next week though, I'm sure we'll just over saturate you as well as everyone else does. Das Kalk comes aboard this week, even as he is locked in epic battle against his router. Who will be the winner? Time will only tell once people in his house stop downloading Angry Birds during podcast recording. Topics covered include the upcoming iCloud announcement, Adobe's master collection, 80s music, Penny Arcade's New Kid has been optioned to Paramount, DC rebooting, Electronic Arts' Origin service, China versus the US cyber war, and carcinogenic cellphones.
item.content:encoded:
Another fabulous episode of 20 Sides of Nerd comes to you right before the media blitz begins for E3. Even while you’re bombarded with nerd and gaming stimuli, we hope that you’ll still be able to squeak some time in to listen to our particular version of babble. Be prepared for next week though, I’m sure we’ll just over saturate you as well as everyone else does. Das Kalk comes aboard this week, even as he is locked in epic battle against his router. Who will be the winner? Time will only tell once people in his house stop downloading Angry Birds during podcast recording.

As it commentary jumbled around and cut out, we covered the following topics:

  • Apple is making an announcement next week on their iCloud service. It doesn’t appear that you’ll be able to upload things to it?
  • E3 starts! Be prepared for the media overload!
  • Thankfully Photoshop CS 5.5 will not only available through a leasing model.
  • We somehow manage to get caught up on ’80s music. Apparently A-ha is still a hot topic.
  • Penny Arcade had their comic idea for “New Kid” optioned to Paramount for an animated film. Congrats guys! Another step in the future of online comics.
  • DC Comics is bringing out the retcon again. Not only for a few series, but the whole universe for a more “modern” feel. Did we mention they are moving to a day and date release as well?
  • Android Marketplace has shut down all game emulators. While nothing illegal about them, are they just trying to avoid issues?
  • How many times DO you have to buy Pac-Man? How broken is our consumer market when it comes to new media?
  • EA has opened up their own download marketplace called Origin. How are they going to survive against something like Steam?
  • More divisions of Sony have been hacked. I’d give some more commentary, but really, are they going to change?
  • China says that the United States are waging an Internet war.
  • Call of Duty Elite. Let’s pay for things that Bungie has been offering for free. Capitalism at work folks.
  • World Health Organization (WHO) says that cell phones are “possibly” carcinogenic. Don’t take this at face value. Know your science guys.

Enjoy folks!

Amber Neely joins us to make up for my decision to make social with the real world apparently. item.content:encoded:
This week we had to record a day early due to my decision to go to a Death Cab for Cutie concert on our usual recording day. Amber Neely joins us to make up for my decision to make social with the real world apparently. While being mocked extraneously and being teased as a hipster before and after our recording ended, we were able to cut out my tears in order to bring you yet another episode of 20 sides of Nerd.

Our hastily gathered topic list this week covered (after my tears were edited out):

  • Skype had a small outage. Folks, it wasn’t Microsoft’s fault.
  • Windows 8 is coming in 2012.
  • Emdee gives a review for JackBacks for the iPhone 4. Thumbs up from him.*
  • Monday Night Combat servers are a little low on population for PC. Why aren’t you playing?!
  • Conduit 2 reviews lead to High Voltage Software retaliating against the reviewer via his book on Amazon. Really folks? Are we school kids again?
  • Is the way games are reviewed outdated? Why do we feel a need to rank them rather than just say ‘yes’ or ‘no’?
  • Sony is still getting hacked. This time it is covering more of their business. Can we get this fix yet guys?
  • Lady GaGa broke Amazon through her $0.99 album promotion of Born This Way on the album’s release day. This is what we’ve been saying should happen, minus breaking the distributor.
  • Emdee and I reminisce on our college radio experiences.
  • Prisoner speaks out about being forced to farm gold in World of Warcraft while in jail. While is sounds terrible, is that really even a punishment?
  • Malware popping up on the Mac again. Apple ignores the problem until they push a patch. Macs are not invulnerable, they are susceptible just like any PC.
  • Amber tells us about her experience with the Serenity RPG.

Enjoy folks! (The concert was good too in case you were wondering.)

*Disclosure – Item was provided by company for review.

item.title: Logic Demon Hunters – Episode 16
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: Now that we're all still around it seems that you'll be blessed with another episode of the podcast this week. Between stocking our emergency bunkers and fortifying our homes, we found the time to record yet another one for you folks. We thought, why not be loyal to our fans? Those left behind could listen to one last episode as they fought on against the horde. My good friend Anpu in joined this week for perhaps the last tech week for mankind. In the end, we wrapped a successful cast, cooked a steak, and put all of our demon fighting weapons away. Thinking about it now, I guess I didn't need to get those warding tattoos as a last minute thing on Saturday. Topics covered include college grads moving back home, the tenth anniversary of Apple retail stores, zero day patches, Lionhead and the used game market, Valve and player's real world value, the continued PSN debacle, and the iOS effect on the entire game industry.
item.content:encoded:
Now that we’re all still around it seems that you’ll be blessed with another episode of the podcast this week. Between stocking our emergency bunkers and fortifying our homes, we found the time to record yet another one for you folks. We thought, why not be loyal to our fans? Those left behind could listen to one last episode as they fought on against the horde. My good friend Anpu in joined this week for perhaps the last tech week for mankind. In the end, we wrapped a successful cast, cooked a steak, and put all of our demon fighting weapons away. Thinking about it now, I guess I didn’t need to get those warding tattoos as a last minute thing on Saturday.

Topics for this week as we thought on to the less crowded streets ahead of us consisted of:

  • Large number of college grads moving back home. Make sure you thank your parents.
  • Tenth anniversary of the Apple retail store. Congrats on ten years of crushing the little guy.
  • Zero Day patches – Why can’t games just be finished when they are released? Don’t companies realize that releasing a broken product will hurt sales? People will wait for good games.
  • Lionhead says that the pre-owned game market is worse for them than piracy. WHAT?!
  • Anpu REALLY hates the fantasy genre.
  • Gabe Newell of Valve toys with the idea of a “real world value” on players. Are you annoying over voice chat? Do you grief people all the time? Be prepared to pay more money. Gabe, you’re welcome for the $5 idea too.
  • Playstation Network – Congratulations, you didn’t actually fix your service!
  • Hellgate: London is making its way back to the States as a free to play MMO. A great game gets a new life. Will micro transactions bring this game a new life like it has others?
  • Dennis Dyack says iOS and other mobile apps are hurting the gaming industry. Uh…ok? Are you sure about that?

Enjoy folks!

Executing our masterful plans as always, we were able to abduct Sarsion of Whisper Game Studios from his out of his bed at the crack of dawn. Our stalwart 20 Sides of Nerd crew, augmented with our getaway driver Das Kalk, puts on a rather meandering podcast as we held him ransom. Figuring out that Sarsion was more trouble than he was worth, we lowered our demands to something a little more obtainable.

He had to listen with fake enthusiasm and gleefully chime in on the following topics:

  • Microsoft buys Skype – We knew change was coming, but how much?
  • Soul Calibur V – What is the deal with that picture? Is there still a market for fighting games?
  • Swag bags and items from conventions (Thank you for your fabulous bags Dungeon Fighter Online!)
  • Why Emdee hates Syfy’s lack of genre television.
  • Endless love for Red Faction: Guerrilla (Should we be scared for Armageddon then? Syfy involvement!)

Enjoy folks!

item.title: Guest Review – MtG: New Phyrexia (Tabletop)
item.dc:creator: Emdee
item.description: here I sat, staring at 6 booster packs of Magic: The Gathering cards; three boosters from the Scars of Mirrodin series, and 3 booster packs from the upcoming New Phyrexia series. Inside Collector’s Corner, in Midland Michigan, I am sitting at a table with four other people: Karl (an unbelievably lanky character and long time friend), Steve (a college friend who could pass as my doppelganger), Ramzy (a California native I just met), and Lee (a long time friend of Steve’s and the reason we are there. It is roughly 12:30 A.M. and Karl, Steve and I had just driven two hours from our home town for this event. We are wired on Monster’s and ready to get our geek on. As the last of the booster packs are handed out we are told we will have thirty-five minutes to construct a deck of at least 40 cards. We are given the OK and the timer starts. I tear open my boosters and begin sorting.
item.content:encoded:
There I sat, staring at 6 booster packs of Magic: The Gathering cards; three boosters from the Scars of Mirrodin series, and 3 booster packs from the upcoming New Phyrexia series. Inside Collector’s Corner, in Midland Michigan, I am sitting at a table with four other people: Karl (an unbelievably lanky character and long time friend), Steve (a college friend who could pass as my doppelganger), Ramzy (a California native I just met), and Lee (a long time friend of Steve’s and the reason we are there. It is roughly 12:30 A.M. and Karl, Steve and I had just driven two hours from our home town for this event. We are wired on Monster’s and ready to get our geek on. As the last of the booster packs are handed out we are told we will have thirty-five minutes to construct a deck of at least 40 cards. We are given the OK and the timer starts. I tear open my boosters and begin sorting. My mind is racing trying to memorize each card as I separate them into piles by color. My thought process tells me that I should build a deck based on the cards I have the most of, and as I finish separating I find that I have a lot of White, Black, and Artifacts. At this point I am both happy and disappointed. Happy that I have the colors/card types that I feel most comfortable using, and disappointed that the one card I was hoping to pull, remained elusive. I begin searching through my cards and trying to craft the best possible deck. I know I need a “bomb”, a high-cost creature that, once summoned, should tip the scales heavily in my favor. I find a “Geth, Lord of the Vault”, whose ability allows me to resurrect creatures from my opponent’s graveyard and place onto the battlefield under my control. I also find a “Shattered Angel”, which lets me gain 3 life every time my opponent plays a Land card. I decide to run a white/black deck and continue picking the best cards from what I have available.

I finish building with about five minutes left, and look around the table. Karl has a face of complete concentration, Steve looks satisfied, Lee has a big grin on his face (bad news) and Ramzy…Ramzy pulled the one card I was hoping to get, “Elesh Norn, Grand Cenobite”, lucky bastard. As the clock winds down I begin to re-think my deck. It looks sloppy and thrown together, granted that is the point of these types of tournaments, but I would like to win at least one round and prove that I am not a complete noob.

The clock strikes 1:00 A.M. and the first round roster goes up. I head out to find my table and opponent, a nice but quiet guy by the name of Andrew. We shuffle, cut, and the game begins. Andrew goes first and he plays fast. It throws me off and makes me second guess myself, I make a few rookie mistakes but end up winning the first game. We re-shuffle, re-set and play again. This time he bowls me over and takes an easy win. 1-1, we have to play a tie-breaker game. We begin again and I seem to have pulled the perfect hand; the right amount of mana, my “bomb” and a couple low-cost creatures. This could work. We begin trading blows and spells back and forth, but I notice that after a few turns he stops attacking. He has plenty of mana, and a hand of at least 5 cards. I begin thinking that he is waiting for me to cast my Geth so that he can counter it and then proceed to clean me out. But as I cast it, nothing happens and he begins to get frustrated. He is running a red/green/black deck and cannot get any green mana. After a few turns, he concedes defeat, not out of anger but it is clear that he will lose during the next turn. We shake hands, report the outcome to the owner of the store, and wait for the next round. Winning essentially by default doesn’t feel great, but it is still nice to know that my deck isn’t completely worthless!

The next round I faced off against a younger player who had about as much experience as I did. He was running a black and blue deck, which was built to stave off attacks from my larger creatures, while he amassed his own army and slowly tried poison me with unblockable creatures. We were pretty evenly matched, but I managed to win two games in a row. The deck I had thought was sloppy had now gotten me through two rounds.

By this point it was nearing 3:00 A.M., we had only finished 2 of the 6 rounds and I had been up for almost 21 hours. I can’t lie, I was tired. While getting some fresh air between rounds, the roster for round three was put up. I was to play against Lee. Fuck. Lee is a walking encyclopedia for Magic, and a tough competitor. Luckily he is a happy-go-lucky type of person so even if he slaughters you, you still have fun. I did my best not to underestimate Lee, for all the good it did me. He started off both rounds the same way, holding back until he could counter my strong cards, and then hitting me with the same unblockable creature the last opponent used to poison me. Then he would bring out the heavy hitter, Swarmlord. At the beginning of his turn he would be able to put out a 1/1 Insect creature with infect for each poison counter I had. After a few turns he had an army that I couldn’t contend with and he walked right past my defenses.

It was now 4:30 A.M. It appeared that the tournament would not be over before 8:00 A.M. and that would mean 26+ hours without sleep, plus a two-hour drive home. As Steve was staying for the remainder of the weekend, Karl and I decided to cut our losses and bow out of the tournament. I was disappointed that we couldn’t see it through to the end, but relieved that sleep was a mere two hours away.

I am very excited to see what other decks I can put together with the New Phyrexia expansion. The new mechanic of using life as mana adds a cut-throat dimension to the game that I am really enjoying, kudos to the Wizards for finding ways to keep an 18 year old game fresh and fun to play.

- Mendicant Bias

item.title: Animated Easter – A Review of Hop
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: “You’re going to go see that right,” asked a friend as we passed a display on the way to our movie. “What, you mean that one with the rabbit,” I clamored as I looked puzzled at the cardboard. “Yeah. You love anything with bunnies.” I glared back at him in reply. Really though, just because something has a rabbit in it doesn’t mean I’ll automatically like it. It just improves its chances a little bit by getting me interested. In this case my object of potential admiration was a large display for the movie Hop. After I got home, I had a little talk with my other half. We decided that this would be a good film for us to both take our daughter to see.
item.content:encoded:
“You’re going to go see that right,” asked a friend as we passed a display on the way to our movie. “What, you mean that one with the rabbit,” I clamored as I looked puzzled at the cardboard. “Yeah. You love anything with bunnies.” I glared back at him in reply. Really though, just because something has a rabbit in it doesn’t mean I’ll automatically like it. It just improves its chances a little bit by getting me interested. In this case my object of potential admiration was a large display for the movie Hop. After I got home, I had a little talk with my other half. We decided that this would be a good film for us to both take our daughter to see.

There were two possible points that gave us pause about seeing Hop though. When I was told that Russell Brand was voicing the rabbit in it, I did cringe a little. There is a place where I hold Get Him to the Greek and Forgetting Sarah Marshall in high esteem, but really Brand isn’t the first person you want your child to hear. It was pinned as a cute, Easter themed movie. You couldn’t think they’d let things go too far, right? The Despicable Me team was able to keep Brand in line for his voice role before, so there was some hope it’d be ok. That ended up being a fantastic movie, so we let that one slide. Another possible point of trepidation was the fact it was directed by Tim Hill. If you aren’t familiar with that name, I’ll give you a second to go look him up on IMDB. Go ahead, I’ll wait. Yeah, he did write for SpongeBob and Rocko’s Modern Life. Click on his section for director. Yeeeeeaah, that’s right. He directed Alvin and the Chipmunks and Garfield: a Tail of Two Kitties. Both of those happen to be two of the worst CGI-Live action combination films in the last five years. Again though, we let the feeling subside as our daughter did like those. In the end, the potential good outweighed the potential bad, so we took a chance on opening weekend.

Hop takes place in a world where Easter is as big as an event as Christmas. Every Easter Eve the Easter Bunny (voiced by Hugh Laurie) travels the globe to bring joy to people around the globe. While the mantle of Easter Bunny is passed on through generations of the most dignified rabbits in history, the next in line, E.B. (voiced by Russell Brand) is the son of the current holder. While the wonder and awe holds his interest as a child, he eventually loses interest as he grows up. Soon we find E.B. as a teenager, wanting to break out of his responsibilities to live his dream of being a drummer. After an argument with his father, E.B. runs away to Hollywood to try and “make it.” Along the way he runs into Fred O’Hare, played by James Marsden, or rather Fred runs into him with his car. Fred has been down on his luck since being laid off from his job. What makes it worse is he had to move in with his parents. Now they want him out. With both Fred and E.B. looking at uncertainty in their lives, they come together in an awkward fashion. They end up crashing together in a fancy house that Fred has been tasked to sit for, but things go downhill for the pair almost instantly. Fred realizes he got more than he bargained for. Throughout the film he attempts to get rid of E.B. to quell the hurricane that his life has become with his new friend. E.B. does everything he can to convince Fred to help him. Now throw in an evil chick, voiced by Hank Azaria. With his plotting to get rid of everything in his way to take over Easter on one end, while dropping hints to E.B.’s father that he can take over on the other, the plot thickens.

The story really worked for the film, even if it was for Hollywood’s attempt to grasp at another holiday tie in. The film started in a way that throws you a little as you think the focus is going to be a certain way. However, it wrapped up in a way that shows you what the writers were aiming for. Even though two people from different worlds are thrown together by consequence (or fate), you come to see that they are really looking for the same sort of things from life. Both E.B. and Fred are lost in life, but really just needed each other to figure out where they needed to be. Fred gets to rack up a few wins in his column and get a once in a lifetime job. E.B. gets to live his dream while being able to fulfill his duties. Even the sister gets what is coming to her at one point. Everyone walks away with what they deserve and you feel content that they did so.

Sadly, I have to say that everything wasn’t a ray of sunshine in this film. My biggest issue had to be with the dialogue. In a mash-up movie like this, you would expect the things people are saying to be a little over the top. The thing is most of it wasn’t. Sure, The Hoff nailed it in his typical bigger than life fashion. Other than Marsden though, it didn’t seem if the actors were putting much effort into it. The best vocal performance by far was Hugh Laurie. He gave life to E.B.’s father with a genuine sense of class and emotion. He was a fantastic casting for this film. On the flip side of the speaking role coin, the biggest let down by far was Kaley Cuoco. Maybe it was how it was written, but she sounded like she was just on another episode of the Big Bang Theory. Hank Azaria was a close second. You’re a wonderful voice actor Mr. Azaria, but your performance was just ear grating.

Before you get all into this idea that it is just a kid’s movie, let me tell you that simply isn’t the case. It brought something to the table for both children and adults. While there were elements and subtitle nods for the adults in the audience, it wasn’t anything inappropriate or off-putting for the kids. Brand was kept under control for the duration, but didn’t actually seem constrained by it. It wasn’t as awkward as seeing him on the MTV music awards in 2009. Hop had something for all of us. It was a heartwarming kid’s movie for my daughter, it had Russell Brand for my fiancée, and of course the rabbits for me. What else could you want?

Bottom line – If you are looking for a movie to watch with your little ones that won’t bore you to death, Hop won’t let you down.
Recommendation – Watch it in theaters, rent it, or buy it. I know I’ll be picking it up on release day.

item.title: Are You Easily Distracted? – A Sucker Punch Review
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: This past weekend I summoned up the courage to step outward from my home and into the grand venue that is our greater Regal Theaters. While one may not think this anything close to a monumental task, I must explain... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
This past weekend I summoned up the courage to step outward from my home and into the grand venue that is our greater Regal Theaters. While one may not think this anything close to a monumental task, I must explain why it indeed was. I had decided that I wanted to see Zach Snyder’s most recent foyer into the big screen; Sucker Punch. As a man in his late twenties, the trailer had everything I could have wanted. It was a little foggy on the details of exactly what the film would be about. That didn’t bother me too much though. From the trailer I was promised cliché things like Nazi zombies and women fighting things out of anime. Not only that, but setting the clip to the fantastic tune of Panic Switch by Silversun Pickups had me frothing for more.

To sum up the gist of the film without giving too much away to the potential viewer, Sucker Punch was to be a film about empowerment. The film opens with a rather misplaced introduction that leaves the viewer pondering exactly what went on. One is left to guess at what happened, but we come to find out that it has lead to an act of violence. In turn for that act, our heroine is lead off to a mental institution. To top that off, a conspiracy is developed behind her back (literally), that wouldn’t make her a burden on her step father any longer. From here Baby Doll, played by Emily Browning, leads a group of other residents in a plot to escape whatever fate awaits them. What makes that interesting is the fact that their salvation is through battles with nefarious beings to obtain things in a dream world. In these sequences the girls are given instructions by a pseudo mentor, played by aspiring one liner king Scott Glenn. The catch here is that Baby Doll creates these violent worlds to escape another dream world that she is in. Did I mention the dreams are initiated by a dance that is never seen? Did I also mention the dream world she conjures to escape the mental hospital is actually a brothel? Yeah, I didn’t get it either, but there you go.

Before watching, I poured over numerous reviews to get a sense of feeling of how it was generally accepted. In almost everything I read Sucker Punch was being panned terribly by critics. Good thing that I don’t really care what most of them think because I was ready for a visual joyride. However, by the number in attendance, even for a late night showing, I could tell that perhaps I was one of the few who remained optimistic. Now folks, let’s just get this out there. If one was to stroll into this film expecting it to be a wonderful success of a dramatic exercise with concise, clear plot points and dialogue that would tug at your heart strings, there is a fair chance that you weren’t watching the same trailer that the rest of us common folk were. To expect anything other than a popcorn popping, eye candy experience is just downright silly. This was to be a purely visual movie with a very specific demographic. Nothing more, nothing less. Elements outside of what was being poured into your retinas were only there to move things along from point A to point B. There had to be something to fill the gap between the stylized sequences.

To refer to this film as mediocre at best almost feels like an insult. Sure it isn’t going to win anyway awards for best dramatic actress or best screenplay, but I’d like to think that it was slightly above the curve. Coming from the background of gaming, I’ve grown to like the CGI enhanced screens we’ve been fed over the years. When you make something look like a video game, I can’t help but be enticed. When you take the sum of the film as a whole though, it is clear that it is far from the best thing on planet Earth. From a clear analytical stand point, studios kept this film on the roster for a reason. You could argue until you are blue in the face about Legendary backing Sucker Punch for whatever reason. Bottom line is they knew it was good enough to turn a profit. Had there not been evidence of a possible strong showing, we probably would have seen this film in the straight to video market rather than the big screen.

In my book, Sucker Punch was alright. Sure, there were numerous flaws. That is to be expected in such a film. To me it was rather apparent that Zach Snyder had formed this idea years ago. It was almost as if he penned it in high school and never bothered to add any polish before he committed it to film. Perhaps this is the real issue people are having. This was Snyder’s first original project. His filmography is filled with flicks that basically had a guide book that came as an accompaniment to the script. Had he been lost in the middle of filming 300, all he had to do was crack open Frank Miller’s graphic novel. Was there a scene he really wanted to pay homage to in the original Dawn of the Dead, but couldn’t work it out in his mind? All he needed to do was pop in the original to flesh out his idea. That said let us all hope he learned something from this experience. There are miles to go for Snyder to create an all encompassing masterpiece of his own. We know he has the visuals down, now he just needs to work on what connects them. If this does end up being the worst film that Snyder ends up offering to the world, then I say bring on more beauty, bullets, and bravado.

Bottom line – A pretty film to look at that is a great escape if you are looking for something that requires no thought.
Recommendation – If you plan on buying it, wait for a few months until it is on sale at say $10. Otherwise, rent away!

item.title: The Internet Apocalypse – Are You Ready?
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: The end is neigh, glowed the text. The message waived in the sky above a single solemn man. Every day he warns the passersby of the impending doom before them. Each time he sees a new face, he tries to... Read More »
item.content:encoded:
The end is neigh, glowed the text. The message waived in the sky above a single solemn man. Every day he warns the passersby of the impending doom before them. Each time he sees a new face, he tries to plead with them to look forward to their salvation. Not one would heed his warnings. For those he does gain notice from, most shrug it off as if the electronic elite would never allow it. The man preaching his vision of the future before the uncaring horde was speaking of something important. He wasn’t crazed or fanatical about his cause. He was an average Joe with nothing more than technology in his hands. Through his eyes he had caught a glimpse of what was coming. The Internet as we know it was crumbling. He knew it and we ignored him. Now it may be too late to do anything.

Excuse the doom and gloom speak, but I felt it was needed to convey the levity of the state of the Internet. The true Internet apocalypse is now upon us. Is this the end? No; far from it in fact. The idea of what the Internet is will slowly crumble to many of us now. Some of you might think I’m kidding, but just a short while ago a third horseman rolled into town. Famine came in to show us just what is in store for our wallets. AT&T strode in upon its decrepit mount, spewing forth the diseased ideals that would spread out amongst all service providers. The time had come. They instituted their plans to stop unmetered internet usage for their broadband customers.

Oddly enough, this is something that each and every one of us should have seen coming. Telecoms have ever so slowly been trying to put a strangle hold on the internet. With War being the first to ride into town on a steed named Comcast, it was only a short matter of time before the others would rear their heads to bring an end to the way things are. Pestilence followed soon thereafter hiding under the guise of a helpful organization, the FCC. We shouldn’t judge these actions so quickly. In the end our lack of care is what is doing the ‘net in. We are doing this to ourselves. Sure people try to champion the cause of net neutrality and foundations like the Electronic Frontier Foundation fight the good fight, but it really isn’t enough. Quite simply, there isn’t a single entity that has the financial backing to compete with these corporations that are forcing changes. Is that our fault? In a way, as we are choosing to give these business the capital to push their agendas.

So who will be the final rider be? The one named Death which brings everything crumbling down around us? Will it be Verizon that follows suit to AT&T? They’ve already been hinting about their future data caps and tiered pricing structures. Why would it be that hard to imagine them follow the new business model norm that AT&T is creating? If not them, could it possibly be the government that would crush our last bastion of freedom? The House has already passed through legislation that will put a damper on net neutrality. Sure it may attempt to fix what the FCC had broken, but how much more will it hurt? Perhaps the democratic Senate won’t be so quick to let it continue to fly. Can we blame it on piracy? Are people downloading illegal things the final needle on the proverbial haystack? Will ISPs across the country finally crack down on the people that use the ‘net for their own nefarious purposes? Will Microsoft step in and shrug at these changes once they are the gatekeeper to the super highway?

Our digital rights have been in question for quite some time. Anyone with a discerning eye could have noticed it from far off. It shouldn’t take a man to stop someone on the street to give you that hint of reality. With companies throttling how much we intake, determining which content we can view, and trying to feed us what is good for us, it is a small wonder that we’ve put up with it for this long. I can only hope that we will learn a lesson from what Canada has gone through earlier this year. Everyone needs to stand up and make their voice heard. The Internet isn’t just another cash piñata for telecoms and corporations to hit up. It is one of the few places we as citizens of the world can make our open voices heard. Don’t let one man fruitlessly try to inform the entire populace of what is to come. Read up, stay informed and speak your opinion.

Until we let folks know this isn’t the way it should be, I’d work on hoarding bandwidth like water and canned goods for the end times. Download all you can, stream all you can and play all you can, while you can. At this point let’s hope that the man with the message was wrong.

item.title: First Thing We Do – Episode 8
item.dc:creator: draeno
item.description: In perhaps one of the more opinionated casts we've had thus far, we talk a bit on some of the legal happenings in the tech world. @Sixokay, Community Manager of Robot Entertainment, was able to join the 20 Sides Duo this week as our very first celebrity guest. Our regular guest, Das Kalk, was able to join in the conversation as well.
item.content:encoded:
In perhaps one of the more opinionated casts we’ve had thus far, we talk a bit on some of the legal happenings in the tech world. @Sixokay, Community Manager of Robot Entertainment, was able to join the 20 Sides Duo this week as our very first celebrity guest. Our regular guest, Das Kalk, was able to join in the conversation as well.

This week started out in a lighthearted manner, but quickly became deeper and more opinionated as we went on. See the list below to see what we mean:

  • Duke Nukem Forever delay.
  • Our first prediction was wrong perhaps? Fringe was renewed for a fourth season.
  • Networks and programmers flipping out over Comcast’s iPad TV application.
  • RIAA’s claim that Limewire owns them $75 trillion in damages.
  • AT&T’s bid to buy T-Mobile.
  • Microsoft backed law circling at the state level for aggrieved companies to sue competitors that may be using pirated software anywhere in their supply chain and the complexities thereof.

Enjoy folks!
